HEADLINE: In Cuba, Baseball Provides Solace to Anxious People

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLGUIN, Cuba, July 3

 BODY:
When an American baseball team of college-age players arrived in Cuba the other day for a pre-Olympic warmup against this country's top players, a one-hour wait at Havana's airport for a flight to this provincial town gave a strong hint of the superior attitude the Cubans had brought to the contest.
While the Americans stood waiting, their older Cuban counterparts slouched in chairs, smoking cigarettes and sneering as they eyed the anxious competition across the departure area. 
 In many matters having to do with the United States, Cuba clings to the role of a feisty and pious David versus an arrogant Goliath, an attitude that serves not only as a rallying theme for the people but also as an official excuse for suppressing dissent.
"A big part of the Cuban game is intimidation," said Bob Bensch, an American team assistant, referring to the mannerisms of a team that thrashed the United States in two of three games here. "They swagger onto the field and act real aggressive; this affects a lot of the teams they face."
Behind the swagger, however, Cuban sportswriters and the players themselves whispered that with the country listing into a demoralized state, a convincing victory over the island's traditional foil had become imperative, since baseball provides a rare and dependable source of contentment.
"It is almost unfair the burden they are carrying," one Cuban sportswriter said of his national team. "They are the best in the world and are not expected to lose to anyone, but they know that a loss against the United States would be more than a sports defeat. It would be a national betrayal."
While American baseball writers here saw Cuba's lopsided victories as the consequence of a matchup that pitted a new team of American college recruits against a finely tuned national team that only happened to play in a stadium bearing a huge red banner proclaiming "Socialism or Death," the games were an especially dear affirmation for Cuban officials.
During a five-day visit by the American delegation, tours were organized to factories and party headquarters here, 400 miles southeast of Havana. The frequent message was that if Cuba is struggling without the Communist friends of the past, baseball has shown that Cuban Communism is capable of home-grown success.
 
Strong, Strong, Strong
 "So you see, we Cubans are strong," Geraldo Delva, a television station manager, said in repeating a line that was drilled home in the news after a 16-to-1 victory. "Strong in baseball, strong in health care, strong in defense, but most importantly, strong in the psychological preparation of our people."
But for the Cuban fans who pressed their faces against the iron gates of the stadium here each morning waiting under a hot sun for a coveted seat for the evening games, such political messages seemed to have little meaning.
Limited food rations and a severe energy shortage have made life especially difficult for Cubans, many of whom have to walk or ride bicycles to work in the summer heat because of a faltering public transportation system.
For many of these people, the three baseball games, which were accompanied by rumba bands that played blaring dance music between innings, helped blot out for a moment the pressure of their daily lives.
"You would need three or four stadiums to seat all of the people who would like to be in this ball park tonight," said Francisco Hernandez, a 21-year-old resident here who got one of the more than 30,000 seats in the stadium after a three-hour wait. "Of course we want the Cubans to win, but with nothing else to do, it is great just to be here."

HEADLINE: BANK CRISIS STIRS POLITICAL FALLOUT

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARWICK, R.I., July 2

 BODY:
For 539 days, in cold weather and warm, Connie and Daniel Thornton marched here, outside the closed credit union where their dreams had been on deposit.
But their picketing ended this week, when they joined 38,000 depositors who reclaimed 90 percent of their money in a state-financed bailout. These depositors were the last to be repaid. 
 The checks came 18 months after Gov. Bruce Sundlun, an hour after his inauguration, closed 45 banks and credit unions in the state, saying that the private fund that insured them had collapsed because of bad loans.
More than $1 billion belonging to 350,000 depositors, or one-third of the state's residents, was frozen in the closings. The crisis galvanized a political movement led by angry depositors, who negotiated for months with the Governor over the terms of the bailout.
Joseph Devine, a computer consultant from Cranston who has become a leader of depositors' protests and an independent candidate for Governor, says the problems with the bank provided only the first hint of widespread corruption in the state.
"What started out as a banking crisis ended up revealing the lack of ethics in government," he said.
 
Still Waiting for Money
 Many hailed the June 30 payout as a sign that the worst banking crisis in the state's history had come to a close. All but five of the closed institutions have reopened. But depositors were quick to note that they were still waiting for the final 10 percent of their money, that they would probably never recover the millions lost in interest payments, and that taxpayers woulld be paying for the bailout for many years to come.
"This is far from over," said Mrs. Thornton, 53 years old. She and her husband are still waiting for more than $10,000 from the state. "Aside from taking our money, they've taken a chunk of our lives."
She was echoed by Mr. Thornton, who is 61. The Thorntons lost access to more than $100,000, forcing them to postpone their retirement and making it difficult to meet mortgage payments on their new house.
Under the $471 million payout plan, financed through state borrowing and sale of credit union assets, depositors with less than $4,000 were paid in full, while the rest received checks for 90 percent of the value of their accounts. The remaining 10 percent is to be paid over the next 20 years by the state's bailout agency, unless the money is recovered sooner in civil suits.
"I'll be dead before I collect the rest of my money," said Helen Pare, a 68-year-old bookkeeper from this city south of Providence. Like Mrs. Pare, many of the depositors are over the age of 60 and question whether they will be able to collect their money.
But Governor Sundlun said today depositors would be paid in a matter of months, when the state is expected to recover millions of dollars from civil suits filed against bank executives and the Rhode Island Share Deposit Indemnity Corporation, the private fund that insured the banks and credit unions.
"This crisis is largely over," the Governor said in a telephone interview.
 
Political Reverberations
 But the fallout from the credit union crisis and subsequent revelations of government corruption -- including reports of state officials withdrawing thousands of dollars weeks before the credit unions were closed -- will continue to be felt at the ballot box in November. Last week, in part because of the depositors' anger, 35 legislators announced that they would not seek re-election.
Sixteen bank executives, developers and state officials are also awaiting trial on charges ranging from bank fraud to conspiracy and falsifying documents to embezzling funds.
Joseph Mollicone Jr., the bank president who is accused of starting the credit union crisis by embezzling $15 million from his bank, Heritage Loan and Investment Company, is in prison awaiting trial. The bailout of Heritage in November 1990 led to the collapse of the private bank insurer.
 
Newcomers Seek Office
 Mr. Devine is one of at least 50 depositors, all political newcomers, seeking state office in the hopes of changing the way government is run in the nation's smallest state. Governor Sundlun, a Democrat whom they accuse of prolonging the crisis, is a primary target of their anger, but hundreds of other political newcomers of every party are hoping to replace other incumbents in the fall.
"We decided the only way to change things is to run for office," said Mr. Devine, who founded Reform '92, the political wing of the depositors' movement, last October.
"Even if we are not elected to office, we've won this war," Mr. Devine said, referring to the number of incumbents who plan to leave office.
Mrs. Thornton agreed. "I used to believe you can't fight city hall," she said. "But you sure can. We're going to change the way business is done in Rhode Island."

HEADLINE: No.1 on Agenda: The Limits to Promoting Growth

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MUNICH, Germany, July 5

 BODY:
With the world economy mired in its worst slump in a decade and a united response to the slowdown seemingly impossible, a new menace hangs over leaders of the world's major industrial countries: a gradual drift toward increasingly protectionist trading blocs.
While leaders of the seven most powerful industrial democracies, meeting here on Monday, will seek to revive their flagging domestic fortunes and revive business confidence through fudged statements full of good intentions, they appear increasingly unable to act cohesively on the issues delaying a recovery. 
 "The recovery is invisible so the theme is clear: stimulating growth," said John Lipsky, the chief economist for Salomon Brothers Inc. "But single prescriptions are not available, and the longer the slowdown continues, the more danger there is of a shift to protectionism and regional groupings putting up barriers."
Three main areas for stimulating the recovery exist: trade, monetary policy and fiscal policy. But in all of them, the seven countries -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Canada and Italy -- appear either to be hopelessly divided or to have already done what they can.
 
A Battle With Vagueness
 Meanwhile unemployment is surging: 20 percent of adults under 25 years old are out of work in the European Community, and the United States jobless rate jumped to 7.8 percent in June. And political unease is spreading in a world bereft of the cold-war certainties that bound the heads of leading democracies together from their first economic summit meeting, at Rambouillet, France, in 1975.
It is in this uncertain context that economists fear a drift to rival economic blocs in America, Europe and Asia -- what J. Paul Horne, chief international economist for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company called "a Balkanization of world trade and economic policy."
In Europe, the 12-nation European Community is trying to put together a frontierless market by Jan. 1. The United States is pressing forward to complete a North American Free Trade Agreement with Mexico and Canada. And Japan is assiduously developing its economic ties with the fast-growing economies of several Asian neighbors.
Such associations have generally been considered beneficial to the world economy: they spurred growth within the blocs without putting up barriers to multilateral trade. But the fear now is that a continued downturn, combined with failure to show cohesive leadership, could bolster the kind of protectionist sentiment already being voiced by Ross Perot in the United States.
 
U.S. Looks Over Its Shoulder
 "I believe we are going to have weaker international organizations, more friction and greater focus on regional development," said Alan Stoga, the managing director of Kissinger Associates Inc., a consulting firm in New York. He noted that the United States Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, had conferred with Latin American finance ministers before the Munich meeting, something he did not do before previous summit talks.
In areas like steel, automobiles, computer chips and farm subsidies, trade wars are looming that may only be headed off by strong leadership.
But the leaders at Munich look as though they will be hard pressed to paper over the splits among them and to offer a convincing recipe for world economic growth. Only in the area of aid and debt relief to Russia, where a first $1 billion payment from the International Monetary Fund may be approved in Munich, do real decisions look likely. But they are decisions that will do nothing to stimulate the world economy over the short term.
In long-stalled and crucial talks on the world's $4.3 trillion in annual trade, France and the United States remain at loggerheads. While the chief focus of disagreement has been the charges and countercharges of unfair farm subsidies, a broader struggle between Europe and the United States appears to lurk behind the talk of grain.
 
Don't Expect Stirring Initiatives
 Indeed, in appealing last week for France to accept Europe's ambitious plans for monetary and political union, President Francois Mitterrand described European unity as the only way to "confront the economic power of countries outside our continent, such as the United States and Japan."
Although a successful outcome in the trade talks, held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, could rally business confidence and add at least half a percentage point to annual world growth, which is sputtering along at no more than 1.8 percent, French and United States officials have said the chance of any breakthrough in Munich is remote. But after Mr. Mitterrand met with President Bush tonight, Reuters reported, a spokesman for Mr. Mitterrand, Jean Musitelli, said, "On the key question of agriculture the positions have moved closer together and the prospect of global balanced accord is quite possible to envisage."
On the question of interest rates, an essential tool for spurring recovery because cheaper money encourages people to invest and spend, Europe and the United States are once again far apart. Only in Japan, economists say, does some room remain for a relaxation of monetary policy.
 
Interest Rates Not the Answer
 Still absorbing the greater-than-expected costs of reunification and battling with an unfamiliarly large budget deficit, Germany remains committed to a policy of high interest rates intended to curb inflationary pressure. While the United States discount rate, which banks pay when they borrow from the Federal Reserve, is 3 percent, the equivalent German rate is 8 percent.
But after senior United States Treasury officials criticized the German rates earlier this year as a hindrance to world growth, it now appears that the seven leaders want to avoid further, fruitless conflict on this question. "It is dangerous to put public pressure on the Germans," said a senior French Finance Ministry official. "They react very badly."
Germany's determination was underlined this week by Horst Kohler, the state secretary in the Finance Ministry, when he said, "It is the Bundesbank's decision what to do about interest rates and they are not going to let anyone force them into policies that could exacerbate inflation."
 
Germany Is the Key to Europe
 But high interest rates in Germany mean high interest rates throughout Europe because the continent's currencies are linked within the European Monetary System. That means sluggish growth at best.
"Europe's going to be weak for some time to come," said David Walton, the senior international economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
In the United States, after 23 reductions in interest rates by the Federal Reserve since mid-1989, economists say there is little if any further room to lower rates.
Last Thursday, in response to the unexpectedly high unemployment figure, the discount rate was lowered again, to 3 percent, but the United States recovery continues to look erratic and uneven. There is no sign of the country acting as a locomotive for the rest of the world.
 
Fiscal Stimulation Unlikely
 With interest rates offering the leaders scant room for maneuver, they will inevitably seek the possibility of fiscal stimulation. But Germany and the United States are battling to lower their deficits and cannot afford to spend their way to growth.
That leaves Japan, among the world's three largest economies, with the burden of coming up with some fiscal stimulation. It seems ready to do so, but economists remain skeptical that Japan can emerge from its current downturn soon.
The Government of Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa has already indicated that it plans to stimulate the economy by increasing public spending by $45 billion or more later this year, so few surprises are likely in Munich. In theory, this spending should attract imports, stimulating world economic activity and reducing Japan's growing trade surplus.
"Each of the countries seems to have already done what it can, which leaves the summit with little more than words," said Mr. Horne of Smith Barney. "It remains to be seen if that will be enough to head off more stagnation and a move toward protectionism similar to the fracturing we have seen in the world political sphere."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
President Bush arrived in Munich, seeking balm for his political pains at a three-day economic conference of the leaders of the seven biggest industrial democracies. Earlier, he received a thunderous ovation in a Warsaw square where he promised that "America wants Poland to succeed and to prosper." [Page A1.]
The Russian Government and the I.M.F. announced a lending agreement that gives President Boris Yeltsin the West's endorsement for his economic policies but also commits him to cut back on Government spending even as the deficit is rising sharply. [A1.] 
 With the world economy mired in its worst slump in a decade and a united response seemingly impossible, some people fear the leading industrial countries will drift toward increasingly protectionist trading blocs. News Analysis. [A7.]
Cellular phones are something of a rage in Hungary, bypassing the traditional network, which is so antiquated that many telephones still have hand cranks. [D2.]
 
The Economy
Financial strategists tell conservative investors that as rates keep falling, they must take more risks to get higher returns. But with the economy wheezing and many securities already high priced, the advisers say to take risks with caution. [D1.]
Travelers who waited to buy summer airline tickets are in for a surprise: Beginning tomorrow, fares are expected to rise to their highest level in months. [D1.]
 
Companies
I.B.M., which once dictated to an industry, is attempting a remarkable reversal, creating a global network of alliances for technology, marketing and manufacturing. [D1.]
Canon U.S.A. may leave Long Island and take its 1,800 employees elsewhere. Its plans to build a headquarters in Brookville, an exclusive North Shore village, have been rejected. [B5.]
 
Markets
The second quarter was topsy-turvy for world stock markets. What was up in the first quarter was down in the last three months -- and vice versa. [D3.]
 
The Media Business
Books by and about gay men and lesbians have burst out of specialty shops and presses. They are now a viable and growing segment of mainstream publishing. [D1.]
Most journalists at the Democratic National Convention will provide coverage for the people back home. But a few publications will be putting out special issues for the delegates themselves. [D6.]
Premiere magazine, which immigrated to the U.S. from France, is returning to Europe under an agreement with a London publisher, EMAP Metro, to start a British edition. [D6.]
 The business of delivering news and information by fax has boomed and slumped in the last three years, and is now showing signs of rebirth in ways that promise serious profits. [D6.]
Many British ads assume that the viewer or reader has a more-than-passing familiarity with history, art or culture, in contrast to the American approach of patterning ads after blockbuster movies or pop culture trends. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]
 
Today's Columns
An unwelcome rise in market interest rates, like the one that came after a big rate cut by the Fed in December, is unlikely to recur in the wake of the Fed's action last week, analysts and traders say. Kenneth N. Gilpin: Credit Markets. [D5.]
Analysts are wondering when Good Guys will see strong earnings gains again. The consumer electronics chain operates in a hotly competitive market and a weak California economy. Market Place. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Investors Face More Risk in Quest for High Yields

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Stubbornly conservative investors found that their scant returns from money market funds and C.D.'s shrank some more last week after the Federal Reserve cut two key interest rates. Financial strategists are telling them that they will simply have to take more risks to get higher returns.
But with the economy wheezing and many securities already high priced, these advisers say, Janus-like, to take risks cautiously. Buy bonds with longer maturities, but not too long, they say; invest some money abroad -- but not too much; buy some stocks -- but not the risky or overheated kind. 
 Reports of rising unemployment and the Fed's quick response last week left many risk-free investments paying too little even to keep up with 3.5 percent inflation. Shorter-term interest rates -- reflected in money-market funds, savings accounts and certificates of deposit -- have plunged to 20-year lows. The most timid investors are earning less than half as much as two years ago.
 
Little Yield From Savings
 Kenneth B. Herz, a spokesman for Chemical Bank, bashfully cited a savings account rate of 3.05 percent, the same as for six-month certificates of deposit. "Lower than I ever thought I'd see as a child of the 80's," he said.
Ian A. MacKinnon, who manages fixed-income mutual funds at the Vanguard Group, said he was pleased to find that customers fleeing such low rates were generally taking his advice to stick with short- and intermediate-term investments.
In 1987, he said, yield-seekers flocked to longer-term funds. When the credit markets turned against them in April and August, he said, "They got clobbered."
Many analysts now predict that if the recovery gains any strength, interest rates will bounce back up, and since principal and yield move inversely in the credit markets, that means the value of outstanding issues will drop. Vanguard's long-term Treasury bond fund yields 7.61 percent, but it will lose 9.5 percent of its value if interest rates rise 1 percentage point.
Shorter maturities gain more in safety than they give up in yield, Mr. MacKinnon said. The intermediate-term Treasury bond fund, yielding 6.74 percent, would lose only 5.6 percent of its value, and the short-term fund, yielding 5.19 percent, would lose 2.6 percent.
Even many stocks and stock funds now yield more than money market funds and C.D.'s. But mutual funds report that investors in stock are becoming more careful.
"People are getting more pessimistic about the economy," said Neal Litvack, senior vice president of marketing at Fidelity Investments. "If they do come back in, I expect they will skew to the very conservative end of the stock spectrum."
Mr. Litvack recommends income funds, which aim more for high dividends than growth. The Fidelity Balanced Fund, with 60 percent stocks and 40 percent bonds, yields more than 5 percent.
Early in the year, he said, many investors were choosing riskier investments -- cyclical stocks, smaller companies, sector funds. Since then, he said, they have had so little appetite for risk that they have invested $600 million more in the Balanced Fund, leaving it with $1.3 billion.
Those searching for higher yields, but not wanting to buy junk bonds, can look abroad. Fidelity's World Income Fund invests mostly in short-term foreign securities, with a 9.2 percent yield.
 
C.D.'s From Abroad
 More exotic still, several banks offer certificates of deposit in foreign currencies. Mark Twain Bank of St. Louis has them from at least a dozen countries. Six-month C.D.'s from Germany yield 8.75 percent, from Britain and France 9 percent.
Foreign investing, of course, carries the risk that exchange rates could turn the wrong way, more than swallowing any extra interest. Mark Twain Bank tries to discourage smaller investors by demanding a minimum of $20,000 for its foreign C.D.'s, and advising them to invest no more than 15 percent of their money.
As Frank O. Trotter, vice president in the capital markets group, put it, "This is not for the average C.D. user."

HEADLINE: Cellular Phones Fill Gap in Hungary

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST

 BODY:
In this bustling city on the Danube, entrepreneurism is on the rise, with 80,000 small businesses having been formed in the last two years.
But try to cajole customers, plan with partners or yell at recalcitrant suppliers over the telephone, and the chances are 6 out of 10 that the response will be silence. Hungary's phone system is so creaky that many phones are still hand-crank models from the 1920's, and the network simply cannot handle the volume of calls. 
 That is why cellular telephones that bypass the traditional networks have become something of a rage in this capital city. In the last two years, Westel Radiotelefon, the joint venture here of the state-owned carrier and U S West, the regional Bell operating company based Englewood, Colo., has signed up 12,000 subscribers for its cellular service.
Westel's customers talk on their cellular phones an average of 400 minutes a month, triple the average in Germany and more than four times the average in the United States.
In many ways, Westel could provide a model for introducing modern telecommunications into the formerly Communist Eastern Europe, putting in place a sought-after service before the Government has time to upgrade the existing land-line telephone network.
 
Dialing Instead of Pedaling
 "We are providing running water in the middle of a thirsty desert," said Andras G. Sugar, Westel's managing director, an ebullient engineer with white hair and a tan, who bears a striking resemblance to the fashion designer Giorgio Armani. "We still have much to learn, but our customers are already almost putting a halo around our heads. Ah, that is good for business."
By the end of this year, Westel's cellular telephone coverage will extend to more than two-thirds of Hungary, up from one-third in 1991. That will allow many of the more than 10.5 million people in this country to get their first taste of personal phone service. Many villages have only one telephone, previously housed in the local police station and now -- post-Communism -- found in the church or post office.
In the countryside, more and more people are hearing on radio broadcasts the chirpy Westel advertising slogan, "Put down your bicycle! Use your Westel telephone!"
 
Technical Limits
 But there are problems, too. Westel's network uses frequencies in the 450 megahertz range on the electromagnetic spectrum, because that was the only portion of the radio-frequency band not being used by the military. That frequency is incompatible with both the current analog and coming digital equipment of Western Europe and the United States.
And because of the limited size of Westel's network, it has a theoretical maximum of about 48,000 subscribers, or less than 5 percent of the 1 million subscribers of the regular phone network.
And within Hungary, while cellular telephones are highly reliable for calling other cellular telephone users, they have only as much luck as Hungary's regular phones -- a call-completion rate of 40 percent -- when calling the vast majority of homes, businesses and government offices.
What is more, Westel's cellular phones cost more than $2,500 to buy (triple the most expensive cellular phones in the United States, though about the cost of a regular phone in Hungary) and $1,000 to activate. That is in a country where the average laborer makes about $230 a month.
Of course, this is also a country where taxes are high, tax evasion is a popular sport, and the all-cash underground economy is Hungary's biggest growth industry. Many more people, in other words, may be able to afford a cellular phone than the official wage data would indicate.
Sales of cellular phones and service will generate at least $50 million for Westel this year, up from $25 million last year, and the company is well on its way to profitability, despite high start-up costs. It has 220 employees and expects to have 10 sales offices nationwide by the end of the year.
Demand, no doubt, stems from a dilapidated phone network of 1 million regular phones, 400,000 of which are in Budapest. As in the former Soviet Union, the Communist Party wanted to keep phone service scarce and primitive to facilitate eavesdropping while crimping the flow of communication among citizens. The Party itself had good phone service, known as the "K" line (for the first letter of the word for "central" in Hungarian). The K line, however, was open to only 4,000 elite subscribers.
Today, as a result, there are only 2 telephone lines per 100 inhabitants in a country of more than 10 million people, one of the lowest levels of phone penetration in Eastern Europe. By comparsion, France has 50 lines for every 100 people and Sweden nearly 70 -- the highest rate in Europe.
"So now in Hungary today and especially Budapest," said Dr. Geza Gosztony, the wiry, intense chief adviser to the state-owned Hungarian Telecommunications Company, in an interview, "it is relatively easy for the top officers of concerns to talk to each other, but not to any normal people below them, the ones who do the actual work!"
As in other Eastern European countries, Hungary's economy is faltering because of the economic collapse of its principal trading partner, the former Soviet Union. Inflation is still high, currently about 25 percent, but down from 35 percent last year. Hungarians are feverishly trying to increase trade with their main Western trading partners, nearby Germany and Austria.
An improved phone service is essential to economic growth pursuit -- and the more phones the better for a company like Westel. There was much muttering among Hungarian entrepreneurs recently about a deal for a large Hungarian dairy cooperative that fell through because the potential purchasers, from Italy, were shocked to find there was no telephone or phone lines anywhere nearby.
Hungary is so backward in terms of telephones that the country's telecommunications officials think the nation has the chance to scrap its antiquated system and leapfrog the current cellular and regular phone technology, once standards and technical approaches that are still being developed by international conferees are settled within the next five years.
 
An Extensive Investment Plan
 Meanwhile, the Hungarian Government plans to spend 112 billion Hungarian forints, or about $1.7 billion at current exchange rates, from government funds and Western loans to modernize the telephone network. The amount constitutes a vast number of Hungarian forints in a country still burdened by $21 billion in foreign debt, the highest per capita of any country in Eastern Europe.
The network investment is badly needed however, for the introduction of advanced digital switches to replace 40-year-old electromechanical switches, the source of the abysmal call-completion rate.
Hungary, therefore, is actively looking for European and American financial institutions for investments. "Are we looking for partners?" said Dr. Gosztony, the Hungarian Telecommunications official. "The door is always open."

HEADLINE: The World's Stock Markets Did an About-Face in the Second Quarter

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The second quarter was topsy-turvy for world stock markets. What was up in the first quarter was down in the last three months -- and vice versa.
High interest rates in Europe, worries about the American economic recovery, and political and economic uncertainties in Japan all helped erase much of any gains made early in the second quarter. European markets also got an extra jolt from Denmark's surprising vote in June: The Danes rejected by a narrow margin the plan to unify Europe economically by the end of the century. 
 "The decision by the Danes did provide a catalyst for European markets to take a breather," said Henry B. W. de Vismes, head of international investments at Citibank Global Asset Management North America. He suggested that with the advent of summer, when trading interest in Europe normally lags, the markets could be in for some more volatile moves. "We are now in a silly season," he said.
 
Free Trade -- and a Free Fall
 The starkest about-face was made by the Mexican stock market. The top performer in the first quarter, Mexico's market dropped to the bottom in both dollar terms and in local currency in the second, according to the Financial Times index of world markets.
The Mexican market was undermined by rising interest rates, which will slow economic growth, and fears that Ross Perot, the undeclared independent candidate for President, might oppose the free-trade agreement that Mexico and the United States are negotiating. The economic lift expected from such an agreement had largely driven Mexico's rally.
The dollar, which had risen during the first quarter, sank. It fell 7.9 percent against the mark, 10 percent against the British pound and 5 percent against the yen.
The drop was positive for American investors. A dollar decline means that foreign-capital gains are worth more when they are translated back into dollars. Therefore, a barely perceptible two-tenths of 1 percent rise in European stock markets in the Financial Times index was swollen to a 9.1 percent gain by the dollar's drop. For the world, a 2.8 percent decline was transformed into a gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter.
While the dollar's fall was helpful, it masked the decline in European stock markets. They are troubled by not only the continued high level of German interest rates but also by the worry about the clouded outlook for economic recovery in the United States. The Federal Reserve was worried enough that on Thursday it cut the discount rate by half a percentage point and pushed down the Federal funds rate.
The British stock market, the third-worst performer in the first quarter, rose to become the second-strongest market in dollar terms in the second quarter. But that jump came mostly from the dollar's decline. While the market rallied sharply after the surprise victory of the Conservative Party and Prime Minister John Major in April, by the end of the second quarter most of the gain had evaporated.
Germany and France also had second-quarter declines, when the dollar factor is excluded. In local currency, the German market fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter compared with a 9.21 percent rise in the first quarter. In France, the market slipped 2.1 percent, according to The Financial Times, in contrast to a first-quarter rally of 10.3 percent.
And in Spain, Italy and Norway, the markets fell to their 1992 lows in the last three months. In local-currency terms, European markets slowed to two-tenths of 1 percent growth in the second quarter, compared with a 3.43 percent rise in the first quarter.
Some markets did not change significantly in the quarter. Hong Kong was still at the top, moving to No. 1 from No. 2 in the first quarter. Its super-hot rally, which has taken it to repeated records, has been powered by the belief that China is moving toward a more open economy. And this is positive for Hong Kong because it is the gateway to China.
Japan, which was depressed in the first quarter, was second to last in the second quarter, just ahead of Mexico, in both dollar terms and local currency.
The Japanese market is now down 29 percent for the year in dollar terms and almost 60 percent off its high at the end of 1989. Investors are still leery, and they await evidence that Japan's Government is willing to take bold action, like increasing spending in a supplementary budget, to help support the economy and the stock market.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
The Curative Power of Celebrations

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
THE summer of 1976 was a Prozac moment in the emotional life of New York City.
Celebrating the nation's Bicentennial and playing host to a Democratic national convention for the first time in 52 years infused New Yorkers with a euphoria that seemed to purge the depression induced the year before by New York's brush with bankruptcy and, earlier, by Watergate and the Vietnam War. 
 The Bicentennial celebration and the convention also "added to the city's self-image and to its perception by worldwide investors," the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey later concluded, and heralded Manhattan's economic revival.
"I think the same sort of circumstances that prevailed then prevail now," says Rosemary Scanlon, the Port Authority's chief economist.
The city is mired in an economic and an psychological slump, much like it was 16 years ago. But it is arguable whether the spirit of '76 will prevail again or endure.
The current slump is more prolonged than the one that was triggered in 1975 when a fiscal crisis was precipitated by a single factor -- the refusal of banks to lend the city any more money. The economic and social causes and manifestations of the latest decline are more amorphous. They have provoked neither the same degree of crisis nor inspired the same urgent solutions.
In 1976, few people were ambivalent about the Bicentennial celebration, even if women and blacks had reason to question the "all men are created equal" part. Response to Columbus has been more equivocal. The political climate has demanded a more inclusive celebration -- though not quite so broad as to include an Arab-American who, after referring to New York as "Ziontown," was dismissed last month from the Mayor's official Columbus committee.
Since the Bicentennial, the city has thrown two other big birthday parties: the 100th of the Brooklyn Bridge and of the Statue of Liberty. New Yorkers are not partied out, but the novelty may have worn off.
The same may be true about another party, the Democrats. They convene here next week (Goodbye Columbus, Hello Clinton) for the second time time since 1976, which was the first time they returned to the scene of their disastrous 1924 marathon.
Delivering a rousing nominating speech that year, Franklin D. Roosevelt invoked Wordsworth in dubbing Gov. Alfred E. Smith of New York "the Happy Warrior." But virtually nobody, Governor Smith included, was happy when the convention finally nominated John W. Davis on the 103d ballot. (In a rare display of boosterism -- "Hickville on the Hudson," William Allen White dubbed the city -- the New York press reported that while 254 people had been treated in Madison Square Garden's emergency hospital, only one had died).
The 1976 convention produced the last Democratic President. Four years later, the Democrats returned to re-nominate Jimmy Carter, who, that November, became the last Democratic incumbent to be defeated for re-election.
This year, more delegates attended several other conventions in New York than are expected at Madison Square Garden next week, but few New Yorkers noticed the influx of tens of thousands of motorcycle or variety merchandise enthusiasts. Still, a political convention, like the breathtaking tall ships, can bring out the best in a party.
"A political convention blows in and out like a 90-mile gale," James A. Farley, the Roosevelt-era Democratic leader, once said. Nowadays, the same volume of wind is generated, but it usually blows like a zephyr. Also, New York's influence has diminished since 1924 when William Jennings Bryan warned: "You New Yorkers are always forgetting that there is quite a bit of country outside of this state."
If the convention is successful, local politicians hope the euphoria will last. Mayor David N. Dinkins is already on a roll, but his once and future Republican rival, Rudolph W. Giuliani, recently suggested that just being able to balance a budget and to keep the city from burning should not merit Mr. Dinkins's re-election next year. In 1977, though, despite the euphoria generated the year before, Mayor Abraham D. Beame was defeated -- in part because he was perceived as having failed both those very tests.
Whoever wins next year will end his, or her, four-year term on the eve of still another anniversary -- the 1998 centennial of the consolidation of Greater New York. The spirit that year may depend on whether Staten Island and Queens have seceded from the city. Also, on whether the fact that Andrew H. Green, the father of Greater New York, was later shot to death while entering his Park Avenue home is recalled smugly or with alarm as evidence of how far the city has progressed in a century.

HEADLINE: Free Spending Survives Port Authority's Attempts at Restraint

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH with RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
On a humid morning last August, an aviation manager of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and an associate stood outside the agency's offices at Kennedy International Airport waiting for a lift.
Promptly at 9 A.M., a Sikorsky helicopter clattered from the skies and plucked the two men from the tarmac for a swift flight over bumper-to-bumper traffic clogging the roads to Manhattan. Minutes later they were deposited at the downtown heliport in time for a meeting at the Port Authority's World Trade Center. The subject: "New snow and ice products." 
 A year later, Port Authority officials were at a loss to explain the urgency of the mission, which required use of a $970-an-hour helicopter and two of the agency's five pilots. Each weekday, logs show, the helicopter crisscrosses the region, ferrying officials to and from routine meetings, medical appointments, ceremonial events and flight connections at airports.
 
Millions of Dollars
 The helicopter trips are among an array of expensive perquisites that emerged in an examination of agency records by The New York Times. Officials spend millions of dollars each year for ceremonial events to host world leaders, entertainment, a fleet of automobiles for top executives, seminars at area hotels, memberships in two dining clubs and meals at Windows on the World, the luxury restaurant atop one of the twin towers of the World Trade Center.
Some of the spending can be attributed to the Port Authority's role as a business enterprise with the mission to promote trade through the region's harbor and airports. Tenants must be wooed and business lured from competing markets. But the Port Authority is also a government agency that gets 27 percent of its financing from bridge and tunnel tolls paid by the public.
"Perceptions are important," said Stanley Brezenoff, the Port Authority's executive director. "The bottom line is, if you take someone's four bucks every day, you have a heavy responsibility to spend your money wisely."
But despite some sharp cutbacks aimed at reforming the agency's free-spending ways, helicopter flights and other perks survive at the Port Authority with a tenacity that irks even the agency's chairman, Richard C. Leone, who heads the 12-member commission that oversees the agency.
Such vestiges of the agency's extravagant past, he said, undercut the Port Authority's ability to win public support for important projects at a time when its judgment has been questioned because ambitious plans to rebuild Kennedy Airport have fallen victim to a deteriorating economy.
The helicopter rides, Mr. Leone said, account for only a small fraction of the agency's more than $2 billion annual budget but stand as "an irritating symbol" of the agency's reputation for excess.
 
A Symbol of Waste
 "I have been an anti-helicopter crusader to an extent that some people have said I'm unreasonable," Mr. Leone said in an interview last week. "They are a magnet for the press and are constantly used as a symbol for inefficiency and waste."
Recognizing the potential for political backlash, Port Authority officials have made a series of budget cuts intended to show they are in tune with new economic realities. Mr. Brezenoff has also moved to strengthen internal scrutiny by giving greater autonomy to the agencies' often underutilized inspector general.
Some cuts seemed acknowledgments of past excess: the travel budget was reduced by 25 percent; an executive dining room was closed, saving up to $700,000 a year; one of two executive helicopters was put up for sale; an official's private club membership was canceled, and out-of-town seminars and parties were scaled back.
"I know there are a lot of people in the agency who are very angry with me and a lot of people who think we're destroying the Port Authority," Mr. Leone said. "But it's a disadvantage in the current environment to insist on these perks."
While declining to say that spending had been out of control, Mr. Brezenoff, a former New York City Deputy Mayor who took over as the Port Authority's executive director in late 1990, said the budget cuts "suggest that costs were too high." He said he had pared $100 million from the budget, adding, "I think my efforts have been geared toward a new reality."
 
Responsibility And Power
 Chartered by Congress in 1921 to defuse a growing war between the rival ports of New York and New Jersey, the Port Authority operates the region's three major airports, the George Washington Bridge and five other New York-New Jersey crossings, PATH trains, the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan, nine marine terminals and the twin-towered World Trade Center.
Despite its lack of regulatory and taxing powers, it wields enormous and near autonomous power through its ability to charge tolls and rents and to float bonds against revenues.
But in 1977, a spending scandal set off a wave of investigations and demands for tighter control of agency perks. Commissioners and managers were authorizing themselves to fly around the world first class, or trading in first-class tickets for economy tickets for themselves and their spouses; taking Port Authority helicopters on shopping expeditions, and getting reimbursed for fictitious guests on expense accounts.
Some of the officials were later forced to reimburse the authority and many of the practices were ordered stopped. But the tradition of perks has been hard to eradicate and harder to live down, Mr. Brezenoff and Mr. Leone acknowledged.
In fact, the reputation of the Port Authority as a flush agency of legendary largesse has drawn poorer public agencies to its door in search of financial help in recent years.
The Port Authority has promised New York and New Jersey $400 million each over several years, in part as the price of winning a $1 bridge toll increase in March 1991, Mr. Leone said.
"Both states and the cities have used the Port Authority fairly heavily in the past few years when they have had budget cuts," he said. "It's fairly routine in this region to ask the Port Authority to foot the bill."
 
From Full Pockets To Ragged Budgets
 In November 1990, the Port Authority sponsored a $16,970 dinner at Windows on the World, a restaurant at the World Trade Center, for an Urban Summit of the nation's mayors presided over by Mayor David N. Dinkins.
Mr. Leone said the gathering gave the Port Authority an opportunity to counter the "awfully bad rap" the city has around the nation and the world. "We're trying to give people a good experience," he said. "The problem is whether that's done in a prudent fashion."
The agency has even been tapped by the United States Government. In an event that seemed to have only a tangential relationship to the Port Authority's mission of promoting trade for the region, the agency sponsored a two-day program last July for Panamanian legislators at the request of the State Department. A memo described the program as an attempt to assist the Government "in preparing the Panamanians for the transfer of the canal to Panamanian hands." The event included a $2,500 dinner at Windows on the World.
Mr. Brezenoff said he had been skeptical that the event was an appropriate expenditure of Port Authority money, but that his staff persuaded him that the smooth operation of the Panama canal was vital to the New York-New Jersey port.
In October 1990, the agency paid $7,750 toward a reception at Windows on the World for Carlos Salinas de Gortari, the President of Mexico. The President of Greece was honored with a $5,355 reception at the restaurant in June 1990.
In fact, the Port Authority is such a frequent patron of Windows on the World that it maintains a standing account and has spent $153,000 there in the last 18 months.
One bill from the restaurant -- for $525 -- was for the 12th annual Jets-Giants pro football luncheon last September attended by two Port Authority officials and five of their guests. The invitation described the prospects of each team and promised that attendees would get to meet two "former all-pro greats" and four current players. "All the fun begins at 12 noon with a cocktail reception," it noted.
Mr. Brezenoff said that the expenditures were carefully monitored and that all had legitimate business purposes. The Jets-Giants event provided an opportunity to entertain several important port clients who might have taken their business elsewhere, he said.
 
A Round Of Party Politics
 The agency also held a series of receptions at Windows on the World last December 16 to celebrate the signing of a lease by a Russian trade and cultural group for space in the World Trade Center. The events included a cocktail reception for 11 Russian guests and 139 others at a cost of $6,480.
The guest list comprised 65 officials and employees of the Port Authority; Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine and 10 other members of the Governor's office, including three state police officers, a security agent and a chauffeur, and two representatives from the State Department.
Later that day, three Russian guests joined 11 Port Authority officials and three American businessmen for an agency-paid dinner at the rooftop restaurant at a cost of $2,590. Afterward, Charles J. Maikish, director of the Authority's World Trade Department, took 15 of the guests for late-night snacks of oysters, steak and drinks in the restaurant's Hors d'Oeuvrerie at a cost of $345.
The agency also has lavish parties for others with whom it does business. In March, an annual reception for 300 port-industry agents and guests cost $27,425. It featured an open bar and a buffet tables offering iced shrimp, clams, oysters and a range of ethnic dishes.
In May, 400 bond underwriters and investment advisers were treated to an annual luncheon and chartered yacht tour of New York and New Jersey harbors, at a cost of $33,391. Last year's outing for 300 cost $37,042.
The Port Authority relies heavily on the sale of bonds to finance its projects and now has $4 billion in debt. The agency would probably have little trouble selling the bonds even if it canceled the annual outing, Mr. Brezenoff said, but added, "I'm not taking that risk. Why should I?"
Other government agencies entertain the bond-underwriting community but at a far lower cost. Last month, for example, New York City treated bond underwriters to a half-hour talk at New York University at a cost of $700 in refreshments. Two days later, the city sold $1.4 billion in notes at 2.72 percent interest, the lowest rate in 20 years, said Louis Haber, a spokesman for City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman.
 
An Agency Celebrates Itself
 Sometimes the agency just fetes its own employees, though less lavishly than in the past. Last October, the annual Port Service Club luncheon employees and retirees with 25 years of service honored 1,050 at a cost of $51,482 -- down from a larger party that cost $94,000 in 1988. Mr. Brezenoff said he was attempting to cut costs for all such events.
But he said the authority has no plans to cut back on its fleet of 154 cars and minivans, 49 of which are assigned to top executives and staff members for business and personal use. Seven cars and five drivers are designated for use by the 12 commissioners, who are appointed by the Governors of New York and New Jersey and serve part time without pay.
But Mr. Brezenoff said the agency is selling one of its two helicopters. The Port Authority employs five full-time pilots and for the $970-an-hour helicopters.
Several commissioners and many executives regularly use the helicopter, according to a review of logs covering the last eight months. When the board holds its monthly meetings, a helicopter is dispatched from its base at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey to ferry several of that state's commissioners from locations near their homes to lower Manhattan, often making separate trips for each.
Mr. Brezenoff defended the practice, saying the commissioners would have to travel long distances to meetings. "We make a lot of demands on them," he said.
Mr. Leone took occasional flights from Princeton, where he lives, to Manhattan. He said only used the service when it was unavoidable.
Mr. Brezenoff, records showed, took occasional flights to make speaking engagements and ribbon-cutting ceremonies and last November flew from Manhattan to Republic Airport on Long Island for lunch with the editorial board of Newsday.
Daily helicopter flights shuttle managers and staffers to routine meetings and ceremonial events. On a typical day, 10 to 20 employees travel by helicopter from one Port Authority location to another for planning sessions, department meetings and medical appointments. One employee was put on a flight to Manhattan to file his retirement papers, records showed.
Peter Yerkes, a spokesman for the authority, said officials told him to point out that "it can take up to an hour and a half to reach Kennedy Airport at rush hour."

HEADLINE: Company Says Pullout Is a Possibility

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 5

 BODY:
Canon U.S.A., the Japanese-owned camera and electronics company, is considering its options, including leaving Long Island and taking its 1,800 employees elsewhere, because its plans to build a new corporate headquarters here are in jeopardy of being rejected by this exclusive North Shore village.
Many of the village's 3,700 residents fear an increase in traffic and further commercialization of an area that is already home to the New York Institute of Technology and the C.W. Post Campus of Long Island University. 
 But James L. Larocca, the president of the Long Island Association, a business group, warned that the 25 Japanese-American companies and other international businesses on Long Island were watching the events in Brookville "as a measure of how friendly and how hospitable Long Island is to their presence."
He noted that the possible departure of Canon, based in Lake Success, comes as business leaders are stepping up efforts to attract new businesses to the region to help pull it out of the recession that began in mid-1989. He estimated that Canon has pumped $500 million a year into the Long Island economy, including payroll, business contracts and taxes.
The decision by Brookville officials to reject Canon's plan was outlined in a letter sent to residents last week, and it caught the company by surprise. David Farr, the company's general manager, said, "A decision like this is devastating."
Mr. Farr has said that if the Brookville project is rejected, Canon might have to look for a site off Long Island.
However, he said Canon is still "truly eager" to find a way for the company to remain on Long Island.
 
Meeting This Week
 Canon executives are scheduled to meet this week at the Lake Success headquarters, which they say the company has outgrown, to discuss their options, including moving to another state, after eight years of seeking a new location on Long Island.
Nassau County officials, shaken by Canon's reception here, are scrambling to head off such a move and hope to find an acceptable site for the maker of cameras and copiers.
"This comes at a time when we're feeling the effects of the worst recession to hit this area since the Depression," said Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau County Executive.
He pledged to smooth Canon's ruffled feathers and to win over Brookville officials or to find another site. One possibility is Westbury, where Canon tried four years ago to purchase a 50-acre site at the long-deserted Roosevelt Raceway for $50 million. It was blocked by a local building moratorium that has only recently been lifted.
When the race track deal unraveled, Canon sought to purchase a 100-acre site for research laboratories and offices on a corner of the sprawling campus of the Institute of Technology. The $15 million deal would have given a financial boost to the institute and preserved the deSeversky Conference Center, an elegant brick mansion built in the 1920's. It was once surrounded by English rose gardens and sweeping lawns and polo fields over which the local gentry, dressed in red riding jackets, chased the local red fox.
 
Less Golden Coast
 Red foxes still roam the remaining estates, but the Gold Coast life style is long since gone, even though many residents cling tenaciously to the remaining mansions, gatehouses and riding trails.
Polo fields have turned into parking lots. The C.W. Post estate is a campus of Long Island University. And the neighboring deSeversky estate is now the conference center, which caters weddings when not used by the Institute of Technology.
Canon proposed in plans filed with the village to use 5 acres of the 100-acre parcel on Northern Boulevard to build campuslike research laboratories and offices employing nearly 1,800 people. The plan would maintain the deSeversky center and a 95-acre greenbelt. A two-level garage for employee parking was to be built out of view. The area is now zoned residential, with a 5-acre minimum lot size.
Despite the prospect of substantial tax revenues from Canon, Brookville village officials, reacting to stiff local opposition, declared that the plan would not comply with the zoning. Mayor Michael P. Galgano and the board of trustees sent a letter to residents indicating that they planned to reject the Canon project.
The letter said, "There was no basis in law to permit a modification of the existing special use permit" under which the Institute of Technology uses the site. It said that granting Canon's request "could be interpreted as spot zoning." The board is expected to vote on the rezoning in September.
Mayor Galgano said the issue had "caused a lot of acrimony." He said opponents were concerned that if Canon moved in, it would not only change the way of life in Brookville, but in surrounding North Shore villages.

HEADLINE: Offtrack Betting Profits Hit Record Low

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
The Offtrack Betting Corporation, which has been criticized for its spending and management practices, saw its profits sink to a record low this year.
In a report to be released today, the agency said it ended the 1991-92 fiscal year last Tuesday with a profit of $600,000 for the city. The showing was the poorest since the agency, which was established to generate revenue for the city and to discourage illegal gambling, expanded into a major operation in 1975. 
 OTB's profit in the 1990-91 fiscal year was $2.9 million.
The report on the dwindling profits follows proposals by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan and the City Council Finance Committee that the Dinkins administration consider selling OTB to a private company.
In addition to the $600,000 profit, OTB provided the city with $25.7 million from a 5 percent surcharge on winning bets. Some state officials and Council members, however, challenge OTB's characterization of the surcharge as profit, maintaining that it is equivalent to a sales tax and has no bearing on OTB's overall success.
OTB's profits and surcharges have declined steadily since the 1987-88 fiscal year, when it produced $15.9 million in profits and $31.5 million in surcharges, a total of $47.4 million. The handle, or gross wagers, also has fallen from a record $1.032 billion in 1988 to $887.3 million in the 1991-92 fiscal year.
State law prohibits OTB from using the surcharge for operating expenses. If profits continue to decrease, the agency would have to cut expenses, and possibly discharge employees at its Times Square headquarters and its 95 betting branches.
Edward T. Lewis, OTB's board chairman, and Leland T. Jones, the chief spokesman for Mayor David N. Dinkins, attributed the decline mainly to the recession, which they said had discouraged wagering.
"These figures make it sound like OTB is going out of business, but it is not," Mr. Lewis said.
Mr. Jones said that city and OTB officials were "looking at ways to cut overhead until such times as OTB's fortunes turn around."
"The idea of privatization has been one of many ideas swirling around," Mr. Jones said. "But no decision has been made."
 
OTB Predicts Improvement
 OTB is a semi-independent agency created by the Legislature in 1970. The Mayor selects an unpaid board of directors to set policies.
In its financial report, OTB said it anticipated a profit of $2.8 million in the current fiscal year that ends next June 30, and $3.7 million by 1996.
Hazel N. Dukes, whom Mr. Dinkins appointed in July 1990 as the agency's president and top executive, declined to be interviewed. Her spokeswoman, Marjorie W. Longley, said the brighter projections were based on assumptions that the handle will rise and on the opening of several branches in Manhattan with live television coverage of races.
"We think we have reversed a downward trend," said Ms. Longley.
 
Council Has Criticisms
 She emphasized that before the city can reap any earnings, OTB is required to pay the racing industry and the state a total of $70 million a year.
The City Council Finance Committee, in a report in March, admonished OTB for what the Council members called excessive expenses for entertainment and office furnishings and for poor management policies. According to the committee, OTB has a manager for every three employees, compared with one for every seven employees in private business.
"The meager profits prove that restructuring of OTB is in order and that privatization must be considered," Councilman Herbert E. Berman, the chairman of the committee, said in an interview.
Mr. Regan, in a statement, said, "It's ridiculous that OTB is unable to generate any more than 0.1 percent profit on betting volume of almost $1 billion."
Ms. Longley, disputing the criticism, said that in the two years of Ms. Dukes's administration, full-time employees had been cut to 1,590 from 1,695 and the annual budget trimmed to $101.6 million from $107.5.million.
She noted that $669 million, about 75 percent of the $887 million handle, was returned to customers for winning wagers.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Electronics Chain On Roller Coaster

BYLINE: By Adam Bryant

 BODY:
THE stock of the Good Guys Inc., the West Coast consumer electronics chain, has not lived up to its name of late. After rising to $29.75 a share last September, the stock took a wrenching roller coaster ride to $13.625 in January, back up to $22.50 in March, then down to its 52-week low of $9.75 in mid-June. It ended last week at $10.25.
What is behind the fall and rise and fall of Good Guys' stock? In broad terms, the problem lies in doubts about future performance, a concern rarely mentioned in the same breath as the company's name in recent years. 
 After going public in 1986, the company posted year after year of double-digit growth in comparable same-store sales, while many competitors worked to muster single-digit increases. It expanded rapidly to 39 stores -- all but one in California -- using its strategy of thoroughly training salespeople to sell a broad selection of products, including some high-end merchandise, at low prices.
But a hotly competitive market and a weak California economy have analysts wondering when they will see strong earnings gains again, prompting many to place a neutral rating on the stock, which trades over the counter.
While retail stocks have also been under pressure lately, some predict that Good Guys will track the general performance of retail stocks until the outlook improves for California's economy and for the next Christmas selling season. The introduction of new digital audio recording formats -- Sony's mini-disk and Philips's digital compact cassette -- is also expected to raise industrywide sales this fall.
It appears that competition will ease somewhat for Good Guys. Rogersound Labs of Canoga Park, Calif., a leading Good Guys competitor, entered liquidation proceedings last month for its 11 locations in Los Angeles and Orange Counties. Good Guys, which is based in Burlingame, a San Francisco suburb, and operates 13 stores in greater Los Angeles, is expected to garner roughly a quarter of Rogersound's $60 million in annual sales. "Good Guys will benefit from the shakeout in the industry," said Lynn Sawyer, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds. "It's a well-managed, well-positioned company."
The enthusiasm of Ms. Sawyer and other analysts started to wane in December after they learned from the company that the stiff competition would hurt earnings. The stock plunged roughly 50 percent in less than a month.
The stock rebounded to $22.50 in March on the strength of Good Guys' reputation as a consistent performer, which it earned with its five-year track record of 36 percent annual growth in sales and 40 percent annual growth in earnings per share.
A lackluster 3 percent same-store sales gain from January through March started the most recent slide. "They had built up so much credibility with investors because of the management team that people came back into the stock each time," said Sharon E. Rappaport of Morgan Stanley, who is also neutral on the stock. "When sales began to slow, people started wondering how long this is going to last."
The stock's current low price makes it good buy for the long-term investor, said David A. Bolotsky of Goldman, Sachs. He applauded recent strategy changes that included focusing Good Guys' advertising on higher-end products instead of loss-leader promotions. Also, the company's gross margins will be helped somewhat by its decision to end a "Double the Difference" promotion and go back to its former program of refunding 110 percent of the price difference when a competitor's price falls below the Good Guys' price for an item.
Eliminating the "Double the Difference" promotion, which it offered from last Thanksgiving to Memorial Day, will add up to two-tenths of a percent to the company's margins, said Robert A. Gunst, president of the company.
A key strength of Good Guys' top management, Mr. Bolotsky said, is its policy of meeting regularly with store-level managers, a costly but important means of insuring quick response to market changes. Mr. Gunst visits each store about twice a year, and top executives meet four times a year with all salespeople in groups of up to 500.
An important next step for Good Guys will be breaking out of the California market beyond its single store in Reno. Mr. Gunst said the company planned to make that move sometime in the mid-1990's.
Some question whether its format will work outside California, where many audiophiles and videophiles are willing to pony up for higher-end, more profitable models. But Mr. Gunst said the company's products had enough broad appeal to sell well in all markets.
"We do not carry tweeky, esoteric, high-end product lines," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Premiere, Growing Film Magazine, Looks Abroad

BYLINE: By JAY E. ROSEN

 BODY:
Premiere magazine, which immigrated to the United States from France five years ago, is returning to Europe.
K-III Magazines, which publishes the monthly film magazine, has reached an agreement with a London publisher, EMAP Metro, to start a British edition in October. 
 "Since Premiere sells so well in the U.K., it only seemed natural to do a British edition," says Susan Lyne, editor and publication director of Premiere, which itself is based on a French film magazine with the same name but a different focus.
The American Premiere sells approximately 15,000 copies a month in Britain, and K-III is projecting an initial circulation of 50,000 for the British edition.
Ms. Lyne said one reason for the strong sales in Britain was the popularity of American films. "Eight out of 10 film tickets sold are for American films," she said.
 
Second International Edition
 The British magazine will be the American Premiere's second international edition. A Japanese edition, published by the Kadokawa Shoten Publishing Company, was started in May 1990. Japan is Hollywood's second-largest market.
Starting international editions is only one of the ways in which Premiere has sought to cash in on its popularity. Its other ventures include television specials about the movies and Preview, a magazine given away at some theaters.
Indeed, the growth of Premiere contradicts the doubts that some people in publishing and entertainment had when plans for the American magazine were first announced. These skeptics wondered whether there was a large audience for a film industry magazine aimed mainly at movie enthusiasts.
But Marian L. Schwindeman, now publisher of the American Premiere, believed that the film-making process was becoming more newsworthy than the movies themselves.
 
Covering More Than Glamour
 In 1986, Ms. Schwindeman approached John B. Evans, then president of Murdoch Magazines, about starting a film industry magazine. "I wanted to create a magazine that would not only cover the glamour of Hollywood, but the craft and process as well," she said.
At that time, Murdoch Magazines and Hachette S.A. of France were studying ways to introduce some of the French publisher's magazines to the United States, and Premiere, a popular film magazine in France since 1976, was a strong possibility.
But after seeing the French Premiere, Mr. Evans quickly lost much of his initial enthusiasm, in part because of different tastes on each side of the Atlantic. "I could not understand how a magazine that could put Jerry Lewis on the cover and be a triumph could ever be successful here," he said.
Moreover, to succeed, an American magazine would need to be more critical of Hollywood than the French Premiere was. "The French were very fawning toward Hollywood," Ms. Lyne recalled. "We wanted to do investigative pieces."
What did impress Mr. Evans about the French Premiere magazine was its access to the studios, which often enabled its writers to go right to the movie sets for articles. He believed that a magazine reporting from inside the industry could be successful.
The introductory issue came out in June 1987 and sold more than 300,000 copies. Regular publication began in September 1987.
In the last half of 1991, circulation averaged 492,940, and the magazine says it now sells about 530,000 copies.
Premiere attracts readers by taking a hard look at business and production practices in Hollywood. It has examined the role of blacks in the industry; the disaster in making "Twilight Zone: The Movie," in which the star Vic Morrow and two children were killed, and reports of mismanagement at Robert Redford's Sundance Institute. Premiere says some of its articles have cost it studio advertising. "We have been punished by every studio at one time or another," Ms. Lyne said.
The American Premiere was supposed to be a joint venture of Hachette and Murdoch Magazines. But in 1989, Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation acquired Hachette's 50 percent stake in the venture.
And last year, K-III Holdings, a partnership of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, bought most of Murdoch Magazines, including Premiere, for $650 million and set up K-III Magazines.
 
Still Seeking a Profit
 Despite its growth, Premiere is still not profitable, Ms. Schwindeman said. In the last year, Premiere lost about 100 pages of advertising because of the recession. But Ms. Schwindeman predicted that advertising in September's issue would be up about 5 percent from a year earlier and that the magazine should run roughly 700 ad pages this year, up from about 680 in 1991, but still below the 820 pages of 1990.
Dick Hawkes, executive vice president of K-III Magazines, said the magazine should be profitable within a year, with a circulation of 600,000.
Premiere competes with a variety of other, smaller magazines, including Movieline, Movies U.S.A. and Film Comment. And, of course, there is Entertainment Weekly, which Ms. Schwindeman does not see as a direct competitor because it covers the entire entertainment industry, not just film.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marian L. Schwindeman, left, publisher of Premiere, and Susan Lyne, editor, plan to expand their film publication into Britain in October. The American magazine has had a Japanese edition since May 1990. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Conditions for Higher Rates Fade

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The unwelcome and surprisingly strong rise in market interest rates that came after the Federal Reserve Board sharply cut rates in December is unlikely to recur in the wake of the action taken by the Fed last week, analysts and traders say.
Yields on 30-year Treasury bonds briefly fell to 7 3/8 percent on the last day of 1991, about a week after the Fed cut the discount rate one percentage point and trimmed its target on the overnight Federal funds rate a half point. But in the next three months, yields on the long bonds rose above 8 percent, and rates on short-term securities also moved higher, though not nearly as much. 
 While acknowledging that rates could temporarily move higher after last week's strong rally, traders and analysts argue that conditions are different than they were six months ago.
 
Rush of New Issues
 The Fed's move last year set off a record volume of new issues in the corporate and municipal bond markets. The surge, coupled with Government estimates that the Federal budget deficit would reach $400 billion in the current fiscal year, helped push rates higher. Statistics showing the economy was improving in January and February advanced the upward momentum.
The drop in rates engineered by the Fed on Thursday -- a half-point cut in the discount rate, to 3 percent, and a similar cut in the target for the Federal funds rate, to 3.25 percent -- will almost certainly keep investment bankers active this week. Some $10 billion to $15 billion worth of new corporate debt issues could be priced this week, bankers said, and the tax-exempt calendar is heavy.
But specialists in corporate and municipal finance said the pace of new issues, at least through the summer, would almost certainly slow from the torrid clip of the first six months of the year.
In the first half, corporations issued $132.8 billion worth of nonconvertible debt securities, according to the Securities Data Company, up more than 38 percent from the comparable period a year ago.
In addition, figures from The Bond Buyer, a publication that tracks developments in municipal finance, show that $109 billion worth of new municipal bonds were sold in the first half, a 46 percent increase from the similar 1991 period.
Analysts are convinced that such a pace cannot be sustained because a disproportionate amount of the volume in both markets were securities issued to refinance debt issued in the mid- to late 1980's. Net new credit demand, however, was quite weak and is likely to remain so.
 
'Not Stimulative for Borrowing'
 "The interest rates move by the Fed is not enough to stimulate large borrowing above and beyond refinancings," said Thomas J. Sowanick, senior fixed-income strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company.
"We have learned," he added, "that lower interest rates are not stimulative for borrowing because the level of debt outstanding owed by corporations and individuals is still extraordinarily high."
George Friedlander, a managing director at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said that unless rates continued to plunge, the volume of new issues in the tax-exempt market should be down substantially from the first half.
Of the $109 billion in new municipal issues priced in the first half, more than 42 percent were refunding issues, he said, a 143 percent increase from the first six months of 1991.
"Refunding capability gets used up," he said, "and there are very few new-money financings that are that rate-sensitive."
Moreover, while the need to finance new projects is manifest, "the number of states that can afford to do them is much less great," Mr. Friedlander added.
In addition, while the supply of new Treasury securities to be sold in the third quarter will be enormous, the Government's financing needs are well below the estimates bandied about at the beginning of the year.
Borrowing by the Treasury in the current quarter will amount to less than $70 billion, according to analysts at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, an economic consulting firm, about half as large as the most dire forecasts presented in January.
Louis v. B. Crandall, Wrightson's chief economist, said yields on short-term Treasury securities were now at much more realistic levels than in the winter.
"Part of the rise in yields during the first quarter was due to the fact that they had fallen too far," he said.
In January, for example, two-year Treasury notes were yielding 4.60 percent when the Fed's target for the funds rate was 4 percent.
At the close of trading on Thursday, by contrast, two-year notes were yielding 4.55 percent. But through two easing moves the Fed had dropped its funds rate target by three-quarters of a percent, to 3.25 percent.
 
More Sputtering
 Aside from easing supply pressures, Mr. Crandall and other analysts say there is little chance that economic data will show the marked improvement this summer that was seen in the first two months of the year. And inflationary pressures remain in check.
For most analysts, the June employment report was a sobering reminder of how wobbly the underpinnings of the current recovery really are, and it virtually insures that most of the important economic statistics to be released this month will be weak.
"I had thought the recovery would be slow, sluggish and sustainable," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. "But this report is making me question if it is sustainable."

HEADLINE: This Week's Auctions Include 7-Year Notes

 BODY:
Financings by the Treasury this week include the regular auction of three- and six-month bills today and an auction of seven-year notes on Wednesday.
By late Thursday, the final day of trading last week, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 3.22 percent after the Fed had cut the discount rate; a six-month bill was at 3.33 percent. In when-issued trading, the new seven-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.51 percent. 
 Among the Government agency issues to be priced this week is a $500 million offering by the Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, of floating-rate notes due to mature on Jan. 14.
