HEADLINE: Review/Television;
For the Unemployed, Some Tips and Empathy

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
With unemployment still rising, it is not for a television reviewer to discourage anyone in need of a job from finding consolation wherever it is offered, in a bar, a beauty parlor, a bowling alley or in the bromides of "Out of Work." But beware. This program on PBS tonight (in New York on Channel 13 at 9) is a bin of banalities from introductory psychology and sociology texts.
One section of the hour, which concentrates on white-collar workers, is called "Termination." Losing your job, it reveals, is a blow to self-esteem, which can result in shock, denial and anger, so it is recommended that you "make peace with your anger." Also: "While it seems simplistic to say so, it helps not to take your employer's treatment of you personally." No more simplistic than the rest of the lecture. 
 The language of the narrator and counselors gives the spirit of the thing: "He has personally experienced termination." "The bank was downsizing the staff." "One lesson in all of this is to face your financial reality immediately." In one regard, "Out of Work" is good news for job seekers; it proves that you don't have to have a facility for English to qualify for making television programs.
The segment on looking for work begins with a visit to a job counseling company, where, the narrator says, "You'll undergo constructive review of your resume writing, interviewing and marketing skills." This viewer had undergone enough; the program experienced termination.
 
P.O.V.
Last Images of War
The Longest Shadow
PBS, tonight.
(Channel 13, New York, at 10.)
"Last Images of War," is a tribute to the talent, daring and commitment of four photojournalists who were killed covering the civil war in Afghanistan. The pictures taken by Jim Lindelof, an American; Andy Skrzypkowiak of England; Naoko Nanjo of Japan, and Sasha Sekretaryov of the Soviet Union capture the grittiness of the war and the pain of the people caught in it. Their explanations as they went into the battle zones of why they were taking such risks serve as eulogies.
Tonight's two-hour offering from "P.O.V.," public television's series of independent productions, concludes with "The Longest Shadow," the documentary maker Kalina Ivanov's reflections on Bulgaria's Stalinist past and her disturbing report on the forces now blocking moves toward democracy.

HEADLINE: Soviet Collapse Lessens Cuba's Threat

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Making Poor Cubans Suffer More" (editorial, June 15) faults the proposed Cuban Democracy Act. The bill raises problems even for those like myself who consider that the United States embargo has been effective against Fidel Castro. 
 The goal of the embargo was to make more costly to the Soviets and to Cuba President Castro's relentless hostility to the United States and his role as a surrogate in the cold war. That goal has been accomplished.
However, to set as a goal the overthrow of Mr. Castro, which is implicit in the bill, exceeds what it can attain and plays into his hands. A totalitarian regime survives on its repressive capacity, no matter its popularity. By pushing the Cubans into a survival economy, we increase Mr. Castro's control over them. The power to allocate the increasingly scarce food and medicines provides another tool for his repressive apparatus. And he can blame us for the hardships.
Cuba is less of a threat to us with the Soviet collapse. Tightening the rules on humanitarian aid is the opposite of what we should do. Rules on remittances by Cubans to their families should be liberalized, not made more restrictive. And we should make it easier for church and other groups to provide food and medicine to Cubans without relatives overseas.
The bill fails to address those dissatisfied Cubans around Mr. Castro who can really start the end of his regime. It does not provide explicit assurance that we respect Cuba's sovereignty and the right of Cubans to choose their leaders. These omissions yield to Mr. Castro the emotional forces of nationalism and personal survival to rally his followers around him.
 
ERNESTO F. BETANCOURT
Washington, June 14, 1992
 
The writer is former director of Radio Marti.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Digging Deeper in Iraqgate

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In angrily insisting to have had no guilty knowledge of Saddam Hussein's abuse of our grain credits to buy destructive technology, George Bush last week showed no understanding of the First Law of Holes: when in one, stop digging.
The President, entertaining tourists in the Rose Garden for "CBS This Morning," was upset by an irreverent question. It had to do with sworn testimony by Frank Lemay, a Foreign Service officer, that he informed higher-ups on Oct. 13, 1989 -- in a memo kept "out of the system" -- about a rash of investigations into Iraq's ripoff. 
 "We didn't know that," Mr. Bush snapped. "The State Department didn't know it. You can talk about what one State Department employee" -- he decided against attacking the F.S.O. "And if we had known it," he said about the corrupt diversion, "it wouldn't have happened."
The Bush Iraqgate defense is apparently to claim ignorance of the spreading Lavoro scandal before James Baker directed Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter to push through a half-billion-dollar payment to Saddam.
The President dug himself in deeper: "We did not go to enhance his nuclear, biological or chemical capability." Then he inadvertently pushed open a door: "I have an executive order out on specifically that."
I called his press secretary to note that the President had just declassified National Security Directive 26 by describing its contents on the air, and asked for the text. Marlin Fitzwater confirmed that N.S.D. 26 was the document referred to, and suggested I get a copy from Congress.
A portion of which I did. That Oct. 2, 1989 policy directive making Saddam our central gulf ally contains this sentence: "We should pursue, and seek to facilitate, opportunities for U.S. firms to participate in the reconstruction of the Iraqi economy, particularly in the energy area, where they do not conflict with our non-proliferation and other significant objectives." (Italics mine.)
What does Mr. Bush's use of the word "nonproliferation" tell us? The "energy area" could mean oil and gas energy, or it could mean nuclear energy. Nobody worries about oil and gas proliferation -- but we do oppose nuclear proliferation.
This strongly suggests Mr. Bush wanted to encourage U.S. firms to supply Saddam's nascent atomic program with our nuclear and computer technology, which the Defense Department had resisted. In the preceding paragraph of N.S.D. 26, he warns of economic and political sanctions for "Any breach by Iraq of I.A.E.A. safeguards in its nuclear program."
George Bush signed that infamous directive to help arm Iraq 58 days after the F.B.I. raided the Lavoro Bank's Atlanta office to discover Iraqi skimming and abuse of U.S. loan guarantees. James Baker, well aware by briefing and in writing of Saddam's fraud, went ahead under N.S.D. 26 to arm-twist Agriculture to disregard creditworthiness and hand over $500 million more to Iraq.
Now about Mr. Bush's "the State Department didn't know it."
On Oct. 17, 1989, three days after Frank Lemay delivered his memo detailing the Iraq-Lavoro investigations to Undersecretary Richard McCormack, the Treasury Department's Rachel Bailey made contemporaneous notes of the reaction of its recipients in State: "McCormack is particularly seized. Baker is putting pressure. Bob [Downes] spending a lot of time: Sofaer, McCormack, Kimmitt. Baker is insisting on being kept informed."
Mr. Bush should stop pretending he and Baker were out of the loop, come clean on the real motive and ask the court to appoint independent counsel before Congress demands it.
Then he should try to redeem his failures before and after Desert Storm. That means recognizing the legitimacy of Kurdish leaders Talabani and Barzani, victors in democratic elections in the zone of Iraq we protect with Britain and Turkey.
It means publicly approving the recent meeting in Vienna of leaders of all anti-Saddam elements, and extending our aerial protection to a provisional government of all factions inside Iraqi Kurdistan. And it means inviting these anti-Saddam leaders to the White House to dramatize America's endorsement of their aim to establish democracy in Baghdad.
That would be a start. Some good may yet come out of prosecuting the crimes of Iraqgate.

HEADLINE: Moldovan Conflict Worries Romania

BYLINE: By MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania, July 5

 BODY:
The willingness of Romanians in Romania to befriend and support ethnic Romanians in Moldova in the face of attacks from Russian and Ukrainian separatists grows with each news account of sniper fire.
But Government officials are taking pains to insist that they do want speedy reunification of the two countries, which together formed a single Romanian state before World War II. 
 "What we want is the German model," said Foreign Minister Adrian Nastase, referring to the era before unification. "We have recognized Moldova as a fully independent state, and so have more than a hundred other countries. It is like the old East Germany and West Germany: one people but separate states."
The 45-year-old official, working in shirtsleeves on Saturday in an otherwise empty ministry, added, "If at some point in the future the people of both countries voted in a referendum to merge, as they did to reunite Germany, then why not?" But he said that at the moment, any such development loomed only as a distant possibility.
 
Pieces Don't Fit, Yet
 A country of 23 million people, Romania has a more highly developed economy than Moldova and its 4.5 million people. And, Mr. Nastase noted, any effort to integrate a Moldova far more Sovietized than Romania had been, even under Nicolae Ceausescu, would delay or derail plans to reform Romania's economic and political life. Moreover, he said, the leaders of Moldova were unwilling to merge into a larger state where their influence could only shrink or disappear.
But politicians from several parties and diplomats from several countries agreed with Mr. Nastase's contention that the longer the conflict in Moldova rages without resolution, the greater the risk that issues of Romanian nationalism could embroil the campaign for presidential and parliamentary elections here. The elections, scheduled for Sept. 27, are viewed as a critical test for Romania's transition toward democracy.
Mr. Nastase said he had met with the leaders of all major political parties, seeking assurances that they would not exploit the situation by demagogic appeals for more belligerence in defense of Moldova. "Our approach has to be nonviolent," he said.
 
Russians Cause Nervousness
 A Western diplomat said that while in principle the politicians may have agreed to play down the issue, they were finding it difficult to keep from accusing the Government and one another of not doing enough for their kinfolk.
Such talk would be provocative, the diplomat said, particularly since the situation across the eastern border was extremely dangerous, with a large Russian Army in Moldova, outside Russia, with undefined aims and lines of command that did not necessarily lead to civilian authority in Moscow.
Prime Minister Theodor D. Stolojan, in a conversation during a Fourth of July party at the United States Embassy, said that for the moment, he did not think the risk of inflamed nationalism of the sort raging in Yugoslavia was great.
Nonetheless, it is obvious that no foreign policy issue since the fall of Ceausescu has so deeply touched the passions of Romanians as have the nightly reports of shooting of Moldovan policemen and shelling of Moldovan villages by Russian and Ukrainian irregulars in the secessionist sliver east of the Dniester river. Romanians remember that almost all of what is now Moldova was torn from Romania by Soviet armies in 1940 under the terms of Stalin's pact with Hitler.
 
Honk if You Hate Russians
 For the last two weeks, several hundred Romanians have maintained a vigil outside the Russian Embassy, protesting the attacks and what the demonstrators contend has been the role of Moscow in arming the paramilitary forces with tanks and artillery.
"Yeltsin is a criminal," said one sign. Another asked, "Where is America when Moldovans are being killed?" The demonstrators also hold signs asking motorists to blow their horns to show their disgust with the Russians; almost every car that passes the busy street honks, night and day.
Mr. Nastase, the Foreign Minister, spoke about Romania's policy toward Moldova only hours after he had returned from Moscow, where he joined the Foreign Ministers of Russia, Moldova and Ukraine in talks on ending the fighting. He said he thought the talks and a meeting between President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and President Mircea Snegur of Moldova had cleared up some suspicions and antagonisms.
Mr. Nastase said two major issues had been identified: the legal status of Russia's 14th Army, and the legal status of the separatist Trans-Dneister region, which was added on to the Romanian lands seized by Stalin to form what had been the Moldavian Socialist Republic of the Soviet Union.
"The question of the army is critical," Mr. Nastase said. "Right now what we have is a Russian army, a foreign force, in an independent country that has virtually no army of its own. Moldova does not even have a border with Russia. What has to be established is to whom is this army responsible and under what conditions is it there."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 9, 1992, Thursday

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: President Bush Impedes Democracy

 BODY:
With his veto last week of common-sense legislation designed to make it simple and convenient for all Americans to register to vote, President Bush has demonstrated his opposition to expanded participation in government.
The measure, nicknamed "motor-voter," would have required states to allow citizens to register when they obtain or renew a driver's license. It also would have required states to offer registration by mail and at welfare, unemployment and other government offices. These steps, experts say, would boost registration to about 90 percent of all eligible voters -- a big leap from the dismal 60 percent now signed up. 
 Why would anyone oppose making it easier to register and vote? To justify his veto, Mr. Bush offers a host of flimsy reasons. Most galling is his assertion that there's "no justification" for imposing new standards on the states. Surely the estimated 70 million eligible Americans left unregistered by the present system provide ample justification.
Mr. Bush also repeats the tired Republican argument that "motor-voter" would increase fraud, even though there has been no recorded increase in cheating in the 29 states that already sign up voters at motor-vehicle offices, or in the 27 states that permit registration by mail.
No matter how he tries to cloak it, it seems plain that Mr. Bush's veto decision was a bow to G.O.P. fears that easier registration might hurt Republicans by enrolling large numbers of low-income Democrats at accessible public offices. Yet the bill's provisions wouldn't become effective until after the 1992 election. This was an opportunity for Mr. Bush to show statesmanship, and he blew it.
There's only a slim chance that the bill's sponsors can muster the votes needed to override the veto. But with fully 40 percent of eligible Americans still unregistered, it's worth a real fight when Congress returns from the July 4th recess.

HEADLINE: Say Goodbye, for Now, to Lower Air Fares

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
With summer vacations in full swing, travelers who have waited until now to buy airline tickets are in for a surprise: beginning tomorrow, air fares are expected to rise to their highest level in months. And if the carriers have their way, fares will continue to climb.
The exact amount of tomorrow's climb remains a mystery, because at least three different formulas have been loaded into the reservations computers. But on average, fares are likely to rise at least 10 percent. 
 It is hardly surprising. Airline executives contend that higher fares are necessary for the future health of the ailing industry, which has lost $6 billion in the last two years and has seen Pan American, Eastern and Midway go out of business. And just Thursday, the shrunken Braniff International called it quits.
Analysts and industry experts generally agree with the airline executives' assessment.
"The only way the industry will return to profitability is by increasing revenues," said Paul P. Karos, an airline analyst with First Boston.
Joseph Murphy, the publisher of Airline Financial News and several other airline newsletters, said, "Airline costs have gone up consistently, but fares haven't kept pace."
Even Christopher Witkowski, the director of the Aviation Consumer Action Project, a Ralph Nader organization, agreed that the industry was experiencing hard times. He also said that most passengers did not believe that fare increases were automatically bad. "But carriers," he added, "often try to use rising costs, including fuel increases, as an excuse to hike fares higher than justified."
In a speech at the National Press Club in Washington last week, Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of American Airlines, said: "By every measure of profitibility, airlines consistently rank dead last among major U.S. industries. Only once during the last 10 years -- in 1988 -- did the airline industry earn a net profit margin of as much as 3 percent. The average margin was actually negative."
Similarly, Stephen M. Wolf, chairman of United Airlines, told a meeting of travel and tourism officials in San Francisco last month that the industry's heavy losses had forced it to re-evaluate a number of airport improvement projects, to reconsider the feasibility of some recently developed hubs and to defer and cancel billions of dollars in orders for new aircraft.
United alone deferred $6.7 billion worth of orders, delaying 122 of 278 planes originally scheduled for delivery through 1995. And American is considering closing its recent hubs at Raleigh-Durham, N.C., Nashville and San Jose, Calif.
But there are limits to such economies, analysts say. Among the principal airlines of 51 nations and two international consortia, the United States fleet ranks 45th in age (more than 14 years compared with less than 11 for the world industry average), according to the publication World Airline Fleet Review.
Moreover, "the airlines face capital expenditures of some $180 billion by the year 2000," according to Robert J. Aaronson, the president of the Air Transport Association.
"Most of that is for the Government-mandated conversion of the airlines' fleet to quieter jets by the end of the decade." Meeting the new guidelines, he said, will require the industry to replace or modify 2,600 aircraft, at a cost of $130 billion.
 
Customers Expect Discounts
 In recent years, published fares actually rose steeply, especially those aimed at business travelers. But only 6 percent of the travelers paid the published fares; most flew at discounts averaging almost 40 percent off published prices. Some analysts wonder whether passengers are now so accustomed to discounts that they will resist any price rise, simply waiting until the next flurry of markdowns.
"Airlines have never been able to sell more than two-thirds of their seats," said Mr. Murphy, the aviation publisher. "So no matter what the fare levels, there'll always be bargain fares to fill the remaining one-third."
What helped keep air fares low in recent years were the death throes of Eastern and Pan Am, which offered big discounts as they struggled to survive. These days the big discounters are T.W.A. and America West, which are similarly struggling to survive. But both carriers would like to see higher industrywide fares, even though their own fares presumably would remain lower than those of the major carriers.
The weak economy also put pressure on fares, grounding many corporate and leisure travelers. Last year, total airline passengers fell for the first time in recent history -- to 452.2 million from 465.6 million in 1990, a 2.9 percent drop.
 
Claims of Predatory Pricing
 Last month's half-price sale on advance-purchase domestic tickets is likely to add millions to the industry's debt load -- possibly $500 million, according to Robert Ferguson, chairman of Continental. He said that while a carrier's costs are typically between 8 to 10 cents per seat mile, during the half-price sale carriers were selling seats at an average of 5 cents a seat mile. (A recent First Boston study reported that the industry's average seat-mile cost last year was 9.7 cents, the highest level in the 12 years covered by the study.)
Soon after the sale ended last month, Continental, Northwest and shareholders of America West filed suits against American, claiming its half-price sale amounted to predatory pricing intended to put them out of business.
Last week, when Braniff quit flying, it also blamed the fare war, saying the flurry of price cuts had undercut its own low fares, and warning that it was considering litigation.
Mr. Witkowski, the consumer advocate, also thinks the fare structure of the major carriers was intended "to hasten the downfall of low-cost competitors." If that happens, he said, "it will be harmful to all of us."
American denied the charge of predatory pricing, saying it merely responded to Northwest's earlier 2-for-1 family promotion.
But Northwest said its promotion had been targeted to only a small segment of the leisure travel market, adding that its previously projected $20 million profit from the family promotion would be transformed into a $40 million loss, since Northwest, like other carriers, felt compelled to match American.
Many travelers may not immediately notice tomorrow's scheduled fare increases, especially if they are traveling on recently purchased half-price tickets, which are valid through Sept. 13.
The new fares are intended to do more than simply return to the levels adopted by most of the industry in April, when American introduced its mileage-based, four-tier structure; American also wants to tack on an additional 4.4 percent increase in most markets, and United wants a 4.4 rise across the board.
Northwest said it would match its competitors, but would raise fares a full 10 percent in markets where it does not compete head-on with America and United.
Because airlines are continuing to adjust a limited number of fares to reflect the actual distance flown, some fare increases will go far beyond the proposed 4.4 percent rise. Thus, a first-class ticket on American between Hartford and Los Angeles, for example, will increase by 63 percent, according to USTravel, a large travel agency with headquarters in Rockville, Md.
In a sampling of 750 markets across the nation, USTravel found that American Airlines' proposed new coach fares will rise an average of 12 percent, first class 8 percent, 7-day excursion fares 13 percent and 14-day fares 12 percent. Between New York and Los Angeles, the increases will range from 29 percent (seven-day excursion fare) to 14 percent (first class).
If oil prices continue to rise, USTravel warned, and if recent labor agreements cost more than expected, "the fare structure could be in for a long, tough summer."

HEADLINE: U.S.-Trained Conservative Is Elected Ecuador President

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: QUITO, Ecuador, July 5

 BODY:
An American-trained advocate of free market economic change was elected President of this oil-producing nation today, projections from two unofficial counts of the vote indicated. With 97 percent of the ballots counted unofficially, Sixto Duran Bellen had a 13 percentage-point margin, according to tallies by local news organizations.
"It's a harvest of a whole life, of 40 years of public service," the winning candidate, a courtly 70-year-old architect, said minutes after learning that exit polls earlier indicated that he had swept 19 of Ecuador's 21 provinces in his quest to become the new leader of Ecuador, South America's largest oil exporter after Venezuela. 
 The unofficial methods of gauging the results proved accurate in the first round of the voting, on May 17, which narrowed the field of candidates to the top two vote-getters. The official count of today's voting is expected to take several weeks.
Two hours after polling stations closed, Mr. Duran Bellen's opponent, Jaime Nebot Saadi, a 45-year-old lawyer, conceded defeat in his home in Guayaquil, Ecuador's main port. Mr. Nebot also advocated free-market policies.
From the Galapagos Islands in the Pacific to Spanish colonial cities in the Andes to Indian villages on the Amazon, an estimated five million Ecuadoreans cast ballots in the voting, which took place peacefully, a reflection of Ecuador's reputation as an island of tranquillity between two violence-wracked neighbors, Colombia to the North and Peru to the South. Long known as the world's largest producer of bananas, this nation in recent years has become a favored destination for American visitors -- tourists, Peace Corps volunteers, and Spanish-language students. In a reverse flow, as many as 500,000 Ecuadoreans, or 5 percent of the population, now live in the United States.
 
Long Ties to U.S.
 Close ties to the United States will undoubtedly tighten on Aug. 10 with the expected inauguration of what one American here called the "Ivy League Ticket."
Mr. Duran Bellen was born in Boston, where his father was an Ecuadorean businessman. He attended American schools, and then graduated from Columbia University with a degree in architecture. His vice-presidential running mate, Alberto Dahik, did postgraduate studies at Princeton University after receiving a degree in economics from Ontario University in Canada. If its victory is confirmed, the new team is expected to push Ecuador toward a free market, now the mainstream of economic policy in Latin America.
To reduce inflation, which has averaged 50 percent a year since 1989, Mr. Duran Bellen proposed reducing taxes on imports and cutting the Government deficit by selling money-losing state companies.
With Ecuador's proven oil reserves slipping, he has called for cutting bureaucratic red tape that hampers exploration and production work by foreign oil companies. This small nation depends on oil exports for about half of its foreign exchange and tax income.
To restore foreign credit flows, he advocates speedy negotiations over repaying Ecuador's $5.7 billion debt to foreign commercial banks. For the last three years, talks have dragged on inconclusively in New York.
In the first round of voting, voters soundly rejected the candidate of the Democratic Left Party of Ecuador's current President, Rodrigo Borja, who was constitutionally prohibited from a second term. Although Ecuador last year experienced one of the region's highest economic growth rates, 4.4 percent, the governing party candidate won only 8 percent of votes cast for 12 candidates. Voting is obligatory in Ecuador, but absenteeism may hit 32 percent, the highest level since the military gave up power here in 1979.
Mr. Nebot's candidacy suffers from Ecuador's strong regional splits. In the May voting, he won only one province outside his Pacific Coast stronghold. Following tradition, voters in the Andes and the Amazon voted overwhelmingly for the most prominent Indian candidate, Mr. Duran Bellen.
Wearing a silver-black business suit, the male uniform of the Indian elite, Mr. Duran Bellen has been a fixture on Ecuador's political scene since he became Public Works Minister in 1951.
During most of the 1960's, he worked in Washington for the Inter-American Development Bank. In oil boom years of the 1970's, he gained popularity by undertaking public works projects as Mayor of Quito, the capital. In 1979 and 1989, he made unsuccessful bids for the presidency. Last year, when his party, the Social Christian Party, chose the younger Mr. Nebot as candidate, the political veteran broke ranks and began his third presidential bid under a new electoral coalition, the United Republican Party.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 1, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of a transmission error, an article on July 6 about Ecuador's presidential election referred incorrectly to the winner, Sixto Duran Be llen. The writer called him an Andean leader, not Indian.

HEADLINE: INDUSTRIAL NATIONS FIGHTING DEADLOCK ON FARM SUBSIDIES

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MUNICH, Germany, July 6

 BODY:
Leaders of the world's seven major industrial democracies today made what they said was a last-ditch attempt to break a six-year-old deadlock and reach a world trade agreement that could reverse the global economic slowdown.
European officials said the leaders were nearer to resolving what has become an essentially French-American dispute over extensive European farm subsidies, which the United States wants to see cut back. But United States officials cautioned against expectations of a breakthrough. 
 The issue has been the main stumbling block to concluding the so-called Uruguay Round of trade talks, which began in 1986.
 
Better Than Nothing
 Confronted by what President Francois Mitterrand called "the morose state of the world economy," the world leaders appeared to recognize that there was little they could do right now to affect interest rates, high unemployment and budget deficits. A trade accord thus emerged as the leaders' best hope to save face before their increasingly disenchanted constituents.
The summit leaders also discussed the Balkans, and the United States said tonight that it would support the use of air and naval power to get humanitarian aid into Bosnia and Herzegovina by land or by sea if Serbian forces block the United Nations-supported airlift through Sarajevo airport. [Page A6.]
Progress was reported to have been made on the trade issue at a dinner Sunday evening, before the summit, between President Bush and President Mitterrand. Jean Musitelli, the French Presidential spokesman, said a "better understanding has now emerged."
 
Degrees of Optimism
 After further talks today between officials of the European Community and the United States, a senior British official said, "The differences are narrowing and they should be bridgeable." But other officials expressed a less hopeful view.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said the chances of an agreement remained "modest" and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said he did not foresee an accord "in the next three days." A European Community spokesman, Nico Wegter, stressed that no breakthrough had emerged.
The most contentious single point is a demand by Washington that the European Community cut the volume of its subsidized grain exports by 24 percent. France, by far the largest grain exporter of the 12 nations, has balked, and the European Community is offering a smaller cut over an extended period.
The United States argues that lower trade barriers would ease several economic problems at once. It would, for example, provide Eastern European countries with greater access to Western European markets for their own farm products, strengthening their fledgling capitalist economies.
Washington also sees more competitive farm trade as an incentive to other countries, especially in the developing world, to open up their own markets to goods and services sold by the United States, like financial services and telecommunications. A trade agreement could add at least $195 billion to world output and bolster faltering business confidence.
With the unemployment rate in the United States now at 7.8 percent and the rate in the European Community at 9.4 percent, many business executives in the United States, Japan and Europe have become impatient with the impasse over agriculture, which accounts for just 11 percent of the world's $4.3 trillion in annual trade. They argue that a breakthrough on trade offers the best hope for spurring economic growth and creating jobs.
 
U.S. Call to Action
 Echoing this view, President Bush, his popularity at home at a low ebb, promised that the three days of talks here would produce jobs for Americans. "Absolutely, it's a yes," he said, when asked about the prospect of more jobs, adding that economic expansion "means free trade."
Treasury Secretary Brady captured the sense of urgency by summing up a growing feeling here this way: "With all the talk, how come we don't get some action?"
A second, previously unscheduled meeting between Secretary of State James Baker and the European Community's chief trade negotiator, Frans Andriessen, was set for Tuesday.
While the trade talks continued, the leaders seemed ready to approve $1 billion in loans and credits to Russia through the International Monetary Fund and to consider postponing Russia's debt payments, after an agreement Sunday between the I.M.F. and the Russian Government. The $1 billion would represent the start of a proposed $24 billion Western aid program.
 
Yes -- and No -- to Yeltsin
 In a further show of goodwill toward Russia, the leaders agreed to allow President Boris N. Yeltsin to attend their dinner Tuesday evening after he announced that he was arriving a day earlier than expected. But French, German and Japanese officials insisted that a proposal by President Bush to admit Russia permanently to the summit participants' group, known as the Group of Seven, was premature.
Statements by participants reflected their unhappiness with the projected growth this year of a modest 1.8 percent, following a paltry eight-tenths of 1 percent last year. All of them deplored the slowdown and the accompanying surge in unemployment.
"The emphasis on growth is now unanimous," said Mr. Brady.
But in another indication of the difficulties of doing something about the problem, Germany showed no sign of lowering its high interest rates, which Bonn says are aimed at curbing the inflationary pressure stemming from the cost of unification. In addition, Japanese officials said they were already doing all they could to stimulate their sagging economy through proposed fiscal measures.
 
The Rising Yen
 In one concession, however, Yuichi Ezawa, the director general of the International Finance Bureau at the Ministry of Finance, said Tokyo was pleased by the recent surge in the value of the yen and would not be displeased if the trend continued. The yen has been hovering at about 125 to the dollar, about 4 percent stronger than three months ago.
Economists say that a stronger yen, which makes foreign products less expensive to Japanese consumers, should attract imports, helping to alleviate the country's rapidly rising trade surplus, which could reach $135 billion this year.
Mr. Ezawa added that Tokyo did not expect the trade surplus to increase after this year.
He expressed Japan's continuing reservations on expanding its assistance to Russia while a territorial dispute continues over a group of islands in the Kurile chain north of Japan, which were seized by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II. But in general, the summit leaders appeared intent on helping Russia as much as possible.
On the question of setting up an emergency $700 million aid fund to overhaul or close down 57 Soviet-built nuclear reactors in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, French officials said there was unanimity on the urgency of taking rapid action. But it remained unclear how this would be organized.
France argued that the seven countries should set up a joint fund administered by the Bank for Reconstruction and Development. But the United States and Japan argued in favor of bilateral programs, and it appeared this approach would be preferred.

HEADLINE: Lives of Unexpected Poverty In Center of a Land of Plenty

SERIES: Rethinking Welfare -- Third of six articles.

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa

 BODY:
This city of 25,000 sits amid cornfields and factories in the center of a state that has been riding out the recession with one of the lowest unemployment levels in the country. Yet around 2,000 poor people here are getting help of some kind from the welfare system, from vouchers to heat a house to a regular welfare check.
This is not the South Bronx or Appalachia, where poverty often is attributed to culture or behavior, to racism or reckless childbearing. 
 But Marshalltown shows with unusual clarity other powerful forces that make welfare and poverty hard to escape anywhere: the nation's proliferation of low-wage jobs and two decades of falling wages, especially for the least skilled, in terms of what they can buy.
 
Working, but Still Needy
 Diana Kuchenreuther, 34 years old, single, the mother of three children, has been working for two years and trying to get off the dole, but she is still desperately poor. Her home is an apartment in a big rundown house in a working-class neighborhood. Her entrance is on the side, over a concrete slab cluttered with two wobbly kitchen chairs and the jetsam of children.
Inside, the drain of the sink in the one bathroom hasn't worked for a couple of years, and the toilet leaked until a friend patched a crack in the bowl. The old carpet on the staircase is foul and torn. The upstairs ceiling leaks in the rain. The place has two bedrooms, one for Ms. Kuchenreuther, Phillip, 9, and Aimmee, 7, the other for Lucinda, 13. The rent is $260 a month.
 
Most Outside Cities
 Although dependence on welfare is concentrated in inner cities, a majority of recipients live in suburbs, small towns like this one and rural areas around the country. And although black and Hispanic people receive welfare out of proportion to their numbers, more white people, including Ms. Kuchenreuther, spend time on it than members of any other group.
Some common patterns of welfare are evident here. Ninety-one percent of the Marshall County households that receive Aid to Families with Dependent Children are headed by women, many of them victims of abusive or runaway men. Forty percent of the women on welfare in Iowa had their first children as teenagers, and 16 percent dropped out of high school.
But no one can blame racism for poverty here. Ninety-eight percent of the 38,000 people of Marshall County, of which Marshalltown is the seat, are white, as are nearly all the families on welfare.
In big cities and the rural South, welfare and poverty might feed on themselves in spreading through neighborhoods. Here, poverty stays indoors. Marshalltown is not rich, but it is barren of slums, and the poor live next to the middle class. The crime and drug problems of the inner cities are, by comparison, insignificant here.
Being on welfare in Marshalltown seems less the hassle it can be in big cities. From the center of downtown, people can walk to the various welfare offices and complete their business in an hour or two. A sign at the reception desk of the human services office tells clients to complain if they wait more than 15 minutes.
 
Feeling the Stigma of Welfare
 But there is also less room to hide. Case workers keep close tabs on their clients, and with more jobs available than in big urban centers, they go to some length to prod them to work. People on welfare here say they also contend with the stigma of dependence in the asides of their neighbors and in the glances of shoppers in the supermarket checkout line when they pay with food stamps.
Ms. Kuchenreuther and other people interviewed are at various stages of the struggle with poverty, welfare and the low-wage economy. She is paid $4.80 an hour as a nurse's aide. She often works up to four hours of overtime a day and earns as much as $350 a week. She no longer receives a cash welfare grant, but she remains eligible for $177 a month in food stamps, and she is in line for a Government-subsidized house that should cost her no more than she pays now.
Ms. Kuchenreuther said she loves working and caring for the elderly. But she is trapped by her wages. "People say, 'Why don't you move out of this house?' " she said. "I can't afford to."
She said she wants to become a registered nurse, which would pay $12 an hour. But that means a couple of years of full-time schooling, giving up her work and going back to living almost entirely on welfare.
The attitudes of Ms. Kuchenreuther and other welfare recipients interviewed here run from defiant and confident to defeated and lost. Two are aiming for well-paid jobs that would free them from welfare. The prospects for the others are less certain.
 
Christine Anderson
A Temporary Tool To Earn a Degree
 For Christine Anderson, 25, the welfare system is not a permanent crutch, but a tool to escape the quicksand of a life of low-wage jobs. She wants to be a social worker.
With the aid of welfare and a Federal grant for college students from families with low incomes, Ms. Anderson has spent a year at Marshalltown Community College working toward a two-year associate's degree. With high grades so far, she hopes to keep getting grants and subsidies and eventually earn a master's degree in social work, which could lead to a job paying enough to support herself and her daughter, Burgundy.
Ms. Anderson, who was born in Wisconsin, moved in with her father in Des Moines at 11 after her parents divorced. At 13 she was sent to her father's parents in South Dakota, who sent her to a Seventh-day Adventist boarding school near Bismarck, S.D. She was valedictorian of a class of 17.
 
'An Irresponsible Thing'
 Lacking money for college, she became a hostess in a restaurant and took up with a waiter. "I did an irresponsible thing," she said. "I got pregnant." She said the waiter fled to Colorado. She took a job at another restaurant in Lincoln, Neb., had her baby, enrolled at the University of Nebraska and lasted a month. "I didn't know about welfare," she said. "I was trying to work, go to college, pay a baby sitter and breast-feed my baby."
She went to Topeka, Kan., and found a job as a receptionist with an engineering firm. In three years, she was making $7.50 an hour. But fighting bulimia, a severe eating disorder, she moved to Marshalltown to be closer to her mother and in 1989 enrolled in the welfare system.
The system has helped her take control of her life, she said. Her apartment is bright and clean. In her living room, she has 12 potted plants, her 6-year-old daughter's toys tucked in corners and school drawings on the wall. "I do not present myself as poor white trash," she said.
 
No Telephone, No Sofa
 But there are many things Ms. Anderson does not have, from a corkscrew to a sofa. She does without a telephone. She changes the oil in her car herself. If short of cash for gas, she gets it with food stamps: if the change due on a food stamp purchase is less than $1, merchants pay in money, so Ms. Anderson goes from store to store buying 5-cent mints, accumulating enough coins to buy gas.
She feels the stigma of being on welfare -- she receives $361 in A.F.D.C. payments a month, $118 in food stamps, a subsidy of $199 on her monthly rent of $303, and Medicaid. When she prepares to pay in the supermarket, she keeps the food stamp book in her purse as she tears out the coupons.
"Someone on my softball team was bitching because I was too tan," she said. " 'Oh, I forgot, Christine, you don't have a real life,' she said. That was someone who got a free car when she got married and gets free rent from living with her in-laws."
She is irked that she lets it get to her. She worked for more than four years and paid taxes. "I don't feel guilty about taking your money," she said. "I'm not taking your money. I'm taking my own."
 
JoAnn Earnest
A Refuge In Bad Times
 JoAnn Earnest, 37, and Roger Bunting, 31, together for two and a half years, say they want to be self-sufficient. He has just started a business, and she would like to start one. But they find the economy blowing against them and the welfare system a refuge.
"I'm tired of all this," Mr. Bunting said. As an able-bodied male without children, he is ineligible for welfare, but he benefits from the help Ms. Earnest gets.
"Nobody should get nothing for nothing," he said. "Russia was a welfare state since 1917, and look what it got them." But it is hard to get along without it, too. "In the winter," he said, "we don't make nothing. She's the one that makes everything happen then."
 
$50 for Child Care
 Most mornings, Ms. Earnest gets up at 5 o'clock. A woman who works in a meat-packing plant brings in her mildly retarded 6-year-old son. Ms. Earnest watches the boy for $50 a week, income she reports to the authorities. The boy curls up with his blanket on the living room rug, and Ms. Earnest goes back to bed for an hour or so. Then she gets up and puts on one of her three pairs of pants.
"I could use some more pants," she says. Her shoes are one of two pairs she wears. She has another pair she doesn't use, high heels that she bought on sale for $5.
She awakens Brandy, her 3-year-old daughter by another man, and then gets up Mr. Bunting if he has any work to do. Since quitting a job making pallets that paid the state's minimum wage of $4.65 an hour, Mr. Bunting has invested in three dump trucks for less than $2,000 to start a business.
He runs advertisements in a local paper. One says, "Hauling and Odd Jobs." The other says, "Black Dirt." The black dirt, good for gardens, comes from the 35-acre back yard. "Want to see a rural ghetto?" he said, gesturing out a back window. Mounds of metallic debris and vehicles parts obscure the view of the property, which is owned by Mr. Bunting's father.
Mr. Bunting said that one month recently he earned four times what he could earn from the minimum wage. But in June, he said, he made nothing at all. In times like that, Ms. Earnest is the sole source of income. Besides her pay from watching the boy, she and Brandy are allotted $200 a month in food stamps and $357 a month in A.F.D.C.
The Mid-Iowa Community Action Program, a service for the poor that is financed in part by the Federal Government, provides about $40 a month in food coupons for Brandy under the Federal Women's, Infants and Children program and vouchers for part of the heating bill. It also insulated the house.
 
Not Afraid to Work
 Brandy turned three on June 18, a threshold age for the youngest child of parents on welfare in Iowa. At that point, parents are beckoned to the state's job service for counseling and possible placement. If they do not show up, they can lose all but the food stamps and A.D.F.C. that their children need.
Ms. Earnest said she is not afraid to work. Earlier, while rearing three other children -- daughters 18 and 19, and a son, 21 -- she worked in nursing home as a housekeeper, in a garment factory and in a woodworking shop. All the jobs paid less than $5 an hour, but living was easier then.
She had a husband who was a machine operator in a factory. But he went to jail in 1983 for burglary, and she went on welfare for three years. They are separated now and he is somewhere in in South Dakota. She said she went back on welfare a few months before Brandy was born because her doctor told her the varnish and paint fumes in the wood shop could endanger her pregnancy.
She wants a better job than before, running a day care business or another skilled job. But she could face a long haul. She stopped school in the ninth grade, and before training for a well-paid job, she would have to get the equivalent of a high school diploma.
 
Yvette Anderson
Fleeing a Spouse, Finding Welfare

After three years on welfare, Yvette Anderson, 33, is a year from vaulting out of the system to a much improved standard of living. A nurse's aide for 10 years before she had children -- daughters aged 3 and 2 by her former husband and a 2-month-old son by the man she sees now -- she set out to become a registered nurse. Next May she expects to complete her training.
Ms. Anderson, who is not related to Christine Anderson, can then expect to earn the $12 an hour that nursing here pays to start. She would also collect the $329 a month that her former husband is paying in child support. For now, the state keeps all but $50 to offset the $272 a month she receives in food stamps and $426 in A.F.D.C. In all, she would receive about $29,400 a year, about $1,000 above the median income for a family of four in Iowa and well above the poverty line.
Ms. Anderson said leaving her heavy-drinking husband put her on welfare. "I was five months pregnant. I was scared to death of him. He'd say, 'If you don't shut your mouth, you're going to find yourself picking yourself up off the floor.' " She said she felt worthless then.
She is the eldest of seven children. She said her mother, now married to her fifth husband, was on welfare more often than not. She said she would not repeat the pattern. "I had no choice. I could live with an alcoholic or get out."
She puts the stigma of welfare out of her mind. "I don't care what people think. And if I have a temporary setback and I have to use the system, that's my right, as a previous taxpayer and a future taxpayer."
 
Glenda Schmidt
Shaky Prospects, Uncertain Pay

Glenda Schmidt, 39, did the right things to get off welfare, getting trained for a job and taking a one as a nurse's aide. But hers is not only a low-wage job. Like many of the economy's newer jobs, it is part time and irregular. She never really knows when she will she will be beckoned to work.
Mrs. Schmidt fits one stereotype of women on welfare but not another. She has five children, ages 9 to 23, which has qualified her for A.F.D.C. and food stamps on and off, depending on her husband's success with his work. Under a special program in Iowa, parents, married or not, can get A.F.D.C. if both are at home, one or both are unemployed, and at least one has been working.
On the other hand, she has had a long and stable marriage, after one that lasted seven months and produced her first child. Every day she carries a lunch to her her husband, Robert, who is 43, at the garage where he is trying to start a machinery repair business.
Mrs. Schmidt seems weary and worn sitting in front of a large television console in the living room of her small, rented brick house. She said Mr. Schmidt bought the television in better times. Because she works, her benefits were cut, and now her big concern is how she will pay for the family's medicine when the Medicaid coverage that came with welfare ends this fall.
She now pays only $1 for each prescription. She takes medicine for an inflamed stomach, for anxiety, for hypertension and migraine headaches. Until a couple of months ago, she was taking an antidepressant. The Schmidts' 9-year-old daughter needs medicine for a urinary problem that alone costs $180 a month. Mr. Schmidt, who has had three heart attacks, takes nitroglycerin. But he is a Vietnam War veteran, so he gets free medical care.
 
Anxiety of Uncertainty
 Mrs. Schmidt's anxiety arises in part from trying to wean herself from welfare. Several years ago she went to school to learn to be a nurse's aide. Last October, she landed a job at a local hospital that pays $5.77 an hour and about 50 cents more for night work. The work, however, is unpredictable, and she does not take the hospital's health benefits because they would cost her $53 a week, or half her pay many weeks.
In April, she earned $700 because she worked overtime filling in for a co-worker. One week in June, she earned $114. The next, she earned $108. The third she earned nothing. "They called me and said I didn't have to come in," she said. When that happens the welfare system helps out, but only after some paper-processing delays.
At the end of June the Schmidts had $300 in bills, for rent, light, garbage collection and telephone service, and nothing to pay them with. She still receives food stamps, $209 in June, but her $495 in A.F.D.C. was cut off the month after she started work.
She scrimps. "I don't buy lipstick," she said. "I don't buy fingernail polish. Now shampoo, that's a necessity. I get that for 89 cents." She drives a 1979 Plymouth Horizon to work, but it has problems with its gears, and the emergency brake is unreliable. The car is not insured.
Mr. Schmidt has been a truck driver for years, but needs less stressful work because of his health. But business for his new repair business is slow, and he may have to give it up.
"I guess I worry if I'm doing things right," Mrs. Schmidt said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Cuomo Turnabout: Now He Will Nominate Clinton

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 6

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who had insisted that he did not want and would not accept a speaking role at the Democratic National Convention, agreed today to place Gov. Bill Clinton's name in nomination next week at Madison Square Garden.
The New York Governor's decision to give the high-profile speech signified a mutually beneficial rapprochement between two men who have had more than their share of personal and political conflict in recent years. Coming one week before the opening of the convention, the announcement defused any possibility that the Cuomo-Clinton contretemps would become an unwelcome sideshow to Mr. Clinton's coronation.
 
Brown Mentions No. 2 Role
 
 Mr. Cuomo's change of heart -- he preferred to say he had simply deferred to the judgment of Mr. Clinton and the Democratic party chairman, Ronald H. Brown -- symbolized a marked improvement in relations between two men who are considered leading spokesmen for the Northern liberal and Southern moderate wings of their party. But it also raised the question of whether Mr. Cuomo might also relax his vow of uninterest in the Vice Presidency.
Mr. Cuomo made a point of saying at a news conference today that Mr. Brown had discussed the Vice Presidency with him by telephone over the weekend. Mr. Cuomo said the party chairman had not asked him to reconsider his position, but he declined to provide details about their conversation. He said Mr. Clinton did not mention the Vice Presidency in a telephone call on Sunday night.
Ginny Terzano, a spokeswoman for Mr. Brown, said "99.9 percent" of the conversation between Mr. Brown and Mr. Cuomo on Saturday concerned Mr. Cuomo's speaking at the convention. She said Mr. Brown mentioned as an aside that he would have liked Mr. Cuomo to serve as Mr. Clinton's running mate.
 
Clinton Says He Is 'Gratified'
 "He was not speaking for Mr. Clinton," she said.
There was no sign today from Little Rock, Ark., where Mr. Clinton spent most of the day, that the Arkansas Governor was considering Mr. Cuomo as a running mate. Aides to Mr. Clinton said he had not yet decided whom he would select. But Mr. Clinton is expected to announce his choice later this week or just before the start of the convention next Monday.
Mr. Clinton said as he left Little Rock for Washington late today that he was "gratified" that Mr. Cuomo would give the speech, adding that the New York Governor "would be very, very compassionate and forceful in making the case."
"I think he'll make a compelling case, not just for me, but for why we have to change," Mr. Clinton said.
Asked on his arrival tonight in Washington whether Mr. Cuomo's role as nominating speaker would rule out his being selected as a running mate, Mr. Clinton said he had not ruled out anyone.
Mr. Cuomo, by volunteering that Mr. Brown had spoken to him about the Vice Presidency and then declining to discuss the context, managed to insert himself back into the Vice-Presidential search from which he had withdrawn weeks ago.
What seemed certain today was that no formal offer of the Vice-Presidential spot had been made to Mr. Cuomo. But what was less clear was whether he would actually be interested in the job. The Governor has conceded in the past that speculation linking him to a Presidential campaign is good for his political stature at home and as a national party leader.
He said he considered the Vice Presidency a critical job. "I hope nobody thinks that a person who knows as much about government as I do and who feels the way that I do about government could say the Vice Presidency is not important enough, that you've got to be No. 1," Mr. Cuomo said. "It is a very important position. So please, it's not a disparagement of the office when I say it wouldn't work for me."
But he declined to predict whether he would accept the job, saying any discussion of the issue was "academic" because he did not expect to be asked. Mr. Cuomo told Clinton campaign aides several weeks ago that he did not wish to be considered.
 
Signals Are Mixed
 "I'm told the process is concluded in the sense that they have all the candidates they can handle," Mr. Cuomo said.
Mr. Cuomo has sent mixed signals about the Vice Presidency in the past. Last week, he said in an interview with The Associated Press that it would be "very, very inviting" to defend the New York record in a campaign against the Bush-Quayle ticket. "But, of course," he added, "it's no justification for running for Vice President."
A top adviser to Mr. Cuomo said he doubted that Mr. Cuomo, who harbors few warm memories of his four years as Lieutenant Governor to Gov. Hugh L. Carey, would be interested in the Vice Presidency.
"Why should he come along for the ride with someone else driving?" asked the adviser, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity. "I don't know how he would feel about playing second to this man."
As recently as Friday evening, Mr. Cuomo said in an interview, "I'm not going to be speaking at the convention."
He asserted then that he had had no discussions with Mr. Clinton or Mr. Brown about a speech and he denied reports that there had been talks between his staff, the Clinton staff and the Democratic National Committee staff.
Members of the Clinton and Cuomo staffs said today that such discussions had indeed taken place, with one Clinton aide saying there had been "a flurry of calls between lieutenants and lieutenants."
Officials in the Clinton campaign said they had also considered offering the speech to Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, who ran against Mr. Clinton for the Democratic nomination. They said Mr. Harkin had been approached about taking another speaking role, possibly to second Mr. Clinton's nomination.
Mr. Cuomo said today that he was persuaded over the weekend by Mr. Clinton and Mr. Brown, who was a student of Mr. Cuomo's at St. John's Law School.
The Governor said Mr. Brown argued that it would seem awkward for him to not speak at a hometown convention.
Mr. Cuomo said Mr. Brown suggested that not speaking might reinforce the perception of hostility between Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Clinton.
The Governor said he argued that important convention roles should be reserved for the party's rising stars.
"Ron Brown said in particular, 'That's very logical as usual, professor,' because he calls me professor, 'but I still think it would be good for the party if you spoke,' " Mr. Cuomo said. "Having heard his reasons, having given him mine, I still think mine were better, but not so overwhelmingly superior that I would not be able to defer to his desire that I speak."
Mr. Cuomo's decision creates the historical paradox that the man who enthralled the 1984 Democratic convention with his keynote address will now nominate the man who anesthetized the 1988 convention with his 33-minute nominating speech of Michael S. Dukakis.
Mr. Cuomo skyrocketed to political fame at the convention in San Francisco by contending that President Ronald Reagan's depiction of America as "a shining city on a hill" was actually a tale of two cities, including one "where the glitter doesn't show."
Mr. Clinton, by contrast, droned on in Atlanta for long past his allotted time and earned his greatest applause with a line that began, "In closing . . . "
 
Showcase for Cuomo
 For Mr. Cuomo, the scheduled 20-minute nominating speech will provide a new opportunity to showcase his oratorical skills and to cement his image as a national party leader. Network officials said today they did not know whether Mr. Cuomo's speech would be shown live as part of their reduced broadcasts of the convention. But several said they planned to at least show excerpts.
For Mr. Clinton, the New York Governor's willingness to nominate him represents an important bit of peacemaking. Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Clinton have long been at odds over the direction of the Democratic Party, with Mr. Clinton saying the party must veer from the liberal tradition represented by Mr. Cuomo.
Earlier this year, the conflict became personal when Gennifer Flowers, a singer, said she had had an affair with Mr. Clinton, and made public a tape recorded telephone conversation in which Mr. Clinton said Mr. Cuomo "acts like" a member of the Mafia.
Mr. Cuomo appeared on a nationally televised talk show to question whether Mr. Clinton might harbor prejudice against all minorities.
In recent weeks, however, both sides have tried to mend fences. Mr. Cuomo complimented Mr. Clinton's economic plan enthusiastically and praised his acceptance of a Cuomo idea to form a united front with Democratic leaders in Congress. Mr. Clinton, when asked on an MTV talk show whom he would like to appoint to the Supreme Court, mentioned only Mr. Cuomo.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 2683 words

HEADLINE: CUNY's Crossroads -- A special report.;
Leader Presses Changes at CUNY, But Some See Threat to Its Mission

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD with SAMUEL WEISS

 BODY:
Two years into her tenure as chancellor of the City University of New York, Dr. W. Ann Reynolds has set off on an ambitious remaking of the nation's largest urban university, raising questions that go to the heart of CUNY's mission to make a high-quality education accessible even to poor and minority students.
Grappling with budgetary problems and an anemic graduation rate, Dr. Reynolds has said she intends to tighten CUNY's academic standards, restructure the system by eliminating and consolidating departments and programs, build up its science and research areas and develop a broad partnership with the public school system to improve teacher training and student preparation. She described the plans in interviews, though many details have not yet been shared with the university at large.
 
'More Scholarly'
 
 "The challenge over the next few years is to make sure this university becomes even more effective, more scholarly, more supportive of its faculty, more supportive of its students," said Dr. Reynolds, who has developed a reputation as an active and sometimes abrasive administrator. "One of the saddest things that can happen in college is to repeat learning things that should have been absorbed at an earlier time."
She and her supporters -- including the trustees and many seasoned faculty members -- are convinced that this overhaul will fortify the quality of the university and ease its fiscal woes, without detracting from its avowed mission of providing seats in its classrooms for all who want to learn. But a number of faculty members and students fear that the effect of Dr. Reynolds's changes will be to exclude many poor and minority applicants.
 
Questions of Access
 "It's just going to be a closed door for anyone except those with money," said June Nash, distinguished professor of anthropology at City College and a faculty member for 20 years. "I think the chancellor's vision is a smaller, middle-class university."
On the other hand, James P. Murphy, chairman of CUNY's trustees, called her "a persistent and very effective crisis manager" who, he said, has presented "a vision for the university over the next decade."
Tensions between Dr. Reynolds and some staff members have been building since her arrival. In May, more than 100 faculty and staff members at City College who were disturbed about tougher academic standards sent a blunt open letter to Dr. Reynolds denouncing what they termed her failure to preserve access to the university for minorities and the poor.
At the recent commencement exercises at Brooklyn College, some 150 students and faculty stood up and turned their backs on Dr. Reynolds when she rose to speak.
The rift over Dr. Reynolds's blueprint comes at a time when CUNY finds itself shadowed by a string of controversies and personnel changes. Just two weeks ago, Dr. Bernard W. Harleston announced his resignation as president of City College, the founding pillar of the 21-branch university. Last March, the storm over Dr. Leonard Jeffries Jr. finally abated when he was removed as chairman of the black studies department at City College because of his racially charged remarks.
In December, nine young people were trampled to death at a celebrity basketball game at City College, an incident that raised questions about administrative oversight of campus functions. Last year, swarms of outraged students seized college buildings in a protest over the latest tuition increases.
 
Setting Standards
 But foremost among the issues polarizing the university now is the sweeping question of what sort of place CUNY is likely to become, a question as traumatic as any it has faced since 1976. In that year, New York City's fiscal crisis forced the system to shut down for two weeks and led it to charge tuition for the first time.
Since the founding of City College in 1847, the institution has been viewed as the surest path to a career for New York's immigrants and disadvantaged, and out of CUNY's huge pool of graduates have come 11 Nobel Prize winners and more corporate executives than have emerged from any other university in the country.
Arguments over standards are not new. By the late 1960's, competition for admission had turned CUNY into one of the most selective universities in the country. After minority groups complained that the university's purposes were being subverted, CUNY adopted an open admissions policy in 1970 and embarked on a vast construction program. The new policy, which guaranteed entrance to any city high school graduate, led to the admission of thousands of under-prepared students and set off a bitter debate.
Tension over the university's character has intensified since April, when the trustees approved Dr. Reynolds's plan for stiffer educational requirements over the next decade. Known as the College Preparatory Initiative, the plan will require incoming students to have 16 college preparatory courses, or else take additional classes at CUNY.
 
'Academic Mission'
 Many faculty members and trustees, who have been distressed by what they see as an erosion in standards caused by open admissions, are staunch advocates of Dr. Reynolds, and speak of her in almost rapturous tones. "I think Chancellor Reynolds's great contribution has been to refocus attention on the academic mission of the university," said Dr. Robert Picken, chairman of the University Faculty Senate. "Right now the university is already a revolving door, and the retention rate for poorly prepared students is just catastrophic."
But there is widespread grumbling from many other faculty members and students convinced that CUNY's time-honored role is being perverted.
"I don't think she's shown a tremendous amount of sensitivity to the issue of access, and I think she's motivated by a desire to reduce the size of the colleges," said Dr. Robert Cherry, an economics professor who participated in the commencement protest.
Leith Mullings, a professor of anthropology in the City University Graduate Center, said she fears that CUNY will no longer "serve the population that it has the mission to serve: those who cannot afford an elite education."
 
Finances
Increasing Tuition And Cutting Jobs
 Professor Mullings's disillusionment, like that of many others, is grounded in personal history. She attended CUNY when it was free, as did her parents and four siblings. Her father, she said, held two jobs and went to Baruch College at night while raising five children. "He would not have had an extra $1,000 for tuition," she said.
Now three rounds of increases in the last two years have nearly doubled tuition, after it had remained stable for eight years. Incoming freshmen will pay $2,450 (compared with $16,500 at Columbia, $10,240 at Long Island University and $3,114 at Rutgers).
The increases are hardly surprising; since the 1989 academic year, state and city financing for CUNY has been cut by more than $200 million a year, trimming its budget to $1.2 billion. As a result, as many as 600 CUNY faculty and staff members, out of 13,700, are expected to be laid off in the fiscal year that began last week.
The system has already been deeply scarred by budget cuts. Students complain that they have been delayed in graduating because classes have been eliminated and they have to wait to fulfill their requirements. Certain courses are so crowded that some students have to sit on the floor.
 
Reputation for Toughness
 Professors say that when their department copying machines run out of toner, they may have to wait several months before there is money for fresh supplies. For lack of janitors, some faculty members are swabbing the floors of their own laboratories. Chalk can be hard to come by. Sports programs, counseling and libraries have all suffered.
Even in rosier circumstances, being chancellor of CUNY is probably one of the toughest jobs in higher education. It is a sprawling hodgepodge of 21 branches with some 200,000 students, the bulk of them poor and working-class people of every imaginable minority group. And it largely serves graduates of a public school system that has inadequately groomed many of them for college.
The 54-year-old Dr. Reynolds, however, has a reputation for brittle, unbridled toughness, in contrast to Dr. Joseph S. Murphy, her less active and more genial predecessor.
She came to CUNY two years ago from California State University, where she attracted her share of criticism. In fact, she was forced to resign as chancellor in a dispute over hefty pay increases that she engineered for herself and top university officials. Those who have worked under her say she does not favor a light touch.
 
Confidence in Plans
 In 1987, she was accused by some associates of verbally brutalizing a president of one of the Cal State colleges; the president died of a heart attack two weeks after she told him to resign. Chancellor Reynolds has denied those accusations. In her two years at CUNY, she has gone through six secretaries. Many faculty members say she has not been effective in communicating her plans or vision for the university.
A self-described insomniac who works at a fiendish pace, Dr. Reynolds speaks of her initiatives with sweeping confidence. In an interview, she dismissed the notion that in imposing tougher admissions standards she wanted to shrink the university and cut off minority students. "National studies have shown a strengthening of college preparation in high school will aid our minority students the most, and ultimately our retention and graduation rates," she said. "I'm not looking to reduce enrollment, I'm looking to increase it."
What bothers her, she said, is the fact that more than half of CUNY students fail to graduate within nine years. A mere 15 percent achieve a bachelor's degree in four years. She wants CUNY to stop spending so much of its resources on remedial education for ill-prepared high school graduates.
 
Programs
Strengthening And Streamlining
 CUNY's budget problems, Dr. Reynolds said, mean substantial changes will be necessary. In March, she appointed an advisory committee to explore ways to restructure CUNY by identifying the most important programs and activities to preserve and nurture. It is due to report in November.
Dr. Reynolds said she opposed closing any of the CUNY colleges, but she expects programs and departments will be eliminated. Officials familiar with the committee's work said a central issue being debated is whether to try to rid the system of duplication.
Until now, the various CUNY colleges have often offered identical programs, even when the schools are situated near each other. For instance, Baruch College and Hunter College, both in Manhattan, have large modern-language departments. Why not, the committee is wondering, shut down a program at one college and have students in that course travel to the other institution?
The task force is also looking at shifting programs from one college to another where there is a better educational fit. As a glimpse of what might happen, CUNY recently moved a technology program from City College to New York City Technical College.
Such steps, CUNY officials argue, will not only save money, but will make CUNY a more unified system and will sharpen the focus of the individual CUNY branches.
 
Science Programs
 On another front, Dr. Reynolds said she expected to outline plans soon to strengthen CUNY in its generally weak fields of science, engineering and technology. She is also planning new programs in areas like health sciences, though she acknowledges that all such plans could be delayed by a lack of money.
At the same time, she has laid the groundwork for a broad new partnership with the city's Board of Education.
CUNY and the city's public school system operate in a curious symbiosis. The university trains roughly 80 percent of the city's public school teachers; those teachers go on to educate the bulk of the students who replenish the CUNY student body. Each year, half of the graduates of the city's high schools enroll at CUNY.
Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez said that Dr. Reynolds's plans to raise standards mesh perfectly with his own to improve the high schools. "In our first meeting, Chancellor Reynolds told me she wanted to get the university out of the remediation business, and I agree," he said. "We are the ones in the remediation business, and I have to improve what it is we do."
 
Broad Collaboration
 Dr. Reynolds and Mr. Fernandez intend to collaborate on an even broader scale. In March, CUNY and the Board of Education opened a pilot Family College at Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn. It enrolled 18 parents eligible for public assistance in college courses while their prekindergarten children attended a nearby public school. Two more similar schools are scheduled to open in the coming academic year, and two more next year.
One of the biggest questions is whether Mr. Fernandez can uphold his end of the bargain and improve the public schools at a time when resources are so scarce. CUNY is counting on it. Last week, it began a promotional blitz intended to acquaint prospective students and parents with the college preparatory plan. Brochures prodding them to take the necessary courses were distributed to 87,000 students finishing eighth grade and mailed to their parents.
"New York is changing," Dr. Reynolds said, "and the university has to stay ahead of where the city is going if we're to be a critical factor in its future and the future of our students."
 
Access
Will Everyone Still Have a Place?
 The trustees have pledged a continued commitment to open admissions, and have called for Dr. Reynolds to issue a report each year on the impact of the new standards.
What many CUNY faculty members fear, however, is that students will not be able to find the required courses in high school and thus the college preparatory plan, coupled with rising tuition, will effectively bar entrance for many poor and minority students.
"It makes me very sad," said Carol Laderman, chairman of the anthropology department at City College. "I have many students living on the edge of poverty, who have to work, have to raise children, but are quite brilliant. I feel bad that the university is shutting out the students who need it the most."
Ronald Quartimon, the student president at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, said that while Dr. Reynolds had been admirably active, students were deeply suspicious that she was working to make CUNY an "institution for white, middle-class students."
 
'Close to the Bone'
 Almost every faculty member can recount a story about a student who must live from dollar to dollar. "I had one student who needed an anthropology course and we weren't offering it uptown," said Dr. Laderman. "So I said, 'Why don't you take it downtown at our Center for Worker Education?' And he said he couldn't do it, because he couldn't afford the extra subway fare to go there several times a week. I don't think people realize how close to the bone so many of our students are."
On the other hand, the Rev. Calvin O. Pressley, a CUNY trustee who avidly supports Dr. Reynolds, contends that CUNY will always have sizable minority representation, because of the makeup of the graduates of the public schools. "Given the nature of the city, we would have to become a very small university to exclude large numbers of minority students," he said.
Nevertheless, Dr. Reynolds acknowledged that money lies at the heart of the matter. She agreed that if financing does not improve over the next couple of years, then CUNY will have to consider curtailing enrollment.
Dr. Sheldon Weinbaum, distinguished professor of mechanical engineering at City College and a supporter of Dr. Reynolds, said: "If the Governor and the Legislature fund it the way a first-rate university should be, then CUNY will be a first-rate institution. If they don't, there is not anything that a Reynolds or anyone else can do about it."
