HEADLINE: Chicago Mayor Threatening to Drop Airport Plan

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 6

 BODY:
Plans to build a third Chicago airport, on the city's southeast side, have been jeopardized by Mayor Richard M. Daley's angry reaction to the State Legislature's failure to approve key legislation for the project.
Mayor Daley said he would now drop his two-year crusade for the airport, but his announcement is widely viewed as a political maneuver to put pressure on the Legislature to approve the airport at Lake Calumet, the Mayor's favored site, on the southeast side. 
 "Most people don't believe him," said Gary Mack, a spokesman for Gov. Jim Edgar, who supports building the airport at Lake Calumet. "We simply can't believe that a project as big and important as that could be thrown away that cavalierly by the Mayor."
The Mayor has said construction and operation of the airport would create at least 200,000 jobs and generate $12 billion to $15 billion for the regional economy.
 
An Emotional Response
 The announcement by Mr. Daley, a Democrat, came during an emotional news conference last week after Mr. Edgar, a Republican, was unable to marshal enough votes in the State Senate for a regional airport authority to oversee airport construction..
The bill, which had passed the State House, stalled in the Senate when legislators from the northwestern Chicago suburbs, most of them Republican, refused to vote for it without assurances that no new runways would be built at O'Hare International Airport, the nation's busiest airport.
Residents in the northwestern suburbs near O'Hare have long complained about the noise caused by the 800,000 yearly flights there. While those residents support the idea of a third airport, they want to forestall any expansion at O'Hare during the 20 years it is expected to take to get a Lake Calumet airport ready for operation.
The Governor, enmeshed in state budget negotiations, told Mr. Daley that the vote on the airport authority would have to wait until after the November general election.
Mr. Daley, saying he did not believe that the bill would garner the necessary votes this fall, then told reporters he would not have Chicago's delegation reintroduce the measure and would no longer push for a new airport.
 
Seeking Regional Consensus
 The airport's estimated cost of $10.8 billion was to be partly financed by user fees at O'Hare and Chicago's other airport, Midway, which is near downtown. But a spokesman for Mr. Daley said that Chicago would also need substantial Federal money and that Federal support would depend on a regional agreement on the site.
"Chicago can't go it on its own," the spokesman, Billy Davis, said today. "It would be difficult to get that kind of Federal funding without a regional consensus."
Mr. Daley has not decided whether he will support the construction of an airport outside Chicago. He told reporters last week that he would use the estimated $90 million raised by airport user fees annually at O'Hare and Midway Airports to improve those sites.
After Mr. Daley's announcement, Gov. Evan Bayh of Indiana said he would consider pushing for Federal funding to expand the airport at Gary, just across the state line from Chicago. But William Moreau, a special counsel for Mr. Bayh and a member of the airport site-selection committee, said the Governor was waiting to see "if Mayor Daley follows through on his threat."

HEADLINE: As New Orleans Plans Huge Casino, Some See Promise, Others a Threat

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, July 1

 BODY:
Arms flailing, expletives flying, Andy Antippas and Francois Lucet are shouting out their views on the issue obsessing New Orleans: will the world's largest gambling casino save this city or will it destroy it?
"You idiot," growled Mr. Lucet, a French architect who often does business here and who supports the proposal to build a giant casino near the Mississippi River. "This is the same unbelievable, negative nonsense you always have here where the clan in control opposes anything new." 
 "You stupid alien, this is the World's Fair only worse," Mr. Antippas, owner of the French Quarter art gallery where the exchange took place, hollered back, referring to the 1984 New Orleans World's Fair, which lost $120 million. "That was a disease that lasted six months. This is a plague that won't go away."
The emotions are commensurate with the stakes in a debate that cuts to the heart of the combination of vaporous, sensual charm and persistent, crushing poverty that makes New Orleans one of the nation's most alluring cities and perhaps one of its most imperiled.
In a city where the promise of easy money is as much a part of the fabric of life as the steamy summer heat, nothing in years has seemed so tantalizing and so horrific as the plan rammed through the Louisiana Legislature last month to make New Orleans the nation's latest city to offer casino gambling.
 
Savior or Satan?
 To supporters, the casino offers the promise of 14,000 jobs and at least $500 million in investment in a city that has never recovered from the collapse of the oil industry in the 1980's. To critics, it is a pact with the devil that will debase the adjacent French Quarter and bring increased crime and corruption for the promise of low-paying jobs that may not last if the casino fails.
What unites both sides is a fear that New Orleans, which was the South's most culturally sophisticated economically important city when Dallas and Atlanta were prairie and forest, may be running out of options to save itself.
"We're like a 60-year-old Southern dowager that's fallen on evil times," said Patrick Taylor, a New Orleans oilman and casino opponent. "It's difficult to keep up appearances, so she sells herself without realizing what her blessings are."
Last month the Legislature and Gov. Edwin W. Edwards pushed through a bill that would allow the construction of a casino on the site of the little-used, city-owned Rivergate convention center downtown.
Long a goal of Mr. Edwards, the casino would be built by a private operator, leased by the city and overseen by a commission appointed by the Governor. The state will get 18.5 percent of casino revenues, or $100 million, whichever is greater, from the casino operator. The city will get the rent for the Rivergate property. Eight companies have submitted proposals costing $187 million to $458 million for casinos ranging from 120,000 square feet to 250,000 square feet. The biggest casinos in Atlantic City and Las Vegas, Nev., are about 120,000 square feet.
A winner will be selected in November, a temporary casino could open as early as March and the permanent casino may open by the end of 1993.
 
Banking in Tourism
 To supporters like Mayor Sidney Barthelemy, the casino is a natural, a huge infusion of tourist-oriented investment . He predicts that the casino will increase tourism to 13 million or 14 million visitors from 8 million now, provide a surge of related downtown development that could mean a billion dollars of investment in the city and bring an immediate payoff of as much as $100 million in leasing fees.
"Nothing else comes close to what this could do for New Orleans," Mr. Barthelemy said. "For a city that has been struggling, that basically had an industry, oil, as its major industry that was collapsing, we had to do something to create jobs."
In fact, the stakes are so high for New Orleans because the city has sunk so low. From 1980 to 1990 the percentage of the city's population living in poverty grew to 31.6 percent from 26.4 percent, making it the nation's third-poorest city, behind Laredo, Tex., and Detroit. More than 10 percent of the population lives in bleak public housing units, and one in six of all housing units, 37,000 units, are now vacant.
"This city has the potential of becoming the Newark of the South," said James C. Brandt, executive director of the Bureau of Governmental Research, a business-oriented research organization based in New Orleans.
But Mr. Brandt is quick to add that the city also has extraordinary potential to prosper, and that gambling is not the way to do it. Mr. Brandt said that the image of a casino town would scare off corporate investment and that the casinos would suck resources from the rest of the city, killing off small businesses and getting a disproportionate share of public investment.
Critics are quick to point to Atlantic City, where few of the rosy projections for gambling came true and where the city has continued to deteriorate despite gamblers flocking to the casinos.
 
Reasons for Skepticism
 "The city is an economic basket case," said Arnold Hirsch, a historian at the University of New Orleans. "The casino is an attempt to bounce back all in one great leap. Whether it's a great leap forward or a leap into the abyss remains to be seen."
Most New Orleans legislators voted against the casino bill, which failed to provide the city with most of the provisions, including a statutory limit of one casino, a share of tax revenues and a seat on the commission board, that the city had sought.
"Edwin Edwards picked up New Orleans by its ankles and dangled it upside down until all the change fell out of its pockets," Mr. Hirsch said.
The casino process began with the prospect of one small European-style casino and ended with the promise of the biggest casino ever built. For good measure, there will soon be riverboat gambling and video poker to go with the state's lottery and horse racing, putting New Orleans on the verge of becoming the gambling capital of the South.
If Atlanta is the plucky and calculating Scarlett O'Hara, to many here the casino process showed New Orleans as Blanche DuBois, the faded belle in "A Streetcar Named Desire," dependent on the kindness of strangers unlikely to deliver.
"There's nothing wrong with a one-horse economy if the horse is big enough," said Tim Ryan, a University of New Orleans economist. "We had a one-horse economy with oil that was big enough. With gambling, I think we're going to have a pony trying to pull a real big wagon."
On the streets of the French Quarter, everyone has an opinion.
To Paul Gros, preaching in the middle of Bourbon Street next to his five-foot-tall wooden cross equipped with an electric moving message sign, the casino is more decadence for a city drowning in sin.
"The Bible says Roman soldiers cast lots for Jesus' garments," he said, as passers-by headed toward Le Paree Orgy, a topless bar. "Lots are nothing but dice. There's nothing new under the sun."
To John Wooters, who moved to New Orleans from Denver three weeks ago when he heard the casino bill had passed, the casino plan is just what the city needs.
"I've worked in a lot of tourist cities, and this is something that's going to make a lot of money," said Mr. Wooters, as he sold hot dogs at the corner of Bourbon and Bienville.
The biggest reservations can be found behind the shuttered windows of French Quarter homes and in the sedate galleries of Royal Street, where people fear that a wave of real estate speculation will kill what is left of the authentic quarter.
Even in the low-income areas most in need of jobs there is little agreement. At the edge of the Iberville housing project downtown, Patrice Miles thinks the casino will detract from what makes New Orleans special, while Nolan Coleman supports the casino.
"It will mean jobs, man," he said, spearing candy wrappers on his job with the city's housing authority. "Life is a gamble. Why not give it a try?"
Carlos Marcello, the city's famous crime boss who has been linked in various theories to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, is old and infirm, and law-enforcement figures say there is little big-time organized crime in New Orleans these days. But many fear gambling would bring organized crime back in a big way.
"We're not equipped to handle major league crime," said Oliver Hauck, a Tulane University Law School professor.
On the other hand, homegrown corruption has a long history here, as does gambling, which dates back to the 18th century and flourished until the 1940's and 50's. Thus, even Mr. Antippas finally concludes that in the coming battle between the gumbo Mammon of New Orleans and the neon Mammon of Las Vegas, the home team will somehow win.
"In my heart of hearts, I know the city will overcome the casino," he said softly, his friendly shouting match with Mr. Lucet finally at an end. "I think they'll learn they can't be corrupt their way, they'll have to be corrupt our way -- a genial, go-with-the-flow New Orleans kind of corruption.
"We'll win. But I'm not sure at what cost."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
The auto industry reported strong sales for late June, propelled by consumers' "buying American." Detroit's Big Three gained market share against the Japanese, and G.M.'s Saturn division had a particularly strong month. June's seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for domestic cars was the best in 18 months. [Page D1.]
For millions of Americans looking for work -- and for the Presidential candidates -- June's surge in unemployment poses a big question: Is the economy's new weakness a blip or a dip? [D1.] 
 New Jersey's high credit rating was affirmed by Standard & Poor's, but the agency said the long-term outlook was poor. [B5.]
 
International
Leaders of the world's seven major industrial democracies began their meeting in Munich by making what they said was a last-ditch attempt to reach a world trade agreement that could reverse the global economic slowdown. [A1.]
Banking regulators from the United States and 11 other industrial countries agreed to tighten the supervision of international banking groups and their cross-border operations. The pact was a move to reduce the chances of a repeat of the B.C.C.I. scandal. [D1.]
Mexico sold the last of its 18 state-run banks, marking the end of a lucrative privatization program. [D2.]
 
Companies
Chair manufacturers are turning to ergonomists -- specialists in adapting machines to people -- to design seating that will help the millions who use computers daily avoid injuries. [D1.]
Cygnus Therapeutic Systems began shipping its nicotine patch to help smokers quit. It is the fourth supplier to enter the market, which had sales of more than $200 million in the first quarter. [D4.]
Digital will introduce a completely new line of powerful computers using its Alpha microprocessor and designed to provide customers with more performance for the dollar. [D4.]
Gap Inc., the red-hot retailer specializing in casual clothes, appears ready to put its brand name on another garment -- women's cotton panties. [D4.]
Ercros, Spain's largest chemical group, will file for bankruptcy after failing to refinance $1.5 billion in debt to creditors including Citibank and Chase Manhattan. [D4.]
After the Democrats and Republicans hold their conventions this summer, it will be time for the meeting of odorization experts, the people who make sure that natural gas has a bad smell. [D4.]
Lazard Freres assigned three investment bankers, including Felix G. Rohatyn, to help raise capital for the American unit of Olympia & York, the bankrupt Canadian developer. [D5.]
 
Markets
Wall Street reopened after a three-day holiday weekend with little fervor. The Dow gained 8.91 in slow trading. [D8.]
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher in the first trading after last week's interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. [D15.]
Soybean futures hit six-month lows after heavy rain fell in the Midwest. The plunge spilled over to wheat and corn futures. [D16.]
The dollar fell in light dealings, with traders awaiting announcements from the economic summit. Gold prices rose. [D16.]
 
Today's Columns
Companies are trying to keep retirees from buying assortments of prescription drugs that can interact in potentially harmful ways. Milt Freudenheim: Business and Health. [D2.]
Tax-free municipal bond funds have outperformed taxable bond funds over the last three months, even before computing the tax savings. Market Place. [D8.]
Abortion rights groups undertook a fervid advertising campaign to rally support in the wake of last week's Supreme Court decision on abortion. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D18.]

HEADLINE: U.S. Sales Of Vehicles Jump 23.9%

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT July 6

 BODY:
The nation's auto industry yesterday reported strong sales for late June, propelled by what executives said was rising consumer confidence and a stronger economy.
The news seemed to run counter to the gloomy economic picture painted by last week's report that the nation's unemployment rate had risen sharply in June. But auto executives said the cut in interest rates that followed the release of the jobless data would help the industry. 
 "With the recent reduction in short-term interest rates, we expect to see even stronger vehicle sales in the second half of the year," said James B. Fitzpatrick, vice president of marketing at General Motors.
 
More Are Buying American
 Analysts said a "Buy America" preference among consumers had helped Detroit's Big Three gain ground against Japanese competitors. G.M.'s Saturn division had a particularly strong month, and in June, the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate for North American-built cars was the best in 11 months.
Sales of vehicles built in North America -- which are considered domestically built -- rose a sharp 23.9 percent in the last 10 days of the month compared with the period a year earlier. Car sales rose 15 percent, to 244,473, and light-truck sales gained 40.7 percent, to 157,284.
The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate of North American-built cars for the period of June 21-30 was 7.5 million. For the month, the rate was 6.7 million, up from 6.3 million in May and the same as in June 1991. The monthly selling rate was the highest since July 1991.
For the entire month of June, sales of all cars and light trucks, which include mini-vans and sport-utility vehicles, surged 6.2 percent, to 1,268,954, from 1,149,021 last year. June car sales were up 2.5 percent, to 826,942, and light-truck sales rose 14 percent, to 442,012.
 
'Very Good News'
 "The latest 10 days are very good news, because it means that dealer inventories will be in good shape, and that bodes well for production schedules," said Harvey Heinbach, automotive analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York. "We haven't been able to say that in a while."
Sales of G.M.'s domestically produced cars rose 18.4 percent in late June, to 106,857, led by strong increases at all divisions except Chevrolet, which suffered a 3.5 percent decline. Sales of G.M.'s domestic light trucks rose 34.3 percent, to 57,527.
The Saturn division sold more than 20,000 cars in one month for the first time. At that rate, Saturn could be approaching capacity at its two-year-old plant in Spring Hill, Tenn.
"We had a tremendous Fourth of July weekend, and we don't have many Saturns in stock," said John B. T. Campbell 3d, who owns several dealerships in Southern California.
 
Ford's Taurus Excels
 The Ford Motor Company's car sales rose 30.7 percent in late June, to 61,952, and the company's light-truck sales rose 39.3 percent, to 51,834. Robert L. Rewey, vice president of sales operations, noted that the midsized Taurus, which was redesigned for 1992, had its best sales month since May 1989.
Ford injected a note of caution by saying unusually strong orders for cars from rental companies had inflated its results. Some rental companies were caught short of cars when airlines lowered fares and caused a surge of travelers, Ford said.
But Stephen Girsky, automotive analyst for Paine Webber in New York, said Ford's sales to rental fleets would help the company's profits because they reflected genuine demand caused by a greater volume of travelers rather than steep discounting.
General Motors said it had not experienced a similar phenomenon in its rental sales.
The Chrysler Corporation, which announces sales on a monthly basis only, said car sales for all of June declined 12.2 percent, to 54,255, while light-truck sales, led by its popular mini-van, rose 23.1 percent, to 101,438.
"Our total vehicle sales have climbed back almost to where they were two years ago, before the economic slump really set in," said Tom Pappert, vice president of sales.
 
Japanese Feel a Pinch
 Japanese auto makers were clearly feeling the effects of their recent price increases and the Big Three's gains in quality. The Toyota Motor Corporation's car sales for the month, including vehicles built in the United States and Japan, fell 5.6 percent, to 61,621. The Honda Motor Company posted an 8.7 percent drop in car sales for the month, to 77,287.
But the Nissan Motor Company's car sales rose 13.4 percent, to 45,479. Earl J. Hesterberg, vice president of the Nissan brand division, said car sales had been rising steadily since January. The division is about to introduce a midsized car, the Altima; a new mini-van, the Quest, has begun arriving at dealer showrooms.
Because light-truck sales have gained so much more than car sales -- and the Big Three are much stronger than the Japanese in light trucks -- Detroit has been able to score a significant gain in overall market share.
 
Big Three's Share: 71.8%
 Taking into account cars and light trucks, imported and domestic, the Big Three captured 71.8 percent of all sales in June, up from 69.7 percent of all sales in the month a year earlier. That left the Japanese auto makers with 22.7 percent of sales, including output from North American-based transplants, down from 24.5 percent a year earlier. Other importers, principally from Britain and Germany, sold 5.5 percent of all vehicles, down from 5.9 percent from last year.
Mr. Campbell, the California dealer, said: "People are buying American, especially here in Orange County, where the import penetration is usually 60 percent. What that means is, people are giving American cars a look."

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Plans Peacekeepers for Moldova

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 6

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin said today that Russia and Ukraine might join Romania and Bulgaria in a peacekeeping force to end the civil war in Moldova.
Mr. Yeltsin made the announcement at the end of a meeting of the leaders of the Commonwealth of Independent States. He also said the other Commonwealth countries had agreed that he would speak for them all when he asks the Group of Seven summit meeting of major industrialized nations in Munich to postpone repayment of old Soviet foreign debts for at least two years. 
 The Commonwealth meeting also reached several administrative decisions, but failed to resolve differences over the future of former Soviet strategic nuclear weapons.
Speaking at a news conference attended by the heads of 10 Commonwealth countries, Mr. Yeltsin portrayed the decision to form a peacekeeping force as one taken by the entire Commonwealth. He said future decisions might be taken to use the force in other ethnic wars.
Mr. Yeltsin later clarified that the force for Moldova would be formed of Russian and Ukrainian troops from the Commonwealth, and of Romanian and possibly Bulgarian troops. He said the force would be deployed only if the Moldovan Parliament requested it.
Mr. Yeltsin said he had been assured by the Moldovan President, Mircea Snegur, that the Moldovan Parliament would do so. But there was no immediate indication how either side in the conflict would react to the introduction of outside forces, or whether Romania or Bulgaria would agree to participate.
Moldova has been torn by civil war between the ethnic Romanians who form the majority in the small republic, and the Russians and Ukrainians who live for the most part in a wedge along the east bank of the Dniester River. The Russians and Ukrainians have proclaimed a Trans-Dniester Republic, arguing that the Moldovans intend to merge with Romania.
Mr. Snegur, who has previously accused the Russian Army of backing the Slav separatists, appeared today to welcome the prospect of a peacekeeping force. "I think that with joint efforts and through Parliament we will find a way out of this situation," he said, "a way to maintain a cease-fire, introduce buffer forces and work calmly in Parliament to find a compromise."
But President Levon Ter-Petrosyan of Armenia, whose country has been ravaged by a four-year struggle with neighboring Azerbaijan over the enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh, reacted bitterly when asked his reaction.
"To my regret, I must state that the Commonwealth has no mechanisms to resolve inter-ethnic conflicts, and all these statements remain mere words," he said.
The Commonwealth meeting was held on the eve of Mr. Yeltsin's departure for Munich, where leaders of the seven major industrialized nations -- the United States, Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan -- are holding their annual economic summit conference.
Mr. Yeltsin has said he will ask the leaders on behalf of all Commonwealth members to defer all interest and principal payment of the $74 billion in foreign debt inherited from the Soviet Union. "Some participants to the meeting thought that such debt should be forgiven altogether because we had little to do with that debt," he added with a smile.
 
Big Aid Package Still Tied Up
 On Sunday, the International Monetary Fund agreed to grant Russia a $1 billion loan after securing new commitments from the Russian Government to further cut spending. The agreement was concluded during a trip to Moscow by the I.M.F.'s managing director, Michel Camdessus, to insure that Mr. Yeltsin would not leave the Munich conference empty-handed.
The agreement, however, was only a stopgap arrangement while the I.M.F. and Russia continued working on the major $24 billion aid program that is pegged to extensive economic reforms. Agreement on the terms of the larger aid package is considered critical because it would effectively provide a Western endorsement of Russia's economic direction and so could stimulate private investment.
Even the more moderate conditions to which Russia agreed for the $1 billion loan, however, seemed excessively ambitious at a time the country is facing a precipitous drop in production and an increase in its budget deficit.
According to Aleksei Mozhin, an aide to Acting Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar who is involved in the I.M.F. talks, the Russian Government agreed to bring the budget deficit down from 10 percent to 5 percent by year's end and to reduce the inflation rate from 15 to 10 percent.
Other commitments include higher tariffs to reduce imports; introduction of a system under which expenditures would automatically cease if Government revenues dropped; a ceiling on credit, which was not immediately disclosed; higher interest rates at Government savings banks to attract capital, and the abolition of export quotas, except for energy.
The agreement, however, did not call for the freeing of oil prices, which Mr. Yeltsin has rejected, arguing that in its current condition the nation simply could not survive the consequences.
The Commonwealth summit meeting, which has become a regular exercise since the Soviet Union was dismantled seven months ago, followed the usual pattern of signing a series of organizational agreements but failing to reach agreement on the major issues that have so far prevented the Commonwealth from progressing beyond a loose and powerless umbrella for most of the former Soviet republics.
Among the latter was failure to reach agreement among the four nuclear republics -- Russia, Ukraine, Belarus and Kazakhstan -- on the disposition of strategic nuclear rockets stationed on their soil. The current roadblock reportedly is Ukraine's insistence that it needs seven years to dismantle its nuclear weapons, and its rejection of interim solutions like defusing or removing the nuclear warheads from the missiles.
The major achievement cited by the presidents was an agreement to set up an economic court to settle financial disputes among Commonwealth members. The idea was proposed by President Nursultan Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan, who has been one of the strongest advocates in the Commonwealth of a strong economic union.
There was no indication, however, how the court would enforce its decisions on the republics.
Nonetheless, the leaders seemed pleased with the meeting and the attendance. President Askar Akayev of Kyrgyzstan, who was chairman of the session, said, "This shows the Commonwealth is not only still alive but has started to act effectively to solve the most vital questions facing us."
Present at the meeting were the leaders of Russia, Ukraine, Belarus, Moldova, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and Armenia. Azerbaijan, whose Parliament never ratified its membership and is not likely to, sent observers, as did Georgia. The three Baltic nations, which were once part of the Soviet Union, have never taken part in the Commonwealth.

HEADLINE: Bush Watches BMW Sign Accord

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MUNICH, Germany, July 6

 BODY:
Despite his busy schedule here, President Bush took the time today for a photo opportunity to observe the signing of an agreement to build a BMW automobile plant in South Carolina.
The Governor of South Carolina, Carroll A. Campbell Jr., and the BMW chairman, Eberhard von Kuenheim, shared the podium afterward to discuss the deal to build a plant in the Greenville-Spartanburg area and eventually employ 2,000 workers. 
 Asked if BMW was attracted to South Carolina by the promise of cheap labor, Mr. Campbell spoke out against "an effete snobbism from some people in certain parts of the country against the South." But he also noted that "South Carolina is a right-to-work state," meaning workers cannot be compelled to join a union as a condition of employment. BMW has said "they will work with the prevailing wage and that they will obviously be in the upper end of it," the Governor said.
"This particular area is not, as has been depicted, another Mexico," he added. "It is a very, very upscale area. The wages would be competitive there."
Mr. von Kuenheim said the company would save about 25 percent on the cars' manufacturing costs. Preparation of the site for the 1.9-million-square-foot plant is to begin this month, and it is expected to begin producing cars by 1995 for sale in the United States, Asia, Australia and Germany.

HEADLINE: New Jersey's Bond Rating Holds Firm

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 6

 BODY:
As indigent kidney dialysis patients worry about where they will get their medicine and state employees wonder which of them are going to lose their jobs, one thing in New Jersey was more certain than it had been: The state's credit rating was affirmed today by Standard & Poor's.
But the bond-rating agency also said the state's long-term financial outlook was poor. 
 Like so much in the politically charged atmosphere in Trenton, how the news was interpreted depended on who was asked.
Republicans say retaining the credit rating shows that the budget they passed last week was fiscally sound; Democrats say the long-term negative outlook shows the spending plan is flawed.
Last year, as a result of budget maneuvering that included the sale of a stretch of highway Interstate 95 from one arm of the state government to another to cover $400 million of a $550 million shortfall, the bond rating from Standard & Poor's slipped a notch, from Aaa to Aa+. It is still among the highest in the nation, which means the state gets the best possible interest rates on the money it borrows.
 
More Immediate Concerns
 But one reason the long term outlook is less favorable is that while the $14.6 billion budget that went into effect last week is technically in balance, it has a relatively minuscule $29 million unappropriated surplus.
About $300 million would be more to the liking of Wall Street.
Some in state government have more immediate concerns about the state's financial picture.
Today, 19 department heads began filing layoff plans with the Department of Personnel. The Republicans say only about one in 30 state employees, some 2,000 out of the 66,000 workforce, mostly well-paid middle managers, need be laid off. The layoffs would be for at least a year and for many employees, permanent. The administration says as many as one in 10 will lose jobs, somewhere between 6,000 and 7,000, in all pay grades.
Just how deep the cuts will be will not be known until Friday, when the layoff plans are compiled, added up and set in motion. "We're trying to keep a threshhold on the anxiety by not speculating" on exactly how many will be laid off, and where the layoffs will come, said Tom Vincz, a spokesman for the Department of Personnel.
All this, according to the Florio administration, means that state parks will have to close earlier in the season than usual and that pollution monitoring and control at the state's beaches will have to be cut back, as will road plowing next winter.
The Republicans describe such scenarios as "scare talk."
 
Court Battle Possible
 Meanwhile, New Jersey budget-makers continue to hope that the Federal Government will bail everybody out with $450 million in Medicaid reimbursements.
When Gov. Jim Florio proposed his budget last January, he included the money, maintaining that it was a sure thing that the Federal Government would honor the state's claim for care provided for indigent patients in its psychiatric hospitals going back to 1989.
He also put into the proposed budget $608 million in expected revenue from the one cent increase in the sales tax the Democrats approved in 1990. The Republicans, who had warned him not to do that, made good on their threat to repeal the tax increase, overriding the Governor's veto.
On June 2, with the sales tax money already repealed and the deadline for a new budget just four weeks away, the hole in the budget opened wider -- to $1 billion. State Treasurer Samuel F. Crane announced that the Federal Government had issued a "preliminary rejection" not only of $380 million in Medicaid reimbursements for the new budget, but also of most of the $70 million that was due for the last half of the fiscal year 1991.
The Republicans made good on their promise to cut a billion dollars out of the Governor's proposed $15.7 spending plan, but to do it they had to cut all sorts of programs.
They slashed the popular $685 million Homestead Rebate program by almost 60 percent, back to $300 million. They also, some say unintentionally, made sharp cuts in medical assistance that, among other things, helps pay for medicine for 1,100 people who get kidney dialysis, 950 others being treated for tuberculosis and 1,600 people with AIDS.
Florio administration officials insist that the state's claim to all, or at least most, of the contested Medicaid money will -- eventually -- be paid, although they may have to go to court to get it.
They turned down a quick settlement that would have provided $126 million right away, since it would have meant giving up any claim to the rest of the $450 million. A court battle could take up to two years.

HEADLINE: A Blip or a Dip?;
The Candidates and the Unemployed Both Have a Big Stake in the Answer

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
For millions of Americans looking for work -- and for this year's Presidential candidates -- the surge in unemployment in June poses a big question: Is the economy's new weakness a blip or a dip?
Last Thursday's jobless report, which showed the unemployment rate jumping to 7.8 percent, led many economists to adopt more pessimistic forecasts. And while most economists still doubt that the economy will slow to near zero for the third time in two years, some economists are now saying there is a 50-50 chance of a triple dip, even with the Federal Reserve's decision to lower short-term interest rates. 
 "With the drop in employment in June, it's hard to see how we can sustain an economic recovery," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist for C. J. Lawrence & Company, a New York investment firm. "I'd say it could go either way in the third quarter -- there could be modest growth or the economy could be flat."
If Mr. Yardeni and his more pessimistic colleagues are right, President Bush, already perilously low in opinion polls, could lose several crucial percentage points in the November balloting.
"The Bush campaign should be very nervous about the economy," said Ray C. Fair, a Yale University economist, whose studies show that incumbent Presidents run into trouble if they do not enjoy strong growth in the six months before Election Day.
Even the more optimistic economy watchers are not predicting much strength.
Kurt Karl, an economist at the WEFA Group, a forecasting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., says the economy may narrowly skirt a triple dip thanks to new-found strength in the auto industry. With the recent weakening in consumer spending and home building, "overall industrial production will be pushed up by production of auto and light trucks," he said. "But if the auto industry gets nervous and starts winding down, then there will be a triple dip."
He puts the probability of a triple dip at 30 percent, up from his forecast of 20 percent before last Thursday's jobless report.
"I think the economy will manage to avoid a triple dip, but it is still going to be a struggle," said Robert G. Dederick, a former Reagan Administration economist who is chief economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "At best, the economy will be at the edge of what might be called satisfactory."
In recent months, the Bush Administration has boasted about the respectable 2.7 percent growth in the first quarter, but the recovery appears to have slowed since then. It is weighed down by a myriad of factors that have not held back the nation after other recessions: large household debt burdens that dampen consumer spending, cuts in the military budget that are causing large-scale layoffs, and the failure of many companies to add workers as they increase output.
Administration officials insist that the economy is continuing to grow despite June's bad unemployment numbers. In a news conference today in Munich, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady noted that growth was 2.7 percent in the first quarter. "I am not going to speculate on what it's going to be in the second quarter," he said. "Let's assume it's less than that. I think during the rest of the year it will pick up to such an extent so that it will be around the 2.5 to 3 percent that we forecast."
The main reason the recovery seems unable to gather steam, many analysts say, is that employment has remained flat for a year, which denies households the added income needed to push the economy forward, and wage gains have been very sluggish as well. In June, nonfarm payroll employment, seasonally adjusted, fell an unexpected 117,000 to 89,769,000. That was down 65,000 from June 1991.
The economy is like a jet plane that seems unable to get up enough speed to take off, Mr. Yardeni says. Every time it begins lumbering down the runway and starts to take off, it seems to go up a few feet before unexpectedly bouncing down again because of a lack of acceleration.
Mr. Yardeni said the nation would be lucky if "we get 1 to 1.5 percent growth in the second quarter." He is predicting 2 percent growth in the second half. But, he said, "I have my finger on the trigger" to lower that forecast if there are a few more negative economic reports. On Thursday, he raised his forecast of the probability of a triple dip to 50 percent, up from 25 percent previously.
Late last year the economy experienced what is generally called a double dip, because growth slowed markedly after the recession -- the first dip -- that occurred in the second half of 1990. The economic pickup in the first half of 1991 was aborted later that year when consumer confidence mysteriously evaporated and consumer spending slid badly, pulling industrial production down with it.
 
'Stupid Stop-Go Stuff'
 "The reason we have this stupid stop-go, stop-go stuff is we have cyclical forces that are starting to turn around, but they are running into a long-term adjustment, and that's tough" said Donald Ratajczak, director of the economic forecasting center at Georgia State University.
He said a full-fledged recovery was also being held back by past overbuilding in commercial construction and by demographic changes that mean there are fewer young people buying cars, furniture and houses. But he said that households were reducing their debt burdens and the construction overhang was declining, paving the way to a stronger upturn eventually.
Some economists questioned the accuracy of June's jump in unemployment because it was so much more negative than other recent reports. Some of them say that the employment report was done a few days earlier in June than many other June jobless reports and that as a result it may have overcounted the number of unemployed students and undercounted the number of payroll jobs because the survey was done slightly before employers added their normal contingent of students.
"Given the fact that June could be either a statistical distortion or the beginning of a triple dip, it's a 50-50 call whether it's the beginning of a new dip," Mr. Ratajczak said. His best forecast, he said, is that the economy will grow by a modest 2 percent in the second half of this year, rising to 3 percent early next year.
There are predictions that the jobless rate could fall substantially in July because students who entered the work force to find jobs might quickly give up their searches and thus will no longer be counted as unemployed. But some others predict that joblessness could continue to rise, because June's dismal job report could push down consumer confidence, which could in turn cause companies to scale back on their production and employment plans.
The hope was that the first quarter's momentum would insure a strong second quarter, but that failed to happen. One reason was that the first quarter apparently borrowed a lot of construction and consumption that would have taken place in the second quarter. Another reason was that the first quarter's job gains were too modest to generate significant gains in personal income. All this meant that the 5 percent jump in personal consumption in the first quarter could not be sustained.
"When you get ahead of yourself, then you're going to run into a period of stagnation and in June things came home to roost," said Roger E. Brinner, chief economist for DRI/McGraw Hill, a consulting firm.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edward Yardeni, C.J. Lawrence & Company -- "With the drop in employment in June, it's hard to see how we can sustain an economic recovery." (C.J. Lawrence & Company) (pg. D6)
 
Graph: "If This Is a Recovery, Where Are the Jobs?"
 In past cycles, total employment grew sharply after the deepest point of the recession. If the current cycle hit bottom in March 1991, as some economists think, then to follow the pattern, jobs ought to be rebounding now. The fact that they are not suggests another trough is still to come.

HEADLINE: Benefits of an Unwelcome Trend;
Growing Prison Population Lifts Economy for Some Towns

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

 BODY:
The business of imprisonment is so recession-proof that the New York State Corrections Commissioner, Thomas A. Coughlin 3d, has a dozen upstate communities eagerly requesting some instant economy from a man who, after 13 years of tenure, expects to see the state prison population triple.
Applicant townships wanting in on one of the state's more redoubtable growth industries say one of Mr. Coughlin's trademark 750-bed medium-security prisons will do, its construction now perfected into a 10-month state-of-the-art package, or perhaps his 500-cell maximum security prototype, easily adapted to the cow pastures of upstate New York. "It's a type of industry offering 400 to 500 new jobs, no pollution, and not here today, gone tomorrow," said the Portland Town Supervisor, Harold H. Smith, one of Mr. Coughlin's prison suitors. 
 In such a keeper's market, the 54-year-old commissioner retains his sense of irony and counts his caged and barracks-secured inmates -- this week more than 60,000, a new high -- as society's mixed curse and cure.
It is a population that continues to rise 5 percent annually yet need not, said Mr. Coughlin, who suggests that up to a third of the inmates, mostly small-scale drug addicts and dealers, might be better served on the outside in work and drug rehabilitation programs, at considerable savings to the taxpayers.
"A large portion would," he said, estimating that number at easily 5,000 inmates. "These are not your kingpins," he added, barely masking his bemusement at the anomalies of the criminal justice system, an overworked catch basin.
"Many of these guys are in and out real quick," said the commissioner, speaking of the fact that while the inmate population has boomed here and across the nation in a decade of law-and-order crackdowns, record prison construction and tough new mandated sentences, the average prison term has dropped 25 percent in New York, to 21 months.
While the state system now has more violent-crime convicts doing long terms, it also has something of a commuter-like subgroup, with a turnover of 22,000 a year, most of them nonviolent criminals busily cycling through the drug culture and facing a recidivism rate of 40 percent.
"They come in to get healthy, get their teeth done, get some good meals and they're out the door," said Mr. Coughlin, rated one of the nation's more able commissioners.
As master of a mushrooming system that includes 14 maximum-security prisons, Mr. Coughlin's credentials are rooted in a mix of crime and compassion. He quit the state police 20 years ago to pursue an avocation in community organizing in Jefferson County for mentally retarded children, a cause brought home to him by the dearth of available services and by one of his three daughters who is retarded. Eventually Gov. Hugh L. Carey chose him commissioner of a new Office of Mental Retardation, then moved him to the prison system in recognition of his knack for trouble-shooting within bureaucracies.
 
Younger, Better-Trained Staff
 The system seems less dangerously crowded than in the prison-scandal days of the 1970's and is run by a younger, better-paid and -trained staff that has grown from 7,000 prison guards to 18,000 in his tenure. Inmates are kept less idle than in the past, with thousands of convicts allowed out each day to clean up cemeteries and churches upstate. Soon, inmate crews will be working along the state Thruway for the first time. The system has trained inmates in asbestos removal in the prisons, providing them with a well-paid, if risky speciality once they are released.
But these are minor aspects of a population secured across 68 prisons at an occupancy rate that still reflects overcrowding -- 124 percent of capacity -- after a binge of construction, a doubling of prison buildings in the past 10 years. The state has built $5 billion worth of prisons in this time, often resorting to Urban Development Corporation financing that, critics note, was originally envisioned for housing poor people in new city apartments, not in new prisons.
But the convicts keep coming and the prisons wind up with seven more inmates in each day's turnover. Commissioner Coughlin concedes he will soon need fresh space after a two-year building moratorium because of tight budgets. This will come either in new prisons or the remodeled mental hospitals he lately prefers. As the system keeps growing, it continues to be criticized as a gross waste of money by such critics as Robert Gangi, the executive director of the Correctional Association of New York, the chief private watchdog agency.
"State policy makers have not gotten control of the situation," Mr. Gangi said. He is calling for an overhaul of the criminal justice system's heavy reliance on mandated drug sentences, which results in filled the prisons. This change, with its restoration of greater leeway to sentencing judges, is one with which Mr. Coughlin does not quarrel but which he estimates is as politically explosive as the unending debate over restoring the state's death penalty.
"It's simply wrong to have to spend so much money on prisons," Mr. Gangi said of the state's $1.2 billion correction budget, which has grown five-fold since 1980 with money Mr. Gangi thinks would largely be better invested in alternative correction methods like work release and home detention and in drug treatment and other social programs.
"My criticism is not of Tom Coughlin; he's the gatekeeper and has to find room for these guys," said Mr. Gangi, who thinks well of the commissioner under the circumstances, especially in enlisting Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in the effort to repeal mandated sentences for low-level second-felony offenders.
 
Better Off on Outside?
 Critics, including the commissioner, say this has been an easy conviction device for anti-narcotic police who sweep the urban drug culture and imprison thousands at a cost of $25,000 a year per inmate. Commissioner Coughlin, sensing opportunity in the state fiscal hardships of the past few years, has pursued some of the alternatives to incarceration that reformers have advocated. Work release and other part-time prison programs are to double in size this year to 6,000 convict participants.
Chief among Mr. Coughlin's own hopes in this area is his plan to release low-level inmates up to 18 months early as reward for completing an intensive, six-month drug rehabilitation program in prison. If it succeeds the way he wants, Mr. Coughlin says he would see 1,200 inmates rewarded this year with early freedom and he would have a track record to show balky state legislators in lobbying for greater alternatives to costly prison time -- in this case, $80 million worth of prison cells plus $30 million in annual overhead.
"When you run short of money somebody's philosophy has to be compromised somewhat," said the commissioner, who argues that hard fiscal times provide the best opportunity for reformers to turn back the huge growth in the warehousing approaches of the 1980's. In that decade, the national prison population increased by 130 percent and is expected to fully triple by 1994 when it tops the one million inmate mark, the highest incarceration rate of any industrialized nation.
As he wonders whether up to a third of his inmates -- the drug culture convicts -- might be better off outside prison, Mr. Coughlin still estimates that society is better served with most of the other 40,000 behind bars. Critics differ sharply, but these convicts, by Mr. Coughlin's accounting, constitute a full doubling of violent-crime offenders in the time since he took office, on Aug. 1, 1979.
"Perception of safety is a difficult thing on the streets, but there are probably fewer armed robbers around today than a few years ago," he contended.
Mr. Coughlin, a long-term survivor in a national incarceration industry that spends $20 billion annually, counts as his greatest failure his inability to get a new prison built in or near New York City. Pressures from neighborhood communities overwhelm the visitation needs of inmate families, he said. "This is why we build upstate," he said.
His greatest motivation seems to be the notorious, bloody Attica prison uprising of 1971 and the long shadow it continues to cast.
"It's always there, unspoken of a lot of times, but all prison policy from '71 till today flows from that and I think that's good," he said. Mr. Coughlin keeps Attica as his reminder that in running the teeming, imperfect prison network as it grows across the state, he basically is in "the business of calculated risks."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thomas A. Coughlin 3d, the New York State Corrections Commissioner, talking with Michelle Meddaugh, a correction officer, at the Coxsackie Correctional Facility in Coxsackie, N.Y. He said he expects to see the prison population triple. (David Jennings for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Watchdog Group Assails Pace of Reorganization

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
An independent group that monitors New York City's finances contends that Mayor David N. Dinkins and the City Council have failed to make good on promises to fundamentally reorganize the city government and reduce its size.
In letters to the Mayor and the Council's Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, the watchdog group, the Citizens Budget Commission, said the city budget for the fiscal year that began last week did not deliver on many of the pledges made earlier by the Mayor and Council to overhaul municipal government. 
 Raymond D. Horton, the president of the budget commission, a nonprofit organization financed by businesses, said in the letters that both city officials had promised to streamline local government, in light of the impact of the severe recession on city tax revenue.
"But your actions belie your words," Mr. Horton wrote. "The 1993 budget turns its back on these sound principles. It seeks to maintain an unsustainable status quo to the detriment of the public. New Yorkers will continue to pay dearly -- in reduced services and higher taxes -- to sustain the current system."
 
Missed Opportunities
 Mr. Horton argued in the letters, which were sent last week, that the city had missed many significant opportunities. Among them, he said, were reducing further the number of city workers, consolidating city agencies, changing a property-tax system that he contended favored single-family homeowners over apartment dwellers, revising rent regulations that sometimes enable wealthy New Yorkers to pay below-market rents, changing cumbersome and unproductive work rules, and creating a smaller, better-paid municipal work force.
First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said in an interview yesterday that the Dinkins administration remained committed to pledges made in budget proposals to reshape the government. He cited several examples of goals already achieved, including a consolidation of agencies involved in economic development, an increase in the number of city-owned apartment buildings sold to private and nonprofit owners and a proposal to sell the Offtrack Betting Corporation.
"I would disagree that we aren't pursuing reorganization," Mr. Steisel said. "We have a series of reforms that we are pursuing."
He also said that the administration was currently negotiating new contracts with unions representing municipal workers, and that it would grant wage increases only if they were tied to productivity gains.
Michael Clendenin, a spokesman for Mr. Vallone, said the outcome of the labor talks will have a large role in determining how much the government is reshaped. "We're still hopeful that many of the structural reforms that we and others have called for will go forward," Mr. Clendenin said.
 
Seeking 'Structural Balance'
 Mr. Horton said in his letters that the Mayor and the Council had not yet done enough to achieve what fiscal experts call "structural balance," a concept that promotes a more stable long-term relationship between the size of the city government and the size of the local economy on which it depends.
Mr. Horton said he was disappointed with the budget for the new fiscal year because it included few changes that would alter the structure of city government.
He noted, for example, that the city planned to increase slightly the size of its work force over the next 12 months, despite a pledge last year to eliminate 16,500 jobs over four years. Mr. Steisel acknowledged that there would be an increase, but he said it was primarily to add more teachers, in response to a surge in the number of students, more civilians in the Police Department and more sanitation workers for recycling.
But the city eliminated 11,000 workers during the last year, city budget officials said. And Mr. Steisel maintained that the administration was still determined to reach the long-term job goals.

HEADLINE: Five-Alarm Fire Destroys Half-Block of Bronx Businesses

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
A raging five-alarm fire of suspicious origin destroyed half a block of small businesses on a busy thoroughfare in the Bronx yesterday afternoon, and while no one was killed or seriously injured, the loss was a heavy blow to a struggling, working-class community.
Eighteen firefighters suffered cuts, bruises, heat exhaustion and other minor injuries in the blaze, which broke out in a loft and spread rapidly. It burned out of control for nearly three hours and gutted much of the south side of East Tremont Avenue between Webster and Park Avenues in the Tremont section. 
 The major casualties were seven small stores, most of them family-owned and decades old, of a kind found in any local neighborhood in New York: a furniture store, an electronics shop, a restaurant, a hardware store, a discount liquor outlet, a fast-food shop and a less common establishment that makes blueprints.
 
Community Stability
 "Those stores are the lifeblood of a community," said Clint Roswell, a spokesman for the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer. "They keep people working. They pay the rent. They make a community stable and determine its character. When you lose seven stores, certainly it has a tremendous impact on the community, culturally as well as economically."
Frank McCabe, a Fire Department spokesman, agreed. "I've lived in the city all my life, and I know what a fire like this can do to a community," he said. "The Bronx is coming back, but something like this can be devastating."
He said the fire broke out at 12:40 P.M. in a "taxpayer," a one-and-one-half-story structure of a kind commonly erected a half-century ago, with stores on the ground floor and a common loft for storage above them.
When the first of 200 firefighters arrived, they found flames engulfing the Tremont and Webster Hardware store at 412 East Tremont, and the fire spread rapidly on either side to stores at Nos. 400, 406, 414, 418, 420 and 422.
Fire marshals said the extent and speed of the fire made it suspicious, and they said they would investigate for possible arson. All the stores were open, and owners, employees and customers ran out, escaping injury. Hundreds of people watched firefighters battle the stubborn blaze, which was brought under control at 3:30 P.M.
 
Series of Setbacks
 As firefighters gathered up hoses later, a group of store owners on the block gathered outside and somberly surveyed the wreckage of collapsed roofs, blackened timbers, shattered glass and smoking ashes that had been furnishings, electronic equipment, liquor stocks and other products.
Some said yesterday's fire was only the latest blow in a neighborhood that had suffered recent reverses. Last year another fire destroyed a row of four stores across the street, leaving a garbage-strewn lot. And, they said, a bank at the corner of East Tremont and Park Avenues failed and is still shuttered.
But they also said that the Tremont area -- whose residents include blacks, whites and Hispanic people, many of them working-class immigrants from Latin America -- was a relatively stable community in a borough with many troubled neighborhoods. Most of the stores that burned yesterday were part of that stability: at least three had been in business for more than 30 years.
 
'I Hope to Rebuild'
 Stanley Bell, the owner of Belco Electronics, which sold two-way radio equipment for taxicabs among other items at No. 418, said his family had been in business at the same location for 40 years, and he said he did not know if insurance would cover his losses.
"I've worked in the Bronx all my life and I hope to rebuild," he said. He said, however, that it would be useless to rebuild if other businesses on the block did not do so as well. "If they don't, I don't think I want to," he said. "It would be bad to be in business with eyesores next to me."
Joseph Armato, speaking for Benny Berkowitz, who owns four of the burned storefronts, said his client's properties were insured and would be rebuilt. And Moses Stein, the owner of Frank's, a clothing store at the corner that was untouched by the flames and that he said had been in his family for 70 years, spoke of hope for the gutted block.
"This is the most stable retail block in the Bronx," he said. "I'm sure I will be here as long as I'm alive."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Prices Higher

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher again yesterday in the first trading session following the latest round of interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve.
Even though yields on short-term bills and notes have fallen to exceptionally low levels, dealers said demand was especially strong for short- to-intermediate-term issues. Bond prices also moved higher yesterday, but by more modest amounts. 
 "There is buying going on for maturities of seven years or less," one government securities trader said. "At the moment the whole trade is in the front end."
Traders and analysts said the impulse to purchase shorter-term issues reflected confusion among investors about the current state of the economy as well as a reluctance to conclude that interest rates might be in the midst of a secular downward cycle.
"In the 1950's and 1960's, when you did a back-of-the-envelope calculation on rates, it started at 5 percent," said Neil M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation.
"In the late 1970's and 1980's, the rate was 10 percent, because that was representative. A lot of people are still caught in that world, even though the place to start that calculation is once again much closer to 5 percent."
Extremely weak June employment data released last week have compounded the problem, analysts said.
The numbers were uniformly bad, but may have overstated just how poor conditions are.
"It is probably a little early to start focusing on the next set of employment numbers, but I think we will probably see a nice rebound when the July figures are reported in early August," said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J.
 
Weakness in Employment Data
 The weakness in the employment data stood in stark contrast to very strong auto sales reported yesterday for the final 10 days of June.
According to car makers, a seasonally adjusted 7.5 million units were sold during that period, up from 6.5 million in the middle of the month.
Traders chose to view the report in the context of the weak June employment data released last Thursday. The big jump in the unemployment rate and the decline in nonfarm payroll employment make it unlikely that car sales will remain brisk, analysts said.
After the employment report, "the car sales numbers make you wonder if you are in the same country," said Jay Goldinger, a principal at Capital Insight, a bond brokerage firm in Beverly Hills, Calif. "Debt market participants are confused. And when that is the case you stay in short-term securities."
The lowest yields in two to nearly three decades did have an impact at yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills, as non-competitive tenders for the securities fell fairly sharply.
Such bids are usually seen as a good proxy of small investor demand for securities.
At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 3.23 percent, down sharply from the average rate of 3.59 percent at last week's auction.
It is the lowest rate on a three-month bill since the auction of February 18, 1972, when the rate was 3.14 percent.
Bids for the new six-month bills generated an average discount rate of 3.32 percent, down from an average of 3.66 percent at the auction a week ago.
It is the lowest rate on a new six-month bill since those securities were sold on July 8, 1963, at an average rate of 3.27 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 104 15/32, up 1/8 point, to yield 7.61 percent, compared with 7.62 percent late Thursday.
 
Outstanding Treasury Issues
 Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 104 11/32, up 1/4 point, to yield 6.88 percent. And the 5 percent two-year notes were offered at 101 2/32, up 7/32, to yield 4.43 percent.
As expected, the latest drop in interest rates prompted a number of corporations to price new debt securities.
Among the issuers was the Shell Oil Company, which offered $250 million worth of seven-year noncallable notes through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.
The 6 5/8 percent notes were priced at $99.859, to yield 6.65 percent, a scant 18 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 percent seven-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The Bell Telephone Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bell Atlantic Corporation, offered $150 million of 15-year securities through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.
The 7 3/8 percent noncallable notes were priced at $99.338, to yield 7.449 percent, 55 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated AA-1 by Moody's and AA by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, demand for outstanding issues remained firm, traders said. Prices of widely quoted issues rose by about 1/8 point.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: This Road to New Rochelle Begins in the Hills of Mexico

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 6

 BODY:
It is 2,800 miles from the peasant mountain communities of Cotija, Quitupan and Jiquilpan in Mexico to the cracked sidewalks of Union Avenue here, but hundreds of Mexicans have found a direct route.
Their way is paved by Antonio Valencia, a housekeeper known affectionately as el padrino, the godfather, for his role in finding jobs, housing and a new life for immigrants who have followed him from Mexico. 
 "The reason they come is because Antonio came," said Juan Sandoval, a 41-year-old merchant whose food market and liquor store on Union Avenue bustles mostly with Mexican customers. "All they need is somebody to know. You need somebody to support you. We are all following the leader."
 
Coming to America
 Every community in America has its own tale of ethnic populations taking root and flourishing. In New Rochelle, the story begins with the 69-year-old Mr. Valencia, who arrived in 1954, alone and speaking not a word of English, to serve as live-in housekeeper for George Vergara, a former mayor, and his wife, Allys.
This city of 67,000 people has seen a surge of growth in its Hispanic population, largely Mexican, which nearly doubled to 7,200 in the last decade. Unlike other parts of the New York region where Mexicans come mainly from the Puebla region east of Mexico City, in New Rochelle most Mexicans are from the tight cluster of towns in the central-western region where Mr. Valencia grew up.
While it is hard to say just how many people Mr. Valencia has shepherded out of hardscrabble existences in rural Mexico, he is credited with improving the lives of thousands of Mexicans.
 
'More Than an Ambassador'
 "He's more than an ambassador," said Manuel Alonso, Mexico's consul general for the New York region. "He's a patriarch of Mexico."
On the streets of New Rochelle, Mr. Valencia is called el padrino not in the strong-arm sense of movie fiction but because he is indeed related to many Mexicans and because of his open-ended generosity, said George Castellanos, the Hispanic liaison for the New Rochelle schools. "He's here taking care of us, that's really what he is doing," Mr. Castellanos said.
The city's Mayor, Timothy C. Idoni, said that Mr. Valencia lets city officials know about the concerns and grievances of Mexicans as well as other Hispanic residents. "He's not shy about calling," Mr. Idoni said.
At a recent meeting, Mr. Valencia talked with the Mayor about the need for the appointment of more Hispanic residents to local civic committees and for expanded police protection for the west side of New Rochelle, a lower-income area where many Hispanic residents live.
"He's very concerned for his people," said the Mayor. "He exemplifies what the city of New Rochelle needs in leadership."
Mr. Valencia also serves as a link between the police and Mexicans, some of whom complain bitterly on the streets that the police harass them.
"He's an excellent liaison between the police and Mexican people," said one detective, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "Mr. Valencia, when the Mexicans get in trouble, helps with the language barrier. The police in Mexico have a bad reputation and they fear working with police. He tries to overcome that."
 
A Chance Encounter
 Such tributes seem to bewilder Mr. Valencia, whose journey to New Rochelle began in Mexico City 38 years ago while he was eavesdropping in the rectory of a Roman Catholic Church. Mr. Valencia, who was then a delivery man, overheard a glamorous American couple tell a priest that they were looking for a "houseman" to bring back to America.
Mr. Valencia stepped up to offer his services. He has lived ever since in the stately Vergara home where he serves cold drinks to guests on a silver platter and occasionally chauffeurs Mrs. Vergara, now an elderly widow, in her white Ford.
"It was always my dream to help people," said Mr. Valencia, who had studied for the priesthood in Mexico before abandoning it to care for an ailing father.
His early days here, as one of the city's first Mexican residents, were the hardest. "I was tempted to go back to Mexico many times because I was so lonesome here," he said. "But there was something that made me stay here, the opportunity to help my people."
One legacy of his efforts began to unfold in 1956 when Mr. Valencia summoned two brothers, Jose and Salvador Sandoval, from the corn and beanfields they farmed by a lake in Quitupan. Mr. Valencia arranged for their permanent residency through a nursing home proprietor who was a friend of his employers. The nursing home owner acted as the Sandovals' immigration sponsor and took them in as cleaning help.
 
A Tradition of Helping
 Since then, the Sandoval family has in turn brought hundreds of other Mexicans, including relatives and friends, to New Rochelle. "Mr. Valencia is the beginner of everybody," said Arnoldo Sandoval, a 29-year-old construction worker whose father, Jose, died two years ago.
Leonides Sandoval, Arnoldo's 34-year-old brother, was too young to know Mr. Valencia in Mexico but he knew of his accomplishments. He learned to read and write at a primary school in Quitupan that Mr. Valencia helped build with money raised from bridge card parties and dances in New Rochelle.
Ten years ago, he brought his wife, his three school-age children and several relatives from Mexico. He now owns a house and has a successful dental practice that serves a large Spanish-speaking clientele, including Mr. Valencia.
"I think most everybody either directly or indirectly has been influenced by him being here," said Mr. Sandoval. "It's just unbelievable. You name it, he helps these people. He brings them to doctors. He gets them out of court."
The dentist said he was eager to follow in Mr. Valencia's footsteps.
"There's a tremendous amount of roots being established," Mr. Sandoval said. "We're buying property like anybody else who wants to stay. Now if Mr. Valencia is not around, he has somehow helped somebody to be in a position to help someone else."
 
Harder to Find Work
 Through Mr. Valencia's efforts, Mexicans in New Rochelle have found work primarily as laborers in construction, gardening and country clubs throughout Westchester County. But tougher immigration laws and the recession have made it difficult for Mr. Valencia and most anyone else to arrange permanent residency and employment for new arrivals.
"Years ago, the managers used to call me from all over the place to see if I knew anybody who needs a job," Mr. Valencia said. "Now it's the opposite. I'm the one who has to call to see if they have any jobs available. It is very difficult for jobs now."
Every year, Mexican immigrants come to New Rochelle. City officials said they had no figures on how many arrive legally versus illegally. Regardless of their legal status, many of these new immigrants find their way to New Rochelle with only hope and a slip of paper bearing Mr. Valencia's name.
"They come here and call him every day," said Juan Sandoval, the owner of La Morelenses grocery on Union Avenue. On a recent afternoon, the store's backroom bar was filled with Mexicans nursing longneck beers and listening to nostalgic Spanish music.
"They have no place to go," said Mr. Sandoval. "Many can't get jobs. We treat them for free when they don't have the money to buy. It's sad. We all come from the same region. We're connected somehow."
These days, Mr. Valencia said his main obligation was caring for Mrs. Vergara, cooking meals for her and sometimes driving her to daily Mass. "There's no one like him in the world," Mrs. Vergara said.
Mr. Valencia would like to be remembered as an ordinary man trying to do good. "That's my only dream in life," he said. But on a recent Saturday afternoon, the guest list of a luncheon that he had organized was testimony to his influence.
There was Jorge Montano, the Mexican Ambassador to the United Nations, Mr. Alonso, the Consul General for the New York area, Mayor Idoni, local civic leaders and several guests from the villages where Mr. Valencia was raised.
"We have a great deal of respect for what he does," said Mr. Montano. "You don't find that many people nowadays who are so generous but not looking for any benefit."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Light Trading; Summit Results Awaited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar moved lower in light dealings yesterday, with traders awaiting concrete announcements from the economic summit meeting in Germany. Gold prices rose.
On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery was unchanged from Thursday's levels at $346.50 a troy ounce. A late bid from the Republic National Bank of New York quoted gold at $346.40, up 15 cents. Metals markets were closed Friday in observance of the Independence Day holiday. 
 Currency traders said trading in the dollar was lackluster throughout the day. Traders were still digesting the June unemployment report, released last week, and awaited announcements from the Group of Seven meeting in Munich, said David Ogg, vice president at Credit Suisse.
On Thursday, the Labor Department reported the nation's unemployment rate jumped to 7.8 percent, an unexpectedly sharp increase. The Federal Reserve later responded by cutting interest rates, a move that tends to weaken the dollar overseas.
There was little in the way of substantial economic news for currency traders coming from the annual economic summit meeting of seven industrial countries.
One currency trader said most dealers are waiting for tomorrow, when the countries issue a communique that outlines their agreements, and perhaps makes some statement on foreign currency levels.
In other developments, United States auto makers showed improved sales for late June, but the reports did not have much of an effect on the market, Mr. Ogg said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124.98 yen, up 0.73 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 124.55 yen. At closing in New York, the dollar was trading at 124.35 yen, down from 124.75 late Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9105, from $1.9080 late Friday. At closing in New York, the pound was trading at $1.9105, more expensive than $1.9080 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.51325 marks, down from 1.5180; 1.3545 Swiss francs, down from 1.3590; 5.0980 French francs, down from 5.1060; 1,145.25 Italian lire, down from 1,150.25, and 1.20055 Canadian dollars, down from 1.20265.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $346.65 a troy ounce, from $345.70 bid late Friday. In Zurich, it rose to a closing bid of $346.65, from $345.70 bid late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold rose 44 cents to close at a bid $346.29.
