HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Helping Retirees Sort Out Drugs

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
IN an effort to contain costs while also looking out for their retired employees' health, many companies are trying to dissuade their retirees from buying assortments of prescription drugs that can interact in harmful ways. Prescription drugs are among the fastest-growing health costs for many employers, especially companies with many retirees, who often consume pills at an alarming rate.
Americans over age 65 spent about $11 billion on prescriptions and $5 billion more on over-the-counter drugs last year, according to Stephen W. Schondelmeyer, a pharmaceutical economist at the University of Minnesota. 
 Retirees probably take twice as many medications as active employees, said Jack Dunn, a Ford Motor Company benefits superviser. Ford spent $130 million last year on prescriptions, just for employees and retirees in traditional health plans. The total did not include the 60 percent of Ford's salaried employees and the 37 percent of the company's hourly workers in health maintenance organizations and other medical networks.
Dr. Loren Lipson, an associate professor of medicine, gerontology and clinical pharmacy at the University of Southern California, said that 20 percent of his patients "have some problem with medication."
These include bad reactions to combinations that include drugs prescribed by separate doctors who have not compared notes, low-priced generic versions of drugs that do not always match the brand-name prototype and heavily advertised drugstore remedies. Another big problem is patients who disregard or forget to take their medicines.
Southern California Edison, which spent $33 million for health care for 9,000 retirees and spouses in 1991, is experimenting with a special counseling program. "We send participants a bag and say, 'Bring in all your prescription and over-the-counter medication,' " said Lourdes Birba, the program superviser.
The 230 participants receive a free annual checkup and immunizations against influenza, tetanus and pneumonia. A geriatrics specialist asks about ailments and side effects and discards outdated prescriptions. A pharmacist rechecks for inappropriate combinations.
Ms. Birba said the program had already resulted in a noticeable improvement in patients' taking medications as prescribed.
Dr. Jonathan T. Edelson, a senior vice president of ValueRx, a unit of the managed-care services company Value Health Inc., says many drugs are used improperly. He cites studies showing that 30 percent of ulcer medications -- a major drug expense for many employers -- are "inappropriately prescribed and used."
Prices often vary widely for similar products. People with arthritis pain who take ibuprofen have a choice of 16 varieties, Dr. Edelson said, "but no one product has been documented to be more effective than any other as first-line therapy."
The USX Corportion recently changed a drug program covering 22,000 employees and their families and 75,000 retirees and spouses. Jim Carney, vice president of the United States Steel and Carnegie Pension Fund, said retirees were encouraged to mail-order "maintenance drugs" for chronic diseases, purchasing them in 30-to-90-day quantities. He said that the program provided "computerized screening that looks at the patient's entire drug history."
The Central and South West Corporation, a utility holding company in Dallas, is also starting a combination mail-order and retail pharmacy network that will generate computerized medical profiles, particularly for the elderly. Tom Hare, director of human resources at the company's Central and Southwest Services unit, said drugs had been "about 37 percent of our total medical plan costs," which were $39 million for 12,000 employees, retirees and dependents.
A number of large companies are considering similar programs. Gary Simko, a benefits planning manager at the Bell Atlantic Corporation, said, "We're trying to come up with a mechanism that will manage those costs and provide a value added: quality."
Bell Atlantic spent $179.5 million on retiree health benefits in 1990. After changing its accounting to reflect the cost of medical coverage promised to retirees in the future, the company reported $252.9 million in retiree health costs for 1991.
Not all retiree drug programs are effective, some experts caution.
"For all the money we pay, the elderly don't get very good health care," said Patricia Wilson, a principal with the A. Foster Higgins benefits consulting firm. Managed-care firms are beginning to "collect patient profiles" showing what drugs have been purchased, she said, "but some are just marketing hype."
Employers need more information on the effects that drugs have on the elderly, she added. "Geriatrics is in its infancy. Geriatric pharmacology is embryonic."

HEADLINE: Physicists Struggle To Save Supercollider From Budgetary Ax

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
A STUNNING vote by the House of Representatives to scuttle construction of the $8.25-billion Superconducting Supercollider poses the biggest threat the huge particle accelerator has faced in its 10-year gestation, and has sparked a desperate struggle by supporters to keep the project alive.
If the supercollider should now die, supporters believe, the chance to discover the cosmic origin of whatever it is that endows objects with mass could be lost for at least a generation. A team of some 2,000 scientists assembled and carefully tuned for their roles in the supercollider venture would be scattered at enormous cost, and to the regret of many scientists. 
 But the regret would be by no means universal. To the supercollider's opponents like Representative Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, the death of "one of the hungriest hogs at the Federal trough" would be no loss.
A vote by the Senate late this month or in August to deprive the project of financing would be a fatal blow. American taxpayers would incur more than $1 billion to wind down the work, with little to show for it but the dozen enormous superconducting magnets completed so far and some cavernous excavations at the supercollider's site in Waxahachie, Tex.
Senator Dale Bumpers, Democrat of Arkansas, one of the project's main political foes, said he believed his side had picked up votes -- perhaps enough to win. In this election year, politicians say voters may object to big Federal programs that do not directly benefit the economy.
High-energy physicists were dismayed by the House vote on June 17, and many have sent or signed letters to United States officials urging continued support of the supercollider. Some of America's preeminent scientists, including 17 winners of Nobel prizes, wrote to President Bush, warning that cancellation would have a "destructive effect" on the entire United States scientific enterprise and raise questions about America's "ability to carry out long-term scientific projects."
Even a potential rival of the supercollider team, the European high-energy physics consortium, known as CERN, expressed the hope that "this vote will be reversed lest it create an alarming vacuum in an important field of scientific research." Rebutting critics who say the supercollider's hoped for discoveries will substantially overlap those of a new machine planned by CERN called the Large Hadron Collider, the CERN statement said the two machines would be complementary.
Supporters of the supercollider were also taken aback by the House's 231-182 vote against their machine, because it showed a sharp shift from the support it received last year. Perhaps too hopefully, they interpret the change as a vote not against big science projects but rather as reflecting a desire of other members of Congress to punish the Texas delegation for reasons having nothing to do with the supercollider.
 
Threat to Japanese Share
 Whatever the reasons for the House vote, the supercollider supporters fear that it may undermine Japan's willingness to share a major part of the project's expenses, as Congress has required it to do within the next year. Without Japanese support, the project will simply die, according to Dr. Roy F. Schwitters, director of the supercollider project. "We have to proceed as if Japan's participation were assured," he said. "We can't wait around worrying about something over which we have no control."
Opponents argue the Supercollider has already doubled in cost and may exceed the $8.25 billion now estimated. But Dr. Schwitters asserts that the technical uncertainties behind the increased cost have been overcome. "We expect to stay within budget from now on," he said.
Many physicists who work in fields other than high-energy research oppose the supercollider, chiefly from fear it will eventually rob funds from their research, whether directly or indirectly.
This fear became so intense that in 1988 the American Physical Society, whose membership includes most American physicists, was nearly split apart. Dr. James A. Krumhansl, president of the society at the time, succeeded in averting fission but said later: "In physics today there are 18 identifiable subfields, and in the American Physical Society there are 40,000 members. Particle physics cannot make an impact on most other areas of physics, chemistry, biology, electronics or other sciences, except astrophysics and cosmology.
 
Fears of Exaggeration
 "In the view of many A.P.S. members," he said, "the extravagant representation of the potential fruits from the supercollider was fictitious and ethically irresponsible."
But to particle physicists interested in pure science rather than potential technological spinoffs or economic and political benefits, the supercollider has a special quality. It is seen as a kind of Philosopher's Stone, a key to at least partial understanding of the ultimate basis of existence.
The machine would create bunches of proton particles and spin them in opposite directions around an oval underground ring 54 miles in circumference. Protons accelerated close to light speed would collide at combined energies of up to 40 trillion electronvolts, 20 times as high as the energies achieved at the Fermilab Tevatron in Illinois, the most powerful existing proton accelerator.
When two protons collide at supercollider energies, a tiny fireball of pure energy results, as intense as that after the Big Bang when the universe was only one-trillionth of a second old.
 
Energy Into Mass
 Some of the energy in this microscopic fireball is transformed into matter according to Einstein's famous equation E=mc<2>, and a zoo of different particles emerges in sprays and jets. Detectors the size and weight of battleships are installed at points around the ring where protons collide, and sophisticated filters and sensors in the detectors gather up the particle debris and analyze it.
If the energy in a supercollider fireball is great enough, physicists hope to detect ripples in a hypothetical all-pervading medium they call the "Higgs Field," a field they compare with the familiar electromagnetic field. Just as photons cause ripples in the electromagnetic field, the passage of predicted supermassive particles called Higgs bosons would cause ripples in the Higgs Field, which may be detectable by the supercollider.
The Higgs Field, theorists speculate, interacts with material objects in such a way as to give them mass and the stronger the interaction is, the more massive the object. Why anything has mass, and why fundamental atomic particles like protons and electrons have the specific masses they do, is one of the great unsolved riddles of science.
 
Differentiating Forces
 In the Big Bang, theorists believe, all the separate forces that govern the physical world today, electromagnetism and the strong and weak nuclear forces and probably gravity as well, were indistinguishable. But as the universe cooled, the different forces "froze out" of their primeval matrix. By reproducing conditions as they were at the instant of the great "symmetry-breaking" between the forces of nature, physicists hope to replay their separation and to understand the nature of their parent matrix, the universal giver of mass.
But aside from their confidence that profoundly important discoveries will be possible with the supercollider, Dr. Schwitters and other high-energy physicists have no clear idea what will turn up.
The miniature fireballs produced by the machine might spawn a fairly simple Higgs boson, the discovery of which would confirm the validity of the Standard Model. This is the generally accepted theory explaining matter in terms of six types of quarks found in such composite particles as protons, six types of leptons like electrons and neutrinos and four types of force carriers: the photons of electromagnetism, the W and Z particles of the weak force, the gluons of the strong force and the hypothetical Higgs bosons.
On the other hand, it might turn out that there are several or many different types of Higgs particles.
 
Possibly a 'Fifth Force'
 Or it may be that the only one of the six quark types that has never been discovered, the "top" quark, is itself responsible for the masses of the particles making up ordinary matter.
Some physicists believe that the supercollider may disclose the existence of a "Fifth Force," a force that underlies all the others but is undetectable except under conditions like those of the infant universe or a supercollider proton collision.
Another set of discoveries might reveal the existence of internal structure in particles that are now considered fundamental and therefore monolithic.
When protons are smashed together at combined energies of 40 trillion electronvolts, the collisions of their constituent quarks occur at energies reaching 2 trillion electronvolts. This might be high enough to reveal if the quark itself has some kind of internal structure. The long history of physics has opened up successive layers of matter within matter like nested Russian dolls, and although no structure has ever been detected in quarks or leptons, the reason may be only that they have not been smashed together hard enough.
 
Aid to Astrophysics
 Experiments using the supercollider can also enrich theoretical astrophysics in several ways, its supporters say. By reproducing conditions just after the birth of the universe, it might be possible, for example, to determine the amount and type of "dark matter" that was created. The hunt for dark matter, which is undetectable directly but which can sometimes be inferred from the gravitational distortions it causes in the passage of light beams, is a major preoccupation of astrophysicists. Depending on how much matter of all kinds the universe contains, both visible and dark matter, it might go on expanding forever, or it might slow to a halt or begin contracting.
But all this may have to await another generation or another century. Accelerator experts agree that the supercollider, if it is built, will certainly be the largest such instrument built by a single nation, and that any more ambitious scientific enterprise could be supported only by an international consortium. If the supercollider is stillborn, organizing an international effort to replace it would be difficult if not impossible in the near future.
"We're now going through the most dangerous period the S.S.C. project has ever faced," Dr. Schwitters said. "We hope our Government will bear in mind that the S.S.C. will cost no more than two nuclear submarines, but it will give the human race knowledge of enduring value."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Discoveries the Supercollider Could Make"
 
1. Higgs Bosons
Physicists do not know why matter has mass, but according to the Standard Model theory, super-heavy particles called Higgs bosons may confer mass. If such particles exist, the Supercolliding Supercollider may be able to find them.
 
 2. The Top Quark
The Standard Model theory holds that there are six families of quarks--the entities of which nuclear particles as protons and neutrons are composed. Of the six quark types only one, known as the top quark, remains to be discovered. If existing accelerators fail to find it, the supercollider may succeed.
 
 3. Particle Structure
Physicists assume that the quarks and leptons that constitute all matter are not thesmelves composed of still smaller particles. This assumption may be wrong. If so, the supercollider may detect these smaller particles.
 
 4. A Fifth Force
The four forces of nature known to physicists are electromagnetism, gravity, and the strong and weak nuclear forces. But if quarks and leptons have internal structure, a fifth force must exist to hold their components together. The supercollider may bring it to light.
 
 5. Symmetry Breaking
The Big Bang produced nearly equal amounts of matter and antimatter which annihilated each other, leaving a small residue of matter from which today's universe was built. The production of this excess of matter may be explained if the supercollider can recreate the primordial soup in which the symmetry of matter and antimatter was broken.
 
 6. New Physics
Best of all, the supercollider may discover entirely new particles or principles that no one has predicted. (pg. C8)

HEADLINE: Case for Other Pre-Columbian Voyagers

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

 BODY:
COLUMBUS, it sometimes seems, was the LAST of the discoverers to find his way to America.
At a conference here three weeks ago on "America Before Columbus," archeologists and an assortment of inspired amateurs recently paraded intriguing fragments of evidence, clues from linguistics and art, and botany and pottery, suggesting Old World influences on the New World centuries before 1492. 
 If there is anything to these alternative-discovery theories, the Atlantic was crossed before Leif Eriksson or Columbus by the Irish, Libyans, Trojans and possibly even some second-century Jews escaping Roman persecution. Also, the Chinese, Japanese and perhaps other Asians supposedly traveled the Pacific to reach pre-Columbian America.
Dr. Nancy Yaw Davis, an anthropologist from Alaska, described the conference as "a playground of ideas" stemming from new research and discoveries showing that "creative mixing of people and cultures occurred earlier in America and more often than originally thought."
 
Contact With Japanese?
 Indeed, scholars say the support for some trans-Pacific encounters seems to be growing stronger. In 1956, pieces of 5,000-year-old pottery were found on the Pacific coast of Ecuador. Their designs bore an uncanny resemblance to pottery produced in southern Japan at about the same period.
Though other experts have raised objections, Dr. Betty J. Meggers, an anthropologist at the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Natural History, said they had failed to give a plausible explanation for the detailed similarities . She said trans-Pacific contact remains the simplest and most persuasive explanation.
Partisans imagine that 5,000 years ago, some Japanese fishermen were blown east in a storm and rode the prevailing current off the Aleutian Islands, down the coast of North America and all the way to Ecuador. Japanese adventurers re-created such a 9,000-mile voyage in 1980.
Likewise, Dr. Stephen C. Jett, a geography professor at the University of California at Davis, reported "striking similarities" of textile designs, dyestuffs and coloring techniques to suggest pre-Columbian connections between southern Asia and coastal Peru.
 
Ears of Corn in India?
 The contacts may even have gone both ways. Showing detailed pictures of 700-year-old temple art from India, Dr. Carl L. Johannessen, a geography professor at the University of Oregon, pointed out many examples of what appeared to be ears of corn. Corn, or maize, was supposedly unknown outside America until after Columbus.
Dr. Davis advanced the hypothesis that the Zuni Indians of New Mexico were distinctive in language, culture and biology, compared with other Indians, partly because they may have come in contact with Japanese in the 13th century. She noted similarities between the Zuni and the Japanese in blood chemistry and some basic words. Even the Zuni migration stories, she said, were suggestive in their description of the trek of a distinctive people from the "ocean of the sunset world" in search of the true middle of the world.
"I'm not saying the Zuni are Japanese," Dr. Davis said, "but they may include influences from Japan at a particular time."
From the audience arose Joseph Dishta, head councilman of the Zuni tribe in New Mexico.
"We do not endorse this theory," Mr. Dishta said. "We have our own interpretation. We always feel we've been in that part of the country since time immemorial. We feel we emerged from the mother earth."
If the Japanese found their way to the Zuni, could Jewish refugees from the Roman Empire have made it to the eastern mountains of Tennessee in the second century? At least that is the meaning a few researchers read in an inscribed stone found a century ago with nine skeletons in a burial mound at Bat Creek in Tennessee.
For years, the inscription was interpreted as a message in Cherokee. When Dr. Cyrus H. Gordon, retired professor of Mediterranean studies at Brandeis University, had a look, he decided the engraving was actually in Hebrew and similar to writings found on Hebrew coins of the first and second centuries. Carbon dating shows the burial took place between the years 32 and 769.
At the conference, Dr. J. Huston McCulloch, an economist at Ohio State University who has become a leading exponent of the Jewish connection to Bat Creek, defended the stone's antiquity and the Jewish interpretation against recent attacks by professional anthropologists. He discounted the possibility of a hoax.
The three-day conference, held on the campus of Brown University, was organized by the New England Antiquities Research Association, a group started in 1964 by amateur archeologists to study the origins of enigmatic stone structures found throughout New England.
"We are open-minded about all points of view," said Donald Gilmore, a retired Foreign Service officer and director of the association. "We shouldn't ignore evidence that there were pre-Columbian contacts and these could have influenced pre-Columbian cultures."

HEADLINE: Norsemen In America Flourished Then Faded

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

 BODY:
FIVE centuries before Columbus, the Norse sailed west across the North Atlantic in search of new lands that were, in the words of their sagas, "habitable and trespassable." They established a colony in Greenland, then moved on to the coast of North America, where they became a long disputed footnote to the history of discovery.
By now, five centuries after the first Columbus voyage of 1492, scholars agree that the Norse got to the New World much earlier and achieved a substantial foothold. Archeologists believe they have firm evidence for at least one settlement in Newfoundland around the time of Leif Eriksson, in the early 11th century. The mystery now is why the Norse failed to sustain their American enterprise. 
 Widening their search, archeologists have also found iron nails, pieces of armor, figurines and other artifacts suggesting a Norse presence in Ellesmere and Baffin Islands to the north and perhaps as far south as Maine. Their visits may have been brief, to hunt and trade or to plunder, but they apparently continued them for several hundred years, almost up to the time of Columbus.
So it raises again the question, who did "discover" America?
Of course, ancestors of the Indians and Eskimos were the first inhabitants, having crossed from Asia thousands of years before. Circumstantial evidence, tenuous at best, is advanced from time to time in support of pre-Columbian contacts by the Chinese and Japanese across the Pacific and the Irish, Welsh, Phoenicians, Jews and Africans across the Atlantic.
Even if the Norse almost certainly preceded Columbus, historians argue, their influence on subsequent American history was inconsequential. Scholars generally credit Columbus with the true discovery, even if he seems never to have been sure where he was, for the reason that his exploits had the immediate and lasting effect of incorporating the Americas into world history.
"Yes, the Norse were here first, but apart from some ethnic pride, so what?" said Dr. Thomas H. McGovern, an archeologist at Hunter College of the City University of New York who is an authority on the cultural and economic aspects of the Norse explorations. "Historically, it didn't make any big difference."
Still, the Norse experience fascinates historians and archeologists, in part because it was so widespread but ephemeral, and it is being examined more systematically by a broader range of experts. New efforts to confirm Norse activities in America are being financed by a Danish businessman, Jorgen D. Siemonsen, who directs an international committee of scientists.
Under the guidance of Dr. McGovern, scholars from 10 countries met in January to establish the North Atlantic Biocultural Organization to promote and coordinate more rigorous investigations of the social and economic dynamics of the Norse ventures.
 
Looking for Cause of Failure
 As the new findings lend credence to the folk tales of adventure in the Icelandic Sagas, scholars are moving beyond simply verifying a Norse presence and are increasingly interested in identifying the likely causes of the ultimate Norse failure to plant permanent roots in America.
According to the sagas, the Norse first glimpsed the American coast when their ships were blown off course while sailing to their colony in Greenland. Leif Eriksson, son of Erik the Red, the outlaw from Norway and Iceland who founded the Greenland settlement, scouted out the coast, probably crossing the Davis Strait from Greenland, a distance of no more than 200 miles, and catching the south-flowing Labrador Current. The explorers came first to a rocky shore they called Helluland, which is probably present-day Baffin Island, and then to the wooded coast of a placed they named Markland, probably Labrador. Finally, Eriksson reached the land he would call Vinland, a place now assumed to be Newfoundland.
There, in about the year 1000, Eriksson built a settlement of large houses to serve as a base for commerce and exploration deeper into this new land. Other settlers arrived, including Leif's brother Thorvald. In what may have been the first skirmish between Europeans and the American natives, Thorvald was killed by an arrow.
In the sagas, when Thorvald drew out the fatal arrow, he had these last words: "There is fat round my belly! We have won a fine and fruitful country, but will hardly be allowed to enjoy it."
The case for a Norse presence in North America gained respectability in the 1960's with the discovery of the remains of an 11th century settlement at L'Anse aux Meadows, on a northern finger of the island of Newfoundland. A Norwegian explorer, Helge Ingstad, came upon the building remains, and he and his wife, the archeologist Anne Stine Ingstad, led an team of archeologists that excavated the collapsed sod walls of eight buildings, a forge, hearths and other ruins of the settlement.
"We know it is a Norse site," said Dr. William W. Fitzhugh, an anthropologist with the Smithsonian Institution. "The question is, whose site is it? Leif Eriksson's, perhaps?"
Dr. Birgitta L. Wallace, an archeologist with the Canadian Parks Service in Halifax, Nova Scotia, completed a comprehensive study of the site last year. The settlement, she concluded, was probably occupied for no more than five or 10 years, with a population of about 100. A soapstone spindle whorl, used in spinning, suggests that not all the Norse settlers were men.
 
Only One Settlement Found
 Also found in the excavations were whole butternuts, which have never grown as far north as Newfoundland. Dr. Wallace cited this as evidence that L'Anse aux Meadows was a gateway settlement, the staging area or winter camp for explorations to the south, especially in the St. Lawrence region that may have been Vinland proper. The settlers presumably shipped lumber back to Greenland, where there was virtually no timber and the forests of Europe were too far away.
L'Anse aux Meadows is still the only Norse settlement ever found on the North American coast, and the prospect of discovering others seems bleak. From archeological evidence the Greenland colony's population in the 11th century may have been no more than 600. Dr. Wallace said it was doubtful that the small colony could have supported another American outpost the size of the one in Newfoundland.
Although archeologists might find remains of later settlements, perhaps from the 14th century when the Greenland colony had grown to about 7,000 people, their searches so far have turned up only isolated bits and pieces of Norse material buried at the sites of early Indian or Eskimo camps. While Eskimos lived in northern Greenland, there is no evidence of trading by them or by Indians in the southern part of the island until after the Norse had settled there. Anthropologists cannot be sure if the artifacts indicate the extent of Norse travels in North America, or if many of them reached the native populations through trade networks many times removed from the original Norse sources.
Archeologists suspect this is how a Norse penny minted in about 1065 came to be in the remains of an Indian camp at Blue Hill Bay near Brooklin , Me. Dr. Bruce J. Bourque, archeologist at the Maine State Museum in Augusta, said that since no other Norse artifacts were found at the site, the assumption was made that the penny reached the site through trade with other Indians from the north. There is no telling how many Indian hands it had passed through or how many hundreds of miles it had traveled after it had left a Norse pocket. The coin is perforated as if it had been used as a pendant.
 
Penny Called Authentic
 As a specialist in Norse archeology, Dr. Bourque has examined many faked artifacts, including inscribed stones being passed off as ancient Norse runes where the symbols were so freshly scratched that dust remained in the lines. But he and other experts who examined the penny proclaimed its authenticity. Further excavations at the site are being proposed to look for more clues to the penny's provenance.
Even if the coin is only indirect evidence of Norse activity, archeologists said it showed that they were still traveling to North America in the late 11th century, or even later. The scattering of other artifacts, Dr. Wallace said, is important evidence that the Norse in Greenland maintained trade and other contact with North America for almost 500 years.
They apparently had their longest and most active contact with aboriginal people known as the Thule Eskimos. In the Thule village sites on Ellesmere Island in the high Arctic, Dr. Peter Schledermann, an archeologist at the University of Calgary, has picked up fragments of chain mail armor, pieces of woolen cloth, knife blades of smelted iron, iron boat rivets and other iron and copper pieces.
On Baffin Island, explorers have found iron and bronze objects thought to be Norse and a figurine carved in the Eskimo style. It depicts someone dressed in a long robe slit up the front and with a cross incised on the chest. The costume resembles no known Eskimo clothing and is more like a cloaked bishop of the Norse period.
 
Travels to Eastern Arctic
 "It's definitely a native carving by someone who had seen a Norseman or had one described," Dr. Fitzhugh said. "From these artifacts it does seem the Norse were more heavily involved in the eastern Arctic than indicated in the sagas, which mention only a few voyages."
Dr. Fitzhugh is studying the 16th-century camps of the English navigator Martin Frobisher, who made a vain search for a possible Northwest Passage across the Arctic to Asia. Among the strangest remains at the site, on Frobisher Bay, are some loaf-shaped iron ingots. They are a mystery because carbon dating indicates that they were smelted hundreds of years before one of Frobisher's expeditions. The Indians and Eskimos presumably lacked the skill to make them. Perhaps the Norse made the ingots and Frobisher found them. No one knows.
Though claims have been made for Norse expeditions as far south as the Chesapeake Bay or even Florida, most experts doubt that they ever ranged south of the Canadian Maritime Provinces or had anything to do with an enigmatic stone tower in Newport, R.I. The tower has some similarities to Norse buildings, prompting local legends, but scholars believe it goes back no further than the 17th century.
Investigation of the Newport Tower is one of seven research projects being supported by Mr. Siemonsen, the Danish businessman, who has sailed some of the Norse routes and says he wants to sort out fact from fantasy in the legends. New tests developed in Finland, he said, may make it possible to establish the age of the mortar and plaster in the tower.
Other new research includes an examination of well-preserved timbers from a Norse farmstead excavated in Greenland two years ago. Determining the type and age of the timber could yield its source, which could possibly be the forests of Labrador.
Scientists at the University of Copenhagen and the Danish Geological Survey are analyzing coal found at another Greenland site. It is a type of anthracite coal unknown in Greenland, Iceland or Norway. Comparisons are being made to see if it might have come from Wales or even Rhode Island or Pennsylvania.
In more than two decades of study, Dr. McGovern has identified several factors contributing to the decline of the Norse in Greenland and to the west. The Greenland colony never developed the economic strength to support itself or the American outposts, and Norway's interest diminished as it developed more ties with Europe.
"Norse who wanted a new life could try Normandy, Sicily, Northumberland, Ireland or Vinland," Dr. McGovern noted. "Which would you choose?"
The coming of the Little Ice Age in the late 14th century brought a sharp climate change that was probably devastating to the Norse farms and livestock on Greenland, as well as Vinland if they were still in operation. While the Eskimos spread and prospered as hunters, Dr. McGovern said, the Norse failed to adapt to the chill. They were "nailed down with their investment in domestic animals and a more sedentary medieval European society," he said. They also suffered because they never developed a harpoon for seal hunting, as had the Eskimos. This limited them to hunting only certain species in certain seasons.
"It's not impossible to imagine," Dr. McGovern remarked, "that the Norse presence was ending at the very time Columbus was setting sail in 1492."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At L'Anse aux Meadows, Newfoundland, a a Norse sod house has been recreated, top, near the site (J. Steeves; B. Schonback); Norse coin minted around 1065 was found at Indian camp at Blue Hill Bay, Me. It may have been used in trade (Maine State Museum); A soapstone spindle, used in spinning, was unearthed at the 11th-century Norse L'Anse aux Meadows site in Newfoundland. (J. Bird) (pg. C10)
 
Map/Drawings: "Traces of an Ephemeral Discovery"
 Archeologists are now confident that the Norse had a firm but temporary foothold in North America, one that they kept for centuries, almost to the time of Columbus. The question now, the researchers say, is why they did not build on it. Based on the artifacts that have been found, their presence seems to have been small but widespread. In Newfoundland, the remains of a substantial village at L'Anse aux Meadows suggest it was a center for further explorations to the south. But it is still the only Norse settlement ever found on the North American coast.
 
Intriguing fragments
On Ellesmere Island, pieces of chain mail armor are among the artifacts that hint of a Norse presence. On Baffin Island, a figurine carved in Eskimo style resembles a cloaked bishop of the Norse period. The long robe, slit in front, and the cross are unlike Eskimo clothing.
 
Hints and doubts
A Norse penny could have reached a site in Maine through Indian trade. The "Norse" Newport Tower in Rhode Island is probably no earlier than
 the 1600's.
 
Routes of the Sagas
The poets say Leif Eriksson's ships came first to rocky Helluland, probably present-day Baffin Island, then to the wooded coast of Markland, probably Labrador, and finally Vinland, now assumed to be Newfoundland. From there, forays may have reached as far south as Maine.
 (Sources: Maine State Museum; Newport County Convention and Visitors
 Bureau; National Geographic; Canadian Parks Service) (pg. C1)

HEADLINE: Q&A

BYLINE: By C. CLAIBORNE RAY

 BODY:

Skyscrapers
Q. How long will skyscrapers last?
A. "If they are properly maintained, they will last forever," said C. R. (Chuck) Pennoni, president of the American Society of Civil Engineers. 
 After proper design, the key is the integrity of the materials, said Mr. Pennoni, who was trained as a structural engineer. Steel or concrete can be damaged by things like acid rain, he said, but if damaged material is replaced, the building will survive.
If a structure like the World Trade Center were abandoned and not maintained at all, the first thing to go would probably be the curtain wall, the skin of the building, Mr. Pennoni said. As it was weathered by rain, pieces would probably start to fall off, he said. However, Mr. Pennoni estimated that it would probably take 25 to 50 years for the core to be affected.
Massive buildings of masonry may have a longer lease on life than those with a glass skin, he suggested, but advances in sealants and other materials and techniques mean modern buildings may have more staying power.
Mr. Pennoni said that except for disaster damage from things like earthquakes and fires, the reason buildings come down is often economic, because there is no money for maintenance or because the real estate is too valuable for the structure that is on it. "In a throw-away economy, we throw away buildings, too," he said.
 
Eating Like a Bird
 Q. How do pigeons feed their young?
A. Rock doves, which are common city pigeons, and the rest of the pigeon family produce a substance called pigeon's milk, said Todd Culver, an ornithologist at the Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology in Ithaca, N.Y.
It is actually a secretion of the stomach lining, he explained. "The living cells of the crop lining slough off, and adults regurgitate a white milk-like substance that is extremely high in fat and protein, the perfect thing to feed young squabs," he said.
It is similar in content to mammalian milk, he said.

HEADLINE: Russia Has Earned Its Reward

 BODY:
What a difference a year makes: Just that long ago, President Mikhail Gorbachev of the Soviet Union went to the economic summit meeting of the seven industrial democracies asking for aid, vaguely promising to launch market reforms. Now President Boris Yeltsin of Russia will go before the same group, meeting in Munich, also to ask for aid. But he comes with more than promises. Russia has adopted astonishingly radical reforms.
Until the past few days the West had reacted more with promises of its own than with cash. Last spring it promised $24 billion as soon as Russia and the International Monetary Fund could work out a feasible reform package. But the fund dithered, unwilling to take a prudent chance on the Yeltsin Government. 
 Finally, on Friday, under pressure from the Bush Administration, Michel Camdessus, director of the I.M.F., flew to Russia and then announced an agreement -- over the seeming objections of his staff and just in time for Mr. Yeltsin's trip to Munich.
President Bush deserves credit for turning the I.M.F. around. He understands that the West's self-interest lies in supporting Mr. Yeltsin's heroic efforts. The important task is to provide some instant relief, to get Russia through current turmoil and use the next several months to negotiate the unresolved differences over the details. This weekend, Mr. Camdessus got the message.
Just since January Mr. Yeltsin has decontrolled most prices, cut the deficit by an astonishing 75 percent and pushed through a bill that will eventually privatize most state-owned enterprises. The fund has applauded these measures but still fears, justifiably, that Russia is printing rubles freely, at a rate that will trigger ruinous inflation.
One reason for all the new rubles is the Government's continuing subsidies of oil at below-market prices.
A second reason is to pay for credits that state-owned enterprises have extended one another when they ran out of cash. Finally, the I.M.F. fears that Russia can't by itself rein in the supply of rubles because central banks in the other republics can, in effect, print their own.
These threats are grave. But the answer -- as the Bush Administration understands -- isn't to sit idly by as the Russian economy collapses. The answer is engagement, which the I.M.F. announcement now finally accepts.
Russia will get $1 billion immediately, which may lead some of the Western powers meeting in Munich to release more of the promised $24 billion in aid. The remainder will await the outcome of further negotiations over oil prices and other inducements to print money.
For all this to work, the Western governments will have to keep the heat on the I.M.F. The fund's staff seems more committed to protecting itself from criticism than to helping Russia complete its radical reforms.
The goal, as Secretary of State James Baker says, is to strike a workable, not a perfect, deal. It's still far from clear whether the I.M.F. knows the difference.

HEADLINE: Mr. Marino's Petulant Walkout

 BODY:
No sooner had New York's Legislature performed the unusual feat of passing this year's state budget almost on schedule than it slid right back into its bad habit of shirking responsibility. The lawmakers actually packed up and left Albany last week without voting on several pieces of critical legislation.
Unless they return, the public won't have a chance to vote in November on an $800 million bond act designed to create jobs and spur economic development; Nassau and Suffolk counties won't get a chance to bail themselves out of fiscal trouble, and other bills that merit attention won't get any. Lawmakers cannot allow the impasse to continue. They have an obligation to go back to work. 
 The chief cause of Albany's gridlock is a Republican, Ralph Marino of Long Island, the Senate majority leader. Mr. Marino, furious that Gov. Mario Cuomo was playing politics with Nassau's and Suffolk's requests for permission to borrow money, got into a shouting match with a Cuomo ally, Saul Weprin, the Assembly Speaker and a voice of legislative reason, then stalked out of Albany. The session's sputtering close left several pieces of legislation unresolved.
Mr. Cuomo was indeed trying to horse-trade. But why would traditional political jockeying surprise and infuriate an Albany veteran like Mr. Marino? If he continues to let bitterness get in his way, Mr. Marino will wind up hurting the very people he wants to protect -- Long Islanders.
The counties say they need to borrow about $190 million combined or will have to raise taxes, lay off workers and cut services. The Governor questions the need for borrowing, and certainly it should only be a last resort. But both counties insist it is necessary, and he will likely go along if Mr. Marino agrees to independent fiscal oversight and supports the bond act and other worthy measures.
The Legislature left town without acting on such important bills as a trust fund for environmental protection and the Governor's sensible plan for state takeover of Medicaid's soaring local costs. Those and other pieces of legislation left in limbo deserve support, once Mr. Marino cools off and returns to his job.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
China's Black Book

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Long before the extermination camps, the world knew that Hitler's basic instruments of power were torture and murder.
Only shortly after the Germans elevated him to office, "black books" were published in the West -- detailed reports of the flogging, genital tortures, deaths by suffocation carried out routinely in Gestapo prisons. 
 From then on, the nations knew their ambassadors were accredited to a regime from hell and their businessmen were buying its products.
Most people did little or nothing until the war. But some did. They too acknowledged the truth and fought it -- with their voices, however lonely, with whatever economic and political strength they had, however small.
After World War II the underground writings of the Soviet freedom fighters told the world about the Soviet gulag. Most people did little or nothing. But some did. They acknowledged the truth and fought with whatever energy and power they had.
Now, black books are published again. They are about another national system of torture and murder -- the Chinese Communist gulag, where every day of every year 16 to 20 million men and women labor and suffer in slavery.
They live -- they exist -- in a world of torture, starvation and humiliation meticulously planned to create greater profit through greater production for the Communist Government. We are the customers.
Recently I wrote about a report on China's slave laborers -- "Laogai: The Chinese Gulag," by Hongda Harry Wu. He spent 19 years in the slave camps. I could not escape that book and cannot escape another on my table. It is about the hundreds of prisons in the huge province of Hunan. "Anthems of Defeat" is reported with documentation, statistical tables, notes and names by Tang Bogiao, a Chinese dissident.
Mr. Tang was moved from prison to prison and has compiled this annotated encyclopedia of evil. It is published by Asia Watch (212-972-8400).
All prisoners received trials -- without confrontation of witnesses or pleas of innocence permitted.
Prof. Peng Yuzhang, in his 70's, was sent to Changsa No. 1 jail for backing student sit-ins. He was placed on the "shackle board," a door-sized plank with shackles for hands and feet and a hole for defecation. Chained to the board, he would sing encouragement to student prisoners he could not see. Sometimes he would cry out, "I need a bath."
Professor Peng remained on the board for three months. Then he was sent to a psychiatric asylum. Is he alive?
The shackle board was just one form of punishment. Other commonplaces:
Torture with electric prods. Public whippings to the blood. Forced boot-licking. Chaining, face on cell floor, arms around toilet buckets in use through the night by other prisoners.
A dozen kinds of hand and ankle cuffs, sometimes with iron rods between them to make movement almost impossible. Multiple fetters to shackle prisoners tightly together. "Martial arts" -- guards kicking prisoners into unconsciousness.
Solitary confinement in metal boxes so small prisoners can neither lie down properly nor stand up straight. "Electric shackle treatment" -- shock applied through hand and ankle cuffs, often while the victim is chained to the shackle board.
Prisoners who do not fill work quotas are punished by all these tortures, by starvation diets, and by extended sentences. By official Communist policy their work is considered an essential part of Chinese export.
So we know -- no escape. What can we do? American laws against forced labor imports are sieves. But stockholders can raise the issue at company meetings. Are we selling slave labor goods, or using our pension funds, to help the torturers? Please investigate and report back fully .
Before we buy, we can ask shopkeepers to find out from their vendors what "made in China" means -- made where, by whom?
President Bush has vetoed every Congressional attempt to apply mild economic sanctions to the Chinese Communists. This battle will not end, whoever is elected President.
Meantime will all the delegates at the Republican and Democratic Conventions remain mute about slavery and torture in China? Will Ross Perot? Or will they cleanse themselves of silence -- at least some of them?

HEADLINE: Conservatives: Beware Perot

BYLINE: By Pete du Pont; Pete du Pont, Governor of Delaware from 1977 to 1985, is chairman of the Committee for Republican Leadership.

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del.

 BODY:
As a conservative who has watched low taxes and restrained Government spending and interference create the world's strongest economy, and who sought the Presidency on these principles in 1988, I urge fellow conservatives to be wary of Ross Perot's candidacy.
I understand why Mr. Perot is receiving such attention. The Bush Administration has given most voters, those who helped the Republicans to three landslide victories in the 1980's, the impression that the principles that fueled those triumphs are open to negotiation and easy dismissal. 
 While conservatives may not see President Bush as the most diligent protector of Ronald Reagan's legacy, I support him for re-election because he understands the policies that made the 1980's prosperous and his goal is to re-create that prosperity. Conversely, Mr. Perot has joined the noisy anti-Reagan minority that sees the 1980's as a problem to be overcome rather than a model to be studied.
Let's take four examples of Mr. Perot's economic thinking: industrial policy, taxation, trade and his analysis of the dairy industry.
First, Mr. Perot favors an industrial policy. He wants the Government to be able to tell the private sector how to plan its future. He denies that he holds this position, but his denial is implausible given his expressions of admiration for Japan's industrial-policy power base, the Ministry of Trade and Industry -- a Government cartel that runs the country's economy. America does not need government cartels telling us what to do.
Second, he is a protectionist. USA Today reported that Mr. Perot "wants to tighten quotas and restrictions on imported goods to match those placed on American goods by other countries." He opposes the North American Free Trade Agreement, suggesting that the agreement with Mexico would virtually destroy every employer in America. But we know that trade increases the wealth of both the importer and exporter; we know that free trade increases, not decreases, our prosperity. We need more free trade agreements, not fewer.
Third, Mr. Perot will raise taxes. "You bet we've got to raise taxes," he said in 1987. Last week on ABC's "Town Meeting" he added: "Let's assume that we're just unable to pay our bills, unable to meet our obligations, we have to raise our taxes." But then again he says he wants the voters to be able to pass a tax increase by plebiscite, never mind that the Constitution gives that power to Congress. Surely, national tax referendums would be the chaotic prelude to annual debates on "deficit-reducing" taxes -- all to be imposed on someone else, of course.
Finally, there is Mr. Perot's curious yet significant answer to a caller on NBC's "Today" last month who inquired about his plans to help dairy farmers. Mr. Perot began by restating the proposition that dairy farmers are a beleaguered lot. The fact is that the average net cash income of a commercial dairy farm in 1990 was $83,000. He then went on to claim that the farmers have no clout in Washington. That must have stunned even the dairy farmers, who in the 1991-1992 election cycle have contributed more than $1.5 million to their political-action committees -- among the richest and most influential of them all, and who have seen beneficial farm bills routinely enacted.
But it is the philosophy behind the words that should scare conservatives. Regardless of the dearth of factual understanding in his answers, Mr. Perot betrayed the way he thinks. When asked to comment on the economic status of one sector of the U.S. economy, his assumption was that it was flat on its back and, worse, that the way to get it on its feet was to tell it to get some clout and go to Washington. That is a Big Government formula that should give pause to every American. But it should terrify any self-respecting conservative.

HEADLINE: Observer;
The Misery's Fine

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
Sometimes I infuriate myself. Just the other day, for instance. On television selling a book I was, but too much the gentleman, too much the eleventh-rate salesman, alas, to look the camera dead in the eye and say:
"My book will not only make you smell better, relieve your headache, transform dingy yellow teeth to gleaming white and add five miles per gallon to your gas mileage, it will also make you live twice as long while enjoying twice as much happiness and getting twice as young every year." 
 Instead, with mouth rattling along completely free of brain control -- television cameras always do this to me -- I started talking about America's anger. Why was the country so filled with anger? What in the world did Americans have to be furious about?
It had just prevailed in the 45-year cold war. The threat of nuclear holocaust was suspended. Stores were overflowing. The choice of entertainments was infinite. There were millions of cars to carry Americans wherever whim or necessity dictated. There was easy access to deadly weapons for every temperament, be it sporting, criminal, political, entrepreneurial, suicidal, self-pitying, paranoidal or just plain fun-loving.
Moreover, Americans could worship such gods as they chose, or none if they chose. And what about other people from all over the world risking everything to get here? If the place was really such a hate-filled sinkhole, why were foreigners dying to get here?
I hate to hear people talking like this, and afterward I hated myself for having done it. It is un-American. Misery is the new American condition, and making a loud noise about your misery is now the most American thing you can do, having replaced washing your car on Saturday afternoon.
Remember when you could sing that old spiritual, "Nobody Knows the Trouble I've Seen," and mean it? Not anymore. Nowadays everybody knows the trouble you've seen. That's because you've told them.
You probably told them at the top of your lungs, too, maybe out in the streets screaming it to television cameras or even inside a TV studio shouting it on a misery panel to some competitive boaster who claims his troubles have been worse than yours. There is so much competition for the misery championship these days that you have to scream to remain a contender.
Thoreau wrote 150 years ago that most people lead "lives of quiet desperation." What an antique idea. Nowadays most people lead lives of noisy desperation, and if you're not shrieking your laments you will be dismissed as a mere flyweight in the misery department.
What we're seeing is a competition to be Number One in Pain and Suffering, to win a statuette for Most Victimized, or Most Oppressed, or Most Forgotten, or Most Abused, or Most Unfairly Treated, or Most Tax-Ridden, or Most Bureaucracy-Persecuted, or Most Medically Ill Treated, or Most Telephonically Violated, or Most Supreme-Court-Deprived . . .
The fact, of course, is that contrary to the whine that everything was better in the old days, almost everything was actually much worse in the old days. True, the old days weren't afflicted with the telephone, much less the fax, but they didn't have air-conditioning either, or the electric car crank, or television, or unemployment compensation, or Social Security, or overnight dry-cleaning, or movies right there in the parlor alongside the cast-iron woodstove with the isinglass windows.
Easy now with those poisonous pens, ye angry millions: I am not saying we ought to count our blessings instead of whining, moaning and wailing it up. It's natural for each new generation of modern times to think it is born into the worst of times. This may even promote happiness. In a century that has lost its certainty about the purpose of life, it can be comforting to believe you are needed to do hero's work.
Deprived so abruptly of the cold war's "long twilight struggle" between heroes and monsters, we haven't found much in the way of a new heroic task to pick us up. Perhaps this fascination with our own troubles is a healthy omen, portending a real effort to use this quiet time to neaten up the American act. Omen or not, it beats washing the car on Saturday afternoon.

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MUNICH;
LEADERS IN MUNICH WARN RIVAL FORCES IN BOSNIAN STRIFE

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MUNICH, Germany, July 7

 BODY:
The leaders of seven major industrial democracies warned the belligerents in Bosnia and Herzegovina today that they would support United Nations-backed military action if it became necessary to get aid through to civilians in Sarajevo and other parts of the war-torn country.
The leaders issued a strong warning to the leaders of Serbia and of the armies it controls that further fighting was unacceptable. Resurgent nationalism and ethnic tensions there and in parts of the former Soviet Union, they said, were causing "death, destruction, and widespread dislocation of innocent people." 
 Joined by the head of the European Community, the leaders also raised the possibility of convening a United Nations peace conference to address the underlying ethnic and national causes of the worst fighting in Europe since World War II.
Shelling continued there today, and the Bosnian President renewed an appeal to President Bush to attack the Serbian forces and supply the Bosnians with arms and ammunition. [Page A8.]
 
A Palace in Munich
 As they met in the elegant surroundings of the Wittelsbach dynasty's royal palace in the Bavarian capital, the seven leaders, from the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Italy, Britain and Canada, were also trying to find ways, and money, to prevent social and economic problems in the newly independent Russia from breaking out into similar violence.
Russia's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, joined them for dinner tonight and will make a pitch for more aid and a debt moratorium on Wednesday afternoon, after they end the formal summit meeting and issue a communique on economic issues.
On talks on a new global trade agreement, stalled for more than two years, the seven continued to seek a breakthrough after years of squabbling about agricultural subsidies.
 
'Much, Much Closer'
 "I'm of the view that we're much, much closer to a conclusion than we were five weeks ago," Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said this afternoon, adding that he thought the leaders would probably agree on Wednesday to stronger language than at the last two of this group's annual gatherings. In each of the past two years, they said an agreement was essential to the health of the world economy and pledged every effort to achieve it by the end of the year.
Before Mr. Yeltsin's arrival, the leaders welcomed the "new partnership" that the collapse of Communism and the Soviet Union had made possible between East and West.
"Partnership will flourish as common values take root, based on the principles of political and economic freedom, human rights, democracy, justice and the rule of law," they said in the political declaration issued today. "Good governance and respect for human rights are important criteria in providing economic assistance."
 
Strife in the East
 But they were clearly preoccupied with the darker side of change, not only in the western Balkans but also in Nagorno-Karabakh, Moldova, and Ossetia, former Soviet territories where nationalities have clashed violently over conflicting territorial claims.
There was concern over their failure so far to prevent war in what was Yugoslavia, and talk in the corridors and by members of national delegations of using air and sea forces to blockade it and send in ground forces if necessary to break the Serbian siege of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Mr. Baker repeated today that he did not believe that American troops should go into Bosnia and Herzegovina.
 
'A Quagmire Potential'
 "There is a quagmire potential," he said, "but there is a real problem that must be addressed."
Asked what the United States thought of a French suggestion that troops of the nine-nation Western European Union, instead of NATO, might be used, Mr. Baker said it would probably be up to the United Nations to decide, but added, "It will be a case of making the most efficient and best use of the assets of these organizations."
Barbara McDougall, the Canadian Foreign Minister, said there had been "serious discussion" among the seven of how to block oil supplies from coming into Serbia from Romania by pipeline, which is happening despite the United Nations economic embargo imposed on the rump Yugoslavia.
But the language the seven agreed to today was cautious, reflecting continuing disagreements about whether and how it would make sense to use outside force to make peace in the region.
 
Access for Relief Effort
 "The airlift to Sarajevo can only be the beginning of a larger humanitarian effort," the summit leaders said. "Safe access by road to Sarajevo as well as to other parts of Bosnia and Herzegovina in need must be guaranteed."
But if United Nations aid is blocked by the belligerents, the summit leaders said, "we believe the Security Council will have to consider other measures, not excluding military means, to achieve its humanitarian objectives."
Serbia and Croatia, they said, should respect the territorial integrity of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Serbian leaders should respect minority rights in full and negotiate with representatives of the mainly Albanian province of Kosovo on granting autonomous status for the territory.
The leaders also called for the suspension of Serbia and Montenegro, the only remaining members of what was a six-member Yugoslav federation, from the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe in Helsinki, where the six European and North American national leaders in Munich will be joining 46 others on Thursday for the most comprehensive East-West summit gathering of the post-Soviet era.
 
Use of NATO Forces
 Officials in Helsinki said today that all C.S.C.E. members except Russia had already agreed to suspend Yugoslavia, and that agreement had been reached on a way to allow the security conference to approach the NATO alliance as well as individual C.S.C.E. members for forces to use in peacekeeping missions if the 52-nation group decided on it.
The security conference plans to agree on a 12-section charter emphasizing cooperation among former adversaries in building a new European security order.
Hours before Mr. Yeltsin's arrival at dinner tonight, half a day earlier than originally scheduled, Mr. Baker was asked about a suggestion -- resisted by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany and Prime Minister John Major of Britain -- that the Russians should be included in the annual economic summit meetings.
"If Russia stays on a democratic and free-market course, it might be very likely that the next summit would see the President of Russia in attendance," Mr. Baker said.
But the Japanese remain skeptical about providing money to help him. Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa expressed hesitation about setting up a multinational fund to pay for repairs to make Soviet-designed nuclear reactors in Eastern Europe safe against the threat of catastrophic breakdown, diplomats said. Japan has made aid to Russia, and normalization of relations, conditional on a return of the four southernmost Kurile islands, seized from Japan at the end of World War II.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MUNICH -- Bush on a Tightrope;
Behind the Facade of Good Intentions Summit Crystallizes Some Problems

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MUNICH, Germany, July 7

 BODY:
Behind their expressions of good intentions on world trade, the Russian evolution and Yugoslavia, President Bush and President Francois Mitterrand of France danced a tense minuet today, with one eye on their own political problems and the other on an increasingly difficult trans-Atlantic relationship.
Carried out in dinners, formal meetings and ad hoc negotiations in the corridors of Munich's Residenz palace, the relationship between Mr. Bush and Mr. Mitterrand at the seven-nation economic summit meeting seemed to crystallize the problems of the Atlantic alliance as the United States and its European partners try to fit themselves into a post-cold-war order that none seems able to define clearly. 
 In public, the United States sought to give some credit to Mr. Mitterrand, saying he had spurred the statement on Yugoslavia that was issued by the seven leaders here today and that Washington would continue to let him lead the European Community's response to the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Like Mr. Bush, Mr. Mitterrand seems to be doing better abroad than at home. He arrived here in the midst of a truckers' strike in France that has paralyzed roads and stranded travelers throughout the country.
Officials from Washington played down the notion that French-American disputes were the major reason for the industrialized democracies' failure to reach an agreement on world trade that they have been promising for years.
 
Private Complaints
 But in private, United States officials complained about French intransigence in the trade talks. The Americans' public deference to Mr. Mitterrand on Yugoslavia was tempered by a political need to present Mr. Bush as a strong leader and Washington officials said privately that Mr. Mitterrand was actually following Mr. Bush's lead on the Balkan fighting.
Indeed, they said the communique was crafted in such a way as to take the issue out of the hands of the European Community, where the United States is largely a bystander, and put it back in the United Nations Security Council, which Mr. Bush feels confident of dominating, if any large-scale military action is needed.
For their part, the French signed a joint communique that spoke of "an era where confrontation has given way to cooperation." But they grumbled to reporters about Washington's reluctance to agree to a new international conference on the Balkans. They said the Americans were blocking -- for no good reason, as far as France was concerned -- a joint nuclear safety fund that would be administered by the French-controlled European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
Aides to Mr. Bush and Mr. Mitterrand said the two men get along well on a personal level, although Mr. Bush's exuberant style clashes with Mr. Mitterrand's more impassive demeanor. Both Mr. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d are said to have a prickly relationship with the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas.
 
Future U.S. Role Questioned
 The two leaders' evident tensions spring in part from significant differences on global security issues, including the future of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and more broadly the future American role in Europe.
The United States is trying to maintain the dominance of NATO as the main European security force. But France, which is not a member of the NATO military structure, argues that the alliance is a cold-war institution and should evolve into something new. They say the United States' influence in European affairs, which French officials resent, should be diminished.
France has been pressing for a new international conference on Yugoslavia, and has been resisting American proposals that NATO form a peacekeeping arm, on which the European countries could call in times of crisis through the 52-member Council on Security and Cooperation in Europe.
Paris wants the European security council to turn to individual countries for peacekeeping missions. The United States can more easily control NATO than the security council.
 
Geopolitics and Elections
 Beyond these geopolitical considerations, the relationship between Mr. Bush and Mr. Mitterrand also reflects the extent to which the actions and statements of the two Presidents and the five other leaders meeting here are colored by their political problems at home.
Both Presidents are facing crucial votes later this year. On Sept. 20, the French will vote in a referendum whether to approve the treaty on European union that Mr. Mitterrand has staked his political standing on.
Mr. Bush is facing his own political troubles in his battle to win a second term in November. His political advisers want him to return from Munich having demonstrated leadership in international affairs and a concern for American economic problems.
 
Reaching a Home Audience
 When a reporter suggested this evening that Mr. Bush had not put his stamp on the proceedings here, Mr. Baker responded, "I think you're missing something.
"I think that we -- as I said in the formal statement -- can and have served as a catalyst for action with respect to Yugoslavia," Mr. Baker said. "But leadership doesn't mean doing it all by yourself. It means doing it jointly with your partners where everyone can agree on what ought to be done. And now we are in the happy circumstance of everyone agreeing on what ought to be done."
Asked how much the 1992 election colored Mr. Bush's actions here, Mr. Baker, a seasoned political strategist who ran the President's 1988 campaign, said: "I don't think to any extent at all. I say with a very, very straight face: The President is not here for domestic political reasons."
But Mr. Baker hastened to connect the visit to the primary issue of the campaign -- the economy. "In terms of how it will impact economic growth at home, clearly we would love to see that enhanced, and the work that's done here by an American President can help in accomplishing that," he said.

HEADLINE: Boy's Effort to Leave Parents May Rewrite Law

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEESBURG, Fla.

 BODY:
For most of his life, the 11-year-old child known as Gregory K. has bounced from parent to parent, house to house and state to state, hoping to find what he described to state investigators as "a place to be."
Now, in a case that children's advocates hope will give children the right to sue their parents, the boy is seeking to sever all legal ties to his mother and father so that he can be adopted by the foster family he lives with in this small central Florida town. 
 But the suit that has been brought on the boy's behalf is being contested by his 30-year-old mother, who argues that a minor has neither the legal right nor the intellectual capacity to ask a court to strip her of her parental rights.
If the boy cannot legally drink until he is 21 or vote until he is 18, his mother, Rachel K., said in an interview, "What makes him able, at barely half that age, to make a decision like this?" The mother, whose last name is not disclosed in court papers, said she had placed the boy and her two other children in the state's care for financial reasons and only temporarily.
The first formal hearing on whether Gregory K. has such rights is not scheduled until later this month in Orlando, an hour's drive from this quiet town of 15,000 people.
But the case has already set off an intense debate among legal experts and children's advocates around the nation. Many of these experts fear that a ruling that gives a minor legal standing to sue would allow thousands of other children to seek what the press has been calling a "divorce" from their parents.
 
Suits for 'Malparenting'?
 It's a term that makes one legal expert, Howard Davidson, executive director of the American Bar Association's Center on Children and the Law, uneasy.
"Although I think it is important that kids be recognized under the law and treated with the same dignity accorded adults," Mr. Davidson said, "I'm not sure that drawing parallels with divorce is not a way to alienate most Americans and frighten most parents to death. Where do you draw the line? Could we then see civil actions for malparenting? How do you define what negligent parenting is? It's very, very difficult."
Across the United States each year, courts agree that thousands of children should be separated from their parents and that their custody should be awarded to other people. In Florida and many other states, this is usually accomplished in proceedings in which a state-appointed guardian or a state agency petitions for a change of custody on a child's behalf.
The case of Gregory K. is unique because the boy and his lawyer claim he has a constitutional right to have his own views presented in court instead of being forced to accept what parents, legal guardians or other adults see as a child's best interests.
 
Seeing Children as People
 "Gregory's position on this matter is different than that of the state or his parents, and the system has not satisfied his needs in this case," said Jerri A. Blair, the boy's lawyer. "I'm not contending that children's rights are absolute across the board. But they have to be recognized as people, with rights in court that are of the same stature as the parents'."
Jane E. Carey and Harry H. Morall, a pair of Orlando lawyers appointed by the State of Florida to represent Rachel K., say that granting Gregory legal standing to sue, could lead to cases in which children are themselves sued.
"This could be a very dangerous precedent," Ms. Carey said. "You know, I'm a child advocate, too, but you can go too far with anything. America is in the shape it is because we don't have a strong family unit. So are we going to allow ourselves to buy into this, which is only going to destroy the family even more?"
Gregory's foster father, a lawyer who has handled many family law cases, said the boy is merely seeking "the rights to which any person is entitled under the United States and Florida constitutions," beginning with the right to a lawyer. He and the children's advocates who have endorsed Gregory's suit argue that the rights to due process, equal protection, privacy and exemption from cruel and unusual punishment apply to minors just as they do to adults.
 
A Right to Be Heard
 "If Gregory is old enough to say what he wants and doesn't want, why aren't people willing to accept that?" asked Karen Adams, national coordinator of the National Child Rights Alliance, a group that consists mainly of adults who suffered abuse as children and that has filed a brief in support of the boy. She said the group believes that children should have the right to be heard in court just as soon as they learn to talk.
"We have had experience with children as young as 3 years old saying, 'I don't want to live here anymore,' " Ms. Adams said. "We feel that all children should have the right to know what their civil rights are and have access to the people who can help them assert those rights."
While acknowledging that the action is "akin" or "tantamount" to a divorce in that it severs the relationship between members of a family, Gregory's lawyer also argues that there are important differences.
"The standard of proof is different," Ms. Blair said. "Irreconcilable differences are not grounds enough" for a termination of the relationship between parent and child, though they are often sufficient to dissolve a marriage. "The child has to show clear and convincing evidence of abandonment, abuse or neglect."
 
Father Relinquished Custody
 Apart from the legal wrangling, the suit involves circumstances common to many custody actions.
Gregory's natural father signed a form in May relinquishing all rights to his son, who has not lived with him for four years.
Gregory's foster father of the last nine months says that he and his wife have become Gregory's "psychological parents" and that the boy has formed emotional ties with them that should not be broken.
In his suit, Gregory asks for "termination of the parent-child relationship" with his mother on the ground that he has been the victim of neglect and "mental and emotional abuse" on her part. His mother, a waitress, is described as "a victim of alcohol and drug abuse" who "developed an intimate relationship with her female roommate" and "chose to continue the relationship rather than keep" Gregory and two younger brothers.
Rachel K. said she had left Florida and was now living in her home state near relatives who help her care for the two younger boys. She said she was also engaged to be married. Gregory's complaint describes Rachel K.'s fiance as a "live-in paramour." It says he has been convicted of armed robbery and drug possession, has "a possible past history of alcohol abuse" and is unemployed.
Rachel K. called the descriptions of her personal and sexual habits "a lie."
As for her fiance, she said, it is true that "he was a young man, and he did a couple of wrong things," but "it's been eight years since the last thing happened" and "he's never been in trouble since."
"He's a grown man with a job now, and he has been a wonderful father," she said.
Rachel K. acknowledged that she had seen little of Gregory but contended that that was because Gregory's father had run away with Gregory when the boy was 4 years old.
In general, the State of Florida will allow adoption of foster children after a finding of abuse, abandonment or neglect against the parents. Rachel K. says she was guilty of none of these things.
"I was trying to care for the children alone, on a waitress's pay, and I failed," she said. "I've had no financial support. I never received any child support from the father. I didn't qualify for welfare. And there was a year's waiting list to get on public housing. I was between a rock and a hard place. There was no money to pay for the bills, and we were living hand to mouth every day."
As Rachel K. sees it, the dispute over Gregory is about class and privilege. After a life of hardship, she said, her son is dazzled by the material goods that have been bestowed on him since he moved into his foster father's house, the home of a lawyer with the money to provide comfortably for eight children of his own.
"His brothers go swimming at the public pool, and Gregory goes swimming at the country club," she said. "Which would you rather do if you were 11 years old? You'd want the same things if you were a little kid and had gone from being poor to having Nintendo and a little water bed of your own. I wasn't even able to buy my kids a bike, and in a child's world those are big things."
Gregory's lawyer and foster father have declined to make the boy available for comment, saying that to do so could give the State of Florida ground to remove him from his foster home. But in an interview at his law offices here, Gregory's foster father rejected the notion that the boy's love or allegiance had been bought.
"This whole thing is riddled with false premises," he said. "It's a fallacy to say that children will sue their parents because they want new Reeboks and can't get them. Children want to get away from abusive parents for the same reasons that abused spouses do, and to presume the reason is material things is ridiculous and shallow minded."
He said that the suit was Gregory's idea and that "he has chosen to do it this way" because "he hopes other children can be spared from what has happened to him."
But Rachel K. said that she, too, is "a victim of the system," and that society should be willing to make amends to her.
"I'm a good mother who's been dealt a crummy hand in life so far and is trying to turn that around," she said. "I've had to fight my whole life to make it, and I won't give up now. A woman making it on her own with three children, it's not easy. If they want a fight, then they've got one. That's my son, my firstborn child, and I'm never giving him up."
