HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MUNICH: Reporter's Notebook;
Yeltsin Quickens Tempo of a Diplomatic Lullaby

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MUNICH, Germany, July 7

 BODY:
The economic summit meetings of the seven industrial democracies, begun 17 years ago in France, are facing a crisis of credibility. With all the talk, pomp and expense, accompanied this year by scant action, people are asking: Where's the beef?
The nearest thing, it seemed, was President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. In an unusual twist, the head of an economy in virtually complete chaos, with an "inflation rate" of 640 percent in the past four months, was welcomed today by the Group of Seven as a potential savior. 
 Unable to agree on anything to revive the sagging world economy, the leaders were at least hoping to save face by offering President Yeltsin an initial $1 billion in aid, promises of imminent debt rescheduling and a place at their dinner table. They did not, however, offer to pay Mr. Yeltsin's estimated $400-a-night hotel bill -- nearly three times his 18,900-ruble monthly salary.
Although the welcome was warm, some questions were being quietly posed about Mr. Yeltsin's presence. "How do you coordinate economic policy with a country that does not even have a market economy?" asked the Italian Prime Minister, Giuliano Amato.
Other officials promised that Mr. Yeltsin would face some tough questions along with the food, the Bavarian beer and the blandishments. The Japanese want to know when Russia will hand back four Pacific islands seized at the end of World War II. And the United States wants to know when 130,000 Russian troops still in the Baltic states will be withdrawn.
Nobody is quite ready to expand the Group of Seven to a Group of Eight. But everybody, it seems, needs President Yeltsin to distract them from routine. Even the black-tie requirement for the gala dinner was waived in the case of the Russian President, who did not bring one.
 
Communique as Band-Aid
 President Bush tried hard to achieve something beyond the support of Russia's reforms: He vowed that the three days of discussions, originally intended as "fireside chats" but now transformed into lavish extravaganzas, would produce jobs for Americans.
Others sought to resolve issues ranging from the menace of the former Soviet Union's nuclear reactors to the world refugee problem. But difficulties abounded.
The disarray was summed up by the French text of the summit's statement on Yugoslavia, which stated: "The humanitarian solution in Bosnia and Herzegovina is tragic and unacceptable." Only hours later was a correction circulated: "The humanitarian situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina is tragic and unacceptable."
 
Shall We Play It Again?
 Nowhere were the difficulties more apparent than on the question of the deadlocked talks on world trade.
Everyone agreed that differences between France and the United States on farm subsidies had narrowed and all that was needed was a "political push."
But President Francois Mitterrand faces a referendum on European union in September and President Bush an election in November, and both want the support of farmers. So the push was pushed back.
This left a delicate problem for the drafters of the final communique, which is due on Wednesday: How to encapsulate the progress and the new determination in a way that would distinguish these talks from the last four summits?
In Toronto in 1988, the leaders said of the so-called Uruguay Round of talks on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade: "It is of decisive importance to safeguard the dynamism of these ambitious negotiations."
A year later, in Paris: "We commit ourselves unreservedly to further substantial progress in the Uruguay Round so that it can be successfully concluded by the end of 1990."
In 1990, in Houston: "The successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round has top priority on the world political agenda."
And last year, in London: "No question has more far-reaching implications for the future prospects of the global economy than the successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round."
What now? Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said, enigmatically, that the language would be "more forward-leaning."
 
Big Bad Bush
 President Bush tried to lift the mood with a sociable jog in a Munich sports club. Even there, he was not a complete hit.
Joined on lap 2 by a girl named Nicole Lechl, the President had to watch as the 4-year-old burst into tears and ran to her father after about 10 yards.
Asked after eight laps what he was taking home from the summit, the President replied laconically: "About what we thought when we came."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia reviewing an honor guard yesterday as he arrived for meeting in Munich, Germany. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Car Buyers Drift Back, Raising Detroit's Hopes;
One City's Dealers See Modest Gains But Meager Profits

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALLENTOWN, Pa., July 7

 BODY:
Policy makers groping to understand how auto sales could be rising even as more Americans are losing their jobs could do at least as well consulting Steven M. Parr as their statistician or economist.
"We had a great June," he said today at the Haldeman Ford dealership here, tapping a well-polished loafer on the floor for emphasis. "Our sales staff is charged up. The buyers are there." 
 But ask Mr. Parr, the general manager, about the dealership's income, and the tapping stops. "Maybe once you made $400 or $500 on a car," he said. "Now you'll take $100," he added with the wounded tone of an accomplished salesman laid low by hard times.
No wonder that if the nation is, indeed, in a recovery, few car dealers or other business people are celebrating. Consumers may be buying, but so grudgingly that neither they nor the dealers are enjoying it much.
"Customers are less emotional these days," said Andrew M. Scott, the general manager of Scott Chevrolet, Chrysler-Plymouth and Saab, stretching along Lehigh Street, also known as Auto Mile. "People shop so much they get tired out. It's not fun."
 
Buyers Stick to Demands
 At age 38, Mr. Scott already has a deeply lined brow (though having six children may have something to do with it). As he talked, salespeople trooped in with worksheets from customers who had priced the same cars at as many as four other dealers. Having nearly met one couple's demand for a break on a five-year lease, he fidgeted as Joseph Albino, a salesman, told him the customers were sticking to their demands.
"That's only $1.65 a month difference," Mr. Scott said.
"The wife says that's $1.65 a month, for 60 months," Mr. Albino responded.
Because the half-million residents of the industrial belt that straddles the Lehigh River here tend to be serious about their cars, auto dealers and shoppers are especially sensitive gauges of the economy's broader health. "They are more likely to spend that raise on a new car than vacations in Europe," Mr. Scott said.
Tight economic times pinch hard here, a feeling that inspired Billy Joel's song "Allentown" a decade ago. The most recent available unemployment rate for Allentown was 9.1 percent in April, compared with 7.1 percent nationally.
But for those who still have jobs at Bethlehem Steel, Mack Trucks, Air Products and Chemicals and other manufacturers, average hourly wages of $11.41 are 9 cents better than the national average.
As John Powell's hourly salary in a print shop has gone from $7 to $17.80 over seven years, he has traded cars every few years. Now, with print shop orders improving, he has enough confidence to ask the Scott dealership about trading in his 1989 Camaro for a new Beretta GTZ.
"Someday I'm going to get one of those black beauties," he said, pointing to a Corvette glistening in the sun.
 
Iacocca's Kind of Town
 The presence of major manufacturers threatened by imports makes Allentown the sort of market Detroit used to enjoy everywhere. Auto Mile has one dealer for Honda and none for Toyota, while Chevrolet, Pontiac, Buick, Ford and Chrysler signs are more plentiful than stoplights.
Dealers say that the Allentown area -- where Lee A. Iacocca was born and grew up -- gives Chrysler its highest market share in the nation.
The salesmen at Valley Honda say they are doing well. But as they chatted idly in their lot, in voices loud enough to be heard above the din of traffic, they watched most of the customers stream into the Ford dealership nearby. The Honda salespeople constantly remind reluctant customers that many of their cars are made in Ohio, in part from materials furnished by Bethlehem Steel.
 
Far Below the Sticker
 Mr. Parr's Ford dealership can boast of selling 160 cars in June, up from 120 or so during several of the previous months. But to get customers like Elna Brooks to buy a new Mercury Sable or Ford Taurus, he has to run newspaper advertisements offering to sell a car with a $20,000 sticker price for $15,999, before the negotiating even starts. "That's pretty much a rock-bottom price," acknowledged Mrs. Brooks, as a salesman led her out to a Caribbean-green Taurus LX for a test drive.
Mr. Parr had drilled his salesmen just that morning to talk up the practical safety features of the Taurus and Sable, and Mrs. Brooks was receptive. "I am thrilled to get a car with two air bags," she said.
Mr. Parr said that attracting customers requires more training for salesmen, who in turn have to spend more time with each customer.
The dealers do say they have gotten some help from Washington in the form of lower interest rates. With payments more affordable, the dealers say, more buyers are looking for new cars, rather than used models.
Ralph Paiz was rushing out of the Scott Chevrolet dealership to see if he could qualify for his bank's 9 percent financing on a new Astro van. A moving company had just promoted him, and he wanted to be done with his dented Chevrolet Blazer.
An hour later, Mr. Albino, the salesman, walked into Mr. Scott's office and said, "You know the deal I thought I'd throw up against the wall and see if it stuck," Mr. Albino said. "Well, it's stuck."

Parr, left, the dealership's general manager, shown at the morning sales meeting, said, "The dealer's profit is down because of the economy." (Photographs by William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

 Markets
Stocks fell sharply as investors appeared to be shaken by inklings that second-quarter earnings would be worse than expected. The Dow dropped 44.03 points, to 3,295.17. [Page D1.]
The dollar fell across the board in hectic trading on world currency markets. [D14.] Despite the decline in the dollar, interest rates moved lower, as investors continued to buy dollar-denominated fixed-income securities. [D13.]
Silver prices retreated after a Middle Eastern holder sold millions of ounces as a result of the B.C.C.I. scandal. [D14.]
 
 The Economy
Detroit is putting a lot of faith in its expectations of rising sales by scheduling the most robust third-quarter production plan in six years. Chrysler, for instance, has placed a $100 million bet by expanding its light-truck production. [D1.] Car dealers note that consumers may be buying, but grudgingly. [D1.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Carter Hawley Gives Debt Plan

 BODY:
Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. outlined a plan of reorganization yesterday that would help it emerge from bankruptcy protection sometime in September.
The plan will eliminate almost $600 million in debt from the department store company's balance sheet by distributing 35 million shares, worth $350 million, in the reorganized company to creditors and stockholders. 
 The Zell/Chilmark Fund, the investment fund that last year spent $280 million to buy 80 percent of the bankrupt company's debt, will own 75 percent of the shares if the plan is approved.
The plan is likely to face little or no opposition since Zell/Chilmark is by far the company's largest unsecured creditor and since its two largest secured creditors, Prudential and the Bank of America, have already signed off on it.
"This reorganization plan is designed to enable Carter Hawley Hale to move forward on a financially sound basis so that it can compete vigorously in its markets," said Philip M. Hawley, chairman and chief executive.
The plan also includes a $325 million, five-year store renovation and modernization program, financed in part by a $50 million cash investment from Zell-Chilmark, which is part of the $350 million in equity. If the plan is approved, the fund will kick in the money in exchange for five million shares, which will bring its stake to 75 percent. Carter Hawley ran into problems when it took on large amounts of long-term debt to evade a hostile takeover bid by The Limited Inc. in 1987.
Then its stores -- the Broadway in Southern California and Arizona, the Emporium chain in the San Francisco area and Weinstocks in the Sacramento region -- were hurt during the recession.
In bankruptcy, the company closed a handful of unprofitable stores and consolidated the operations of three divisions into a single unit.

HEADLINE: Carrots for Castro

BYLINE: By Wayne S. Smith; Wayne S. Smith, chief of the U.S. interests section in Havana from 1979-1982, is director of Cuban studies at The Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Even in the case of Cuba, the cold war should be over. The island is no longer a problem to us or others. Cuban troops are out of Africa. Cuban support for revolutionary groups in Latin America is finished. Cuban-Russian military ties are no longer a matter of concern.
None of this, however, has resulted in any change in U.S. policy. The Administration has moved the goal posts and now says that only after Cuba has a market economy and has held fully democratic elections can there be any change in our approach. 
 Congress hasn't seemed to notice the change in Cuba's situation either. It is considering a bill that would allow the President to impose sanctions against Canada, Britain and other major friends and allies unless they reduce their economic relations with Havana. Elizardo Sanchez and Gustavo Arcos, Cuba's leading human rights advocates, oppose the legislation, which is sponsored by Representative Robert Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, and endorsed by the Administration and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. The two Cubans argue that the measure would stir up Cuban nationalism and help President Fidel Castro rally support.
And to no gain, since the legislation would not work. Why would we want to complicate relations with vital friends and trading partners over an island of little importance?
Does this make sense? Of course not. But it's an election year, and the bill is the brainchild of the ultra-conservative -- and ultra-rich -- Cuban-American National Foundation. It doesn't matter that the organization, which speaks for a minority of Cubans in the U.S., has misjudged the island for a long time. In February, Jorge Mas Canosa, the head of the foundation, assured an audience at the Heritage Foundation that the Cuban economy would collapse by summer. It hasn't.
What matters is that Mr. Mas Canosa's foundation has lots of money to put in campaign coffers. Federal Elections Commission records indicate that foundation members have contributed substantially to Mr. Torricelli. Increasingly, the organization defines our policy toward Cuba.
Ronald Reagan said the best way to bring about reform in South Africa was through constructive engagement. He was right. George Bush says the same of China, which has a worse human rights record than Cuba. It is only when the subject is Cuba that Mr. Bush insists isolation is the best course.
In fact, our policy toward China and Cuba is flawed. Constructive engagement means using carrots and sticks to encourage foreign governments to move in the desired direction. We have a full relationship with China: trade, credits -- the works. Those are the carrots. We should not try to isolate China, but if its leaders do not begin to halt repression, we should limit certain aspects of our relations. Removal of carrots amounts to applying sticks. Unless we apply them, our policy is one-sided and encourages wrongdoing.
Our policy toward Cuba is equally one-sided. But here the problem is an absence of carrots: no diplomatic ties, trade -- anything. We need not rush to put all that in place. But we should at least indicate that we are willing to begin a dialogue and gradually expand relations if Cuba improves its human rights record. That is what Mr. Sanchez and Mr. Arcos, who have spent years in Cuban prisons, have urged. The U.S. could help most, they say, by reducing tensions and offering some carrots. That is the key to the creation of a climate for peaceful change.
Unfortunately, the Administration seems determined to avoid anything so subtle as carrots and sticks. It prefers the blunderbuss -- even one, as in the case of the Torricelli bill, aimed squarely at our own foot.

HEADLINE: Car Buyers Drift Back, Raising Detroit's Hopes;
Buoyed by Figures, Big Three Expand Production Plans

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 7

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation, buoyed by recent strength in the American automotive market, has placed a $100 million bet that vehicle sales will continue to rise. The company announced today that it would expand its light-truck production.
Chrysler's action came a day after late-June retail sales of domestically produced vehicles surged more than 20 percent, compared with the period a year earlier, and auto makers reported a rise in sales for the entire month. Although one 10-day selling period is hardly a harbinger of recovery, several 10-day periods of improving retail sales have fueled demand for vehicles from dealers, whose inventories have dwindled. 
 As it responds to the dealers' demand, Detroit is putting a lot of faith in the sales trend by scheduling the most robust third-quarter production plan in six years. While the goal is to keep inventories one step ahead of demand, the last thing Detroit needs now is to be caught without enough cars to sell to buyers who would be likely to buy elsewhere. But after a year of stunning losses, betting on a recovery by ordering more cars is a dicey -- and expensive -- gamble.
 
Expecting a 17.7% Gain
 Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry trade publication, estimated production scheduled at North American plants for the third quarter, which began a week ago, at 2.99 million cars and trucks, including output at plants in Mexico and Canada.
If that schedule holds, it would result in a 17.7 percent increase from the third quarter of 1991 in the number of vehicles built.
Ward's estimated that the number of weeks that assembly plants will be idled by the Big Three in the third quarter is down 20 percent. The number of weeks of down time in the second quarter was off more than 50 percent from a year earlier, sharply reducing the unemployment benefits paid to hourly workers.
Even if third-quarter projections are met, Ward's said, the vehicle production total for the year to date remains relatively weak, because the first half was so sluggish. That means that auto makers' earnings, which depend on production volume, are not likely to be strong this year.
"No question, things are better," said Jerry Paul, an automotive analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company in New York. "It's just a question of how much and how quickly sales will accelerate."
Sales began to improve last year, but then dropped steeply and unexpectedly in July. Analysts are nervously waiting to see if a decline comes again this year, Mr. Paul said.
 
Saturn Stocks Are Falling
 Several dealers for the General Motors Corporation's Saturn models reported this week that they might soon run out of cars if the rapid pace of sales continued. Saturn has continued to increase its rate of production, aiming at a goal of 1,100 cars a day by the end of the summer. In the latest month, sales peaked at 21,038, which was exceeded only slightly by the monthly production of 21,357 cars at the Saturn division's single assembly plant in Spring Hill, Tenn.
In its announcement, Chrysler explained that increased optimism about a new full-size pickup truck, known by the code name T300, had resulted in its decision to invest an additional $100 million in an assembly plant in Warren, Mich., at a time when the No. 3 auto maker has little financial cushion. Chrysler had already decided to invest $125 million to prepare the plant for T300 production, which is to begin next year.
Chrysler said it would transfer production tooling from the Warren plant -- now used to build the midsized Dodge Dakota pickup -- to an aging plant in Toledo, Ohio. That will give Chrysler enough capacity at its Warren plant to build as many as 200,000 T300's, up from a planned 160,000.
 
Plant's Future Was Murky
 When Chrysler decided three years ago that it would close its Jefferson Avenue assembly plant in Detroit and open one across the street to build a new Jeep utility vehicle, the fate of the Toledo plant, the nation's oldest auto assembly plant, was in doubt. But Chrysler has been able to continue selling an older utility vehicle, the Jeep Cherokee, even after the introduction of its new Grand Cherokee.
Now, with the transfer of the Jeep Wrangler from a Canadian plant to Toledo, and the transfer of most Dakota production there, the future of the Toledo plant appears much brighter. In return, Toledo and the State of Ohio have pledged tax abatements and financial aid.

HEADLINE: Dow Plunges 44.03, to 3,295.17, on Worries Over Earnings

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON Jr.

 BODY:
Stocks fell sharply yesterday as investors appeared shaken by inklings that some second-quarter earnings reports due out next week would be worse than expected.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 44.03 points, or 1.32 percent, to 3,295.17. After having moved upward in the morning, the Dow began slipping shortly after noon, and then dived steeply just before 3 P.M., ending below the 3,300 level. 
 Trading was heavy. On the New York Stock Exchange, 226 million shares changed hands, compared with 186.9 million shares on Monday. Losing issues outnumbered gaining ones by 1,059 to 720.
Among the biggest losers were two companies with depressed earnings estimates for the second quarter: Dillard Department Stores, which fell 3 5/8, to 32 1/2, and Georgia-Pacific, down 4 3/8, to 55. Dillard was down as much as 6 1/8 at one point after analysts cut their earnings projections.
Lower earnings, coming after last week's higher unemployment figures, would be yet another indication of the wobbly nature of the recovery.
"It looks like a lot of companies are going to have depressed earnings reports," said Ricky Harrington, director of equity investments at Marion Bass Securities. "This is the second quarter, the time when most companies were supposed to turn it around."
Some technical analysts are now pointing out dangerous similarities between the current market and the beginning of the deep bear market in 1973. [Market Place, page D6.]
Mr. Harrington said he and some other analysts had interpreted the Federal Reserve's decision last week to lower interest rates as an indication of how weak the economy remained, rather than how inevitable a recovery had become.
"You reach a point where earnings become the driving force, and not interest rates," he said. Low interest rates are widely believed to have driven the market upward earlier this year.
Yesterday's market retreat was broad and was spread evenly among leading stocks. In an unusually uniform trend, 27 of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow Jones industrial average fell in price, and only two registered gains, which were minor. United Technologies rose 1/8, to 51, and Union Carbide rose 1/8, to 11 3/8. General Motors was unchanged at 40 3/4.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 4.68 points, or 1.13 percent, to 409.16; the American Stock Exchange index dropped 2.32 points, to 380.26, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 5.76 points, or 1.02 percent, to 557.41.
Marion Merrell Dow dropped 6 1/8, to 27 3/8, after the Food and Drug Administration instructed the drug company that it needed to warn doctors about potential side-effects caused by its drug Seldane, a popular antihistamine.
Philip Smyth, a market analyst at Birinyi Associates, said he monitored six different computer-generated sell programs yesterday. The largest sell program, he said, began at about 3:30 and involved 140 different stocks, with an average size of about 10,000 shares per trade.
"That took the market down about 17 1/2 points," said Mr. Smyth, noting that the selling involved a total of about 1.4 million shares.
 
Effects of Arbitrage
 Robert Freedman, chief investment officer at John Hancock Mutual Funds in Boston, said that the selling was accelerated by arbitrage -- or trading on a discrepancy in price between two similar financical instruments -- once the price of the S.& P. September futures contracts dropped faster than the S.& P. cash index of leading stocks.
Mr. Freedman said many traders programmed computers to order selling once the discrepancy between the two prices got as high as 40 cents. Yesterday, it grew to $1.26.
Among the Dow 30, the biggest loser was International Paper, which fell 2 1/4, to 65 3/4, after Georgia-Pacific, another paper company, reported that second-quarter net income would be only "slightly better than break even" and well below the 38 cents a share earned a year earlier.
Circuit City Stores fell 3, to 28 1/8, after the electronics retailer reported that same-store sales in June rose only 2 percent, less than expected.
Among over-the-counter stocks, Micrografx lost 60 percent of its value by falling 5 3/4, to 7 3/4, after the company said on Monday that earnings would be below expectations.
Mr. Harrington predicted that if the Dow fell below 3,250, it could fall even more precipitously.
"There are pluses and minuses to lowering interest rates," he said. "After all, our main problem is debt. Why do we want people to borrow more?"
Mr. Freedman sounded a similar tone of pessimism.
"There's been a lack of confidence since those unemployment numbers came out," he said. "The recovery just doesn't seem to be happening."

HEADLINE: Making Work More Attractive: Many Suggestions, Little Money

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
Most people agree that there is something wrong with a welfare system that penalizes women like Linda Baldwin for trying to support themselves. But the laws of politics and economics alike have made the problem surprisingly difficult to fix.
There are really only two options for bolstering work incentives: the country can either make welfare less rewarding, or it can make work more so. Both choices pose difficulties. 
 "Either you have to cut welfare benefits incredibly low, and then you risk hurting the people you're trying to help," said Christopher Jencks, a sociologist at Northwestern University. "Or the Government has to get in the business of permanently subsidizing the wages of low-income mothers, and that's very expensive."
In fact, policymakers have at different times tried bits of both strategies. For several decades, inflation has quietly eroded the value of welfare and food stamps, and budget cuts in some states are now accelerating that process. In 1991, a mother with two children qualified for an average of $7,471 a year in combined welfare and food stamp benefits. That is 27 percent less, accounting for inflation, than the amount two decades earlier.
 
Wages Are Lower, Too
 On the face of it, the erosion of benefits should raise the incentive to work. But wages for low-skilled workers have also eroded. That leaves welfare mothers with less attractive options both on welfare and off it.
Both Democratic and Republican Governors now advocate plans that would allow working welfare mothers to keep larger portions of their grants. But some of this strategy has already been tried. From 1967 to 1981, Congress allowed welfare mothers to keep the first $30 they earned, and a third of the rest, without having it counted toward their welfare benefits.
Presidents Richard M. Nixon, Gerald R. Ford, and Jimmy Carter all backed proposals that would strengthened this incentive by allowing welfare mothers to keep half of their earnings without penalty. But in each case, the proposals were tied to doomed plans for a guaranteed national income.
In 1981, President Reagan led a successful drive for the repeal of the incentive, arguing that women who were able to work should do so and not receive welfare at all. Studies of the repeal's effect have suggested that the incentive, in any case, did not play a major role in decisions about working.
More recently, efforts to bolster work incentives have focused not on the welfare rules but on strategies that support all low-income workers. One Congressional strategy has been to raise the minimum wage, to $4.25 an hour. But this level is still 23 percent lower than the average minimum wage during the 1970's.
Another strategy has been to expand the earned income tax credit, which provides an annual payment to workers with low earnings. By 1994 a family with two children will be able to receive as much as $2,008 a year from the credit.
 
Expanded Medicaid
 While there is substantial bipartisan support for expansions of the credits, economists warn of inherent limits. Some, for instance, argue that a large credit can create its own work disincentives, since it could cause workers who receive the credit to cut back on their hours.
Recognizing that the fear of losing their health insurance keeps many welfare recipients from working, Congress has also expanded the Medicaid program. It now covers all children in poverty born after September 30, 1983, whether their mothers are on welfare or not. That is why Ms. Baldwin's youngest son, born in 1987, qualifies for Medicaid, while her older children do not.
But the mothers can keep their Medicaid only for a year after leaving welfare, and most low-skilled jobs do not provide insurance. While more recipients would work if they could get subsidized health care, there is little agreement about how to do this, or where to find the money.
There are many other proposals to bolster work incentives. Some would expand subsidized day care for working mothers. Others would try to bolster the collection of child support payments from absent fathers, which, unlike welfare, are not cut when mothers take jobs.
But motivated by budget problems, many states are now altering work incentives through a different approach: plain cuts. In California, where a $663 monthly payment for a family of three is among the nation's highest, Governor Pete Wilson, a Republican, is advocating cuts of as much as 25 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Cemex Acquiring Spain's Top Cement Producer

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MORELIA, Mexico, July 7

 BODY:
Cementos Mexicanos S.A., the giant Mexican cement company, announced today that it would spend as much as $1.25 billion to take over the leading cement producer in Spain.
After intense negotiations with Spanish shareholders over the weekend, Cemex, as the Mexican company is known, acquired 24.9 percent of Compania Valenciana de Cementos Portland S.A. on Monday for 14,850 pesetas, or about $157, a share. It did not disclose the total price, but said it had received commitments for an additional 29.1 percent. 
 Cemex said it would make a tender offer with Citibank for all the publicly held shares of Valenciana at 15,075 pesetas a share. If all are sold, Cemex officials said, the entire purchase would be worth about $1.25 billion. (Valenciana's stock closed on Monday in Madrid at 14,950 pesetas a share.)
The acquisition gives Cemex a foothold in Europe, home to some of its leading competitors, including the Swiss giant Holderbank. But the move apparently perturbed Mexican and foreign investors, who have snapped up Cemex shares primarily because of its 63 percent dominance of the booming Mexican market.
The company's B-series shares, held by foreign investors, fell 10.4 percent today on the Mexican stock exchange; the A series, restricted to Mexican owners, fell 9.9 percent.
The drop in Cemex's shares helped pull Mexican stock prices down across the board. The Bolsa index of 40 issues fell 58.72 points, or 3.51 percent, to close at 1,614.19.
"Cemex is a very sophisticated company, but investors think they got a little too aggressive with this one," said Jorge Suarez Velez, director of the Latin America department at Nomura Research in New York.
Valenciana holds 14 percent of the Spanish cement market, a fraction more than its nearest rival. Speculation that Cemex was after that rival, Sanson, S.A., paused last Wednesday when Apax, the cement division of Unifund, a Swiss consortium, placed a public offer to buy Sanson for a reported $623 million.
A spokesman for Cemex, Luis Martinez, said he did not know whether the company was interested in Sanson.
 
$1.7 Billion in Sales
 For several years, Cemex has followed a strategy of expanding through acquisitions, building itself into the fourth-largest cement producer in the world, with $1.7 billion in annual sales. Until today, the biggest of its buys was Empresas Tolteca, its main competitor in Mexico, for which it paid $663 million in 1989.
Cemex has also bought smaller concrete and ready-mix plants in the Southwestern United States. But its exports, held back by anti-dumping duties levied against it by the United States International Trade Commission in October 1990, accounted for only 2.9 percent of its sales last year.
The company's profits jumped 164 percent last year, to about $450 million, and its ambitions have risen apace. Before this week, it had planned to spend $2 billion on new investments and expansion in the next five years.
Some stock analysts in Mexico City and New York argued that while the acquisition might have diluted Cemex's status as an especially pure investment in Mexican economic growth, it was expanding into a Spanish-speaking country with considerable potential of its own.
"They have shown that they can acquire companies, make them more efficient, reduce their operating costs and also know how to time the financing," said one Mexico City broker who has been bullish on Cemex.
Nomura's Mr. Suarez Velez, however, wondered about that.
"It's a little risky," he said of the deal. "The cement industry in Spain has been very weak. Valenciana is a company that's way behind in technology, so Cemex will have to make a considerable investment to bring it up to international standards."

HEADLINE: TENSION IN WASHINGTON HEIGHTS;
Events Don't Surprise Dominican Residents

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
"The glass is full and it has started to spill," said Manuel Viera, citing a Dominican saying as he reflected on the anger and violence that have erupted in his community since Jose Garcia was shot to death by a plainclothes police officer on Friday night.
"All this was coming, with all the problems we've been having," said Mr. Viera, who owns a travel agency in Washington Heights. "The death of that man filled the glass." 
 The violence that erupted may have jolted the rest of the city like a splash of ice-cold water, but the residents of Washington Heights say they have long seen it accumulating. Residents and community advocates said that police harassment was common, sometimes provoked only by walking down the street or standing on a stoop. They added that despite the law-enforcement focus on drug dealing, the deeper-seated problems with affordable housing, day care, overcrowded schools and high unemployment remain unaddressed, heightening the needs and frustrations of a rapidly growing community.
 
Struggle Without Respect
 Mr. Viera's travel agency sits on Amsterdam Avenue, near 156th Street, a bustling area crowded with bodegas, car services, clothing shops, restaurants and auto-parts stores that represent the labors of a people eager to claim their stake in American society. His partner, Jesus Rodriguez, fretted that despite these signs of legitimate economic struggle, too many people deny his community the respect it deserves, focusing only on the steely-faced youths who cluster on street corners with beepers and a swift, surreptitious sales pitch.
"We're in the United States, but we still lack a lot," said Mr. Rodriguez. "We are marginalized."
Outside the building, at 505 West 162d Street, where Mr. Garcia was shot, scores of people swirled about the street, sometimes breaking into Spanish chants of "no justice, no peace" and "united in combat." Facing the building was a mural in memory of Kiko, Mr. Garcia's nickname.
Radames Marte and Rafael Geminian leaned against the freshly painted mural, casually scanning the crowd. Neither condoned the violence that broke out after the killing, but they said they understood its source.
"There's no other way for the government to listen to us," Mr. Marte said. "There have been too many abuses."
Mr. Geminian said that last month he walked six blocks to his sister's apartment to take a bath when the hot water failed in his apartment on 157th Street. As he left her buillding, he said, a police officer stopped him and asked him where he lived.
"So what are you doing here?" he said the officer replied.
Although he said he was only there to take a bath, the police officer remained suspicious.
"He said if he ever saw me again he'd break my face," Mr. Geminian said.
Altagracia Sanchez, who has lived in the neighborhood for 10 years, stood nearby, shaking her head as she watched the growing crowd of protesters. "This is it," she said of the abuses that she says her community has endured over the years. "Things can't stay like this."
Ms. Sanchez said that last September she was double-parked on 181st Street when a police officer started to write her a ticket. She talked him out of it, but he took a parting verbal shot before she drove away.
"You have money; you have a nice car," she said he told her. "You earn that easy."
The implication that she was dealing drugs was too much for Ms. Sanchez, who pays her bills working two jobs and is going to school at night to study accounting. She recounted how she took out her Social Security card and challenged the officer to run her name through the computer.
Dennis DeLeon, the city's Human Rights Commisioner, said there had long been reports of police mistreatment of residents of the area, but in some cases, people held in their anger rather than report it to authorities.
 
An Insulting CharacterizationImplication
 Most frustrating, he said, was the characterization of the neighborhood as populated only by drug users and sellers. "It's an accumulation of years of seeing the words 'drug dealer' with the word 'Dominican' right after it," said Mr. DeLeon.
At a meeting of community advocates and politicians yesterday morning at Public School 28, there was animated debate on how best to address the situation. Most wanted to channel their efforts into public forums and prayer services. But some wanted a demonstration through the neighborhood and up to the 34th Precinct station house.
Yolanda Pineda, a member of the Community Association of Progressive Dominicans, worried that it would be difficult to control the anger. She added that some residents had told her they were scared of outbursts by youths.
Some community advocates said they hoped that the events of the last few days would prod elected officials and other city residents to understand their concerns better.
As he walked down Amsterdam Avenue, he reeled off a list of the area's concerns: inadequate day care, high unemployment, scant affordable housing, overcrowded schools, the city's largest concentration of teen-agers, and the neighborhood's dubious honor of leading the city in homicides.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
With Smile on Face, and Foot in Door

BYLINE: By Douglas Martin

 BODY:
IN two decades, Amal Martelli has sold 2,800 sets of World Book Encyclopedias and seems to be just hitting her stride. She sat on a couch in an apartment in Stuyvesant Town in Manhattan, surrounded by sales paraphernalia, making a soft, not unsubtle pitch.
"I'm here because of you, not because of your daddy," she assured 5-year-old Michael Hood. "You are the important person here for me." 
 She complimented him on his grasp of letters and numbers, gave him a poster and introduced him to Zak, a hand puppet. She unveiled what she called a magic pencil. "I have one of those," Michael said dismissively.
"It's not exactly the same," Ms. Martelli insisted. "It's the same principle."
She changed the subject. "Do you like animals, Michael?" she purred. "No," he answered.
The saleswoman, revealing no exasperation, turned her attention to the man with the checkbook, Dan Hood. She displayed such an array of educational aids it seemed impossible they wouldn't automatically spawn Einsteins.
The message rang like a bell. "A lot of families are interested in raising their children's intelligence," she said sweetly.
There was no immediate sale. She left them Volume A of the encyclopedia, as well as a quiz on its contents. She would return soon for them. Her foot was still decidedly in the door.
Ms. Martelli says one in three calls result in sales, compared with an average of one in five for World Book sales people. The key is persistence, to plant a seed and keep calling back.
Her doggedness had been manifest earlier when the Hoods were late because of a broken bus. She made a beeline to the playground of the apartment complex, spotted a mother with twins and struck up a conversation. "What a unique experience twins must be!" she chirped.
She left brochures. "A little dent has been made," she said.
Ms. Martelli is part of an economic sector surprisingly insulated from downturns. Even as times get worse, overall sales hold up because more people are willing to go door to door, and push that much harder to sell everything from vacuum cleaners to toothbrushes.
"A slow economy is to our benefit," said Steve Wilson, zone manager for World Book Educational Products. "There is no such thing as a layoff."
And door-to-door sales are certainly no drop in the bucket. They exceeded $12 billion last year, up 13 percent from 1988, according to the Direct Selling Association.
In New York City, people are even willing to swallow hard and summon the unimaginable courage to knock on the door of a stranger. "That's how you sharpen your wits," Ms. Martelli said of randomly ringing bells.
Not that she doesn't take precautions as she makes her rounds of the entire East Side. When she feels an area or building might be dangerous, she never travels alone.
But is she afraid? "No, it's exciting," Ms. Martelli insisted.
If some people are born to sell, this cheerful 57-year-old resident of Flushing, Queens, is not one of them. She was born in Argentina, the daughter of an engineer. She studied in Florida, and became a microbiology researcher at New York University.
In addition to English, she speaks Spanish, French, Portuguese, Italian and German. She drew the intricate illustrations that accompanied her scientific team's articles.
But the university hired outsiders to do more of the drawing, and her income declined. A friend told her about the World Book opportunity, and Ms. Martelli sold her first set of encyclopedias in 1972. She continued part time until 1986.
She then started full time, and her responsibilities came to include supervising a sales staff of 25. She received medical insurance, a pension and other benefits in a position that World Book says pays some more than $100,000 annually, including commissions. Part-timers working 10 to 15 hours a week average $10,000 to $15,000 in commissions.
One of them is Mary Ann Latorre, whom Ms. Martelli was training the day they visited the Hoods. The student was learning her lessons well.
"We don't want to make it seem like we're selling anything," she said.
This is only one of the tricks Ms. Martelli has collected from the school of soft knocks. She has learned to quickly bail out if a deal seems unlikely, that boyfriends seldom want to spend money on the education of a woman's children, that it never pays to argue with a potential customer.
And to play down the fact that World Books cost $599 to $899, depending on binding. "I'm not talking money now," she assured Mr. Hood. "But how do you feel about Michael growing up with these?"

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Interest Rates Continue to Slide

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Interest rates slipped again yesterday, as investors continued to buy dollar-denominated fixed-income securities despite a drop in the dollar to its lowest level in more than a year.
Aside from Treasury issues, demand was said to be strong for nearly $4 billion worth of new corporate bonds priced yesterday and around $1 billion of new tax-exempt municipal bonds. 
 While the dollar's decline has not deterred domestic investors from continuing to pour money into the Treasury, corporate and tax-exempt bond markets, traders said weakness in the currency pursuaded foreign investors to look elsewhere.
"This is a domestic-led bond rally," said Nick Sargen, a managing director at Global Fixed Income Advisors, a unit of Prudential Insurance with more than $5 billion under management. "I see no evidence of foreign investors flocking in. But for globally oriented companies like ours, who are based here, we have been shifting our allocations into the United States and other dollar-bloc bond markets, because the recovery here is proving to be even more muted than expected."
Comments by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady in Munich yesterday seemed to suggest that the dollar might become even weaker in order to stimulate the economy.
"We have had 6.5 percentage points worth of monetary policy over the last three years, with little result, and fiscal policy is still on the back burner because of the deficit," said Joseph A. Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S.G. Warburg & Company.
"So now it seems we are going to try some dollar devaluation to get things going here," he said. "And the Treasury is doing about as much as it can to talk the dollar down."
Under different circumstances, a drop in the value of the dollar might stir inflation fears among fixed-income investors. But expectations are high that a Government report Friday will show that prices at the wholesale level remained quite tame in June. And yesterday oil prices fell sharply.
 
Positive Inflation Outlook
 Despite the positive inflation outlook, investors in the Treasury securities market continue to favor parking money in short-to-intermediate- term securities rather than in more speculative long-term bonds, even though the interest rate spread between those maturities has widened to record widths.
Late yesterday, the yield spread between outstanding two-year notes and 30-year bonds stood at a staggering 3.27 percentage points.
"We aren't calling it a yield curve any more," Mr. Liro said. "Now it's a yield pole, because it's just too steep to be a curve. "
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 104 21/32 , up 6/32 , to yield 7.60 percent, compared with 7.61 percent late Monday.
Among outstanding note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 104 21/32 , up 10/32 , to yield 6.84 percent. The 6 3/8 percent five-year notes were offered at 102 5/32 , up 12/32 , to yield 5.86 percent, breaking through lows set in January. And the 5 percent two-year notes were offered at 101 1/4, up 6/32 , to yield 4.33 percent.
In when-issued trading late yesterday, the $9.75 billion worth of new seven-year Treasury notes to be auctioned today were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.40 percent.
Yields on seven-year notes were at comparable levels at a seven-year note auction in January, but then shot up by a full percentage point over the next few months.
Mindful of recent history, traders said yields on the new Treasury securities may well move higher before the auction.
Elsewhere, predictions late last week that the Federal Reserve's move to cut short-term interest rates would energize companies to price new debt issues are being borne out.
Yesterday, just under $4 billion of new issues were priced, following the more than $1 billion that were sold on Monday.
By far the biggest issuer yesterday was the Province of Quebec, which offered $750 million worth of 10-year notes through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company. The 7 1/2 percent notes were priced at $99.765, to yield 7.534 percent, 68 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing. The issue is rated AA-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Lehman Brothers acted as lead manager for a $250 million 10-year subordinated note offering by the Republic New York Corporation. The 7 1/4 percent noncallable securities were priced at $99.002, to yield 7.393 percent, 55 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing. The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by Standard & Poor's.
 
Bonds of Georgia
 In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the State of Georgia conducted the day's largest competitive bid debt sale, offering a total of $291.91 million worth of bonds. A bid from a group led by Lehman Brothers won the securities.
The Georgia bonds were reoffered to investors with yields from 3.60 percent in 1994 to 5.95 percent on bonds maturing from 2009 to 2012. Bonds maturing in 1993, 2002 and 2003 were not reoffered. The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
Despite the torrent of new corporate deals, traders said that prices of most outstanding investment-grade debt securities rose by about 1/8 point.
Demand for secondary issues in the tax-exempt municipal bond market was also firm, traders said. They said prices of most widely quoted municipal securities rose by 1/8 point to 1/4 point.

HEADLINE: Children in Poverty: 1 Million More in 80's

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
The number of American children living in poverty grew by more than 1 million during the 1980's, with rates rising in 33 states, according to an advocacy group's analysis of Census Bureau data.
The group, the Children's Defense Fund, found that the rate of children up to age 18 living in poor families rose by 11.2 percent nationwide from 1979 through 1989. 
 About 18 percent of children in the United States lived in families with incomes below the Federal poverty line in 1989. That included 39.8 percent of all black children, 38.8 percent of American Indian children, 32.2 percent of Hispanic children, 17.1 percent of Asian-American children and 12.5 percent of white children.
The states with the highest child-poverty rates in 1989 were Mississippi, with 33.5 percent; Louisiana, 32.8 percent; New Mexico, 27.5 percent; West Virginia, 25.9 percent, and Arkansas, 25.0 percent.
The lowest rates were in New Hampshire, 7.0 percent; Connecticut, 10.4 percent; Alaska, 10.9 percent; Maryland, 10.9 percent, and New Jersey, 11.0 percent. The rate in New York was 18.8 percent.
The study said the rise in poverty rates was caused by the failure of wages to keep up with inflation and by government cuts in income-support programs.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines Worldwide In a Hectic Day of Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar plunged across the board yesterday in hectic trading on world currency markets.
Gold prices also declined. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $346.20 an ounce, off 30 cents an ounce from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold had slipped 20 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $346.20. 
 Traders began selling dollars overnight in Asian markets, and the selling pressure was increased by the Bank of Malaysia's sale of dollars for German marks, analysts said.
"That was just a speculative play," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. But he said it "got the ball rolling" for further dollar selling when trading shifted to European and American markets.
The dollar fell through the important psychological and technical support level of 1.50 German marks, which set off even more selling.
Traders were disappointed by developments at the Group of Seven meeting in Munich, Germany, where finance ministers for leading industrial democracies have gathered. Participants at the summit meeting were largely reticent on issues involving foreign exchange.
"The dollar is in seriously bad shape," Mr. Donney said.
In Tokyo the dollar closed at 124.17 yen, down 0.81 yen from Monday's close. Later in London the dollar was quoted at 124.45 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 124.10 yen, down from 124.35 yen on Monday.
In London the pound rose to $1.9255, from $1.9105 late Monday. In New York it cost $1.9340 to buy one pound, more expensive than Monday's price of $1.9105.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.4900 German marks, down from 1.5133; 1.3400 Swiss francs, down from 1.3545; 5.0160 French francs, down from 5.0980; 1,126.25 Italian lire, down from 1,145.25, and 1.1948 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2006.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Silver Prices Pushed Lower In Selling Linked to B.C.C.I.

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
The spreading stain of the scandal at the Bank of Credit and Commerce International appeared to hurt the international silver market yesterday, pushing prices significantly lower.
Traders said a chain reaction apparently set off by an indictment in the case led to a huge selloff of silver by a Middle Eastern holder of millions of ounces. 
 The sale, which was estimated by traders to have been between five million and seven million ounces, pushed the market to a new low for the year. But it eventually regained some ground before the close of trading in the United States yesterday.
"The market basically just fell apart," said Peter Cardillo, director of research at Westfalia Investments in New York.
 
An 18-Month Low
 On New York's Commodity Exchange yesterday, July silver closed at $3.873 an ounce, down 15.5 cents, to the lowest levels since December 1991. During the trading day, the contract hit a low of $3.82 an ounce.
Traders and analysts attributed the dumping in the Middle East to a forced sale of silver brought about by the resignation of the chief operating officer of Saudi Arabia's biggest bank, the National Commercial Bank.
The executive, Sheik Khalid bin Mahfouz and an associate, Haroon Kahlon of London, were indicted last week in New York on charges of defrauding customers at B.C.C.I. of $300 million. Sheik Khalid resigned his position at the Saudi bank yesterday to devote his time to fighting the charges.
Traders and analysts said that Sheik Khalid, like many Arab sheiks, was a speculator in the precious metals markets. After his resignation yesterday, the word among traders was that the National Commercial Bank liquidated Sheik Khalid's entire silver holding.
Sheik Khalid could not be reached at the bank by telephone yesterday. A man answering the phone at the bank's offices in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, said that no one was available to discuss any actions taken by the bank or its customers in the silver market.
The heavy selling from the Middle East was just the latest in the woes of the silver market, which has been struggling unsuccesfully for months to gain upward momentum as the economy has grown stronger.
Traders said that yesterday's selloff will likely hurt the troubled market for the near future. "People are a bit nervous and are going to wait and see if there is any follow-through selling before they get bold and step in and get long," said Jeffrey Klein, the chief dealer for Union Bank of Switzerland.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Safeway Net Down by 6%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., July 7

 BODY:
Safeway Inc. said today that net income fell 6 percent in its fiscal second quarter. The company cited a weak economy, low food prices and increased competition both in the United States and Canada for the drop.
Net income for the quarter, which ended June 13, fell to $33.3 million, or 28 cents a share, from $35.6 million, or 31 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales fell 2 percent, to $3.45 billion, the retail grocery store operator said in a statement. 
 Operating profit fell 14 percent, to $120.5 million, reflecting "continued sluggishness in the economy and low overall food price inflation," Peter A. Magowan, Safeway's chairman, president and chief executive, said. He did not elaborate.
Interest expense fell 20 percent, to $67.5 million, reflecting the company's refinancing last July of $1.6 billion of leveraged-buyout-related debt.
As a result of the lower interest expense, Safeway's ratio of operating cash flow to interest expense improved to 2.96, from 2.56 a year earlier, reflecting increased liquidity.
Shares of Safeway stock fell 12.5 cents each today, to $12.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: In 90's Cuisine, the Farmer Is the Star

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
A BRIEF history of food heroes:
In the 1970's, it was the restaurateur, the man who owned the joint and could give you the best table at the best time. 
 In the 1980's, it was the chef, the man -- or woman -- who looked at cooking as an art, and dinner as a canvas.
In the 1990's, it's the farmer, a perfect walking symbol of something Americans now crave: connection to the earth, labor that produces something genuine and, not incidentally, great food, in season, picked at its peak of flavor.
In culinary circles, knowing the farmer has become more important than knowing how to make a beurre blanc.
Chefs who were once judged by technique, by their ability to deftly mix flour and butter and cream into sauces that would glorify and embellish, are now judged by their ability to enhance, not disguise. A great chef now provides the freshest and best ingredients -- berries off the bushes for only hours, mesclun ripped from the earth when the flavors of the greens combine in the most felicitous way.
Ever more conscious of the importance of ingredients, chefs meet with farmers early in the season to discuss what seeds to plant. During harvest, they make pilgrimages to visit the farmers who supply their restaurants. David Bouley, the New York chef, sometimes visits Blooming Hill Organic Farm, a purveyor 60 miles north of New York. It is run by Guy Jones and his sister, Cindy Jones, who once a week drives vegetables directly to Mr. Bouley's four-star restaurant, Bouley.
Less famous consumers get to know farmers at the local markets that are multiplying in many American cities. Although economically crucial, farmers' markets are also social networks with layers of complex interactions between the urban and the rural, the seekers and the sought. Customers at the markets linger at the stands, asking about food, but also about what time the farmers wake up, how long it takes them to get to the city and how their children are doing.
"This is a very loving relationship," said Barry Benepe, founder of the New York Greenmarket. "A lot of conversation is going on, not just selling." That contact is so important that most markets require the owner of the farm to sell at the stand in person.
Hilary Baum, a founder of Public Market Partners, a Bronx organization that provides technical assistance to farmers' markets, said this kind of personal interaction is "part of the product, of what's being sold at the market." Americans have always expressed a longing to return to the land, but they rarely do it. Every year, there are fewer and fewer farmers, struggling to hold on to a way of life that is now shared by only 4.6 million people in this country, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.
Although the new respect for the farmer may help those who sell directly to consumers and chefs, many other, decidedly unchic farmers are having a lot of trouble surviving. Indeed, farmers take on more symbolic value and become the object of greater nostalgia as they become scarcer. The same thing happened with cooking: chefs became celebrities and cooking became an art as fewer people cooked complicated meals on a daily basis.
People cut off from the earth tend to be intrigued by its most mundane manifestations. Last year, the Hudson River Club, a restaurant at the World Financial Center that features Hudson Valley foods, had a farmer bring in 50 corn plants, still rooted in dirt, and plant them in the restaurant. "I had people pick their own," said Waldy Malouf, the restaurant's chef. "They loved it. I guess they had never picked corn before." At another special event, fishermen brought huge, whole salmon, and diners crowded around so they could touch them.
In Philadelphia, the White Dog Cafe has a Farmer's Sunday Supper in the fall, where farmers mingle with the restaurant's customers. Keith Stewart, who has a farm in Greenville, N.Y., sends a newsletter to his regular customers about life on the farm. "To talk to a real farmer is meaningful to them," he said.
Hall Gibson, resident manager of Ryder Farm in Brewster, N.Y., said at least a dozen customers visit the organic farm each year. Breezy Hill Orchard in Clinton Corners, N.Y., holds a harvest celebration each fall; so does Blooming Hill Farm, where hundreds of customers sit around a huge bonfire and roast potatoes.
"We don't want to be some abstract source of food," said Mr. Jones of Blooming Hill, whose 15-acre farm in Blooming Grove, N.Y., is known for its mesclun. "We wish more people would come to visit. We want people to think this is a viable occupation, for some kid to think, 'I want to be a farmer when I grow up.' "
The city dwellers want more than just good food or an outing in the country. They want the contact; they want the farmer. In Petoskey, Mich., Bill McMaster's farm stand draws a constant stream of visitors. "When you buy this food from Bill, you get the sense that life is still good, that life makes sense," said Justin Rashid, president of American Spoon Foods, a maker of specialty foods that is situated in the same town. "What you're buying into is this sense of well-being."
The small specialty farmers who have gained star status generally began tailoring their crops to please chefs, who were rebelling against the tasteless tomatoes and mass-produced lettuces they were forced to buy. "Fifteen years ago, the farmers were really out of the loop," said Larry Forgione, chef of An American Place in New York and a pioneer in the effort to use locally grown food.
Now, chefs routinely nurture relationships with farmers. "The more you can be involved with the people producing the food, the better it is," said Mr. Malouf. When he wanted venison with more fat around the meat, for instance, he met with the producer, Eberhard Deer Farm in Millbrook, N.Y., to discuss changes in the feed.
Finding good ingredients has become a major part of the job for chefs. No longer can they call a few big dealers and order everything; to track down the best, they have to deal with many vendors. Joseph Pace, the chef at Petrossian, spends Wednesday and Friday at the Union Square Greenmarket in New York. "I scout out things I want, and then a van picks them up," he said. Other days, he calls farmers to find out when certain items are expected to ripen. "Like anything else, it's part of my day," he added. "It's got to be a quarter of my time."
As the natural qualities in food become more important, chefs prefer to keep their favorite farmers to themselves. "Every chef doesn't want to think their special ingredients are being bought by someone else," said Lora Zarubin, chef and owner of Lora, a restaurant on 13th Street in Manhattan. She admits to being obsessed with a special variety of arugula and hopes to find a local farmer who will grow it for her.
The fetish for freshness, too, is transforming the way cooking and shopping are approached. In her new cookbook coming out this fall, Alice Waters, the owner of the Chez Panisse restaurant in Berkeley, Calif., emphasizes the importance of going to the market before deciding what to make, not after. Peter's, a restaurant in Indianapolis, sometimes has striped bass that has been raised in purified water and delivered live to the restaurant in a portable tank. Freshness carries such status now that some farmers, with understandable bitterness, say some chefs brag that they get all their food at farmers' markets -- even when they don't.
Could farms replace museums as the place to party? Peggy Hirschberg, president of Parties to Perfection, a party-planning concern in Mamaroneck, N.Y., is trying to persuade one of her clients to hold a party on a farm. "Most of my clients have been everyplace and seen everything," she said. Everyplace and everything, that is, except a farm.
"We're like folk heroes," said Elizabeth Ryan Zimmerman, who with her husband, Peter Zimmerman, owns Breezy Hill Orchard. The admiration helps compensate for the stress, she said.
Not that many urbanites know about that part, or want to. "Remember 'The Waltons'? How they're all eating together? That's what they think farm life is like," said Vincent D'Attolico, who owns an organic farm with his wife, Joan, in Pine Island, N.Y.
Daisy Miller, an art student from Boston, is working on a farm this summer and has discovered what farm life is really like: rise at 6 A.M., and work until 7 P.M., dinner, then bed. "This teaches you about work."
New Yorkers who want a briefer look can sign up for farm trips with Farmhands-Cityhands, a nonprofit organization that takes people to farms for a day or even a week. The trips are often transformative. "They fall in love with themselves, with each other and with the farmer," said Wendy Dubin, founder of the organization, which is administered by Food Work, in Manhattan.
Most alluring are the small organic farms, where food is being carefully planted and harvested, absorbing the touch of human hands rather than a blast of chemicals. "Everything these people are doing is politically correct, and being politically correct is sexy," said Karen Schloss Saad, whose public relations work involves many food clients and who is on the board of Farmhands-Cityhands.
Those with a knack for turning sentiment into money are probably already at work on the inevitable: with parties on farms in the not-too-distant future, will we not need farm fashions, farm travel guides, farm furniture -- and farm perfume?

HEADLINE: FOOTBALL;
Owners' Salaries Focus of N.F.L. Trial

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
National Football League owners paid themselves between $50 million and $60 million in salaries from 1987 through 1990 but listed the salaries as part of general expenses instead of profits, according to testimony yesterday in the Freeman McNeil vs. the N.F.L. antitrust suit over free agency in United States District Court in Minneapolis.
A Stanford economics professor, Roger Noll, a witness for the players, said owners' salaries have ranged from nothing to $7.5 million. The owners could choose to take money from their teams in profits or salaries, Noll told the jury. 
 "This is a matter of discretion on the part of the owners how to take returns from their ownership," Noll said.
The players want to show that the N.F.L. is more profitable than its financial statements suggest.
The N.F.L. disagreed with Noll's assessment. Greg Aiello, the league's director of communications, said that during the same period (1987-90) $2.4 billion was paid to players in salaries, bonuses and benefits and that the N.F.L. is second to no sport in the amount of its total revenue that it spends for player costs.
For the N.F.L., total revenue is 56 percent, Aiello said, compared with 50 percent for the National Basketball Association and 46 percent for major league baseball.
"Even if we granted that the numbers of $50 to $60 million from Roger Noll were true, that would mean that owners during that period averaged $412,000 a year per owner," Aiello said. "That does not seem exorbitant and it is less than the average player salary in the N.F.L. The issue in this case is if the players are being treated fairly, not N.F.L. owners salaries."
Player representatives insist, however, that the owners' salaries are not a team expense.
 
Giants Report Losses
 The Giants lost almost $6.7 million between 1986 and 1989, according to the financial statements introduced at the trial.
The biggest loss reported by the team during that period was $4.2 million following the 1988 season. The team said it lost $1.09 million in 1989, $1.4 million in the strike-marred 1987 season and just $7,000 in 1986, when the Giants capped the year with a victory over Denver in Super Bowl XXI. The club's financial statements for the 1990 and 1991 seasons were not included in the documents.
The Giants' Bill Parcells was among the highest paid coaches in the league in the 1990 season, earning $725,000. General Manager George Young earned $441,250 in 1990. The team capped that season with a 20-19 Super Bowl victory over Buffalo.
General Manager Dick Steinberg was the highest-paid employee of the Jets with a $500,000 salary in 1990-91. Steinberg, who also is listed as a vice president of the Jets, earned $100,600 for working less than three months after being hired Dec. 18, 1989. He then earned $500,000 for the period from March 1, 1990 through Feb. 28, 1991.
The documents did not show how much Coach Bruce Coslet was paid for the period, which included his first season as Jets coach. He was hired by Steinberg in February 1990 at a reported salary of $350,000.
The highest-paid coach in 1990 was Jimmy Johnson of Dallas, who was paid $1.433 million. That was Johnson's second year as an N.F.L. coach and followed a 1-15 year as a rookie.
Miami's Don Shula was second, at just under $1.1 million, about $100,000 less than what San Francisco's Bill Walsh was paid in his final season, 1988, when he won his third Super Bowl.

HEADLINE: Eating Well

BYLINE: By Marian Burros

 BODY:
TWELVE million Americans consider themselves vegetarians, according to Vegetarian Times magazine. That's about two million more than a decade ago. While part of that growth may come from a looser definition of the term, the practice of vegetarianism, in all its many permutations, has moved beyond a cult and into the mainstream.
Some sort of meeting of the minds is at work here. Those who have been vegetarians because they believe that not consuming animal products is morally or environmentally correct now have the support of a large body of scientific evidence suggesting that increasing the consumption of fruits, vegetables, grains and low-fat dairy products, and decreasing or eliminating the consumption of meat, poultry and fish, may forestall the chronic ailments of aging like cancer and heart disease and can reverse the effects of atherosclerosis. 
 This confluence of forces is what made Faith Popcorn, a corporate trend-spotter, predict that during this decade "people all over America will have very little choice but to become more vegetarian initially and then totally vegetarian finally."
Ms. Popcorn doesn't always get it right, but that she would even raise such a possibility in an interview with Vegetarian Times at least suggests that vegetarianism is no longer just for aging hippies or followers of George Bernard Shaw.
"It's less uncool to be a vegetarian," said Dr. Patricia Johnson, associate dean of the School of Public Health at Loma Linda University,"because Madonna is a vegetarian." Loma Linda, in Southern California, is a Seventh Day Adventist school. At one time its undergraduate dietetic program was not accredited because it was based on a vegetarian diet. Now, people like Dr. Johnson are advising the airline industry about meatless menus because so many passengers request them. And organizations for nutrition professionals, like the American Dietetic Association, offer advice on meatless eating instead of scorning it as they once did.
Madonna is just one of many celebrities -- including Lindsay Wagner, Meredith Baxter, Candice Bergen and Phylicia Rashad -- who prefer to go meatless. All for different reasons.
Candice Bergen told Parade magazine, "You teach children about animals -- piggies and lambs and cows and chickens -- and then feed them these animals for lunch and for supper." Meredith Baxter is a vegetarian because she wants to stay thin, and Phylicia Rashad believes abstinence from meat gives her greater stamina and sense of spiritual well-being.
Dr. Johnson thinks the current interest in vegetarianism is connected with ecological issues -- the waste of natural resources caused by the way livestock is raised. "It's a cause," she said, "to save the earth."
There certainly has been a surge in organizations for teen-agers who have joined together to save the earth. "How on Earth" is a new magazine that says it is for "teens supporting compassionate, ecologically sound living." It is underwritten by a nonprofit organization called Vegetarian Education Network in West Chester, Pa.
Earthsave, a group founded in 1988 by John Robbins, a radical environmentalist, has created a young-people's branch called YES (Youth for Environmental Sanity) that tours the country, bringing its message to high-school students.
And books like Mr. Robbins's "Diet for a New America" (Stillpoint, 1987), and Jeremy Rifkin's "Beyond Beef" (Dutton, 1992), which preach against the "crime" of raising livestock, have captured the imagination of many Americans. Enough so that the beef industry has been issuing news releases and position papers to undermine the theories set forth in these books and others like them.
Being a vegetarian means different things to different people. The Institute of Food Technologists listed six types of vegetarians in its journal, Food Technology, in 1991, but not all of the current forms of vegetarianism are recognized by the traditional vegetarians like the lacto-ovo vegetarians, who include eggs and dairy products in their diets; lacto-vegetarians, who eat dairy; ovo-vegetarians, who eat eggs, and vegans, who eat nothing of animal origin.
The newer variations include semivegetarians, who eat eggs, dairy, chicken and fish, and pesco-vegetarians, who eat dairy, eggs and fish. Many of those who include chicken or fish in their diets are vegetarian not for ethical or environmental reasons. Their form of niche nutrition has more to do with health.
Whether or not the group that has become interested in a vegetarian diet for health reasons is larger than the others, it certainly has gained enormous support from recent studies on diet and health.
This much is known: On average, vegetarians have lower levels of cholesterol and triglycerides than meat eaters of similar age and socio-economic level; the incidence of high blood pressure is generally greater among meat eaters than among vegetarians; cancers of the breast, colon and prostate are more common among people on a high-meat, high-fat, low-fiber diet; on average, vegetarians are leaner than meat eaters; breast milk from vegetarian women contains fewer hazardous chemicals than breast milk from meat eaters.
Two years ago, Dr. Dean Ornish of the Preventive Medicine Research Institute in Sausalito, Calif., was able to show a reduction in coronary artery blockage in people who had followed a strict vegetarian diet, along with a mild exercise and stress-reduction program. The patients, 35 to 75 years old, ate no animal products except egg whites and up to a cup of nonfat milk or yogurt a day. The diet, which was no more than 10 percent fat, consisted of fruits, vegetables, grains, dried peas, beans and lentils. The greatest reduction in blockage was seen in those who made the greatest changes in their regimens.
There is also much tantalizing evidence that fruits and vegetables are filled with substances that reduce the risk of cancer, so much so that the National Cancer Institute and the Produce for Better Health Foundation, an organization established by the produce industry, have instituted a program to encourage the consumption of these foods. The goal is to get Americans to eat a minimum of five half-cup servings of fruits and vegetables a day as part of a low-fat, high-fiber diet. A majority of studies correlating the intake of fruits and vegetables with the incidence of cancer shows that people who eat fewer fruits and vegetables are at significantly more risk for most cancers than those who consumed more.
Based on recent surveys of eating patterns in this country, there is a wide gap between the 10 million or more vegetarians and everyone else. Few Americans come close to eating the minimum recommended amount of fruits and vegetables. In a nationwide Government survey of food consumption patterns, released in 1991, only 9 percent of American adults had eaten five servings of fruits and vegetables on the day of the survey and 11 percent had not eaten any at all on that day.
There's a long way to go in this country before Faith Popcorn's prediction about a vegetarian society is more than just a wild guess.
