LENGTH: 1163 words

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, July 7

 BODY:
Three years ago, somber spokesmen for the Champagne industry declared that the good times were over. For too long, the public had been enjoying their wine at artificially low prices, and the time had come to return to (harsh) reality.
Grape prices were about to skyrocket, they warned, because of a breakdown in relations between growers and the Champagne companies, most of whom own very few of the vineyards whose fruit they crush. Prices had to climb -- steeply. 
 The retail trade was quick to join the chorus. Buy now, the shopkeepers advised; who knew what would happen in the months ahead?
What happened is that prices increased, right on schedule. "It's just as we planned," the industry said, in effect. "Stocks were too low, and mediocre wine was making its way into the market to meet the high demand. As prices increase, demand will fall, just long enough for us to build up stocks a bit and catch our breath."
Demand went down, just as planned. But unlike the heroes of 1930's aviation films, it didn't pull out of its dive. The Comite Interprofessionnel du Vin de Champagne, the industry's professional and promotional organization, said exports fell more than 7 percent in 1990 and just under 10 percent last year. In two years, shipments were down 3.25 million cases, to 17.5 million from 20.75 million. As for stocks on hand, some five years' worth of wine is now in the cellars of Rheims and Epernay, about two years more than the industry wants or needs.
In the United States, the market dropped 15.5 percent in 1989 and 12 percent more last year. In Britain, historically Champagne's best market, shipments were down 34 percent in 1991 after a 6 percent drop in 1989. And nothing suggests that any improvement will occur in 1992.
The domestic market in France has fared no better: it was off about 10 percent last year, to about 11 million cases, from 12.3 million in 1990.
The industry's reaction has been swift. In the Paris market, one of the world's highest priced, little-known brands of Champagne can be found for about $12. Trade publications here have reported prices as low as $9 a bottle. In New York, where not long ago it was being said that any Champagne under $20 would soon be no more than a fond memory, discount wine shops are offering lesser-known brands for $15. And the price is expected to drop further for the end-of-the-year holiday season.
What happened? Impact International, a trade newsletter, cited a confluence of factors, all set off by the precipitous rise of grape prices in 1990. The impact of the Persian Gulf war, the global recession -- Champagne is after all a luxury product -- the falloff in conspicuous consumption (that metaphor of the 1980's) and increased competition from non-Champagne sparkling wines, particularly from Spain, were all suggested as reasons for the decline.
For some 30 years, the price of grapes purchased by the Champagne houses was set by the Comite Interprofessionnel after talks with the growers. Convinced they were not sharing in the prosperity of the 1970's and 80's, the growers began bypassing the big concerns and making their own wine, usually through cooperatives like Marne & Champagne.
With the big houses Louis Vuitton Moet Hennessy, Seagram and Laurent-Perrier demanding a larger and larger share of the grape crop and the growers in a position to make more money on their own, the old arrangement collapsed and the beginnings of a free market appeared.
Now the Champagne concerns get an allotment based on sales volume the previous year and the size of the current crop. In principle the allotment is 5 or 10 percent higher than the previous year. Initially, the price under the new system shot up. From 1989 to 1990, a kilogram of grapes, about 2.2 pounds, went up more than $1, to about $5.75, despite the fact that the 1990 harvest was enormous; Champagne houses wanted grapes to build up their dwindling stocks.
Now, the stocks are up -- too high -- and the price of grapes, which dropped slightly in 1991, is expected to go down further this year, assuming the harvest is normal or better.
Does the current crisis signify long-term problems in Champagne? "The problem," said Jean-Claude Rouzaud, chairman of Louis Roederer and president of the Syndicat des Grandes Marques, the organization of the big Champagne concerns, "is to determine whether the current slowdown reflects the economic crisis or a change in consumer attitudes."
If the problem is economic, it should resolve itself. A gradual end to the recession could spark interest in some luxury products. And, too, a couple of poor harvests could shrink stocks again. In any case, the industry plans to seek lower grape prices this fall and to set aside part of the 1992 harvest for a less abundant year. And, of course, to lower prices.
From the consumer's point of view, it can be argued that even in the over-$20 and over-$30 categories, Champagne is not expensive when compared with the most prestigious still wines. Even in the current tough market, a top Burgundy can sell for $60. The first growths of Bordeaux are priced well above that, and most second growths command as much. So do top California cabernets.
Somehow, Champagne has managed to preserve its luxury image even though its prices, comparatively speaking, are not all that high. But with many more cheap brands entering the market each year, the industry will have to make a greater effort to insure that Champagne continues to be seen as a drink apart.
One approach has been suggested by Christian Bizot, the president of Champagne Bollinger. Mr. Bizot would create a classification system like those in Bordeaux and Burgundy. The finest Champagnes would be called grande marque Champagne, and back labels would disclose production methods, length of aging, grape varieties used and their origin.
Only Champagne concerns that met the high grande marque requirements could sell their wines under that rubric, Mr. Bizot said. He first made his proposal in March, and all factions say they are considering it.
 
TASTINGS
Chateau Chamirey, Mercurey, Antonin Rodet, 1988; about $20.
 Along with Faiveley and Bouchard Aine, Antonin Rodet is one of the most important producers in Mercurey, the popular wine commune in Burgundy. Actually, it's just south of the famous Cote d'Or in a region called the Cote Chalonnaise. This location doesn't prevent its wines from being as good as, and sometimes better than, some far more famous -- and expensive -- wines from better-known towns to the north. This is a rich, velvety pinot noir, dark red like most good 1988's, and with plenty of that earthy component that makes fine Burgundy unique. This is a wine for drinking now and over the next three or four years. Not that $20 is inexpensive; it's just that in this case it represents good value for the money. What's more, as Mercurey becomes better known, its prices will rise. Buy now and have something to remember.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: On the Trail;
HARKIN TO GET HIS REWARD AT CONVENTION

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, the loyal soldier who ran for President, fell on his political sword and then turned into an energetic campaigner on behalf of the foe who vanquished him, will get his reward next Tuesday.
At 10 P.M. that night, aides to Mr. Harkin said, the Senator will deliver a speech on jobs and the economy, giving him a valuable convention platform from which to deliver one of his trademark speeches. Mr. Harkin has been the most supportive of Gov. Bill Clinton's original competitors for the Democratic Presidential nomination, but was never seriously considered for the Vice Presidency. 
 Clinton campaign officials have been grateful for Mr. Harkin's help, especially in the Pennsylvania and New York primaries, where the Iowa Senator played a major role in recruiting recalcitrant labor leaders to Mr. Clinton's side.

HEADLINE: Bank Yields Down Sharply

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's decision last week to lower the discount rate and the subsequent cut in the prime lending rate by most big banks set the table for a steep decline in yields for bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit in the week ended today.
Analysts at The Bank Rate Monitor said the declines in yields were among the biggest weekly drops in many years. "This clearly refutes what many banks were talking up last week -- that the decline in yields was near the bottom," said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor. 
 "This could cause a further erosion of depositors at banks. But there will always remain that hard core who remember the Depression and keep put rather than risk their cash elsewhere," Mr. Heady said.
 
Bill Rates Drop
 At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills on Monday, rates fell sharply because of the cuts initiated by the Fed. The auction is seen as an indicator of what many banks will pay to their depositors in coming weeks.
The average rate on a three-month bill was 3.23 percent, down 36 basis points from the previous auction, while the six-month bill fell 34 basis points, to 3.32 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
New York area banks, including commercial and savings banks, took a head start in this latest round of cuts and reduced the average money market account 14 basis points, to 3.20 percent, while cutting the yield on a three-month certificate of deposit 19 basis points, to 3.30 percent, and a six-month C.D. 16 basis points, to 3.48 percent.
Commercial banks were aggressive in lowering yields. The average money market account fell 13 basis points, to 2.96 percent; the average three-month C.D., 23 basis points, to 3.1 percent, and the average six- month C.D., 19 basis points, to 3.22 percent.
Savings banks were just as aggressive, lowering the average money market account 15 basis points, to 3.44 percent; the three-month C.D., 14 basis points, to 3.52 percent, and the six-month C.D., 13 basis points, to 3.73 percent.
Among the largest changes in the New York area, Astoria Federal Savings dropped its money market account 62 basis points, to 2.94 percent, and its six-month C.D. 42 basis points, to 3.40 percent. Fleet Bank in Connecticut, cut more than 50 basis points from its three-month C.D., to 3.04 percent.
For 20 large banks outside the New York market, the average bank money market account was down 12 basis points, to 3.11 percent, and the six-month certificate was down 16 basis points, to 3.42 percent.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MUNICH;
7 NATIONS UNABLE TO AGREE ON TRADE BUT SEE PROGRESS

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MUNICH, Germany, July 8

 BODY:
Leaders of the world's richest industrial democracies narrowed their differences on world trade today. While they failed to reach an accord, they left the economic summit meeting here with many confident that an agreement was possible by the end of the year.
As they have at the last two summit meetings, the leaders vowed to conclude the so-called Uruguay Round of trade negotiations within a few months. 
 In the past, similar promises have proved empty. But this time, both European and American officials said, there had been progress in resolving the differences on farm subsidies that have paralyzed the talks.
 
French Concessions Expected
 Many officials said that after a referendum on European union in France on Sept. 20, in which the Government of President Francois Mitterrand needs the support of farmers, France would be prepared to make concessions so that the contentious talks on agriculture to be concluded.
"I am not only optimistic, but I truly expect that we will finally reach an agreement by the end of the year," said Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who had not been sanguine on the possibility of completing the negotiations.
Economists say that a successful conclusion of the talks would add about half a percentage point to the world's economic growth rate, which in turn would bolster business confidence. The sagging world economy grew just eight-tenths of 1 percent last year.
 
Help for Russia, With a Warning
 The seven nations also agreed to channel $1 billion in aid to Russia as part of a "comprehensive partnership" with Moscow, but warned that additional help for the former Communist countries depended on evidence that they were working hard to reform their economies. [Page A12.]
Bush Administration officials cautioned that even if the farm issues were resolved this fall, other critical issues needed to be settled and an agreement might not be possible before the United States election in November.
Aides to President Bush are also concerned that any long-term economic benefits of a trade accord would be hard to sell to voters, especially if workers in the steel, textile and citrus industries see themselves as suffering from a new flood of imports.
Mr. Bush has been a strong advocate of a trade agreement because investment banks, pharmaceutical manufacturers, computer makers and other businesses would benefit from greater access to foreign markets.
In their final declaration of the three-day talks, the leaders could do little to disguise the fact that they had failed to stimulate the world economy.
Among other promises, they vowed to "create the scope for lower interest rates through the reduction of excessive public deficits." But the United States has already lowered interest rates about as far as it can, Germany is not prepared to do so until it has controlled a budget deficit swollen by reunification, and Japan is grappling with an economic downturn and the psychological shock of seeing its stock prices plunge.
The bluntest assessment of the talks was provided by Prime Minister John Major, who declared, "There are no specific agreements on anything in the final declaration."
Mr. Major had hoped for more. Aides said he came to Munich with an elaborate plan to coax the participants into agreement. He came close.
 
Details Seemed to Be Settled
 A dinner on Sunday night attended by Mr. Bush and Mr. Mitterrand had narrowed differences between the two countries most at odds here, and a meeting on Monday morning between Mr. Major, senior European Community officials and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d suggested that a trade accord was technically feasible.
In essence, several United States and European officials said, the elements of a deal were in place: the European participants, principally France, would agree to cut their subsidized grain exports, and the United States would accept some limit on its exports of cereal substitutes -- mainly corn-gluten feed -- to Europe.
France has been particularly angered by Washington's insistence that it reduce its subsidized grain exports by 24 percent. But the officials said the British proposals for a somewhat lesser cut spread over a longer period, combined with Washington's willingness to cap exports of corn-gluten feed, seemed to have brought the sides within range of an accord.
On another European sticking point -- an agreement by the United States not to take legal action against alleged European trade malpractices for a certain period -- the two sides were also moving closer, the officials said.
 
Yes? No. C'mon, Yes!? No.
 Then, on Monday night, Mr. Baker and the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, attended the same dinner. A senior European official who overheard their conversation said an extraordinary exchange ensued.
"Are you prepared to make a deal?" Mr. Baker asked, referring to the trade talks.
Mr. Dumas replied that he was not.
"But suppose all the conditions you are seeking were fulfilled," Mr. Baker said. "Would you then be prepared to make a deal?"
"No," said Mr. Dumas.
So before the talks had even reached the second day, it was clear that not even an outline trade agreement could be reached and that the final communique would be no more than a list of good intentions.
Paris disputes that account.
Several officials close to President Mitterrand said he was prepared to make a trade deal. But, they argued, the United States refused to budge as much as the European Community already had in agreeing to reforms intended to reduce agricultural subsidies.
Despite the confidence of future progress expressed by many of the summit leaders today, concluding a GATT agreement is likely to be intricate.
Even if the dispute over farm subsidies is quickly resolved, no overall agreement would be ready until after the November elections.
Critical issues like international patent protection and tariff reductions remain unresolved, and even the most optimistic negotiators say these matters will require four to six months to settle after the farm subsidies issue is finally set aside.
Pessimists inside and outside the Administration say that these questions could prove almost as tough as farm subsidies, and predict that the talks will quickly become deadlocked again, even with an agreement on agriculture.
Few Republican strategists, particularly those working on President Bush's re-election campaign, have been enthusiastic about completing a trade agreement in an election year. They fear that a global free-trade pact will please few voters because its benefits are hard to understand while workers in the steel and textile industries and in citrus-fruit growing are likely to suffer -- and will vote accordingly.
 
But Would It Change Votes?
 Investment banks, pharmaceutical manufacturers and computer makers would benefit from extra access to foreign markets and better legal protections abroad for their trade secrets. But Republican strategists have been skeptical that employees in these industries would vote any differently if an agreement were concluded.
The Administration and the campaign have not systematically analyzed the political implications of a GATT deal because of a consensus that no agreement is likely in the immediate future. Mr. Mitterrand must win next September's referendum on the European monetary union, and cannot afford to have French farmers picketing Euro-Disney for the next three months, a top Administration official said last Friday.
Yet the Bush Administration is unwilling to settle for any agreement that will not "drive French farmers crazy," the official said, making a prolonged standoff highly likely.

CHILD LABORERS IN INDIA
For 12, 14, 16 hours a day, every day of the week, every week of the year, thousands of children, some as young as 8 are forced to sit on rough planks and help make the carpets that India sells around the world. The United States is the biggest customer for Indian carpets. A8

In another serious setback for Japan's budding space program, the Government announced that it would delay the launching of its next-generation rocket by a year because of a recent accident. The H-II is the first rocket to be built solely by Japan and is a source of national pride. It will be the first rocket powerful enough to let Japan launch communications and weather satellites. A9

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1084 words

HEADLINE: HOUSE VOTES BILL TOUGHER ON TRADE

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
Turning aside a last-minute surge of White House lobbying, the House of Representatives today passed a broad trade bill that would require the Federal Government to adopt a more confrontational approach to reducing foreign trade barriers.
The vote, 280 to 145, reflected election-year considerations as much as foreign trade factors, with Democrats hoping to present the President with a measure that would force him into a politically unpopular veto and Republicans hoping to be able to label the Democrats as crassly protectionist.
 
Prospects Remain Uncertain
 
 If the Administration had defeated the bill today, it would almost certainly have prevented a trade bill from reaching the President's desk this year. Even now,prospects for final passage remain uncertain. The House vote is fully 10 votes short of the two-thirds majority needed to overcome a Presidential veto. And before that stage is reached, the measure would have to pass the Senate, where no comparable bill has even been introduced and the autumn legislative calendar is already crowded.
But in an election year a bill could suddenly move fast, Republicans could start voting for it, and the President might not necessarily follow through on this veto threat. In a last-ditch effort to prevent the measure from becoming a campaign issue, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, spent nearly two hours this morning urging House Republicans to vote against the measure, while Administration lobbyists patrolled the halls in search of wavering representatives.
Yet 34 Republicans joined 245 Democrats and an independent in support of the bill, while 15 Democrats and 130 Republicans opposed it. The large number of members crossing party lines in both directions -- unusual on highly partisan issues -- reflected members' ideological positions on free trade and varying regional interests.
Representative Sam Gibbons, the Florida Democrat and avowed free-trader who heads the subcommittee on trade, voted against the bill after repeatedly using the Republicans' time during the debate to criticize the American auto industry's export efforts. Representative Richard T. Schulze, Republican of Pennsylvania, a steelmaking state ravaged by imports, voted in favor of the measure after pointing out that it would help domestic industries that file trade cases against imports from formerly Communist countries.
 
More Dumping Seen
 These countries' shortage of internationally traded currencies "will lead them to dump as many products as they can, as quickly as possible, into the hospitable U.S. market," Mr. Schulze said during debate this morning before the vote.
Today's bill would also revive Super 301, a section of American trade law, much reviled by foreign governments, that would force the Administration to challenge foreign trade barriers on a faster and more rigid schedule. The bill would oblige the Administration to file trade cases against Japan, Korea and Taiwan because of their restrictions on American rice exports and another trade case seeking to open the Japanese market for auto parts.
Under an amendment added this afternoon on the floor, the bill would also order the Administration to replace Japanese auto makers' self-imposed limit of 1.65 million cars exported this year to the United States with a lasting limit at the same level imposed by both Governments. The bill would also require the Administration to monitor the compliance of Japanese auto makers with the Japanese Government's informal offer to President Bush in Tokyo last January to double Japanese purchases of American auto parts by 1994.
Both the White House and Congressional Democrats claimed victory after today's vote. Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the majority leader from Missouri, said the bill had lured more Republican votes than he expected. "At bottom, I think, the Congress is desirous of more aggressive trade policies," he said after the vote.
 
Gephardt Sees a Bill
 Mr. Gephardt said that he would be talking soon to Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee, and that he believed a trade bill could be delivered to the President "as soon as possible" this autumn.
But Kathleen A. Lydon, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Hills, also described the vote as a success. "We're delighted because it's not veto-proof and it was not bipartisan, and it clearly was election-year politics," she said. "There's no point in the Senate picking it up except as a political tool."
The Administration's strategy has been full of risk. It made little effort to water down the trade bill, and discouraged House Republicans from introducing a more limited alternative.
Yet House Democrats from car-making states ended up watering down the bill on their own to win support from other Democrats, withdrawing a measure that would have tightly restricted imports from Japan and sales by Japanese-owned assembly plants in the United States.
Mr. Bentsen has been reluctant to move on a comparable Senate measure until the House acted. He said in an interview on July 1 that he had not yet decided whether to sponsor a trade bill. The Senator was traveling today and not available for comment, but his aides said that they did not believe the Senator had made up his mind yet.
A bigger stumbling block, from Mr. Bentsen's point of view, may be his disagreement with Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr, Democrat of Michigan. Mr. Riegle has said repeatedly that he would try to amend it with his plan to allow Congress to change a free-trade agreement with Mexico and Canada after it has been negotiated.
 
Texas Big Beneficiary
 Economists say that border states like Texas would be the biggest beneficiaries from a free-trade pact, and Senator Bentsen has been a strong backer of negotiating an agreement. Trade negotiators from all three countries are in the final stages of drafting such an agreement. Amending the agreement in Congress could scuttle it, if Mexico and Canada do not agree to the changes.
A general framework could be ready when President Bush meets President Carlos Salinas de Gortari at baseball's All-Star Game next week, although Administration officials say this is unlikely.
Some representatives also warned that passage of restrictive trade legislation this year could hurt negotiations in Geneva for an agreement reducing international trade barriers, and that such an agreement would require revamping American trade legislation next year anyway.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
For Perot, a Time of Need

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, July 8

 BODY:
Now is the testing time for Ross Perot. The last few weeks have battered the Texas independent's still-undeclared Presidential campaign and have stalled its momentum, causing slippage in the polls and worry here in the offices of the Perot Petition Committee, a suite of rooms with a clean, shiny just-unwrapped look.
Mr. Perot, who conceived of, and sold, his extraordinary run for the Presidency as a rebellion against the ways and wiles of party politics, has discovered he is not, after all, above the problems that bedevil mortal politicians: organizational weaknesses, turf battles in the ranks, criticism in the press and from opponents, the threats and persistence of pressure groups, the endless, complex demands of a national campaign.
 
On-the-Job Training
 
 He is learning the immutable needs and frustrations of the job he has set for himself. He needs good press, and he has found political reporters far more fickle and reflexively critical than the business writers to whom he is accustomed.
He needs a pleasant, positive image, and he has found that opponents are determined to paint him in darker hues.
He needs to attract a running mate and policy advisers of the sort that advertise his credibility, and he has found that few members of the establishment he so colorfully disdains wish to have much to do with him.
Above all, it appears he needs the very thing he most mocked a month ago: clear, detailed positions on the issues.
But now he finds himself modifying some early stands. Today he said he would not rule out naming someone to a Cabinet position on the basis of sexual orientation, reversing a stance that had earned him the wrath of gay groups [Page A18].
From the outset of his undeclared campaign, Mr. Perot presented himself not as a thinker, but as a doer, someone who should be made President not so much for any specific ideas on how to fix the nation's ills, but simply because he was, in general, good at fixing things. A President Perot would be a sort of Mechanic in Chief -- as he often put it, "under the hood of the car, working on the engine."
It now appears that many voters did not accept the analogy. At Perot rallies, on television and radio programs, and even in Mr. Perot's own campaign headquarters, reporters hear the same thing over and over.
"I like Mr. Perot a lot, but I'm still undecided about voting for him," said Ken M. Hiltz, a retired Air Force fighter pilot who was serving as grand marshal of an Independence Day rally on behalf of Mr. Perot. "I just don't know enough about where he stands. I guess I'm like the old boy from Missouri: Show me."
The event seemed nearly an advertisement for the varied ills of the Perot campaign. It was the sort of thing that sounded great on paper: a red, white and blue, Fourth of July Perot-for-President rally at Southfork Ranch, the opulent Dallas-area spread that served as the television home of the mythical Ewing clan. There would be a parade, music, fireworks, perhaps Mr. Perot.
The reality was a good deal less. The rally was put together on a week's notice by local volunteers who did not coordinate their activities with campaign headquarters a few miles away. Scheduled in the middle of a day devoted to long-planned activities with family and friends, it drew only a few hundred people. Mr. Perot never made an appearance, and no member of the Perot family or high command showed up to serve as surrogate.
The parade consisted of three Scout troops, a bagpipe band, one woman on horseback, one man with a 'Make U.S. History with Ross Perot' sign, two small fire trucks and an honor guard consisting of a lone Gulf War veteran and six men from the Plano, Texas, Veterans of Foreign Wars post. It lasted 5 minutes. After another 10 or 15 minutes, the amateur speechmakers ran out of things to say. The band struck up a country and western tune, but only one couple was brave enough to even think of dancing on the shadeless grass under the baking sky. An hour after it began, long before it was dark enough for fireworks, all but 20 or 30 people had succumbed to heat and ennui, and departed.
Perot campaign officials acknowledge they must get beyond this sort of thing, must begin to shape what they are about, rather than simply following Mr. Perot as he goes ahead on a path of his own spontaneous making.
"We recognize that we have to have people in key spots who are political professionals," said the Perot Petition Committee chairman, Tom Luce, in an interview today. "People who have been there, who can say, 'Hey, Perot, here are the things -- X, Y, and Z -- that are going to happen to you in the next 30 days, and here are our recommendations for dealing with those things."
 
Surprise Attack
 To this end, the campaign has hired, in the last month or so, a full range of political pros. The considerable task facing these men is to refurbish the Perot public image, greatly tarnished by Republican attacks and news coverage that caught the campaign off guard last month.
"I personally was surprised by the timing of the attack, by the degree of the efforts the opposition parties were willing to go to," said Mr. Luce. "And, while I think Ross handled it very well, to the extent that they succeeded in making the agenda a debate on the personality of Ross Perot and not on the economy and the budget, it was good for them.
"We are going to have to move beyond that now. We have got to get Ross rolling out there with his policies, saying every day: 'Folks, here are the core issues facing this country -- the economy, jobs, the deficit, health care -- and, folks, you need 'to know what I am going to do about those issues, so let me tell you what I am going to do."
Until that happens, Mr. Luce suggested, it will be very difficult for Mr. Perot to move up in the polls. "There is a large number of people out there who want to vote for Mr. Perot, who want to choose him," he said. "But they want some answers: Where are you headed, and how are you going to get there."
Mr. Luce would not say when the campaign would be ready take this step -- originally promised by July 4 -- other than that it would be before the end of the summer.
Former Reagan advertising producer Hal Riney was busy shooting film here on Tuesday, but the advertisements he was making won't be ready for some time either, Mr. Luce said.
In the meantime, those who are, for one professional reason or another, critical of Mr. Perot, will continue to define him in the public eye. This kind of thing has happened before, most famously to a man named Michael Dukakis.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN MUNICH -- Yeltsin's Song: Summit Blues;
7 Pats on the Back -- And Some Token Aid

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MUNICH, Germany, July 8

 BODY:
Boris N. Yeltsin's journey to Munich was familiar: the preliminary vow that he would not "get on his knees" before the West, an encouraging pat from leaders of the rich world, a handful of change and promises of far more once he really got moving on reforms.
Mikhail S. Gorbachev had made the same pilgrimage a year earlier, when the Group of Seven met in London, and Mr. Yeltsin had recently returned from much the same sort of thing in Washington at a meeting with President Bush. 
 True, there was talk of a new relationship with a new, democratic Russia, and hints that Mr. Yeltsin might have a rightful place at the exclusive table of the democratic, rich and strong.
But in fact there was little difference between Mr. Yeltsin's standing and that of Mr. Gorbachev before him. Neither was invited because he represented a big, powerful or worthy country, but more because the leader and his country were so weak as to pose a potential threat to global stability.
 
Dose of Shock Therapy
 There were differences, of course. A year ago Mr. Gorbachev was still clinging to the old elites and resisting real economic liberalization, while Mr. Yeltsin had at least given the first jolt of an economic "shock therapy" and seemed authentically dedicated to change.
But in a way, the Russian President's reach to the West was more difficult. Mr. Gorbachev at least represented a recognized system and indisputable power, while Mr. Yeltsin and his Russia were still groping for an identity and a place in the world.
It was obvious in Munich, at least, that Russia and its leader were still very much on probation. The rich nations were clearly not yet ready to throw open their coffers, and certainly not to clear a place for Russia in their exclusive club. If there was a debate in the posturing and posing of the summit, it was on how best to prop up Mr. Yeltsin's administration while reserving the bulk of proffered aid as a reward for real change.
The greater question, as evident in Munich as in Moscow, was not whether Russia was ruled by a Communist Party or not, but whether that huge and richly endowed country was really prepared to renounce the imperial ambitions, the authoritarian heritage, the military might and the anti-Western instincts that had estranged it for so long.
 
'East-West Divide' Persists
 Mr. Yeltsin arrived in Bavaria conscious of the West's reserve. "The cold war has ended," he said, "but so far our economic relations have not become a partnership. The East-West divide is still there."
The shape of that partnership, the leaders of the great powers effectively replied, ultimately depended not on them, but on a choice only Russia could make.
"I don't know that there's enough money in all the world to solve Russia's economy," Mr. Bush said at his news conference. Western assistance, he said, "has to be accompanied by a vigorous reform program."
Nobody really doubted Mr. Yeltsin's determination and courage, nor the free-market faith and Western orientation of his acting Prime Minister, Yegor T. Gaidar. But the signals from Moscow were not always encouraging.
 
Unrest at Home
 The Communist far left and nationalist far right found common cause in their nostalgia for might and order. The orphaned military grew more assertive, claiming the right to help Russians trapped in foreign civil wars. Those wars continued to intensify on the periphery of the former empire, oblivious to mediation. Ukraine seemed to grow ever less inclined to surrender its nuclear weapons, while the Central Asian republics felt the heat of Islamic fundamentalism.
The economic landscape was hardly more encouraging. Despite vigorous debate and more than 500 decrees, privatization was barely moving, land ownership remained blocked, inflation threatened to run out of control and production declined. Miscalculations by the central Government led to monstrous debts among state concerns, and a shortage of cash prevented many from receiving pay for months.
It is a situation many have compared to Russia in 1917 or to Weimar Germany, a fertile chaos in which anything can happen. For now, Mr. Yeltsin remains secure in his popularity and lack of serious challengers. But hardly a week goes by without some senior official or commentator -- most recently Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev -- warning of a potential challenge from the frustrated political fringes.
 
Warning to I.M.F.
 Mr. Yeltsin dismissed such muttering at his news conference in Munich. But even he warned in talks with the International Monetary Fund that his people were reaching "the limits of their patience," when he declared that raising oil prices at this time was out of question.
There are limits, he doubtlessly also knows, to how fast Russia can change, to how fast it can find a new identity. It is a country that inherited a huge military machine and a desolate economy from the Communist state, along with attributes and habits of a great power -- a seat on the United Nations Security Council, a hot line to Washington, a critical role in European security.
These are not attributes that Mr. Yeltsin or Russia can easily shed, physically or economically or psychologically. Speaking of the difficulties of withdrawing from the Baltic states, Mr. Yeltsin said: "You have to understand us too. We can't take 100,000 soldiers and put them in an open field."
If it was only the troops, Russia might soon be home free. But it is also a mind set shaped through the past 70 years that he must change, a habit of viewing the West as a rival and of neighboring countries as fiefs, a pride born of might, a disdain of commerce and a respect for the strong leader. Mr. Yeltsin, a former Communist and a man enormously proud of his land, must wrestle with these habits as much as any of his countrymen, however genuine his faith in reform. He would not have become the Russian leader any other way.
And so in Munich, as in Washington, the world witnesses another Russian proudly insisting that respect is his natural due even while openly admitting his dependence on the former adversary. And it witnesses a clutch of powerful leaders conscious that their security depends on this man and anxious to encourage him, but just as clear that there is a long way to go before he can join them.

HEADLINE: Robert Calkins, 89; Headed Brookings Institution

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Robert D. Calkins, an economist and educator who was president emeritus of the Brookings Institution, died yesterday at the Carriage Hill Nursing Center in Silver Spring, Md. He was 89 years old.
He died of pneumonia, the nursing center said. 
 Dr. Calkins led Brookings from 1952-67 during an era of growth as an influential policy analysis organization. Brookings, a nonprofit institution, specializes in foreign policy, economic and government issues.
During his tenure, Brookings broadened its range of research projects, expanded its budget fivefold, enlarged its staff, built a major endowment and tripled its space by building its Center for Advanced Study in Washington.
The organization's influence was evident when President John F. Kennedy took office in 1961. His Administration relied heavily on the institute's briefing papers on many issues facing the nation. Theodore C. Sorensen, who was Kennedy's special counsel, wrote that Brookings "deserves a large share of the credit for history's smoothest transfer of power between opposing parties."
Before running Brookings, Dr. Calkins served from 1947-52 as the director of the General Education Board, a foundation financed by John D. Rockefeller Sr. that promoted education improvements in the South.
In his earlier academic career, Dr. Calkins was an administrator at the University of California at Berkeley from 1932-41, serving as chairman of the Economics Department for five years and dean of the College of Commerce for four years. From 1941-47 he was dean of the Business School at Columbia University.
After leaving Brookings in 1967, he returned to academia, becoming vice chancellor of the University of California at Santa Cruz until 1970.
 
Labor Mediator
 In labor relations, Dr. Calkins served as vice chairman of the Regional Labor Board of San Francisco, a member of the National Railway Labor Panel and a mediator for the War Labor Board during World War II.
His other Government service included serving as director of the New York Federal Reserve Bank and a member of the 1957 Gaither Committee, which conducted a top-secret review of the country's military and civil defense for the National Security Council.
Born in Lebanon, Conn., Dr. Calkins grew up in Florida and Virginia.
He worked his way through the College of William and Mary as a telephone operator and drug store soda jerk, graduating in 1925. He spent the next seven years at Stanford University, earning his master's and doctoral degrees in economics.
His wife of nearly 63 years, the former Mary Gilmer, died in March. He is survived by a daughter, Elizabeth C. Davis of Pullman, Wash.; a son, Robert G. of Ithaca, N.Y., and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Appeals Court Voids Rules On Work-Place Air Quality

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 8

 BODY:
National air-quality standards for the work place have been thrown out by a Federal appeals court, which said the Government agency that set the standards had not given sufficient supporting evidence for the rules.
The standards, issued in early 1989 by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, were challenged by unions as too weak and criticized by industrial groups, which said the agency had not shown that the standards were economically and technologically feasible. 
 A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit here said in its ruling late Tuesday that the agency had issued its standards for 428 substances with "such inadequate explanation that it is virtually impossible for a reviewing court to determine if evidence supports the agency's conclusions."
The panel also said the agency had given insufficient explanation for its decision to wait nearly four years, until the end of 1992, before requiring that industries meet the standards.
 
'Devoid of Reasons'
 An OSHA spokesman said today that the lawyers for the agency, which is part of the Labor Department, had not had time to study the ruling and would have no immediate comment.
The standards lowered the permissible limits for exposure to 212 substances that can be found in the air in work places and set limits for 164 substances that were previously unregulated. For 52 others, limits were unchanged.
They were challenged by the A.F.L.-C.I.O., individual unions and numerous industrial associations, including the American Petroleum Institute, the American Iron and Steel Institute and the Corn Refiners Association.
"With rare exceptions, the individual substance discussions in the Air Contaminants Standard are virtually devoid of reasons for setting those individual standards," the judges said.
The unanimous decision was by Judge Peter T. Fay, appointed to the court by President Gerald R. Ford; Judge Emmett R. Cox, appointed by President Ronald Reagan, and Senior Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr., appointed by President Jimmy Carter.
 
Reduced Risk Is Unproven
 The judges said the agency had shown that the substances on the list posed a significant risk when they were present in the air at some levels. But it said the agency had not proven that its new air-quality levels were low enough to significantly reduce that risk.
The court said that in most cases the agency had cited a few studies and then established an exposure limit without explaining why the studies mandated the limit.
The court said the only explanation the agency gave for setting such standards was that time and resource constraints prevented detailed analyses of the substances.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Economic Memo;
Clinton's Economic Plan Has a Roosevelt Tone

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
Democrats hate to admit it, but Bill Clinton sometimes sounds like Ronald Reagan, especially when he says that the economy can grow its way out of the budget deficit.
Bush partisans who deride Governor Clinton's economic program often sound the way Democrats did when they questioned whether the tax cuts of President Reagan's first term would reduce the Federal deficit. 
 But appearances can be deceiving. When the Arkansas Governor and apparent Democratic Presidential nominee calls not for tax cuts but for more spending on public investment, he sounds far more like a Roosevelt Democrat than a Reagan Republican.
Mr. Clinton's advisers acknowledge that their plan relies heavily on economic growth. But they assert that their focus on increasing investment will serve as an engine for growth that will in turn increase tax revenue, reduce poverty and cut the demand for social programs like food stamps. All this, they say, will serve to lower the deficit.
 
$200 Billion Public Investment

The heart of the Clinton plan is spending $200 billion over four years on public investment: building high-speed railroads and a national computernetwork and improving education and job training. This, his advisers say, will increase productivity by three-tenths of a percent a year. They decline to estimate how much it will spur growth.
Indeed, what comes through strongest in speaking to Mr. Clinton and his advisers is their conviction that enhancing investment is a more urgent priority than cutting the deficit. And while insisting that he remains committed to eliminating the deficit, Mr. Clinton said the economic plan he unveiled on June 21, was influenced by 100 leading economists, including six Nobel laureates, who signed a letter urging the Government to spend $50 billion a year on investments to speed economic growth.
"In the absence of increasing investment in this country, including public investment, you can't get growth going again," Mr. Clinton said.
There is an undeniable adroitness to Mr. Clinton's economic plan, just as there was to President Reagan's. Mr. Reagan's arguments that tax cuts would increase growth and Government revenue dovetailed perfectly with conservative dogma. And Mr. Clinton's contention that beefed-up public investment will produce growth and a lower deficit dovetails neatly with Democratic beliefs.
The new Clinton plan has drawn plenty of Republican fire, with Vice President Dan Quayle lambasting it as just another "tax-and-spend" Democratic proposal that fails to discipline spending. He said the plan does not get serious about cutting the deficit. And conservative economists generally contend that it is too generous in estimating how fast growth will be and too stingy about specific proposals to trim the deficit.
"I don't think he has really addressed the budget deficit at all," said Edward Hudgins, an economist at the Heritage Foundation. "Unfortunately, he still hasn't focused on the major structural reasons for big spending and high taxes."
Mr. Hudgins is among those who fault the Governor's plan for failing to spell out how it would reduce spiraling Medicare and Medicaid costs.
Other conservative critics of Mr. Clinton say he exaggerates how much money can be collected by closing loopholes on foreign companies doing business in the United States. And some say that to obtain the gains in tax revenue that he envisions, Mr. Clinton's plan need annual economic growth at an unattainably high 5 percent.
"Seriously analyzed, it is transparently a phony," said Richard G. Darman, the Bush Administration's budget director.
The Congressional Budget Office predicts that the deficit will fall to $190 billion in the fiscal year 1996 from about $330 billion next year. Mr. Clinton says that under his plan, the deficit will fall to $141 billion in 1996.
According to the budget office, the main reason for the anticipated decline is that while the Government will pay out some $69 billion next year to bail out failed savings and loans, the Government expects to earn about $45 billion in the fiscal year 1996 when it sells off thrift institutions that are restored to health.
"The worst someone can say is we have a bold investment agenda," said Gene Sperling, director of economic policy for the Clinton campaign. "We detail how we are going to pay for every single cent of new spending, and we have billions left over for deficit reduction." Mr. Sperling conceded, however, that without an increase in growth, their plan would cut the deficit by only about $8 billion a year.
To pay for his ambitious investment plan, Mr. Clinton would cut spending by $140 billion from 1993 to 1996, suggesting, for instance, deeper cuts in the Pentagon budget. He would raise $58 billion by closing tax loopholes enjoyed by foreign corporations and would also raise taxes on the richest 2 percent of Americans by $92 billion over four years -- an increase that the Governor said would affect couples earning more than $200,000 a year.
 
Economists' Arguments
 The 100 economists promoting a $50-billion-a-year investment plan argue that such spending will lift the economy in the short term and create a more competitive economy in the long run. They say that by stimulating growth, and thus tax revenue, the plan will increase the deficit by considerably less than $50 billion a year.
The economists draw a sharp distinction between the effect of their plan and Mr. Reagan's tax cuts, which he said would stimulate the economy and eliminate the deficit. The economists say their plan will do more to hold down the deficit, because the deficit spending they envision will be go not for consumption but for investment.
The Clinton plan, like that of the the proposal of the 100 economists, embraces Keynesian deficit-spending techniques to accelerate growth. In that way, it resembles the modest tax cuts of President John F. Kennedy, which spurred a lackluster economy and, many economists say, helped cut the deficit.
Mr. Clinton said he plans many moves outside the Democratic mold, such as cutting Washington's bureaucracy by 100,000 workers and trimming Federal administrative costs by 3 percent a year.
As for criticism that closing loopholes on the foreign corporations would not bring in $15 billion a year, Mr. Sperling noted that the revenue projected in the Clinton program was only half that of Congressional studies.
 
Health Care Package to Come
 Mr. Clinton also said he did not include in his deficit-reduction plan any possible savings from reining in health-care costs because he is still working on a comprehensive health plan. He said the money saved "in reforming the Medicare and Medicaid system" will in large part go to helping finance "a basic health care package for uninsured Americans."
Six winners of the Nobel Memorial Prize in economics have praised Mr. Clinton's plan. They are Kenneth Arrow of Stanford University, Lawrence Klein of the University of Pennsylvania, James Tobin of Yale and Franco Modigliani, Paul Samuelson and Robert M. Solow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
"Clinton's economic program makes prudent sense," said Professor Samuelson. "America most needs capital formation -- human and material capital, private and public capital."

HEADLINE: Tokyo Slide Has No Shock Wave

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Just a few years ago, lots of people worried that a financial collapse in Tokyo would devastate financial markets and economies everywhere, and nowhere more than in the United States.
But now that the wildly inflated Tokyo stock market has dropped a swooping 60 percent in two years, hitting a six-year low just last week, the plunge has created more ripples than waves in this country. 
 "So far financial distress in Japan has had astonishingly little impact on the U.S.," said David Wyss, chief financial economist for DRI/McGraw-Hill. "And that's probably going to continue."
In fact, the clearest evidence in the American economy that Japan has problems lies in what is not happening. Japanese investors are no longer snapping up luxury Hawaiian hotels, Impressionist paintings or Manhattan office towers. Mitsubishi, Sumitomo and other Japanese bankers have stopped undercutting their American competitors on loans and letters of credit.
Nor has there been any wholesale dumping of United States Treasury securities by Japanese investors -- the nightmare most often cited when financial experts tried to imagine what might happen if Japan disengaged from the United States financial markets. According to the doomsayers, the world's markets are so tightly intermeshed, and the wheels of America's financial markets so lubricated by Japanese money, that the machinery could not run without Japan's backing.
Why has there not been more impact?
Bankers, stockbrokers, real estate deal makers and economists have lots of answers. They range from the fact that Japan's stock market drop was stretched over two years -- rather than a couple of days -- to the fact that Japanese money continues to flow abroad (albeit in different forms), to the fact that the easygoing Japanese regulators are not putting pressure on banks to face up to their losses and liquidate their holdings.
Moreover, despite the increasingly international outlook of investors, stock ownership remains overwhelmingly national. Tokyo and Wall Street, as often as not, have gone their separate ways.
"If anything, this whole Japanese stock market deflation is helping the U.S. market," said Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist at Bear Stearns. "It's seen as a safe haven."
Indeed, Japanese investors have continued to send money abroad. Although the plunge in Tokyo stock values has cooled Japan's capital spending boom, it has not made Japanese citizens less thrifty. And as they continue to save, their money keeps flowing into world capital markets.
"The scare stories that Japanese institutions would be dumping securities simply ignore the more basic fact that capital outflows from Japan are at record levels," said John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers. In the first quarter of 1992, he said, Japanese net outflows reached an annual rate of $108 billion.
That is not to say there has been no change. Japanese investors are buying a very different mix of foreign assets than a few years ago. They are shunning long-term investments (bonds, stocks, buildings), and concentrating on investments with shorter lives, such as three-month certificates of deposit and one-year bank loans.
 
Trend Toward Short-Term Assets
 Net purchases by Japanese of long-term foreign assets dropped to an annual rate of $36 billion in the first quarter, one-fifth of the $192 billion rate in 1989. At the same time, their net purchases of short-term assets zoomed to a $152 billion annual rate last winter. Those transactions were largely made by Japanese banks. The banks formerly financed purchases of long-term assets by borrowing short term in world capital markets; now that Japanese buyers are not as eager to buy such assets, the banks are paying down their short-term debt with foreign lenders.
"The form of capital going abroad has changed dramatically," Mr. Lipsky said. "The Japanese are implicitly supplying short-term liquidity to the world financial system and leaving it to others to transform these liquid funds into other investments."
What's more, some financial experts now say that even when the Japanese were throwing their yen at art, real estate and Treasury auctions, their role was often exaggerated. Japanese net bond purchases for example, reached only $15 billion at their peak.
"We were gnashing our teeth that the Japanese were taking over the U.S.," said Ed Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence. "Now we're sweating bullets wondering whether the collapse in Japan will end Western civilization."
By the time that the Nikkei collapse started to cause serious pain -- at the point, say, that it fell below 20,000 earlier this year -- the Japanese owned only a tiny fraction of United States long-term assets. The best estimate is that their cache amounts to a couple of percent of outstanding government securities and about double that percentage of American stocks.
 
Effect Is Not Large
 Economists agree that whenever the preferences of a large investor shift from one kind of asset to another, prices are affected. But the effect is not necessarily large. Speaking with a touch of hyperbole, Stanley Ginsberg, senior vice president of marketing at Daiwa Securities said: "Even if the Japanese sold everything all at once, it would be a blip. We're not talking a huge position."
Mr. Yardeni says of the Japanese: "They bought a lot and also sold a lot. They are very active traders." He points to the fact that even as Japanese investors have bought fewer bonds at Treasury auctions over the last couple of years, yields have declined. "Now, nobody even mentions the Japanese as a factor."
Would United States bond yields be even lower if Japan's financial woes had not kept Japanese investors from bidding up American bond prices by pumping more money into the market. Not enough to notice, Mr. Yardeni said. With a weak American economy, and soft demand for loans, American banks put more money into bonds, taking up some of the potential slack.
Last year, American banks poured $100 billion into United States government securities. Presumably, if Japanese banks were still feeling frisky and underwriting the worldwide commercial real estate boom, American banks would also be putting their cash into real estate loans instead of government securities.
In any case, the Japanese pullback from long-term assets came when the recession was stifling the demand for credit in this country. For the last year, consumers have been trimming debt and American businesses have been spending less on inventories and new plant and equipment.
 
'A Lot of Room' for the Treasury
 "That meant there was a lot of room for the Federal Government to borrow without pushing up rates," said Henry Kaufman, president of Henry Kaufman & Company, an economic consulting and money management firm.
And in a notable reversal, foreigners, including Americans, are pouring money into long-term Japanese assets. "The Japanese capital was going to keep us going," said Robert Z. Lawrence, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. "But the fact is that we are keeping their market up."
All this is not to say that Japan's troubles have not hurt some American individuals, businesses and local economies.
Japan's problems have been an added blow, for example, to battered commercial real estate. In the late 1980's, Japanese investors paid top dollar for choice properties, and Japanese banks were happy to lend them money. Jack Rodman, the Los Angeles managing partner at Kenneth Leventhal, an accounting firm, says that Japanese buyers own as much as 60 to 70 percent of prime office towers in downtown Los Angeles, space they paid $40 a square foot for that now rents for $15 a square foot. Needless to say, the buying has stopped.
At the same time, Japanese banks, which had offered cheaper real estate loans and at one point accounted for more than one-third of the commercial real estate loans in California, no longer are placing market share ahead of profitability. That has benefited competing American banks by easing the sharp price competition, but raised average prices of loans for borrowers. More important, feared liquidations have not materialized. "They are not under pressure to sell buildings, because the banks won't force them to," Mr. Rodman said.
 
Fewer U.S. Companies Acquired
 One area of major cutbacks by Japanese buyers, who held about $84 billion in so-called direct investments, is in acquisitions of United States companies. One reason, of course, is that on the average such investments have not been very profitable to date.
"With the exception of MCA and the Seattle Mariners, there have been almost no deals," said Jeffrey E. Garten, a managing director of the Blackstone Group, a New York investment bank. "The big companies all wanted to be here. But now that they are here, all the financial problems in Japan mean that they are not going to expand as fast as they might have."
American exporters are also being pinched a bit by Japan's problems. Japan is America's second-biggest export market, after Canada. If Japan's economic slowdown worsens as a result of spreading financial distress, American exports of everything from cotton to cigarettes to computers could suffer. United States exports to Japan have already flattened over the last year, after growing vigorously through the end of 1990.
"This thing can stay slow for a while," said David Rolley at DRI/ McGraw-Hill. "I don't think Japanese companies are coming clear about how much retrenching they're doing."
But not everyone has noticed. W. H. Clark is chairman and chief executive of the Nalco Chemical Company in Naperville, Ill., which for five years has been selling specialty chemicals in Japan, mostly to oil refiners, steel mills and chemical plants. Mr. Clark says his business there continues to do well. "To us, Japan is a great big hunk of cheese that we're nibbling at," he said.
"What difference does it make if 2 percent gets knocked off by a recession?" he asked rhetorically. "It's still a pretty big hunk."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Perot's Standard Campaign Speech: 'Plain Texas Talk' About 'People Power'

 BODY:
Ross Perot, whose flirtation with an independent Presidential candidacy has shaken the political establishment of both parties, likes to boast that he has no handlers, no "spin doctors" and, most important, no speech writers.
For some voters, such a do-it-yourself candidacy is a refreshing change from slick politics as usual. It also seems to mirror Mr. Perot's political philosophy. 
 Unlike that of most candidates, his basic campaign speeches are usually short, about 15 minutes, and are a recitation of the nation's ills. He often reads from notes, and his speeches tend to be woodenly delivered, often peppered with lyrics from Broadway show tunes, and devoid of detailed solutions for the problems he outlines.
Instead, Mr. Perot tells his audiences that they hold the key to righting the listing ship of state, and that citizen involvement in the political process is the way to break the Washington gridlock. He says the way for America to restore its competitive lead is for workers to make the words "made in the U.S.A." the standard for excellence. He says the way to end racial, religious and ethnic animus is for people to understand that the nation's diversity is "a strength, not a weakness." And he says poverty can be eased if "we help those who cannot help themselves."
For Mr. Perot, the revolution he seeks to lead -- he says he wants to be its servant -- is directed from the bottom up, not the top down. In "plain Texas talk," as Mr. Perot likes to say, his speeches are all about "people power."
What follows are excerpts from the speech that Mr. Perot delivered at a rally in Olympia, Wash., on July 2, as transcribed by The New York Times. The content is representative of the standard speeches that Mr. Perot gives to his supporters around the country in his still undeclared campaign for President.
Just a few months ago, all the people who were political professionals said that people like you couldn't organize yourselves in 50 states. In just five weeks, millions of you across the United States successfully organized yourselves and have produced a blizzard of petitions never seen before in the history of this country.
You literally have changed the political process. You have told the people in Washington, "Listen to us for a change." You have reminded the people in Washington that you own this country. Once again, we've gone back 200 years to a point where the people in Washington are your servants, thanks to what you've done. Now that's a lot of change in just three or four months, but my sense is you've just started.
This great country and all of you -- and many of you on a very personal basis -- on the battlefield for 45 years stood at the gate and kept the nuclear war from occurring. And I would like to pause for a minute and ask the crowd to let the military people who provided that service for us and kept the nuclear war from occurring until the cold war was over, let's let them know how we feel about them. In many cases we didn't do it when we should have, but now that the walls have come tumbling down and the Russian empire is broken into republics and the cold war is over -- thanks to all of you who did it -- I suggest that it's time to come and rebuild America.
Can we agree that we have work to do? Is there anybody here that's not willing to put his or her shoulder to the wheel and do it? Is there anybody here that can live with the fact that we are no longer the No. 1 economic superpower in the world? Is there any question in your minds that if we get off our seats and get in the ring. you and I can make the words "made in the U.S.A." once again the world standard for excellence?
Is there any reason, as someone in the audience says, we don't need any morning glories that wilt by noon. I agree with that. Is there any reason why we cannot outcrank, outcreate and outwork anybody anywhere in the world, and beat them in economic competition?
 
An Economic Super Bowl
 Let's look on it as an athletic event. If we were going to compete in sports, let's say football, we would want to go for the Super Bowl, right? Please, as we strive through this process, never forget this in your daily work. All day, every day, you are competing in an economic Super Bowl. Somebody wins, somebody loses, and the loser loses his job. There's no place to run, no place to hide, we just have to be better.
Now we've been the best in the world in a lot of things, and we can be the best in the world. Can we agree that we should not move all the manufacturing industries away, out of this country? Right. Why, we've just got to go to work, and I'm certain that you'd join me with that.
Now let's go back to sports for a minute. If we have an athletic team of geniuses that was all divided up, they'd lose, right? We've got a country all split up by race, religion, various beliefs. Can we agree that we are all in this together as a team? Can we agree that we cannot waste time fighting with one another? We've got to spend all of our energy working together. Now if we do that, the magic starts.
Can we agree that we will never be a great nation unless we have the finest public school system in the world? Does everybody here understand that you cannot elect someone and send that person to Washington and have that person do it for you? O.K. You are going to have to stay deeply involved at the local, county, state and national level as an owner for these revolutionary changes to occur. But if you, the taxpayers, want it, you can get it. Now that's our challenge.
 
Recalling the Pioneer's Creed
 Can you live with the fact that this great country is now the most violent, crime-ridden society in the industrialized world? Are you ready to get rid of the bars on the windows, the bars on the doors? Can you live with the fact that we've got 5 percent of the world's population and 50 percent of the world's cocaine use? Can we agree we will never win an economic competition, we will never have the best public schools and we will never have safe neighborhoods unless we get rid of drugs?
It took tough, hard people to create this country, and it's going to take tough, hard people to go from $4 trillion in debt to passing on the American dream to our children. When you think about this, think about the pioneer's creed. You're all the way out West, you hit the Pacific. The people who brought you here were tough people. Their creed was the cowards never started, the weak died on the way and only the strong survived.
We'll need the strong to do all this. But you have done a brilliant job. We can make this country anything we want it to be because of a very special, magic dream. It belongs to you and me. Everybody's worried about me getting sick and tired of all the stuff that gets thrown at you in a political campaign. As far as I'm concerned, those are little insignificant spitballs -- they have no impact at all. The only thing that matters to me is what the American people want.
All right. My position is very simple. I don't care whether you vote for me or vote for someone else. Now, what I do care about -- here's what I do care about. It's very important that everybody casts an informed vote in November as an owner of this country, right?
 
Putting America Back to Work
 As far as I'm concerned, if we don't rebuild our industrial base or, in plain Texas talk, we don't put America back to work, well, all these other things we want to work for are academic. We don't have the money to do it. We've got to put America back to work. I can't think of anything more exciting to do; as long as all of you stay linked together, anything is possible.
I urge you now -- get people to register to vote. I constantly look for good ideas. The story of my business success is that 99 percent of them were other people's. On the voters' registration, your state has one of the finest ideas in the country in that they're getting it done for less than 40 cents a voter, when people renew their driver's license.
Let's get everybody registered to vote. Let's get organized by precincts. Let's make sure that this is an election in November that comes from the people and not at the people from Washington.
And if you think about our great country, let's all do whatever it takes, whatever it takes to pass the American dream on to our children. Our parents worked and sacrificed for us, and most of our dreams far outstripped anything we thought we would accomplish as children. It's a special obligation we have to pass on to the next generation, and I know we can do it.
But when you kind of get tired and worn out, ask yourself aren't you as tough as your parents were? Look at your children and ask yourself, "Don't I love them enough to rebuild this country and have alabaster cities that gleam undimmed by human tears?" Certainly you do.
And to just close it all out, let me thank you again. And let's try to leave our country that has two characteristics. Where everyone of us -- not because there's a law that requires it, but because it comes from our hearts -- love and help one another. If you've got an elderly neighbor down the street who's an invalid, get the neighbors down there to pick up the house, cut the grass and look after that person. Don't just count on some government agency to do it. . . .
And then finally in closing, as you look at your children, let's leave them a memory. . . . Climb every mountain, ford every stream, follow every rainbow, until they find their dream. God bless you all. Thank you.

HEADLINE: Rabin's Call: What's a Housing Start?

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 8

 BODY:
From a welter of numbers made public this week, it is beginning to appear that if Yitzhak Rabin is serious about scaling back settlement activity in the occupied territories, he may want to bring along statisticians and attorneys when he moves into the Prime Minister's office.
He may need them to define what a housing start really is, not to mention what it might take to keep his disparate coalition partners and the Bush Administration happy on this most sensitive issue. 
 Mr. Rabin, who continued today to put together his governing coalition by meeting with political parties representing left-wing, right-wing and religious interests, has been firm in his pledge to curtail settlement-building in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
The construction has been denounced by the United States as a peace-busting activity and has been cited by Washington as the reason it has withheld $10 billion in requested loan guarantees for absorbing new emigres.
He is opposed to "political" settlements, Mr. Rabin says, adding that the only acceptable housing in the territories is that which enhances Israel's security. Most of that is music to Washington's ears, and there have been more than a few encouraging American nods in Mr. Rabin's direction since his Labor Party's election victory two weeks ago.
 
An Embarrassing Possibility
 But the definition of political vs. security has been left deliberately vague. If anything, the situation grew murkier this week when the Housing Ministry of the present Government and a major settlers' group announced that more than 16,000 houses and apartments were in assorted stages of construction across the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
In addition, the ministry said it had plans for another 3,500 housing units, not including a variety of mobile homes that it would like to scatter around as well.
If all those houses are built and occupied, the settler population could in theory nearly double from the 110,000 Jews now estimated to be nestled in 140 communities in the territories. It would put Mr. Rabin in the obviously embarrassing situation of presiding over extensive settlements growth when he was expected to put on the brakes.
From his post-election statements, it seems likely that the new Prime Minister will not fully satisfy either his would-be partner on the left, Meretz, which prefers an absolute freeze of all planned construction, nor the Tsomet Party on the right, which wants the builders to keep on rolling.
 
Stages of Completion
 But then which numbers will Mr. Rabin use? That is where the lawyers and statisticians come in, and the ultimate answers are anybody's guess.
For example, the new ministry numbers, whose rough outlines are accepted by anti-settlements groups, show that 4,000 units are basically finished and will soon be occupied once they are connected to power and gas lines. Will the new Government accept those as unstoppable at this point?
If so, what about 9,000 other units said to be in varying stages of construction, from the laying of foundations to near-completion?
Or what about the 3,000 units where nothing more has been done than to get the ground ready, which some here argue is no small feat, given the rockiness of West Bank soil? Or the 3,000 or 4,000 others -- the numbers at this point become a bit elusive -- for which building contracts may have been signed but no actual work has begun?

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Rabin Urges Fairness to Arabs
 TEL AVIV, July 8 (Reuters) -- Mr. Rabin said today that Israel could best fight anti-Semitism worldwide through fair treatment of its Arab minority and of Palestinians in occupied lands.
Speaking via satellite to to a World Jewish Congress meeting in Brussels on anti-Semitism, Mr. Rabin said Israelis should set "certain moral standards of behavior" toward the Arab minority in Israel. He said Israelis should also uphold such standards of behavior toward Palestinians in the occupied territories insofar as possible.
Mr. Rabin said reasons for the rise of anti-Semitism in the world were ignorance and denial of its existence, political changes in Eastern Europe, economic recession and the Arab-Israeli conflict.
