HEADLINE: Bound to Looms by Poverty and Fear, Boys in India Make a Few Men Rich

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEWAPURI, India

 BODY:
As the summer sun labored toward the desiccated plains of northern India, Amarnath Kumar, a straw-thin 10-year-old boy, and three friends crept away from the red adobe hut that had been their prison for 18 months. Across the blistered soil of fallow wheat fields, the boys hurried north, avoiding other people, hurrying into the descending darkness.
Behind them, in the adobe enclosure, they left other children -- children bought or stolen from their parents, taken to toil as virtual slaves on the carpet looms of eastern Uttar Pradesh. 
 For 12, 14, 16 hours a day, every day of the week, every week of the year, children as young as eight sit on rough planks knotting colored yarn around the stretched cords of the loom's warp, creating the carpets that India sells around the world.
What the four boys were escaping was the explosion of such slavery in this area, the use of children to fuel the rapid growth of the carpet industry. The United States is the biggest customer for Indian carpets.
 
Buying a Boy for $50
 There are no reliable data on the number of children working here; indeed, carpet brokers, professional associations and judicial officers all deny that any substantial number of children are working in bondage.
But estimates by others of the children's workforce in this area range from 300,000 to over a million. According to a report last month by the International Labor Organization, India has 44 million child laborers nationwide.
In most cases, the children who work in the carpet belt are purchased from their parents, or merely taken with promises of future payments. The vast majority come from the poorest parts of Bihar, the most impoverished state in India.
When parents are in fact paid, the going rate for an eight-year-old boy is 1,500 to 2,000 rupees ($50 to $66), a substantial sum for many families.
Once the deal is struck, the procurer will take 10 or 15 children at a time by bus and train to the carpet belt, usually to the town of Badhoi near here, where the loom owners will come to pick up their new workers.
Typically, says Raman Kant Rai, who campaigns to help the children, a boy may work three to five years before being returned to his family, having grown too large to work in the cramped dirt wells behind the looms. On occasion, however, some boys continue to work into their late teens and twenties, at which point they are given a minimal wage and become permanent workers in the industry.
Across India, in quarries, brass smelters, glass factories and match and explosives plants, children labor in dangerous, unhealthy and oppressive conditions, often against their will, sometimes with the consent of their parents. Child labor continues despite a 1976 law prohibiting all forms of bonded or slave labor and a 1986 act banning workers under the age of 14 from a broad range of industries.
Yet each year more and more children are forced into hazardous work places, sometimes with the connivance of the authorities, often with their tacit acceptance of child labor as an unpleasant fact of life. No one has ever gone to prison in India for using children as workers.
 
Locked in Dormitories
 "Nowadays, migrant child labor, bonded child labor, has increased," said Mr. Rai. "The people who are engaged in this have all kinds of money and influence. In this area, there has not been a single raid by the authorities."
Only rarely, it seems, do children escape their servitude: they are too young, too far from home, too terrified. At night, many loom owners keep the children locked in dormitories, adobe buildings with simple mats on dirt floors. And during the day, while not literally chained to their looms, the stare and the lash of loom owners bond the children to the planks on which they sit.
There are no roads into the nearby village of Bibris, just a rocky path that meanders in from a faint macadam strip that heads off toward a nearby town. Cows and coal-black water buffaloes are tethered to wooden stakes outside mud-walled houses.
Here and there, faint thumpings drift from earthen buildings. Around a corner, a row of village houses opens onto a courtyard bustling with the pat of bare feet and quiet words as dozens of boys, some just seven or eight, unwind huge skeins of undyed wool.
Inside the huts, huge wooden looms, strung with plain yarn like harps, reach from the bottom of the pits to the clay-tiled roofs. And behind them, on worn planks, sit more shirtless young boys, four to a loom, poking fingers through the warp, squeezing a snippet of yarn through and back and knotting it, all in a blur of movement. The tips of their fingers are strangely pink and shiny. After a time, the boys bash their knots together with mallets.
"In this village," explained Mr. Rai, "there are 4,000 looms. This village is the most problematic in the carpet belt, problematic in the sense it has the most loomage, the most notorious men." He pointed to a doe-eyed boy whose head barely reached above the seat of the bicycle on which he leaned.
"That boy," Mr. Rai said, "is eight. He was beaten for one year because he couldn't learn how to weave fast enough. The youngest boy I have seen is six and a half."
 
Industry Growing Rapidly
 India is expected sell about $170 million worth of carpets abroad this year, the vast majority hand-woven on looms here, virtually all of them by children. The United States, the largest customer, takes about 45 percent of the exports; Germany is the second-largest buyer.
India's carpet industry began to blossom in the last decade, after carpet exports from Iran and Afghanistan were reduced by international sanctions and war. While Indian carpets did not approach the quality of Persian or Afghan rugs, the finest is inexpensive enough and well enough made to sell well in the West.
"In 1970, there were not more than 20 or 30 exporters in this country," said Jalil Ansari, the secretary of the All India Carpet Manufacturers Association, in the town of Bhadohi. "Now there are more than 2,000."
Typically, an exporter will contract with dozens or hundreds of loom owners scattered through the carpet belt.
 
Bondage? What Bondage?
 Both the exporters and the carpet association are aware that widespread use of child labor violates Indian law and could create difficulties in selling carpets in the West if the extent of the practice became widely known. As a result, the association has suggested labeling carpets with tags declaring that they had been woven without the use of children.
Chandramani Mishra, a member of the manufacturers' association, said nothing had come of the suggestion. But, he added, "if you want a label, no problem."
Sometimes children are able to break out of their imprisonment. Amarnath Kumar is one of the few.
"We came to the railway crossing," he remembered. "The man who operated the crossing said, 'Where are you going?' We told him we escaped from Chhateri village. He let us sleep there. The next morning a man came and we told him our whole story. He said, 'Come with me.' He gave us food and then brought us to Dr. Rai."
For nearly 20 years, Mr. Rai, a chemist by training, has worked in this area to enhance village economies by encouraging new but simple farm technologies, home weaving of garments, improved sanitary conditions, education for village women -- consciously emulating Mahatma Gandhi's idea of small-scale, self-reliant rural communities. Only in the last year or so, however, has he begun to pay attention to the children laboring in the villages.
 
A Boy Escapes
 "For a long time, you look at something and don't see it," he said. "You don't know what you're seeing. We have a lot of blindness."
Amarnath, who was eight years old when he first began working on the looms, talked of his life in Chhateri a few days after he escaped with his three friends.
He said that a middleman, a man well-known in the area of north Bihar where his family lived, had told his father, "Your son will get good clothing, good food and 350 rupees a month" -- about $12.50. "My father said O.K. After all, I was just a cow boy."
"The first day we were brought there," he said, "we were told we had to weave carpets. I took two months to learn. No money was paid to me. All day we had to weave, even up until midnight. We were not allowed to rest during the day. If we became slow, we were 'murga banatha' " -- a phrase that means "made like a chicken." Amarnath squatted on the ground and bent over like a chicken. "We were beaten with sticks," he said. "We were beaten on our backs."
 
No Vegetables, No Milk
 "He used to lock us up at home, in a room," Amarnath continued. "There were nine of us in the room. For one and a half years we never had green vegetables, not to talk of milk. He did not even allow us to have a bath."
Among the more worldly exporters and business leaders, there is increasing sensitivity to the use of children on the looms, but little has deterred the practice.
Mr. Ansari, the secretary of the carpet makers' association, said his industry was the backbone of the region's economy. But he denied that children, particularly children in forced labor, were the main workforce in the industry.
 
'It Is Not True'
 "It is not true," he said. "Once or twice a week I go and I do not find it. They are getting the salary. They are getting food." Even downstairs from his office, though, children were hunched over carpets, clipping the outlines of flowers from the wool surface.
The senior civil official in the carpet belt, the district magistrate for Varanasi, Saurabh Chandra, said no children were being held in abusive labor in his domain. "Whenever any violation of any statute is pointed out," he said, "action is taken. We have released a large number of bonded laborers."
But in the interview Mr. Chandra could not say how many children had been released or when, or whether any penalties had been imposed on the loom owners who had pressed the children into bondage.
Then Mr. Chandra asked, "Why are you defaming our industry?"
Several hours after the interview, the reporter was approached at his hotel by two of Mr. Chandra's associates lugging a stack of files and seeking to expand on Mr. Chandra's comments.
One, Sudhir Kumar, the subdivisional magistrate, said no cases of bonded labor had ever appeared in his court.
The other, D. P. Singh, the deputy labor commissioner, said he was unsure how many children worked in the region's carpet industry. "When my inspectors come, the neighboring looms hide the children." But then, he admitted, "no inspector has been posted for this specific problem."

HEADLINE: A Saudi Bank and Ex-Chief Violated U.S. Law, Fed Says

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Board has found that Saudi Arabia's largest bank and its former chief executive violated American banking laws in trying to acquire control of the Washington-based First American banks with help from the Bank of Credit and Commerce International.
The board last week determined that Sheik Khalid bin Mahfouz and the National Commercial Bank of Saudi Arabia had failed to properly report the 28.7 percent of First American's holding company they acquired in 1986, according to papers the Fed released today. 
 The Fed said it would also begin proceedings that could lead to the assessment of civil monetary penalties of as much as $170 million against Sheik Khalid and as much as $6 million against Haroon Kahlon, a former official of National Commercial also charged in the case. The two men can contest the board's findings.
In addition, the Fed has scheduled a hearing to determine whether a cease-and-desist order should be entered that could require the two men and their bank to make restitution and other payments in connection with the case.
The Fed's action adds considerable detail to the dealings between Sheik Khalid and B.C.C.I. that were the basis for criminal fraud charges against the sheik announced last week by the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau.
On Tuesday, Sheik Khalid said he intended to fight those charges as he stepped down as chief operating officer of National Commercial Bank, the kingdom's largest bank, with more than $22 billion in assets.
National Commercial enjoyed close ties with B.C.C.I., the Luxembourg-based bank that regulators seized last year after evidence emerged that billions of dollars in deposits had been lost in what has become the biggest bank fraud in history. Today's announcement deepens the Saudi connection to the still- unfolding investigation of B.C.C.I.
 
Roles of Two Lobbyists
 The Fed's finding also presents new details about the role of Clark Clifford and Robert Altman, the two Washington lawyer-lobbyists who once were officers of First American. In 1986, as Sheik Khalid was completing his acquisition of First American stock with B.C.C.I.'s help, he toured First American operations in Washington and New York and "discussed First American business with Clark Clifford and Robert Altman," according to the Fed's statement of facts.
The document the Fed issued also indicates that Mr. Altman participated in discussions with a B.C.C.I. official and an official of National Commercial Bank in 1987 about helping Sheik Khalid file reports that might be required by the Fed in connection with his acquisition of First American stock.
Later in 1987, another partner in the Clifford and Altman law firm directed First American's transfer agent not to record on First American's books a pledge of First American stock in favor of National Commercial Bank, the statement also said. Not recording the statement could have made it more difficult to determine the extent of National Commercial Bank's control of First American.
 
Bank as International Bridge
 National Commercial Bank, controlled by the Mahfouz family, is not just another foreign bank. American officials, both past and current, and international businessmen consider it part of the Saudi royal family's inner circle, acting as the ruling family's principal bank and a vehicle for sensitive political transactions. And as an important foreign exchange dealer, the institution serves as a financial bridge between Western economies and the Middle East.
The diplomatic and financial ramifications of the case are many. Silver prices dropped on international markets Tuesday, stemming from the bank's large selloff, and representatives of the Saudi Arabian Monetary Authority have held discussions with the Fed, according to investigators.
No other private bank in Saudi Arabia enjoys the tolerance afforded National Commercial Bank, according to officials and businessmen. The bank has not published an annual financial statement, the best indicator of a bank's health, for two years. Such statements are required by regulators in the United States and elsewhere.
The Mahfouz family has ties to the United States, including properties and holdings in New York and Texas. A Federal judge signed an order today freezing Sheik Khalid's assets in the United States, including a luxury penthouse apartment on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan and bank stockholdings in Texas.

HEADLINE: Continental Cutting Some Vacation Fares

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Just days after the major airlines promised to raise fares after a bruising price war, Continental Airlines said yesterday that it would cut many summer vacation fares by an average of 25 percent on roughly half its routes.
If recent history repeats itself, Continental's competitors may feel compelled to outdo the fare cuts, touching off yet another round of discounting, said Lee Howard, executive vice president of Airline Economics, a consulting firm in Washington. 
 "There's a battle out there for fare leadership," he said.
In general, Continental's competitors said they would have to assess the details of the new discounts before announcing any specific actions.
Amy Spreeman, a spokeswoman for Northwest, said the airline was still planning to increase its fares by 4.4 percent across the board tomorrow. "But we tend to stay competitive," she said.
Joseph Crawley, a spokesman for American Airlines, added that American considered Continental's move odd in light of Continental's decision to sue American over predatory pricing.
The Continental sale runs from July 16 through Sept. 15. Tickets have to be purchased by Friday, July 17, and require a Saturday stay.
The seat sale includes a $350 round-trip flight between New York and Los Angeles, an 8 percent reduction from the existing fare of $380. Round trip to Baton Rouge, La., from Newark or La Guardia airports will cost $250, a 24 percent reduction.
The individual cuts range from 8 percent to 35 percent.
Continental said it intentionally limited the number of seats sold in the recent fare war because it could not justify selling those seats at such sharp discounts.
It hopes that the new discounts will still entice travelers who were shut out of the recent price sale, and give the airline better revenues on the tickets it does sell.
"We were keeping our powder dry," said David Messing, a spokesman for Continental.

HEADLINE: Japan, Citing Recent Accident, Delays Launching

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 8

 BODY:
In another serious setback for Japan's budding space program, the Government announced today that it would delay the initial launching of its next-generation rocket by one year because of a recent accident.
The rocket, known as the H-II, is the first to be built solely by Japan, without reliance on foreign technology. As such it is a source of national pride and will be the first rocket powerful enough to let Japan launch communications and weather satellites for other nations and private companies. 
 But much to the embarrassment of this usually technically proficient nation, development of the rocket has been dogged by a series of accidents and delays, including an explosion in August that killed an engineer.
The new delay of the first launching, from early 1993 to early 1994, puts the program fully two years behind its original schedule and could hurt Japan's chances of competing in the commercial launching business against American companies and Europe's Arianespace.
"This is a very big problem for us," said Hiroshi Imamura, a managing director of Rocket Systems Corporation, a two-year-old venture owned by 75 Japanese companies that was formed to offer launching services using the H-II. Already, Mr. Imamura said, potential customers have been reluctant to sign up to use the H-II until it has shown it works.
The latest setback occured during an engine test on June 18 at Japan's space center on Tanegashima Island. Within seconds after ignition, liquid hydrogen fuel leaked, setting off a fire and explosion that severed some parts of the engine and melted others.
The National Space Development Agency of Japan said today that it had determined that the leak started with a crack in a weld that joined a chamber in the liquid hydrogen fuel pump to an elbow-shaped pipe leading to the fuel injector. It appeared the weld had been subjected to greater temperature fluctuations than expected, officials said.
Moreover, subsequent inspections revealed other tiny cracks in other welds within that engine and in other test engines, necessitating a complete review and redesign of part of the engine.
"If it was only in this particular engine, the problem would have been minor," Dr. Tomifumi Godai, executive director of launch-vehicle development and operation at the space agency, said at a news conference today. "But we consider this a more comprehensive problem. That is why we decided we need a design change."
Dr. Godai said it was not surprising that there have been problems building that type of engine, which uses liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen under high pressures.
"Nobody in the world develops liquid engines easily," he said. "It's better not to have any trouble, but I think we are making steady progress."
An American aerospace executive stationed here agreed.
"They've tackled a very challenging engine," he said. "When they get it completed, it will be as advanced as anything we have in the U.S. or France."
Still, for all its expertise in cars and computer chips, Japan is not playing to its strength in the space business. For one thing, rocketry involves building a few very expensive items, rather than millions of inexpensive items, a task at which Japan excels.
Moreover, Japan is a latecomer to space, in part because of restrictions imposed by the American occupying forces after World War II on developing military technology. Japan did not launch its first satellite until 1970, a year after the United States had already landed on the moon.
In previous rocket generations, Japan has licensed technology from the United States, but with restrictions that prevented it from offering commercial launching services. Frustrated with that situation and eager to build its own industry, Japan has been trying to become more self-sufficient.

HEADLINE: Blue-Chip Stocks Slip as Dow Eases 1.89

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks closed slightly lower yesterday as investors struggled with worries over second-quarter earnings and the economy.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed 1.89 points lower at 3,293.28, after skipping over a wide range of nearly 30 points. Declining issues led advancers, 897 to 834, on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume was 201 million shares. 
 The Nasdaq index closed 0.16 higher at 557.57.
The market's focus was on coming earnings results, particularly airlines and California banks, the newest sectors to weaken.
The market attracted late buying on talk that stocks may be oversold after the Dow index plunged nearly 45 points Tuesday. It was the steepest loss in three months.
"I think we could see the market back up to the 3,300 level," said Robert Walberg, an analyst at MMS International." I think the market is looking pretty good for the next few days."
But he conceded that earnings, the Presidential election and stagnant economy all were lingering impediments.
Jack Solomon, a technical analyst at Bear, Stearns, said: "We became a little bit oversold. Everyone turned bearish."
Bradley Turner, chairman of McDonald & Company's investment policy committee, said the weakness in airlines' stocks was an "indication of yet another sector in an ongoing series of corrections."
Mr. Solomon said the cut to 3 percent from 3 1/2 percent last week in the Federal Reserve's discount rate "is one of the goodies taken out of the cookie jar." Now, he said, investors have to wait for earnings to provide direction.
Mr. Walberg said cyclical stocks, having outperformed other sectors earlier this year, are now succumbing to profit taking. Cyclicals are companies that traditionally do well in an economic rebound.
Mr. Solomon said market conditions would stay skittish.
"There's enough fear of bad earnings reports to keep the market off balance," he said, adding that he suspected the worst of the selloff was over for now.
Among individual stocks, Marion Merrell Dow continued to slip, losing 3/8, to 27. The drug maker on Tuesday said it was forced to modify the labeling for its prescription anti-allergy product, Seldane, to include certain health risks. Dean Witter lowered its 1993 estimate on the company.
Durr-Fillauer Medical jumped 5 1/4, to 27 1/2, on news that the Bergen Brunswig Corporation had begun a $26-a-share bid for the company.
Among airline stocks, AMR lost 2 1/8, to 63 5/8; UAL fell 2 3/4, to 114 3/4, and Delta Air Lines was down 1 5/8, to 55 1/8.
The Exabyte Corporation, the cartridge tape maker, rose 2 3/4, to 29 3/8, after reporting a rise in second-quarter profits.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 1.12 points to end at 410.28.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite index rose 0.34, to 225.49, while the American Stock Exchange index ended 0.40 point lower at 379.86.

HEADLINE: Hospital Data Show Increase In Drug Abuse

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
After showing modest signs of improvement, the drug situation in New York City has taken a turn for the worse, state officials said yesterday. Hospital treatment of heroin and cocaine cases is up sharply, they said, and some dealers are expanding their operations and dropping prices.
In a midyear assessment, the New York State Office of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse Services reported that emergency-room treatment for adverse effects from heroin increased by more than half in the first nine months of 1991 over the previous year and that emergency treatment for cocaine was up almost a third. 
 The agency said that field workers have found new heroin dealers setting up shop throughout New York City, some of them having cut the price of the standard $10 or "dime" bag to $5. In some parts of the city, the agency said, crack is being sold at an all-time low of 75 cents a dose.
 
A Clear Picture
 The semiannual reports by the state office are considered the best snapshot of the drug culture in the city. Officials study hospital, medical examiner and drug-treatment-center statistics and dispatch field researchers to interview buyers and sellers on the street.
The emergency-room data form a primary barometer of trends in illegal drug use. Fluctuations in the number of patients treated are generally thought to reflect changes in the number of people using drugs. But heavy users sometimes make multiple visits to emergency rooms, making assessments on volume difficult.
Increases in cocaine casualties are being reported in other cities around the country, but only New York and Baltimore, which has the highest rate, have shown jumps in adverse reactions to heroin.
The state estimates there are at least 200,000 heroin addicts in New York City and at least twice as many heavy crack and cocaine users, the largest drug-taking groups in the country.
 
Abundance and Competition
 State officials and private drug experts said the lowering of prices seemed to reflect an abundance of heroin and cocaine in New York City, the largest drug import center and market in the country, as well as increasing competition as more young sellers, facing unemployment in the recession, enter the drug business
The advent of $2 or $3 vials of crack, readily smokable cocaine, in the mid-1980's played a major role in attracting new users.
Now, for 75 cents, a customer can get a single "hit," or puff, of crack, the agency said. Often working in abandoned buildings, sellers light a crack pipe and pass it through a slot in a locked door, the agency said, "so the smoker can get a fast hit."
 
Too Many Say Yes
 "This is troublesome data," said Dr. Mitchell S. Rosenthal, the chairman of the Governor's Advisory Council on Substance Abuse and the president of Phoenix House, the largest residential drug treatment organization in the country.
"It tells us," he said, "that this chronic problem that we have been dealing with is in fact deepening, that new users are continuing to come into the system and that we have not halted drug abuse in the most vulnerable, most disadvantaged population."
Record amounts of heroin have been produced in Asia, and Colombia recently began producing the drug, along with its mainstay, cocaine. As a result, the purity of heroin being sold in New York has increased dramatically. As recently as five years ago, a $10 bag of heroin contained as little as 4 to 7 percent of the drug. Laboratory reports now show bags containing 55 percent heroin being widely marketed in New York City, the agency said.
The potency of the heroin makes it possible for people to inhale the drug like powdered cocaine instead of injecting it, making the drug attractive to more people, the experts say. In addition, some longtime users are shifting from injecting to snorting because of fear of contracting H.I.V., which causes AIDS, from shared hypodermic needles.
John Galea, the head of the Office of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse Services' street research unit, said that while heroin dealers are expanding their markets and moving into areas that were once exclusively crack and cocaine markets, he saw no signs that crack and cocaine use were diminishing.
"Crack is not increasing at the level of a few years ago," he said, "but it's still increasing."
 
Little No Rise in Deaths
 In addition to the apparent increase in heroin use, the more potent blends, Dr. Rosenthal said, may at least partly explain the sharp rise in emergency-room cases. But, inexplicably, there has not been a concomitant rise in deaths from heroin overdoses. In the first half of 1991, the agency said, 278 people died after taking heroin, compared with 264 in the first half of the previous year. Cocaine deaths rose 11 percent in the first half of 1991, to 461, compared with 417 in the first half of 1990.
The agency reported a 20 percent increase in the number of cocaine users who entered drug-treatment programs, as opposed to those seeking emergency help at the hospitals. In 1991, up to 12,631 cocaine users entered treatment, surpassing the previous record level of 11,286 in 1989. The agency said 11,712 heroin users entered treatment in 1991, 207 fewer than the previous year.
 
A Long, Slow Desperation
 Heroin addictions are slower to develop and usually last longer than cocaine addictions, drug experts say. Either drug may create a health emergency, both for new users unfamiliar with the amounts they can tolerate and for practiced users whose systems begin to fail, but cocaine addicts tend to hit bottom or burn out and seek treatment sooner than heroin addicts.
Emergency-room incidents jumped after diminishing and then holding steady for about a year. Heroin cases rose to 4,510 in 1991 from 2,906 in 1990. Reflecting the much greater number of cocaine users in the city, emergency room cases rose from 9,347 in 1990 to 12,129 in 1991. The soaring figures in New York City have rippled out to the surrounding metropolitan area, with higher numbers of visits for cocaine and heroin users registered in hospitals in Westchester, Rockland and Putnam counties.
Arrests for both cocaine and heroin have been dropping in New York City. But Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown, in a recent interview, said arrests were down because he had thinned the ranks of special drug units to make more officers available for neighborhood patrols. Instead of trying to arrest thousands of buyers and sellers, Mr. Brown said, his officers were focusing on middle- and upper-level traffickers.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Who Will Pay, If Not Japan?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THIS economic news just in from Munich: Leaders of the industrial powers have affirmed, in principle, their support for open trade, stable growth and aid for the former Soviet Union.
Wait; don't turn to the crossword puzzle. While the gathering in Munich, Germany, was a snooze -- economic summit meetings are convened to reassure, not entertain -- some of the subjects conspicuously not on the agenda are very interesting indeed. And surely nontopic A was Japan, or more precisely, the contradictions between what the world says it wants from Asia's economic colossus and what it really needs. 
President Bush's pre-election beef with Japan is the trade deficit. And no wonder: After a few years of narrowing, Japan's surplus of exports over imports is heading for a record $135 billion. The trade gap with the United States alone is creeping back toward $50 billion.
These numbers do not surprise Gary Saxonhouse, an economist the University of Michigan. "We're coming out of a recession," he noted, "while they're going in." As a result, foreign demand for Japanese goods is stronger than Japan's demand for imports.
Nor does the fiscal remedy prescribed by the White House and seconded by the European powers. A kick in government domestic spending by Japan would help suck in imports, as well as create demand at home for Japanese goods that might otherwise have been shipped to Pittsburgh or Paris. And by all accounts, Kiichi Miyazawa, Japan's economics-savvy Prime Minister, is eager to oblige: the $50 billion public works package that he showed off at Munich should add a percentage point or two to Japan's growth rate.
So far, so good; idle productive capacity in Japan serves no one's interest. But the same is not necessarily true for the rest of the economic prescription being pressed on Japan.
Take that pesky bilateral trade deficit. While American politicians have grown accustomed to measuring the health of the economic relationship with Japan by the size of the deficit, John Taylor, a White House economist who recently returned to Stanford University, acknowledges that a bilateral balance in trade would be neither practical nor especially desirable. Energy-poor Japan is bound to run a deficit with oil exporters, he notes, and is thus prone to running surpluses with industrial trade partners.
Of course, some American exporters -- notably rice farmers -- would benefit from an opening of the Japanese market. But Mr. Saxonhouse argues that the rhetoric of trade injustice long ago outstripped the reality. If every Japanese barrier to trade were removed, he estimates, American sales to Japan would increase by only a few billion dollars a year.
Robert Z. Lawrence, an economist at Harvard's Kennedy School, wonders whether even these modest gains to some American exporters would lead to an overall reduction in Japan's monster trade surplus. An economy's balance on external accounts, he points out, is by definition the difference between domestic savings and domestic investment: if neither changes, the only way Japan can import more is to export more. Thus the only way to placate foreign critics, whose real concern is Japanese competition in their home markets, is to persuade the Japanese to save less or invest more at home.
That logic has not been lost on the Bush Administration. Indeed, Mr. Taylor was in charge of nagging the Japanese to act more like us, to invest more in public amenities and to give Japan's overworked, underhoused "salary men" a taste of the good life. And he can point to at least one important victory: the repeal of retailing laws that made price discounting and Western-style chain merchandising almost impossible.
But Mr. Lawrence does not "have a lot of faith" that outsiders can alter the Japanese inclination to delay gratification. More important, he and many other economists wonder whether it is really in the West's interest to transform Japan's thrifty ants into what-me-worry grasshoppers.
Europe and America save less than they invest at home. Even prudent Germany has become a net importer of capital, as Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government struggles to pay the trillion-dollar bill to transform eastern Germany into a capitalist paradise. That leaves Japan to fill the savings void -- to provide most of the imported capital to develop China, southern Asia, India and Latin America, not to mention Russia and its former chattels.
America could always pull up its socks, Mr. Taylor suggests, slashing the Federal deficit or squeezing an extra hundred billion dollars in savings from household budgets. But that would not help Mexico or Thailand if, as Gov. Bill Clinton and Ross Perot are apparently proposing, the savings were plowed into better schools or faster railroads.
Prudence would suggest that Japan be lectured less on the virtues of life on the installment plan. For some day, they might listen.

HEADLINE: Lease Deal By Airbus And United

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
United Airlines, long the most loyal and biggest customer of the Boeing Company, yesterday said it had leased 50 planes from Airbus Industrie, the four-nation European consortium battling Boeing's world dominance in commercial aircraft.
It was the first Airbus order for United, which had used Boeing planes exclusively, and analysts said it was a breakthrough that could lead to more orders in the future. 
 "It's a move of big strategic significance," said George Shapiro, the aerospace analyst for Solomon Brothers. He added that Airbus might have offered terms that did not bring much of a return, but would get the consortium a foothold at one of the biggest airlines in the United States.
For Boeing, the loss of the order is not expected to have a big impact in the short term. The company still has a huge backlog of orders from the world's airlines.
 
Positive Side of Losing
 "I think losing the deal is going to be a minor positive for Boeing because of their unwillingness to make an uneconomical deal no matter how important a customer is," Mr. Shapiro said.
But the company has lost some of its appeal in recent years as the airline industry has consolidated and some carriers have stretched out orders for new airplanes and cut back on capital spending.
Boeing's stock dropped 87.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, closing at $40.375 in heavy trading. It had traded as low as $39.875. In the last year, the stock has traded as high as $54.625.
Exact terms of the order for the 50 Airbus A320 aircraft were not disclosed, but it does include options on 50 more A320's.
 
Similar to Other Leases
 John Leahy, vice president of marketing for Airbus in the United States, said the terms of the United Airlines lease were similar to other leases like one between Boeing and American Airlines for new Boeing 767's.
The twin-engine A320 jets normally sell for about $45 million each, but United will not buy the planes, it will lease them from Airbus.
It has become common practice for airlines to buy aircraft, sell them to outside investors and then lease them back. What is unusual in the United arrangement with Airbus is that the lease will be held by the manufacturer.
United was considering mainly the A320 and the Boeing 737 line of airplanes.
Mr. Leahy said the A320 offered better performance, greater range, better fuel economy and the ability to fly at higher altitudes.
The A320 generally carries about 150 passengers in a first- and coach-class configuration and has the range to fly transcontinental routes like New York to San Francisco.
The A320 aircraft will be powered by two engines made by a consortium of companies led by Pratt & Whitney and Rolls-Royce. The first airplane is to be delivered in November 1993.
United has 109 Boeing 727's, which have three engines, in its fleet. The Airbus A320 requires only two pilots in the cockpit compared to three for the 727 and uses about 30 to 40 percent less fuel.
Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman and chief executive officer of United, said that the transaction "provides us the right-sized aircraft with the requisite performance capabilities."
He added that United still had a huge number of airplanes on order from Boeing and that the airline "will remain Boeing's largest customer."
 
An Eventual Profit?
 Airbus, which is made up of companies from France, Spain, Britain and Germany, has battled with Boeing for every large order and now controls about 30 percent of the world airplane market.
The company has many of its plants and its headquarters in France.
Other United States carriers that have ordered or operate Airbus airplanes are American, America West, Continental, Delta, Northwest and Trans World Airlines.
Mr. Leahy said that while United could turn back the planes under certain conditions, he believed that Airbus would eventually make a profit on the deal.
He said the A320 technology was shared by other planes made by Airbus, like the A321, A330 and A340, giving Airbus a base to sell United other lines of planes.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Amoco Is Cutting 8,500 Jobs

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
The Amoco Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest oil company, said yesterday that it would eliminate 8,500 jobs, 15.7 percent of its 54,120 employees, by the end of the year.
Amoco's announcement was one of the largest staff reductions announced in recent months. Hughes Aircraft, Aetna Life Insurance and Digital Equipment have also announced plans to reduce thousands of jobs, and economists, stunned by the extent of job losses last month, have issued more pessimistic forecasts. 
 Amoco, which is based in Chicago, attributed the cutbacks to the weak global economy, low energy prices and the need to dispose of unneeded divisions. About 1,100 of the jobs lost will be in the Chicago area.
"This is a significant move," said Eugene L. Nowak, an oil analyst at Dean Witter. "They don't want to sit around and count on being bailed out by higher oil and gas prices."
The cutback reflects in part the company's belief that any recovery will be weak.
H. Laurance Fuller, Amoco's chairman and chief executive, said in an interview: "It's very clear that none of the major trading areas in the world are in a strong economic position at the moment. That's true in the Far East and true in the United States."
Amoco said it would take an $800 million after-tax charge against earnings in the second quarter to cover the costs of pruning its operations.
Among the changes are a reduction in Amoco's oil and gas exploration and production and the sale of several businesses, including petroleum additives and carpet-yarn operations.
"It's part of an industry process," said John H. Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York. "It's not the first company to cut back, and it won't be the last."
Indeed, Unocal Corporation also announced plans yesterday to eliminate 1,000 jobs -- 6.4 percent of its work force, and the Mobil Corporation said Monday that it would drop 2,000 jobs.
Over all, Amoco is shedding 2,800 jobs by selling some operations. Of the other 5,700 jobs, some will be lost through attrition, some through voluntary retirement and severance incentives and some through layoffs. Mr. Fuller said he could provide no further figures.
Wall Street often cheers news of cutbacks, and Amoco found ready approval yesterday.
For several months, Mr. Fuller has been telling analysts and investors to expect some cutbacks. The extent of these economies still impressed those who follow the company. On a day when other oil stocks were mixed, Amoco popped up $1.25 before settling at $48.75, up 87.5 cents. The company said efficiencies resulting from the cutbacks would add more than $600 million a year to earnings before taxes by the end of 1993. Mr. Nowak of Dean Witter called this prediction credible, adding that it translated to an extra 80 cents a share above his estimated earnings of $2.45 a share this year.
The cutbacks and reorganization are the broadest evidence of where Mr. Fuller, who took over in February, 1991, wants to lead his company.
Of the $800 million in charges, the cuts in oil and gas exploration and production will result in losses of $250 million in the second quarter. And the sale of several businesses will mean a net loss of an additional $220 million.
The job reductions are costing the company $170 million, and other reorganization expenses $160 million.
What will be left, Mr. Fuller said, is a company better able to grow in its core businesses, especially energy refining and marketing and chemicals.
"My vision of the company is basically as follows," he said. "We need to be the most cost-efficient organization in our respective businesses, and we're setting forth to do that."
Mr. Fuller, who is 53 years old, said he expects the energy industry to rebound eventually. "But we have to recognize the realities of the economy today," he said.

Unocal Details Cuts
 LOS ANGELES, July 8 (AP) -- Unocal provided details today of its plan to cut debt by $1.5 billion over five years, saying 1,100 jobs would be eliminated.
The oil giant, which is based here, had said earlier that 800 to 1,100 jobs would be lost and had previously announced that it would combine its "downstream" refining, marketing and chemicals businesses into a single division.
It said today that it would do the same for its "upstream" exploration and production businesses. The new Energy Resources division combines three divisions: International Oil and Gas, North American Oil and Gas and Geothermal, eliminating or downsizing seven regional structures in North America.
Unocal said it anticipates the steps will increase after-tax cash flow by $200 million a year beginning in 1993.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Dip in Price

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of outstanding Treasury securities dipped in fairly active trading yesterday, as dealers pared positions in order to place bids at yesterday's auction of $9.5 billion of seven-year notes.
Traders said demand was good for the new securities, which were sold at an average yield of 6.44 percent, down from the 7.11 percent average yield at the last seven-year note auction on April 8. It is the lowest yield on a seven-year note since the auction on Jan. 8, when the yield was 6.40 percent. 
 Speculative accounts generally are the biggest buyers of seven-year notes, but dealers said that was not the case at yesterday's auction.
"We had a lot of high-quality buyers and not a lot of speculative accounts," the head government securities trader at a Wall Street house said. "And because of the steepness of the yield curve, for the first time we are seeing the banking community move for the first time into this issue."
Over the last few years, big banks have been heavy buyers of Treasury issues but have tended to concentrate their purchases in maturities of five years and less.
The Treasury auction was held during a session when issuance of corporate and municipal bonds remained heavy.
More than $1.6 billion of corporate debt securities were priced yesterday, according to analysts at MCM Inc., a New York investment advisory firm. Close to $1 billion in municipal bonds were offered, and nearly $1 billion in asset-backed securities were priced.
 
Dealers Lightening Positions
 Although some decline in Treasury prices reflected the auction, traders said some dealers were lightening their positions in Government securities to cover inventories of unsold corporate bonds issued so far this week.
Despite the price decline, analysts said the market's positive tone remained in place, and that interest rates could fall further.
"We don't think there is much risk that bond yields will rise, and we can't see short rates moving higher over the next three months," said Mike Niedermeyer, a senior vice president in the fixed-income department at the Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco. "It would take a gross scare to get rates to move up the way they did over the winter, but we don't think there is enough steam in the economy to do that."
Most of the drop in prices yesterday was recorded among shorter-term notes and bills, issues that have been star performers over the last few weeks.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 29 1/2-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 104 5/8, down 1/32 , to yield 7.60 percent, unchanged from late Tuesday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 104 11/32 late yesterday, down 9/32 , to yield 6.88 percent. And the 5 percent two-year notes were offered at 101 6/32 , down 3/32 , to yield 4.36 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates moved a bit higher.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 3.20 percent, up 2 basis points, or two one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 3.27 percent.
In the corporate bond market, Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager on a $937.5 million offering of securities backed by auto loans for a financing arm of the Chrysler Corporation.
The two-part issue consisted of $900 million of senior 5.05 percent notes, and $37.5 million of subordinated notes.
The senior notes, which have an average life of two years, were priced at $99.89, to yield 5.143 percent, 77 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 5 percent two-year notes at the time of pricing.
The subordinated notes were priced at $99.977, to yield 5.424 percent, 1.05 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 5 percent two-year notes at the time of pricing.
The senior notes are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The subordinated securities are rated A-2 by Moody's and A+ by Standard & Poor's.
The Comcast Corporation offered $300 million of 20-year high-yield senior subordinated notes through Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 10 5/8 percent notes, which are noncallable for life, were priced at $100, or par, three percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 29 1/2-year bond at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated B-1 by Moody's and B by Standard & Poor's.
New issues in the tax-exempt municipal bond market were led by the sale of $517.4 million of revenue bonds for Arizona's Salt River Agricultural Improvement and Power District.
 
Yields on Serial Bonds
 Yields on serial bonds range from 2.40 percent in 1993 to 6.05 percent on bonds maturing in 2009.
Term bonds offered have a maximum yield of 6.219 percent on securities maturing in 2030.
Bear, Stearns & Company acted as lead manager for the negotiated sale.
Ratings of AA are expected from both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal bonds said that despite the heavy inflow of new securities demand for outstanding bonds remained good.
Prices of most corporate bonds were unchanged to up 1/8 point, traders said. Meanwhile, prices of widely quoted municipal bonds firmed by about1/8 point.

HEADLINE: Suffolk, Facing a Budget Cliff, Gets a Little Rope From Albany

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., July 8

 BODY:
The State Legislature failed to approve financial bailout plans for Nassau and Suffolk counties before adjourning last week, but it did enact a local hotel room tax for Suffolk, the first such tax on the island.
The tax, which Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is expected to sign into law, was adopted with little notice last Friday amid a dispute between Long Island Republicans and Governor Cuomo and other Democrats over the counties' proposals to balance their budgets by borrowing $190 million. 
 The revenue from the Suffolk room tax -- estimated at $900,000 a year -- will go to promote tourism on the island, maintain historic buildings and aid museums. Nassau County, encouraged by Suffolk's success in Albany, is now expected to pursue similar legislation.
The new tax will add 0.75 percent to the daily rate charged by hotels, motels, campgrounds and bed-and-breakfast establishments in Suffolk County, or 75 cents on a $100 room.
Hotel guests now pay state and county sales tax totaling 8 percent on rooms that cost more than $100 a day. The date for the new tax to go into effect has not been set.
 
Negotiations Continue
 Though the legislators adjourned for the summer last Friday after heated partisan wrangling, their staff members continued to try to negotiate an agreement so that Nassau and Suffolk could get their bailouts and Governor Cuomo could win approval of his $800-million bond proposal to create jobs, the centerpiece of his economic-development program.
Both the jobs proposal and the Long Island bailout bills were defeated around 4 A.M. Friday, after the State Assembly Speaker, Saul Weprin, a Democrat from Queens, and the Senate Majority Leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Republican from Oyster Bay, exchanged angry words.
Governor Cuomo has urged both sides to seek a resolution. Leaders of the Senate and Assembly could call a special session, and some officials had hoped for one this Friday, before the Democratic National Convention occupied Democratic legislators. But there were indications today that the stalemate was continuing.
 
Oversight in Dispute
 Mr. Weprin said he still believed the counties needed financial review boards, which are strongly opposed by Republicans.
Mr. Marino said today that an agreement could have been reached last week. "It's not a question of when we'll meet," he said. "It's a question of when the Democrats stop trying to play politics with the fortunes and future of Long Island."
Nassau is seeking Albany's approval to borrow $100 million dollars, 70 percent of it in five-year general obligation bonds, and to raise $213 million by the end of 1997 by doubling its mortgage recording tax to 2 percent. Suffolk wants to borrow up to $91 million and to raise the county's 8 percent sales tax to 8.5 percent.
Without the funds, both counties will run out of money by October and will lay off thousands of employees, drastically cut services and raise property taxes between $200 and $300 for each homeowner. Nassau's $1.8 billion budget has a $153 million shortfall, and Suffolk's $1.3 billion budget has a $100 million gap.
The room tax was one of several measures supported by the Suffolk County Executive, Robert Gaffney, to close the gap.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.M. Signs an Accord With Environmentalists

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
In an unusual expression of detente between industry and environmentalists, General Motors and the Environmental Defense Fund announced yesterday that they had signed an agreement to hold formal discussions on environmental issues.
"Over the last 20 years, it's been each side preaching to the heathen on the other side," said Joseph Goffman, a lawyer with the environmental group. "We've decided to skip the great conversion speeches and talk about what we can talk about." 
 G.M., the world's largest car maker, is at the center of a wide range of such environmental issues as urban smog, destruction of the ozone layer and the threat of global warming.
The Environmental Defense Fund, a New York-based nonprofit group with 200,000 members, often sues polluters. Last November, however, it negotiated an agreement with the McDonald's Corporation under which, among other things, the fast-food company replaced its plastic "clamshell" packaging with biodegradable cardboard. .
The dialogue required a formal agreement, said Samuel A. Leonard, G.M.'s director of automotive emissions control, so the environmentalists "could not be accused of selling out."
The agreement specifies that the environmental group will not accept funds from G.M. and that G.M. cannot publicize the dialogue in advertising, marketing or point-of-purchase materials, without the group's permission. The fund would be unlikely to give such permission, Mr. Goffman said.
Informal collaboration has been going on since January and has already produced a proposal presented to the Federal Environmental Protection Agency on running a program for scrapping old cars.
President Bush proposed such a program in November, in which a company that faced a requirement to cut air pollution at a factory it owned could instead buy old, high-pollution cars and scrap them, taking credit against other obligations to cut pollution.
 
2 Heads Better . . .
 Both G.M. and the Environmental Defense Fund have said the joint proposal is better than each could have come up with on its own. The Environmental Defense Fund proposed that pollution-reduction credit be limited to 90 percent of the actual reduction.
"It makes eminent sense when you think about it," Mr. Leonard of G.M. said in a telephone interview yesterday.
G.M., Mr. Leonard said, had added that the vehicles to be scrapped be selected by actual measurement of tailpipe emissions, rather than simply by their age.
"The process we've gone through on vehicle scrapping has increased our respect for what the other brings to the table," Mr. Leonard said.
The two sides plan to discuss ways to encourage the use of clean vehicles that run on other than gasoline, ways to measure automotive emissions, cost-effectiveness of new fuels and new standards on vehicle emissions, the role of vehicles in global warming and the impact of regulatory requirements on vehicle design.
But they will avoid some long-standing areas of dispute, including fuel economy standards and installing larger canisters on cars to filter the polluting gases that evaporate from fuel tanks.
"We will have to use more traditional methods to solve those," he said, alluding to lobbying in Congress and arguing before the administrative agencies and the courts.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Cocoa Prices Up Sharply; Gasoline at 4-Month Low

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Cocoa futures registered big gains yesterday in heavy trading on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange amid concerns about dry weather in cocoa-producing regions of West Africa.
Energy futures were mixed. 
 Judith Ganes, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company in New York, said the rally in cocoa futures came despite an oversupply of cocoa. She said there was a seven-month supply of cocoa in storage.
"It is still a bear market," she said.
Cocoa for delivery in September settled $55 higher at $1,036 a metric ton.
Ms. Ganes said the dryness in Africa was a major concern for the market, and she said producers were not selling cocoa because they were awaiting the outcome of the International Cocoa Organization talks in Geneva, scheduled to end July 24.
"There is a lot of differences between the producers, particularly between Brazil and the African countries," Ms. Ganes said, adding that past cocoa agreements have been failures.
Some producers would like to see talks aimed at curbing production, noting the 1.5-million-metric-ton surplus. However, the Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer, is resisting that suggestion.
Brazilian representatives to the talks are suggesting that producers search for ways to increase consumption of cocoa. Brazil has suggested selling the International Cocoa Organization's buffer stock to the Commonwealth of Independent States at subsidized prices over a five-year period.
Ms. Ganes said that was a good idea because the commonwealth and Eastern European countries were heavy consumers of cocoa, although consumption has been lower in recent years because of economic problems.
Gasoline futures fell to a four-month low on the New York Mercantile Exchange as a result of high inventories and sluggish demand.
American Petroleum Institute figures showed gasoline stocks rose by 2.3 million barrels for the week ending June 26. Expectations were for a decline in stocks.
Crude stocks fell by 3.6 million barrels, while an increase was expected, which helped sweet crude futures.
Light sweet crude oil for August delivery was 1 cent higher at $21.41 a barrel; August heating oil was 0.33 cent higher at 59.06 cents a gallon; August unleaded gasoline was 1.38 cents lower at 58.53 cents a gallon; August natural gas was 3.5 cents higher at $1.630 for a thousand cubic feet.

HEADLINE: Consumer Debt Down

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
The nation's consumer borrowing declined $2.4 billion in May for the fourth consecutive monthly decrease, suggesting spending needed to sustain a recovery was wavering.
The annual rate of borrowing fell by 4 percent and followed the sharpest decline in more than a decade in April, the Federal Reserve System said today in its monthly report. 
 Only credit card borrowing posted a small increase. Auto and other borrowing, which includes personal loans, declined further.
Instead of spending as they did in the 80's, consumers have been paying off loans, worried they could lose their jobs and homes during the recession.
"Consumers are working off debt," said Jean Sundrla, an economist at Evans Economics here. The gain in credit card borrowing showed only that that people are having trouble paying their bill, rather than that they are deliberately increasing their debt, she said.
The level of consumer debt declined to a seasonally adjusted $721.4 billion in May after declining $3.6 billion in April, or at a 5.9 percent pace, to $723.8 billion, the Fed said.
The April decline was the largest since a 6.1 percent drop in February 1982, a Fed spokesman said.

HEADLINE: Business Failures Up

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
United States business failures rose 15.9 percent for the first five months of 1992, Dun & Bradstreet said yesterday. Business failures for the period totaled 42,118, up from 36,355 in January through May 1991.
"While the economy has begun to show modest improvements, for many financially troubled firms this growth is too little too late," said Joseph W. Duncan, vice president and chief statistician for Dun & Bradstreet. 
 Every United States census region except the East South Central had an increase in business failures during the first five months of the year. The Middle Atlantic region, with 39.8 percent, and the Pacific region, with 36.4 percent, posted the sharpest rises. Failures in the Middle Atlantic were propelled by a 62 percent increase in New York.
Failures in the agriculture, forestry and fishing businesses posted the largest percentage increase, with a 36 percent jump to 1,320 from 969. Failures in the services sector were the most numerous: 11,597 compared with 9,400 in the first five months of 1991.
Wholesale trade failures for the first five months increased 21.3 percent, to 2,978 from 2,456. Retail trade failures rose 15.7 percent, to 8,312 from 7,186.
Finance, insurance and real estate industry failures rose 18 percent, to 2,665. Manufacturing failures climbed 16.2 percent, to 3,140, and construction industry failures rose 10.6 percent, to 5,499, Dun & Bradstreet said.

HEADLINE: Surpluses Up For Japanese

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 8

 BODY:
Japan's unadjusted worldwide current-account surplus reached $9.49 billion in May, more than double the $4.16 billion surplus in May 1991, the Finance Ministry said today.
Japan's politically sensitive current-account surplus with the United States also rose, by 6.3 percent, to $40.03 billion in the calendar year 1991 from $37.65 billion a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said. 
 Its trade surplus with the United States in 1991, meanwhile, edged up 3.7 percent, to $43.44 billion from $41.87 billion in 1990, it said. The country's unadjusted trade surplus almost doubled to $10.09 billion in May from a $5.47 billion surplus in May 1991.
Economists' estimates for the surplus in current account, the broadest measure of goods and services, had ranged from $6.3 billion to $9.3 billion, a Reuters survey said. The economists attributed the big rise to steady growth in exports while imports remained weak, and they said the surplus was likely to continue to grow.
Japan's current-account surplus with nations in the European Community quadrupled to $25.22 billion in 1991 from $6.16 billion in 1990, while its trade surplus with the community doubled to $33.37 billion from $16.35 billion in the same period.

HEADLINE: Clint Frank, 76, Dies; Won Heisman in 1937

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 8

 BODY:
Clint Frank, who won college football's Heisman Trophy in 1937 as a two-way back for Yale, died on Tuesday in Evanston (Ill.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 76 years old.
Mr. Frank was the third winner of the Heisman, which goes to the nation's outstanding player, and the second one from Yale, following the selection of his teammate Larry Kelley in 1936. The runner-up to Mr. Frank in 1937 was Byron (Whizzer) White of Colorado, who went from football stardom to the United States Supreme Court. 
 After Mr. Frank graduated with a degree in economics, he went into advertising. After five years with the Army Air Corps during World War II, Mr. Frank returned to advertising. In 1954, he founded Clinton E. Frank Inc., which he sold to Campbell-Ewald Co. in Detroit in 1976.
He was elected to the National Football Hall of Fame in 1955 and in 1988 was named recipient of the Gold Medal, the hall's highest award.
He is survived by his wife, Margaret Rathje Frank, three sons and six daughters.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
ROCKWELL'S CZECH VENTURE GETS INITIAL APPROVAL

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The Rockwell International Corporation said yesterday that it had received preliminary approval to form a joint venture in Czechoslovakia that would manufacture automotive parts and sell them to Czechoslovak auto makers. Czechoslovakia's Privatization Ministry approved the venture, which still requires approval by the country's Economic Council, said Richard Pacini, a Rockwell spokesman. 
 Rockwell's auto parts division, based in Troy, Mich., will purchase an existing factory complex in Liberec, about 75 miles northeast of Prague, Mr. Pacini said. Rockwell will assume majority ownership of the plant and will invest an undisclosed sum to improve it. The plant will produce window regulators and seat slides.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Obstructing Justice

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In 1958 Sherman Adams, Eisenhower's chief of staff, improperly called the S.E.C. from the White House to inquire about the status of an investigation into his friend Bernard Goldfine; that influential call led to scandal and prosecutions.
In 1989 Boyden Gray, President Bush's White House Counsel, told his aide Jay Bybee to call the U.S. Attorney in Atlanta to express White House interest in a criminal investigation that might embarrass Saddam Hussein. 
 That improper intervention -- phone calls now remembered by the local prosecutor as "a few at the most," urging delicate handling from the highest level -- fit into a pattern of obstruction of justice and lying to Congress we call Iraqgate.
Let's review the bidding in 1989, as George Bush and James Baker determined to abuse our grain export program to provide backdoor foreign aid to Iraq:
On Aug. 4, the F.B.I. raids the offices of an Atlanta bank channeling billions of dollars of taxpayer-guaranteed loans to Iraq. Despite evidence of skimming and diversion, on Oct. 2 President Bush signs N.S.D. 26 encouraging U.S. companies to sell Saddam nuclear technology.
On Nov. 6 the C.I.A. reports Iraq is using the Atlanta bank loans to purchase "military-related technology," though the politicized C.I.A. summary concentrates on the effect of publicity about this on U.S.-Iraqi ties.
During that first week of November, Gail McKenzie -- the Assistant U.S. Attorney in Atlanta preparing an indictment that would embarrass Saddam Hussein's family -- gets what she now tells associates were "a few at the most" calls from the White House reminding her of the "embarrassment level" of prosecution.
Ms. McKenzie tells Marilyn Muench of the Treasury Department, who also wants to know about the status of her case, of the White House calls; Ms. Muench tells Rachel Bailey, an economist monitoring the export credits to the uncreditworthy borrower, about the hard-to-forget calls; Ms. Bailey's notes were forced out of Treasury this week by Representative Henry Gonzalez.
On Nov. 8, Secretary Baker pressures the Bush interagency committee to ignore both nuclear warning and corruption evidence and O.K. $500 million more to Iraq.
The "few at the most" calls from Boyden Gray's White House office are now characterized as requests for "publicly available information" by the Bush Justice Department.
Let's be serious: When the President of the U.S. needs information about a criminal case, he asks his Attorney General, who knows how to inquire without influencing the prosecution. But when the President wants to influence the case, he has his Office of Legal Counsel call the local prosecutor from the White House.
That's how Ms. McKenzie knew not to indict a member of the dictator's family in Baghdad, and why she was willing to delay her indictment for a year. It suited the Bush-Baker benighted foreign policy for this case to be botched, and botched it was -- with the White House calls intended to be kept secret.
Can Justice investigate its own manipulation? Gerrilyn Brill, the Atlanta team player now being used as spokeswoman for Ms. McKenzie, who seems to have mislaid her phone logs, asserts proudly: "We are not investigating a possible obstruction of justice." Attorney General William Barr served with George Bush at the C.I.A.; his closest political pal is Boyden Gray, who initiated the corrupting phone calls.
This morning the Judiciary Committee chairman, Jack Brooks, will get the requisite 11 signatures on a letter pointing to "personal, political or financial conflict of interest" within Justice. Here is why it is urgent that he trigger the Independent Counsel Act this week:
Attorney General Barr could claim after 30 days that no evidence of wrongdoing existed, but such bald-faced cover-up would invite impeachment. After 60 more days -- Oct. 7 -- he could ask the courts for a 60-day extension, to Dec. 7.
On Dec. 15 the Independent Counsel Act expires, and George Bush wants it to stay dead. That means Judiciary must trigger the act now or it's back to the good old days of White House whitewashes. George Bush would investigate Iraqgate himself and -- surprise! -- find himself not guilty.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Cuddling Saddam

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Did President Bush's policy toward Iraq before its invasion of Kuwait involve law-breaking? Maybe. And maybe some official cover-up afterward. In any event, it would take far too long for an independent counsel to get to the bottom of the matter, and the results would be problematic.
Was the policy merely a "mistake," as Bush officials are wont to say? This remarkably generous description would be laughed off by Republicans if Democrats had committed even remotely similar sins. 
 Was it a blunder? Yes. And of such proportions that Bill Clinton and Ross Perot would be crazy not to drag the issue into the Presidential campaign.
This much is already clear from the previously secret documents put on display by Representatives Henry Gonzalez and Sam Gejdenson: The Bush Administration knew or had good reason to believe that Saddam Hussein was involved with nuclear weapons, terrorism, genocide with chemical weapons against the Kurds, illegal diversion of loans to buy arms -- and that he was a very bad guy with boundless ambition.
Yet in the face of all this, Bush & Co. consistently protected him from an increasingly suspicious Congress.
Protect Saddam to what end? To "moderate" his behavior, the officials say and said. To glimpse how zany this was, to see what they saw as acceptable behavior, look at what they knew or suspected about Saddam from 1988 on:
They had good reason to believe Saddam had a secret nuclear weapons program. True, international inspectors were giving Iraq a clean bill of health. But they knew of its longstanding effort to acquire weapons-grade uranium, and that in 1990 it tried to smuggle in U.S.-made nuclear capacitors. They also knew that from 1985 to 1990 the U.S. had approved 771 items of dual-use technology, of which 162 had possible nuclear applications.
On June 15, 1990, less than two months before the Kuwait invasion, a senior State Department official told Congress that Iraq was not a "near-term" nuclear threat. But he went on to note Saddam's "great lengths to develop non-conventional weapons," including nukes.
Bush aides also had definite information about an Iraqi missile program with capabilities well beyond Scuds. Many officials argued that these missiles, given their potential accuracy, made sense only as carriers of a nuclear payload. Some officials further maintained that Iraq had been diverting loans from the Banco Lavoro to finance this effort.
Administration officials knew that Saddam was still engaged in terrorism. In a secret memo in late 1988, Assistant Secretary of State Richard Murphy wrote that the Iraqis had "curbed their support for Palestinian terrorism, while remaining willing to use international terrorism themselves against their opponents." Though officials had even harder information later, they continued to reaffirm their decision to remove Iraq from the list of terrorist countries.
Officials also knew that Saddam was trying to exterminate Kurds and had used chemical weapons to do so. A State Department memo of November 1988 referred to "reliable reports" of chemical weapons use and went on to say that "upward of 500 Kurdish villages have been depopulated. . . ."
Officials also believed Saddam was evil. A typical State Department memo from 1988 said, "His worldview is that of a conspirator who believes that power comes from the barrel of a gun." Another from that year called his state "totalitarian," and added: "The brutality visited on portions of Iraq's Kurdish population fits into the general framework of repression. . . ."
Knowing or at least worrying about all this, Mr. Bush nonetheless approved new farm credits and dual-use technology sales for Iraq and opposed Congressionally imposed economic sanctions. And in July 1990, as Saddam's forces were poised to attack Kuwait, he opposed a Senate move to bar further loans to Iraq. As bizarre, on Nov. 16, 1990, with 500,000 U.S. troops already in the Persian Gulf, he vetoed a bill that would have forced him to impose sanctions on states that use chemical weapons.
Just imagine what George Bush, Ronald Reagan and other hard-nosed Republicans would be saying today if "President Dukakis" or soft-headed Democrats had made any such simple "mistake." Just imagine.
