HEADLINE: Making a Case for a Fiscal Jolt

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Could fiscal policy, long buried under the rubble of the $4 trillion Federal debt, rise from the grave?
A few months ago, the prospects of using tax cuts or government spending to jolt the economy from its torpor were virtually nil. But higher unemployment and, more important, the growing realization that business-as-usual means high unemployment for years to come, have made the unthinkable merely unlikely. 
 In fact, 100 leading economists, including six Nobel laureates, recently urged the Government to spend $50 billion a year on investment to speed growth. And Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas is offering a public investment plan in his campaign. But many others are still skeptical.
 
Economists Lose Faith
 Why is fiscal stimulus such a hard sell? In the stagflation of the 1970's, many mainstream economists lost faith in the efficacy of economic fine-tuning. The new view, notes Robert J. Gordon of Northwestern University, was that "tax cuts are dissipated in private savings, and spending takes too long."
In recent years, however, this post-Keynesian critique has been overshadowed by the problems of managing the economy in an era of $300 billion budget deficits. While there is plenty of unused productive capacity today, the deficit, to many, represents a large, already mortgaged claim on future savings. Many analysts interpret stubbornly high long-term interest rates as the financial markets' vote of no-confidence in Washington's ability to contain demand once the economy is again chugging. "They must be projecting a capital shortage," concludes Barry Bosworth of the Brookings Institution.
 
Prospects Seem Bleak
 By this logic, the tonic of deficit spending might be fully offset by the depressant of higher long-term interest rates. Even economists who scoff at the idea of a dollar-for-dollar offset acknowledge that fiscal stimulus could tilt output toward consumption and away from investment -- hardly the game plan of choice in an era of sagging productivity growth.
All this suggests that the prospects for applying a fiscal jolt (or getting the desired results, if applied) are bleak. The mechanics alone represent a formidable political barrier: To get past the deficit reduction agreement of 1990, notes Robert Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, the President would have to declare an emergency and Congress would have to accede. But even today, four months before the election, 7.8 percent unemployment has a way of clarifying politicians' priorities. And those who dread the consequences of fiddling while the voters burn can certainly muster arguments to justify taking action.
Mr. Gordon, for example, doubts that the traditional argument against public works applies. With financially pressed local governments cutting back on projects already begun, he argues, "every dime from Washington would be spent."
Analysts caution, however, that any stimulus package would have to be crafted with care to generate maximum effect with minimum backlash. It makes sense, for example, to focus spending on muscle rather than fat -- on highways or job training rather than supplements to personal income. And Mr. Bosworth says Washington must show that any deficit increase would be temporary.
The best means to this end, he suggests, would be to tie the spending increase to a tax surcharge down the road. That way, there would be less reason to believe that money invested in 1992-93 would push the budget even further out of balance later.
But Mr. Reischauer warns that no matter what the recipe, lunch would not be free or even cheap.
What follows are the views of nine economic experts on where the economy might get the most useful jolt -- with the biggest future payoff -- if the Federal Government decided it did want to loosen its purse strings.
 
Rebuilding Inner Cities
 
Paul S. Grogan
President, Local Initiatives Support Corporation, which provides financial and technical assistance to nonprofit community-based developers
The great physicist Niels Bohr once observed: "There is not much hope if we have only one difficulty, but when we have two, we can match them off against each other."
That's how we should be approaching two of the nation's most pressing problems: stimulating the American economy for the short and long term and doing something about the inner cities.
Both sets of problems have been festering for years. And the Federal response, despite the Los Angeles riots and renewed evidence that the economy languishes, has been painfully anemic.
Understandably, there is little enthusiasm for the rigid and prescriptive government spending programs of the past that were better at producing bureaucracy than results.
But there is another way, one that relies on bedrock American values such as decentralized local initiative, self-help, partnership and private investment. Using a constellation of existing, modest Federal programs, administered primarily at the state and local levels, public money can be quickly used to stimulate substantial long-term private investment in rebuilding inner cities.
The most efficient way to proceed is by funding existing programs that have bipartisan support and can be expanded without red tape. Here are three:
*The Low Income Housing Tax Credit, at a cost of $2.5 billion over five years, should be extended permanently and increased. Since 1987, the credit has attracted billions of private investment dollars to build 400,000 low-cost housing units and is linked to 94 percent of all new affordable rental housing. The credit creates 100,000 jobs each year, 40 percent of them in construction, as well as $16.8 billion in economic activity and $1.2 billion in tax revenue.
*The HOME program, established in 1990 as part of a new Federal housing act, should be fully funded at $2 billion instead of slashed, as the President has proposed. It gives cities and states flexible funds to invest in homeownership and rental housing, money that attracts other private investment.
*Community Development Block Grant funding should be doubled to $6 billion restoring it to 1980 levels (adjusted for inflation.) Cities and states use C.D.B.G. for a wide range of economic development, housing and infrastructure investments in low-income communities.
Finally, to add to these proven winners, Congress should enact a new tax credit for inner-city economic development projects like supermarkets. Such a credit would create thousands of jobs for low-income residents, slash exorbitant food costs and re-create an essential part of community life.
 
Needed: New Ideas On Investment
 
Michael H. Walsh
 President and chief executive, Tenneco Inc.
Changing the country is hugely more difficult than changing a company, but the principles are similar. It starts with facing facts. We consume too much and invest too little. We've got to pay the piper for past excesses. Frequently this means saying "no" to things we need, but can't afford. Mostly it means saving and investing -- sacrificing -- to build for tomorrow.
What does this mean for the country? First, it means investment in people, technology and infrastructure -- three of the key things which drive our economy. Second, unless we cut back on the runaway entitlements in the Federal budget, there won't be much added Federal money to invest in anything. Third, it means a joint effort between the public and private sectors, with less posturing and much more leadership from both. Fourth, and most importantly, it requires mobilizing a collective national will to conquer the economic and social challenges we face as we look ahead to the 21st century.
All of this requires a high level of infrastructure investment. Creative investment vehicles (such as Felix Rohatyn's idea of investment-rated bonds to be acquired by private and public pension funds) need to be examined with an eye as to how they can be made to work (as opposed to finding the endless reasons they won't because we haven't tried).
We also need to be creative about long-term tax incentives to stimulate productive investment, as well as market-related efforts like Jack Kemp's proposal for enterprise zones.
A focus on productivity -- doing more with less -- is also critical. So is new thinking.
The bottom line? Our problems will not fix themselves. They require genuine tough-minded leadership from business and government. We can find additional funds (provided we think the need is great enough) from tough but necessary measures such as increased gasoline taxes, possibly even temporary income tax surcharges, reductions in the growth of entitlements, creative finance devices, major improvement in government efficiencies, and so on.
The payback from all of this will be less inner-city decay, fewer inadequate public schools, reduced unemployment and increased competitiveness. None of these steps is popular or easy. But if our current paralysis continues, we'll go nowhere -- except down.
 
Technologies Need Nurturing
 
William J. Spencer
 President and chief executive, Sematech, an alliance of companies in the semiconductor industry.
It's time for the United States to think about investing in the United States -- and in the critical technologies that will determine the nation's competitiveness.
Those technologies, which include such fields as semiconductors, electronics, software and advanced materials, have already been identified by such diverse organizations as the Departments of Commerce and Defense, the President's science adviser, and the commercial Council on Competitiveness, as well as by Japan's Ministry for International Trade and Industry and by the European community. The interesting aspect of these lists is not that they exist, but that they are nearly identical.
Other economic regions are already investing in these technologies. Only the United States among leading nations has hesitated in setting national priorities and finding ways to develop U.S. leadership in them.
One approach to investing in these technologies is to set up a series of national experiments in critical industries. They should involve industry and government, and -- where they have expertise -- our universities and national labs.
One such experiment, Sematech, has been under way for five years. Eighty percent of the United States semiconductor industry banded together to focus on manufacturing capabilities in this key industry. Costs were shared by industry and government, and the directions for the program were principally set by industry.
In 1991, an independent research organization showed that for the first time in more than a decade, the United States market share in semiconductor manufacturing equipment increased. This increase represented jobs generated in the United States, or not lost, greater than the government investment in the experiment. If this market share increases, as we expect, it should generate additional new jobs, tax revenue and personal income.
The experiments should be short term, and must focus on measurable technical results, as well as such measurable criteria as job creation, increased exports and increased tax revenue. The experiments should be constantly monitored, and those that are unsuccessful should be ruthlessly terminated.
These experiments would represent an American approach to partnership aimed at establishing American manufacturing and industrial leadership in technology. If we want to be among the world's leaders in the future, we must have a stake in developing new critical technologies today.
 
$25 Billion For Programs
 
Sar A. Levitan
Director of the George Washington University Center for Social Policy Studies.
Measured by rising unemployment rates, current economic conditions reflect the longest downturn since World War II. Even as President Bush repeatedly proclaims that the recession is over, joblessness and welfare caseloads continue to rise. Monetary policy has fallen short of pulling the economy from its prolonged doldrums. The time is long overdue for Congress to stimulate the economy by creating jobs and expanding educational and training opportunities. In response to every recession during the past three decades, the Federal Government funded job creations initiatives -- even during the Reagan Administration. But President Bush has shunned such measures.
It would take five million new jobs to reduce unemployment to 4 percent, close to full employment, but creating only 600,000 jobs immediately would significantly ameliorate hardship. Society's work is never done, and there is no shortage of unmet needs, particularly since state and local governments have cut many essential services. A jobs program should fund services and labor-intensive public works projects because they would boost employment quickly, target the jobless least likely to find work on their own, and invest funds in jobs rather than materiel.
Eligibility criteria, therefore, should offer priority to the long-term, jobless and job-ready welfare recipients. The limited skills of these individuals could be readily matched with important unmet societal needs. Additional aides in public schools, hospitals and the criminal justice system could enable teachers to devote more time to instruction, free nurses for more skilled tasks, and put more police officers on the street. By employing job-ready welfare recipients, the program would encourage work and raise the living standards of recipients.
Jobs programs are often dismissed as too costly, but the price of inaction is compelling. In addition to boosting income support outlays, higher unemployment rates have demonstrated a correlation with rising mortality, health impairments, crime, mental illness and divorce rates.
Expanded education and training programs would also produce longer-term benefits. Millions of Americans are inadequately prepared for work. "Second-chance" programs would assist individuals who failed in or were failed by the educational systems.
Altogether these proposals would carry an annual price tag of about $25 billion above current Federal expenditures, to be divided equally among job creation, education and training. But the added outlays would reduce the current annual $50 billion welfare and unemployment insurance expenditures and produce a better educated, trained and more productive labor force.
 
Time to Plan For Long Run
 
William J. Baumol
Director, C. V. Starr Center for Applied Economics, New York University.
If Japan's growth is founded on borrowed technology, United States growth policy has missed the lesson: the need to facilitate rapid adoption of the latest technological developments from abroad.
It is probably too late to do much about our shorter-run recession problem, particularly as the legacy of Reaganomics has largely destroyed many of the policy options. Any anti-recession measures we adopt today are unlikely to show results until it is all over and very different programs are required. Now is the time to plan for the longer run, and particularly policies to encourage growth.
Most discussions advocate stimulating savings. But surprisingly, we know almost nothing about how to do that. Various tax gimmicks are proposed, most notably, reducing the capital gains tax, but statistical studies yield inconclusive or even negative results.
Three courses of action seem more promising: infrastructure investment, industrial policy to encourage promising industries and public sector support for the adoption and dissemination of foreign technology.
Almost every industrial economy has cut back on investment in governmentally provided infrastructure -- the airports, bridges, rail networks and other structures that are a foundation of economic performance. This provides an opportunity for the United States to forge ahead, but we have cut back more than anyone.
Reductions in the military budget can provide the requisite funds and can be timed to provide new jobs for those laid off by military cuts. Paradoxically, such reallocation of funds will actually help to strengthen our defense, because, as American military history confirms, our productive capacity has often been the key to victory.
Second, any country that succeeds in expanding a growth industry with scale economies attains a powerful competitive advantage over its rivals. The danger lies in succumbing to the political temptation to resuscitate dying industries. We must focus only on fields that promise to permit substantial growth.
 
Useful Investment In a Hurry
 
Francis M. Bator and Robert M. Solow
Dr. Bator is professor of political economy at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard and Dr. Solow is a professor of economics at M.I.T. and a Nobel laureate.
The economy has been stagnant since the last quarter of 1988. The resulting loss of production and jobs is irrecoverable. The further danger is that prolonged stagnation makes ultimate recovery even slower.
Under these circumstances, almost any kind of prompt action to increase total demand is desirable, and there is every reason to believe that direct fiscal steps will be effective. A temporary widening of the budget deficit is a price well worth paying, in fact not much of a price at all; it will lead to more, not less, private investment. Our businesses need customers right now, not savers.
Although any effective stimulus would help solve the short run problem, the country will gain in the long run if it takes the form of higher investment in future productive capacity. So the real question is: How can the Federal budget get us some useful investment right now, in a hurry?
We favor tax incentives for incremental business investment, as part of a long-run program. But with idle capacity increasing, that will take too long and temporary tax credits will just borrow investment from the immediate future. So we turn to direct Federal spending. The country is short of infrastructure and what we have is crumbling. A more efficient transportation network and a high-technology information transfer system would add to the productivity of private industry. The trick is to get moving fast.
The most effective way to get needed public investment quickly is through a prompt increase in Federal grants in aid to states and cities, earmarked for increased spending on infrastructure. Many states and cities have been canceling and postponing projects that could be ready to go in a few weeks. Workers and materials are easily available. Of course there will be slippage. Mayors and governors, desperate for funds, will try to pass off ongoing activities as candidates for Federal financing, and squirrel the new money into operating budgets. But under the scrutiny of Federal watchdogs they would not want to risk disqualification.
We think $50 billion could be spent very productively in one year. But we caution that continuation of increased public investment will need to be financed by new taxes or reduced military spending when the economy returns to prosperous conditions. For adequate total investment we must gradually shift the Federal budget into surplus. Private saving is unlikely to be large enough to finance both private and public investment.
Federal infrastructure investment would be welcome too. Federal money could probably find quick and useful employment in buying civilian research and development, perhaps by letting contracts to idled high-tech defense contractors.
The principle is clear: To put idle workers and capacity back to work, buy now -- but buy for the future.
 
Need to Insure Technology Base
 
George N. Hatsopoulos
 Mr. Hatsopoulos is chairman and president, Thermo Electron Corporation.
Historically, the U.S. Government's expenditures for aerospace and defense research have paid great dividends in fields such as computers, commercial aviation, energy and the environment. As defense research and development declines, we need to insure that the nation's technology base continues to receive the support necessary to sustain future growth through the creation of new commercial activities and all-new industries.
In considering additional short-term measures to stimulate economic recovery, we should avoid creating new governmental organizations and try to work within the present structure. We must also take care that our actions will strengthen this country's long-term competitiveness. These goals can be met by concentrating on what America does best -- conducting advanced scientific research and developing innovative new products and services. I believe that significant results can be achieved over the next few years by applying a reasonable portion of the money we are currently cutting from the defense budget.
One way to obtain fast results, without expanding the Government's existing bureaucracy, is to appropriate additional R&D funding for agencies such as the National Institutes of Health, Environmental Protection Agency, Department of Energy, and the Department of Transportation. These agencies already sponsor programs designed to meet society's current and emerging problems -- health care, air and water quality, energy conservation, airline and highway safety and many others. We can capitalize on this structure by boosting Federal sponsorship of technology development without substantially altering the present national priorities and goals.
Additional research and development spending introduces an almost immediate stimulus to the economy through the procurement of equipment, software, and other supplies, and it expands employment in a wide range of industries. There is no lack of problems to which new research funding can be productively applied. Furthermore, we have seen that the commercialization of advanced technologies, particularly through small start-up ventures, has been one of our most effective vehicles for creating new, high-value jobs.
 
Highest Priority: Young People
 
Reuben Mark
Chairman, president and chief executive, Colgate-Palmolive Company.
Our society cries out desperately major investment in many areas. But investment in our young people should be of our highest priority.
Think back to what happened when we first approached school.
First, we came to school somewhat prepared. Second, we entered a building that, generally speaking, was hospitable, well maintained, and technologically equipped to fulfill our needs. Third, we encountered caring, motivated individuals whose training and experience helped us learn.
Contrast that with the situation today. Many urban youngsters approach school totally unprepared and face the difficult, if not impossible, task of "catching up". School buildings are dilapidated, detrimental to the learning process, and not up to the technological standards required.
And finally, while teachers and principals are as caring as ever, frustration, poor pay, and cuts in professional and leadership training budgets have taken their toll.
Federal investment is needed in each of these three areas:
1. Investment in Early Childhood Development
Increased early childhood investment is critical. If a child cannot read by second grade, he or she is lost to the educational system. Headstart's effectiveness is widely acknowledged, but the program currently reaches only 30% of eligible, disadvantaged children. It must be expanded to 100% as quickly as possible, must address chidren as young as two, and must be extended to full rather than half-days.
Further, funding must be increased for Chapter 1, the national remedial program for math and reading. In addition, chapter 1 needs greater flexibility for a broader array of services and school projects.
2. Investment in School Buildings and Facilities
Capital investment in school buildings is vital. Just as a nation must put huge sums into bridges and roads, the federal government must find ways to improve the physical plant and technological capabilities of our nation's schools.
3. Investment in Teaching Skills and School Leadership
Every human endeavor depends on people. Our teachers must be viewed as performing a vital national role. An investment mechanism must be found to insure appropriate pay and to increase morale, retention and performance.
Funds must be found for increased training at all levels and for reducing class size. We must also further develop the leadership of school principals and administrators. We must invest in these three areas: Pre-school education; school buildings and facilities; and the training, motivation and encouraging of the people who affect our children profoundly.

HEADLINE: An Unequal Justice;
Little Aid for Hard-Time Sisterhood

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

 BODY:
T. J. Rivera lingered remorsefully over her role in one of the most startling social turns of America's last decade -- a tripling of the number of women in United States prisons and jails, a growth rate well beyond that of male inmates.
"Here I had just assaulted this 74-year-old woman," Ms. Rivera recalled, backtracking to bad times on the streets of Manhattan as a 28-year-old drug-addicted mugger of a pedestrian, a particularly vulnerable woman whose purse she grabbed. 
 "Franny was covered in blood," the ex-convict continued, now knowing the name and nature of her victim. "I stopped. 'Oh my God,' I said. 'I'm so sorry.' And Franny said, 'Honey, if you had just asked me.' "
The underlying notion of sisterhood that drove Ms. Rivera to meet and befriend her victim of six years ago is a driving factor in her new post-prison life as an organizer of female convicts and their children who have the AIDS virus.
Sisterhood is no less a motivation for Ms. Rivera's new partner, Ann Jacobs, the executive director of the 150-year-old Women's Prison Association. She is busy shedding the vestiges of noblesse oblige from the esteemed organization's 19th-century roots and throwing open the doors of its brownstone headquarters, 110 Second Avenue at East Seventh Street in lower Manhattan, to H.I.V.-positive babies and their felonious mothers. Ms. Rivera is a regular visitor as the association takes on its new focus.
 
Institutional Invisibility
 "The criminal justice system remains male-focused in spite of the fact that women are the fastest growing part of the prison population," noted Ms. Jacobs, who is turning the association toward rough-edged inmate organizations like Ms. Rivera's Ace-Out (AIDS Education Counseling on the Outside). She is living with the problem that, amid the nation's vast growth in prison population in the past decade of the "war on drugs," the number of incarcerated women has grown by 202 percent, compared with the male population's 112 percent increase.
The dragnets of the narcotics police are sweeping in more women from a growing cottage drug industry in ghetto neighborhoods. Many of these women, while likely to be fix-hungry addicts and low-ranking surrogates of men in drug deals, have had to do more hard time as a result of recent mandatory drug-sentencing laws. With these laws, state legislatures across the nation have deprived judges of leeway to consider extenuating circumstances, most notably that more than three-fourths of the sentenced women are mothers.
A result in New York is that between 1982 and 1989 the number of women entering prison went up more than 500 percent, from 337 to 2,264. Convictions for violent crimes went down, while drug sentences rose more than twentyfold, from 67 in 1982 to 1,641 in 1989.
 
Lost in a Flood of Men
 Nationally, the numbers show that men remain the more felonious sex by almost 19 to one. There were 40,556 women in Federal and state prisons in 1989, a record tripling from the 13,420 imprisoned at the start of the decade, according to the Federal Bureau of Justice Statistics. The number of male prisoners totaled 669,498 in 1989, slightly more than doubling during a decade of vast prison construction that leaves the United States with the highest rate of incarceration of any industrialized nation.
In New York, leaders in addressing the badly overlooked needs of female inmates include Tracy Huling, director of the Women in Prison project of the Correctional Association of New York, a private monitoring organization. She is focusing on the special problem of women being used increasingly as unwitting "drug mules" -- relatively naive or desperate drug couriers who are receiving long sentences, as if they were substantial drug dealers.
"Mandatory sentencing is primarily being used against drug offenders, with the most harsh sentences going to the least offensive individuals," Ms. Huling said in an interview. "Everybody in the criminal justice system knows it's a joke. But it provides very effective political cover, an easy way to be 'tough on crime.' "
She prefers alternatives to prison time like intensive probation, house arrest and community service, programs that, while increasingly talked about, involve less than 5 percent of the nation's offender population.
While Ms. Huling has been working to reduce the number of female inmates by getting drug penalties eased, Elaine Roulet, a nun, has been starting infant nurseries inside the prison system and a chain of nine halfway houses in the metropolitan area for female ex-convicts with babies. The latter deal with a Catch-22, in which an ex-convict, dealing with multiple bureaucracies, cannot gather her children from foster care without adequate housing, which she cannot obtain without having her children in tow to show her need.
 
Looking for a Way Out
 "As I get older, I am obsessed with the thought that I have made these prisons 'prettier,' " said Sister Elaine, who has spent 22 years as a social worker at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, a maximum security prison for women a few miles north of Mount Kisco, N.Y. "But I don't believe in prison. We now have 23 mothers and babies in Bedford Hills -- and these are felons?" she said, offering an incredulous smile.
Sister Elaine cited the stories of two young women from the prison arrested in the same crack bust at an apartment in New York. One, a low-level courier for her boyfriend, accepted a plea bargain and served 18 months. The other, insisting she was an uninvolved baby sitter, declined to plea bargain and pressed her innocence in court. But she was convicted and is serving 15 years to life. The two work together in a Bedford Hills social service program, on separate sides of the prison wall.
Young black and Hispanci women who use drugs have proved to be among the easiest targets of antinarcotics police sweeps, said Jo Anne Page, director of the Fortune Society, a private program that helps ex-convicts. Whatever the public thinks of the headlined war on drugs that focuses most easily on the economic underclass, Ms. Page notes that some studies suggest the white majority's drug abuse is comparable.
"All we've really been doing for the past decade is building low-income housing for the poor -- prison cages -- at an astronomical level," said Ms. Page, referring to the $52,000 median cost of providing space for each new prisoner and noting the hidden costs were even greater for the majority of women in prison whose children were placed in foster care, at a cost of $20,000 or more annually per child.
The cost of space for two new prisoners would almost make the budget of Women Care, a mentor program for female ex-inmates in the city that is highly praised but, even with a budget of $110,000 a year, is scrambling to find new financing. "I always had the quick answers and thought I knew poor people," said the program's founder, Eileen Hogan, a nun who worked nine years with female inmates at Rikers Island and realized something more was needed.
Sister Eileen started a program to reach beyond group programs and carefully match female inmates one to one with female mentors -- a cross-section of society, from lawyers to a few ex-convicts. They talk to the ex-inmates daily about immediate problems, meet with them at least weekly and build some very deep and beneficial friendships, program workers said.
 
The Trouble With Leniency
 The State Legislature, reflecting constituent fears, has demonstrated its continuing faith in prison construction. It has been skittish about Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's recent attempt to soften some sentencing laws, like one that mandates prison time for anyone convicted of a felony for the second time. But Ms. Huling of the Correctional Association hopes that the attention being paid to the issue of women used as drug mules in such influential circles as the office of John Cardinal O'Connor of the New York Archdiocese may eventually provide the first wedge for drug-law reform in more than a decade.
The second-felony law, in particular, has been contributing to the record rise of female inmates, corrections specialists say. They say a drug-addicted woman shown leniency in a first offense typically turns back to illicit low-level criminal activity within a few weeks in order to maintain her habit and her family.
"Every day I want out of here," said Miriam Benitez, a 33-year-old inmate at Bedford Hills who fell into just such a pattern and is to be released July 16 after finishing a second drug-related prison term of 22 months. Her daughter, Felisha, was born in the Bedford Hills prison nursery 21 months ago. Mrs. Benitez went through labor with a handcuff holding one wrist to the bed.
Mrs. Benitez, who has three older children, said that Bedford Hills remained every bit a prison, brooding and confining, despite its pastel colors and well-praised programs and administrators. But they have allowed Felisha to become the state's first prison-commuting infant. By law, the baby had to leave the prison after 18 months, but Sister Elaine recruited a local family to provide foster care and drop the baby off at prison for six hours every weekday.
"The mothers in here worry a lot about our kids out there," Mrs. Benitez said. "The streets. The killings. The drugs. I pray every night for my kids." If she falls a third time in society's war on drugs, she will face 25 years to life.
Marty Melendez, an ex-convict who was released after a drug term last December, had supported her drug habit through prostitution, from which she traces her infection with the AIDS virus. Female inmates from the drug subculture are particularly alarming to AIDS researchers, for some estimates are that well over a quarter of them may be carrying the virus back to a world offering more drugs and prostitution.
"I didn't want to bring a baby into this world who was H.I.V.-positive," Mrs. Melendez recalled thinking, but then changed her mind and gave birth, days before her prison term began, to a daughter, Punky, now 15 months old and H.I.V.-positive.
"Oh, I love my baby. I'm glad she's here," said Mrs. Melendez, bolstered for a moment by Ace-Out as she visited the Women's Prison Association. Ms. Jacobs welcomed her as a bit of progress in reaching the growing prison sisterhood.

HEADLINE: Mugabe's Aura Fades as Drought Sears Zimbabwe

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARARE, Zimbabwe

 BODY:
After enjoying more than a decade of respect at home and abroad, President Robert G. Mugabe is beginning to fit a common profile on the continent: the African leader under fire.
One of the few African countries with a semi-modern economy, Zimbabwe now has an unemployment rate of more than 40 percent, inflation of nearly 40 percent, interest rates of 36 percent and critical food shortages caused as much by bad Government policies as by a devastating drought. 
 Malnutrition has soared in this country, which usually exports food, and many children are being turned away from public schools because their parents cannot afford the fees.
 
Captain Is Absent
 In the face of this grim economic and social picture, Mr. Mugabe has failed to make decisions or inspire confidence, say both his supporters and his critics in this country of 10 million.
"Mugabe gives the impression of being overwhelmed," said Ariston Chambati, the chairman of a major business conglomerate here, TA Holdings, and a former Ambassador to West Germany who still sees the President. "The boat is without a captain. Two years ago he was very much in charge."
[On July 3, Mr. Mugabe announced that he was abolishing seven Cabinet positions. Some of the Cabinet departments will be closed and others melded into existing departments, he said. It was a step that international donors, eager for Zimbabwe to reduce the size of its civil service, had been demanding for two years].
 
Early Hopes Eroded
 When Mr. Mugabe became Zimbabwe's first leader in 1980, he was bequeathed a country in a different league from most of Africa's economic crisis cases. Industry, agriculture and a relatively sophisticated transportation network had been developed in the white-ruled Rhodesia of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith.
Indeed, it is the promising start that is causing much of the disappointment now. "With what we inherited, the economy in Zimbabwe could have done much better," said A. Abner Botsch, a prominent businessman and former head of the Chamber of Commerce.
Internationally, Mr. Mugabe was given high marks for encouraging the white large-scale farmers to stay and at the same time developing broader education and health services for poor black Zimbabweans than were available in most other African countries.
Jesuit-educated and the holder of several university degrees, including two law degrees from the University of London, Mr. Mugabe mixes easily with admirers, white and black, in New York and London.
 
A Mixed Reputation
 Unlike most of his colleagues on the continent, Mr. Mugabe has not been seen as personally corrupt. The same cannot be said of many of his ministers. And he does indulge in an opulent headquarters for ZANU, his political party, and demands an airport reception by traditional dancers when he arrives home from overseas.
He has long espoused socialist principles; civil servants must still call one another comrade. But Mr. Mugabe officially abandoned his commitment to socialism at the end of 1990 when he accepted World Bank and International Monetary Fund programs to get new infusions of cash into the economy.
In a speech to Parliament in late June, Mr. Mugabe promised to carry out the World Bank programs -- mostly by creating a more competitive economy -- despite the drought. But so far the Government has been slow in changing the economy.
"The Government could have avoided half the total food import with better policies," said John Robertson, the chief economist of the First Merchant Bank in Harare.
 
The Corn Shortage
 In the last several years, Mr. Robertson said, the Government decided to pay a low price to farmers who grew corn, the staple crop. This meant that the large-scale farmers switched to other crops and the Government had to rely on the small peasant farmers, who live on less fertile land.
Relying on this less certain source for corn, the Government, expecting the usual rainfall in January and February, sold its entire corn reserves by last December, Mr. Robertson said.
But instead of rain, record high temperatures swept across southern Africa, causing the worst drought in this century. If the Government had not sold the reserves, it would have had to start importing grain only now instead of in April, economists say.
As ordinary Zimbabweans find food hard to get, there are increasing complaints about corruption at the top of Government as well as among lesser bureaucrats.
 
Corruption as Disincentive
 Mr. Mugabe's Minister for the Public Service, Eddison Zvobgo, acknowledged recently that there was a "high incidence" of corruption in Government and that the civil service was "wrought with bribery, patronage, embezzlement and extortion."
Business executives say that the scale of corruption has not reached the levels found in Nigeria and Kenya but that it remains a barrier to badly needed foreign investment. The Canadian High Commissioner, Charles Bassett, recently warned that corruption was discouraging investment.
In contrast to the diversifying political activity in other African countries, the organized opposition here is so far muted, largely because dissatisfaction has only gathered steam in the past two years.
 
Opposition Emerges
 A new political group, the Forum for Democratic Reform, emerged in May, led by lawyers and business executives, both black and white. So far, many Zimbabweans say, the group has too many whites to be credible. But it is bringing issues into the open by calling for a market economy, a more limited presidential tenure than the current six years and the re-establishment of the upper house of Parliament.
Mr. Mugabe lashed out at the Forum recently, saying he would not make way for "Ian Smith's people." He was aware, he said, of opposition groups with ambitions "based on false calculations that they can raise little armies," adding, "We will not let those ambitions take effect."
The whites in the Forum are liberals who opposed Mr. Smith and favored black majority rule.
Perhaps a more significant call for change came from the Roman Catholic Church. Its magazine, Moto, ran an article on Mr. Mugabe in May headlined "Time To Go, Comrade Mugabe."
A general election is not scheduled until 1995. By then, when Mr. Mugabe will be nearing 70, there will be an organized opposition, Mr. Chambati, the former Ambassador, said. "The only way this Government can successfully forestall a credible opposition is to deliver the goods," he said.

HEADLINE: Jordan Starts Enforcing Sanctions On Iraqi Trade and Exports of Oil

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, July 9

 BODY:
The Jordanian Government, which has permitted Iraq to export oil and import goods across its border in violation of the United Nations embargo, appears to have ended this trade in the past week, according to Western officials who monitor the traffic.
The decision by Jordan to stop the flow of oil and other goods across the border will further isolate President Saddam Hussein of Iraq and increase the strains on the Iraqi economy. 
The move is seen by many Western diplomats as one more step in a concerted effort by the Bush Administration to topple the Iraqi leader by the end of the year. "Jordan is the Iraqi lifeline," said a European diplomat, "and if the Jordanians are really serious about this, it will be a big blow."
 
We're Trying, King Says
 Jordanian officials, who have always maintained that they were complying with the United Nations sanctions, said there was no change in policy. "We've tried our best to adhere to these sanctions and implement them," King Hussein said in an interview Tuesday.
But a recent United States estimate said that up to 30 percent of the cargo crossing into Iraq from Jordan violated the embargo. Some smuggling also occurs across Iraq's borders with Turkey and Syria, but the quantity is negligible, these officials said.
The end of the illegal traffic was confirmed by shipping agents in Amman. "The clamp-down happened about a week ago," said Tawfik Qawar, the president of Amin Qawar & Sons, one of the largest shipping agencies in Jordan. "As long as it is foodstuffs or medicines, it can go into Iraq, but anything else is not allowed."
If the sanctions are tightened up, this will help ease the strain between King Hussein and the Bush Administration, which believes that the Jordanian monarch reneged on a promise he made in March at a White House meeting with President Bush.
In a display of Washington's pique with Jordan, the Pentagon last month canceled joint military exercises and slowed military aid to Amman.
The decision to tighten border controls was a result of intense lobbying by United States officials, including the Director of Central Intelligence, Robert M. Gates, who met with King Hussein three weeks ago in Amman, officials here said.
United States officials at first asked the King to place up to 50 United Nations inspectors in the Red Sea port of Aqaba to turn back Iraq-bound cargo, according to diplomats and Jordanian officials.
 
Jordan Rejected Monitors
 But the plan was angrily rebuffed by the King, who said the proposal violated Jordanian sovereignty. "We will not be treated as suspects who are in need of observations and supervision," King Hussein said of the proposal in an interview Tuesday with The Associated Press.
Despite the King's denunciation of the plan, however, the Government ordered customs officials a week ago to tighten border controls, Jordanian officials said.
Western officials also contend that the Jordanians have offered to cooperate in a campaign to oust the Iraqi leader, although it was not clear what this cooperation would entail. Since last year, the C.I.A. has been authorized to step up efforts to destabilize the Baghdad Government, including making covert contact with Iraqi citizens and Government officials.
"The Jordanians have come to realize that Saddam Hussein will not last forever and they had better get back in the good graces of the Persian Gulf states and the West," said one Arab diplomat. "They straddled the fence as long as they could."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Their Own Words;
Excerpts From Clinton's and Gore's Remarks on the Ticket

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 9

 BODY:
Following are excerpts, as transcribed by Reuters, from the news conference today at which Gov. Bill Clinton presented his running mate, Senator Al Gore.
 
CLINTON'S REMARKS
 Several weeks ago, when I named Warren Christopher, Madeleine Kunin and Vernon Jordan to head a team to recommend a Vice-Presidential running mate, I asked them to look for a candidate who met three tests. I said I wanted a Vice President who really understood what had happened to ordinary Americans in the last 12 years, someone who was committed to making government work again for average, hard-working American families. 
 I said I wanted a Vice President who would complement me and my own experiences and bring other experiences, knowledge and understanding to our common endeavor.
And above all, I said I wanted a Vice President who would be ready, should something happen to me, to immediately assume the office of President of the United States.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The running mate I have chosen is a leader of great strength, integrity and stature, a father who, like me, loves his children and shares my hunger to turn this economy around, to change our country, and to do it so that we don't raise the first generation of children to do worse than their parents.
The man standing beside me today has what it takes to lead this nation from the day we take office -- Senator Al Gore of Tennessee.
Throughout his public life, Al Gore has done what I've tried to do here in Arkansas. He's put government back on the side of ordinary men and women. Time and again he's stood up to powerful interests, to put people first. He's fought for health care and consumer protection. He is perhaps America's leading proponent of the development of new technologies like fiber optics and biotechnology to create the high-wage jobs America needs to move into the 21st century.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Al Gore has spent the last decade working on the global environmental challenges we desperately need to address: global warming, ozone depletion, energy conservation. He has written a magnificent book on his thoughts and recommendations. He has asked me to join in his commitment to preserve not only the environment of America but to preserve the environment of our globe for future generations, and together we will finally give the United States a real environmental Presidency.
Al Gore is a leading expert in foreign policy, national security and arms control. He supported the use of American force to drive Saddam Hussein from Kuwait. And when the gulf war was over, Al Gore did himself even more credit by being the one who took George Bush to task for abandoning the Kurds, and shaming the Republicans for trying to use patriotism as a political issue.

 	 	 		. . .	 	In the end Al Gore and I understand what this election is really all about -- the end of years of drift and division and denial, the beginning of an honest attempt to rebuild and reunite, and to renew this great nation, not just for ourselves but for our children and for our children's children.
 
GORE'S REMARKS
 I can tell you truthfully, I didn't seek this. And up until very recently when I began to get an inkling that I would get the call that came late last night, I didn't expect it.
But I'm here for one simple reason: I love my country.
And I believe in my heart that this ticket gives our country the best chance for the change we so desperately need -- to move forward again.
I'm proud to stand here with Bill Clinton at the beginning of a long, hard fight on behalf of the hard-working people of the United States of America. We have watched for 12 long years as the Republican Administration still in power has driven this country into the ditch. The time has come for all Americans to get off the sidelines, to get involved in the process, to be a part of the healing this country needs, to bring us together, not divide us one from another, to get to work on the changes for the average working people of this country.
 
'They've Run Out of Ideas'
 The time has come. Throughout American history, each generation has passed on leadership to the next. That time has come again -- the time for a new generation of leadership for the United States of America.
I believe very deeply that this nation simply cannot afford another four years of the kind of leadership that we have now. They've run out of ideas. They've run out energy. They've run out of the ability to inspire our people.
One of my greatest hopes as I join this ticket is to help Bill Clinton in his dramatic effort to lift the public dialogue so that we can make this campaign a national conversation about America's future, so that we can present to the American people ideas, choices, a sensible plan for getting our country moving in the right direction again.
Bill Clinton has for his entire career stood for that kind of responsible change, to improve the lives of the average people in Arkansas and in this country. I want to be a part of that effort.
I know from conversations that the two of us have had, that Bill Clinton is speaking from his heart when he says here, as he did just a few minutes ago, that together we can make all the difference in determining whether or not the United States of America will offer the leadership our world needs to save the earth's environment. We're in a race against time. That leadership is critical and it can't wait four years or eight years. It can't wait any longer than November.
We're going to make that change for the earth's environment and for the people of this country. The Republican Administration has been trying to divide us for too long. They claim to be pro-family, but when we pass legislation for the people of this country which gives mothers and fathers a chance to have a little time off from work when a child is seriously injured, or when a child is first born, the Bush-Quayle Administration vetoes it because they're afraid that it's going to cost money to the wealthy and powerful in this country.

 	 	 		. . .	 	When the Democratic Congress passes an idea that Bill Clinton advanced, to give a tax credit for working families with children, to make it possible for families to stay together, for families to be able to give their children the kind of upbringing that they need, the Bush-Quayle Administration vetoes that legislation and still tries to describe itself as pro-family.

 	 	 		. . .	 	I come from Carthage, Tenn. I've never been to Hope, Ark. But I'm told that it's just like Carthage in one respect: it's a place where people know about it when you're born and care about it when you die.
That's the America Bill Clinton and I grew up in, and when we elect Bill Clinton President, that's the kind of nation we will once again become.

HEADLINE: Convention Costs Keep Going Up and Away

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
Three days before the Democratic National Convention opens, the costly reality of putting on a show in New York City has sunk in.
The bid for blowing up the balloons that will be dropped from the ceiling in Madison Square Garden was $30,000 -- 50 cents a balloon -- so the Democrats recruited 50 volunteers to get the job done for nothing. 
 New York Telephone is demanding an advance payment of $600 for each telephone line it installs at the Garden, more than twice the price being charged in Houston, where the Republicans will hold their convention next month.
 
Expensive Cable>
 Estimates for the cost of laying cable for the radio and television networks that have to broadcast from an office building across from the Garden range from $2 a foot to $5 a foot. In Houston, the cost is 20 cents a foot.
To the Democrats, the convention is an all-out show for the media, but many in the media are grumbling.
Upset by unforseen costs and the Garden's complicated work rules, which delayed the installation of equipment, some Democratic officials are worried that logistics, not post-prime-time speechmaking or backroom politicking, will alienate producers and correspondents who should be pampered. The Democrats' concern is that behind-the-scene snafus will keep the party from taking advantage of the convention as a weeklong showcase, a coast-to-coast chance to spread their message -- and get on television -- without having to spend money for the exposure.
Already, the convention is exacting a price in psychic energy. Caffeine and long nights have become a staple for broadcast technicians and their bosses even before the opening gavel on Monday. In part this reflects the new realities of broadcasting: satellite technology has made it possible for local stations to send correspondents to national events like conventions. That means more hookups, and potentially more confusion, than in the days when conventions were the virtually exclusive province of only three networks.
"It's the unions," said one television producer for a group of stations who insisted on anonymity, adding that she was worried that angry technicians might snip a cable and cripple her operation if she was quoted by name. "This isn't Eugene V. Debs organizing garment workers in the 1930's. This is big business. These are people making good money, looking for a lot more."
Producers say some of their headaches at the Garden involve questions about union jurisdictions. There were meetings about whether the Garden's electricians could pull cables from the Garden across 33d Street. The answer was no. Other electricians had to be called in.
Some producers also said they had been given stratospheric estimates for the work they needed done. One television producer said the quote for labor on a cable-laying job was $49,000. After some bargaining, the figure was reduced to $6,000.
 
That New York Attitude
 But not all the complaints have to do with work rules and jurisdictions. In the temporary newsrooms set up near the Garden, budget-conscious network officials are complaining about being charged $3 a square foot for space. In Houston, they say, they will be given work inside the Astrodome at no charge.
"Just to have the freight moved in cost a couple of thousand," said Norb Gallery, the election technical director for National Public Radio, referring to trunks filled with tape decks, amplifiers and computers that were shipped from Washington.
The age-old New York attitude -- "You want the job done? It's going to cost you" -- has been compounded by a recession that has hit the construction trades especially hard, making construction companies and the craftsmen who work for them unusually eager for work. Even though they have a long history as the party of organized labor, the Democrats came to town hoping for a break.
"We expected more assistance" in making deals that did not bust budgets, said one Democratic official who spoke on condition of anonymity. "Part of it is City Hall is unwilling or unable to exert pressure to make things happen."
 
17 Unions Involved
 High-ranking city officials worked last week to settle the dispute over electricity to television trailers parked outside the Garden. But some of the snags are tied to the sheer complexity of the Garden as a convention site. The Garden has contracts with 17 unions, from stagehands to projectionists, although fewer than 10 are involved in this event.
"Sometimes because things seem to be confusing -- who takes a cable from point A to point B and from point B to point C -- that gets exaggerated to a general problem, which is not the case," said Robert Russo, the Garden's senior vice-president and general manager. "Things cost, but not just here."
Mr. Russo defended the way the work had been managed, particularly the Garden's efforts to hold down overtime. "We've oversupervised, probably," Mr. Russo said. "We've been supervising it and the city is supervising it and the D.N.C.C. is on site, to keep the hours down." The D.N.C.C. is the Democratic National Convention Committee.
With or without overtime, some producers are worried about an uncertain bottom line. "We haven't a clue" about the cost of cable, said Ray Conover, the vice president and director of engineering for Conus, a national news cooperative based in Minneapolis. "It's changed every day since we've been here."
As for telephones, New York Telephone says part of the $600 advance payment covers the regular business installation rate, $150 a line. But the company is adding a one-time special-event charge of $207 a line, $9 less than the comparable charge for the 1980 convention. The rest goes toward the calls made.
"It's expensive to put in, then take it all out four days later," said Steven Marcus, a New York Telephone spokesman.
Some media executives came to the same conclusion and decided to set up shop elsewhere. Congressional Quarterly, which is publishing a daily newspaper for delegates in with International Medial Partners Inc., rented a room in the Hotel Macklowe on West 44th Street after estimates for its costs at the Garden came in.
"I think there was a certain price gamesmanship going on" at the Garden, said Robert W. Merry, the executive editor. "I didn't want to play."

A sunbather was oblivious to workers who put up scaffolding at the rear of the New York Public Library. (Adam Fernandez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Plant Expansion Project Near Swamp Is Criticized

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHATHAM, N.J., July 6

 BODY:
Morris County conservationists are calling it the Second Battle of the Great Swamp, and as with so many sequels, the issues are not as clear cut as they were the first time around.
The fight, specifically, is over a request by the Township of Chatham to upgrade the capacity of its sewage-treatment plant, a move that would allow a developer to build a million square feet of prime office space, which would in turn generate millions of tax dollars for the township and school district. Opponents of the plan say it would pour unmanageable amounts of water into the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge, 8,000 acres of burbling, chirping and croaking nature less than 20 miles from the unnatural chaos of Manhattan. 
 More broadly, the fight represents the new reality of the old tussle between development and conservation in suburbia. Instead of the sweep of earlier fights like the one over a Port Authority plan to build a new international airport where the swamp was located, or the plan to flood the Delaware Water Gap with a dam at Tocks Island, or the proposal to build an airport for Philadelphia in the New Jersey Pine Barrens, many of today's environmental battles tend instead to be drawn out arguments over fractions of an inch of this, or so many parts per million of that.
"In a sense, we've settled a lot of the big issues," said John Weingart, assistant commissioner for environmental regulation for the Department of Environmental Protection and Energy and the man to whom the issue may come for a final administrative decision. "Now when we have debates over the environment versus the economy, people say it's a stupid question -- of course we have to protect the environment. But we still have to decide where we draw the line."
Chatham Township has already spent $7 million to upgrade its sewage treatment plant and to enlarge its capacity by 33 percent, from 750,000 gallons per day to 1 million gallons per day. Now it is seeking permission of the Department of Environmental Protection to use the extra capacity, which will be the subject of a hearing July 23 in Chatham. A decision will not come before the end of September.
 
More Dollars or More Water?
 If the township wins approval to use the capacity, the Prudential Life Insurance Company will proceed with its plans to expand its big Giralda Farms office campus development from adjoining Madison Township into Chatham Township. And it will pay the township $4 million toward the cost of expanding the plant and $2.5 million to help the township meet state requirements to provide affordable housing.
But a rising groundwater-table level in the Great Swamp is already forcing people who live nearby to build septic systems above ground, under odd-looking mounds the size of tennis courts. And opponents of the township's plan maintain that putting more water into the swamp and more traffic on the surrounding roads would make things worse.
"The Great Swamp is like a giant bathtub that can only let so much water out at the end," said Helen Fenske, until two years ago the deputy commissioner for natural resources at the Environmental Protection Department and, as a resident of Green Village, at the edge of the swamp in Chatham Township, a leader of the opposition.
"So where does it go?" she said. "It goes into my basement, it's where my husband can't garden any more, it's in my neighbor's septic system that doesn't work any more."
Prudential says the added water flow into the Great Swamp would amount to less than one-half of 1 percent of the annual flow, and elaborate measures would be taken to keep runoff from roofs and roadways from polluting the wetlands.
 
Issue Less Clear Cut
 It took Morris County residents just two years to win the first Battle of the Great Swamp, when they routed the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which wanted to pave over the wilderness, along with several hundred houses, for a new international airport. The fight over Chatham's sewage-treatment-plant expansion has been going on for at least four years, with studies, commission meetings, hearings and yet more studies, the most recent of which concluded that, to determine the impact of the sewage-plant expansion on the swamp, another study was needed.
Defenders of the development plan maintain that the environmentalists are disappointed that no clear-cut environmental threat to the Great Swamp could be pinpointed in a study that was released in January by the Great Swamp Watershed Advisory Committee, a 30-member panel set up by the Department of Environmental Protection.
"We do not want to antagonize the D.E.P. or anyone else, but to date we have not been able to see any adverse results from this plan," said Ken Hetrick, the Chatham township manager, who represents his town on the advisory committee. "People will say there would be adverse effects, but they are so minor that we don't really think they are valid."
Opponents like Mrs. Fenske concede that there was no clear-cut harmful impact that could be identified in any of the studies, but they insist that the degradation of natural spaces occurs in small increments as well as by major disruptions. For example, few of the houses in the surrounding townships are connected to sewers, said Sally Dudley, a Harding Township Committee member and a leader in the state environmental movement. With more and more septic systems leaching into the groundwater, the addition of a new source of water, even when treated to the right cleanliness, only adds to the swamp's rising waters, she said.
 
Little Bit May Mean Much
 Added car traffic from the Prudential development would mean dirtier runoff from more crowded streets and more air contamination to settle on the soupy waters of the swamp, opponents say. The tributary streams to the swamp are weed-choked where they used to be free running, and the swamp itself is increasingly clogged with growth from nutrients washed in from fertilized lawns and from treated sewer water.
So Mrs. Fenske bristles when she is asked if the fight is not, after all, just about keeping newcomers out of a tranquil, upscale enclave.
"That question really disturbs me," she replied. "I really care about the public land, and the question is, do we protect it for us and for our children, or do we just protect it by itself, and say anything goes in the area around it?"

HEADLINE: New Unemployment Claims Drop for 2d Straight Week

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits shrank by 4,000 in late June, the Government said today. It was the second straight weekly decline.
"It's consistent with other data that the economy has lost some of its earlier momentum, but keeps moving higher," said Robert G. Dederick, an economist with the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. 
 The number of first-time applications for jobless benefits totaled 416,000 during the week that ended on June 27, down from 420,000 a week earlier, the Labor Department reported.
After ranging in the 450,000 level during the winter, new claims for unemployment benefits dropped below 410,000 for much of the spring before jumping to 421,000 during the week of June 13.
 
Four-Week Average Climbs
 But despite the back-to-back declines in the two weeks that followed, the four-week moving average of new claims climbed to 415,750 during the period that ended on June 27, up from 414,000 a week earlier and the highest since it reached 427,250 during the period that ended on April 11.
Because of the volatility of the weekly applications, analysts often prefer to track the four-week average to discern trends.
Still, Mr. Dederick said, the back-to-back drops in weekly claims were more "consistent with small gains in nonfarm payrolls" than with the June unemployment report.
The department reported last week that the unemployment rate in June had jumped to 7.8 percent, from 7.5 percent the month before. The June figure was the highest monthly rate in eight years.
Most economists expect little job creation until there is noticeable improvement in the economy. Until then, employers are expected to rely on overtime to meet any increase in demand, rather than hire new workers.
The largest increases in benefit claims were recorded in Massachusetts, up 5,084; New Jersey, 2,917; New York, 2,500; Virginia, 1,650, and Michigan, 1,512.
The largest drops were reported by North Carolina, down 3,300; Pennsylvania, 2,952; Minnesota, 2,151; Texas, 1,452, and Wisconsin, 1,417.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies, but Many Discount Technical Gains

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday in an active, technically driven rally. But many traders said they expected the gains to be short-lived.
The dollar rallied early in the day after the French Economics Minister, Michel Sapin, said France and the United States had agreed that the dollar had fallen far enough. 
 The dollar kept its strength despite reports that members of Germany's Bundesbank were comfortable with the German mark's rise in value.
Scott Cozzens, treasury officer for Chemical Bank's foreign exchange unit, said the German and French comments forced traders who had bet on a dollar decline to buy dollars to cover their losses. That had the technical effect of raising the dollar's value even more.
Earl Johnson, vice president at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, said the technical rally did not mask the fundamental problems facing the dollar. It is burdened by a weak United States economy, an uncertain Presidential race, and unfavorable comparisons with higher interest rates in other countries, Mr. Johnson said.
"As far as I'm concerned, the sentiment still is very bearish for the dollar," Mr. Johnson said.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 124.57 Japanese yen, from 124 yen at Wednesday's close. Later in London, it rose to 125.65 yen. At closing in New York, the dollar fetched 125.60 yen, up from 124.70 yen late Wednesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.8960, from $1.9190 late Wednesday. At closing in New York, sterling fetched $1.9000, less expensive than $1.9300 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday rates, included: 1.5130 marks, up from 1.4885; 1.3670 Swiss francs, up from 1.3415; 5.1035 French francs, up from 5.0160; 1,144.00 Italian lire, up from 1,124.25, and 1.19125 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19155.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.5165 marks, up from 1.4965; 1.3720 Swiss francs, up from 1.3475; 5.1130 French francs, up from 5.0412; 1.7095 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6865; 1,147.25 Italian lire, up from 1,130, and 1.1933 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1912.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Rises as Uncertainty Over Currencies Continues

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Gold prices rose yesterday as the wild fluctuations of foreign exchange markets highlighted gold's role as a safe haven in times of uncertainties.
On New York's Commodity Exchange, August gold ended up $1.00 at $349.40 an ounce, near the session's high of $349.50. 
 "I think gold is supported by general concerns over the choppiness of foreign exchange trade," said William O'Neill at Merrill Lynch.
Foreign exchange trading has been chaotic in the last week, with the dollar tumbling to a 17-month low against the German mark after Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said Washington was not worried about its falling currency.
 
Silver in Technical Rebound
 Silver rose in a technical rebound from Tuesday's free fall on reports that Saudi Arabia's National Commercial Bank had sold millions of ounces of silver.
The sale of silver, which traders estimated at 6 million to 20 million ounces, drove July silver on the Commodity Exchange to $3.873 an ounce on Tuesday, its lowest since December. The July contract ended at $3.926 an ounce, up 4.3 cents from Wednesday's close.
"It appears to have been a one-time sale, and people are relieved that the market was able to absorb it all," said George Nickas at Geldermann Inc.
He said traders were still uneasy about the outlook for silver.
"The value-minded traders who usually buy after big price falls aren't convinced that the selloff in silver has leveled off," Mr. Nickas said.
Analysts said the market reflected uncertainty about the economy. Silver is widely used by the electrical and photographic industries, and a weak recovery from the recession could cripple demand.
Some analysts expect silver to return soon to $4 an ounce, a former psychological level.
Oil prices finished mixed.
Light sweet crude for delivery in August settled at $21.40 a barrel, down 1 cent from Wednesday, at the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices for delivery in later months were slightly higher.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, soybeans fell on reports that growing conditions may be ideal for the crop. Weather forecasts called for rain this weekend in the Midwest growing states, which would benefit the maturing soybean crop, trade sources said.
July soybeans closed 5 cents lower at $5.6975 a bushel.
