HEADLINE: Eric Sevareid, 79, Is Dead; Commentator and Reporter

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:
Eric Sevareid, a radio and television correspondent who became one of the country's most respected reporters and commentators, died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 79 years old.
He died of stomach cancer, said a spokesman for CBS. 
 Mr. Sevareid, who was recruited as a CBS News correspondent by Edward R. Murrow when both men were covering the outbreak of war in Europe in 1939, wrote elegant commentaries that he delivered in grave and sonorous tones, even when he was being caustically witty. Like Mr. Murrow, Mr. Sevareid was tall with rugged good looks that served him well during the transition from radio to television.
His writing ability and experience, combined with an ability to project a sense of fairness and sound judgment, brought him the respect of his peers and audiences, allowed Mr. Sevareid the right to introduce analysis and even opinion into his broadcasts. Among his colleagues, he was considered a journalist above the daily battle for news who had a scholarly mien and a knowledge of the American past to his choice of words.
Mr. Sevareid took outspoken positions in favor of civil and constitutional rights on the air and in writing. During the Vietnam War, Mr. Sevareid traveled to South Vietnam in 1966 and, in a special broadcast, clearly indicated that prolonging the war was unwise and that a negotiated peace was desirable.
In his long career, he worked in several European and South American countries and in Washington and New York. He became nationally known for breaking through the strictures of straight-news reporting by pioneering editorial analysis on prime-time television.
Mr. Sevareid defined himself as a cultural conservative and a political liberal. "I find myself politically liberal on domestic affairs and increasingly conservative on foreign affairs," he wrote in 1964 in the introduction to his book "This Is Eric Sevareid." He worried a good deal about America's sense of direction. "The hour may be too late for a high civilization," he said. "We are frightened to think that the very rich grow richer, the very poor poorer, the dark-skinned more violent, our cities simultaneously more crowded and more desolate, our countryside more ugly."
His was an adventurous life, which included a harrowing month among headhunters in the Burmese jungles. That was in 1943, after the plane in which he was riding developed engine trouble as it was flying over the Himalayas from India to China. Mr. Sevareid and 19 others had to bail out on the India-Burma border but made it out of the jungle on foot.
 
Saw Himself as a Writer
 Even at the height of his fame as a television correspondent, when his appearance and stature drew movie offers and invitations to do lucrative commercials -- which he declined -- Mr. Sevareid told friends that he always considered himself primarily a writer, not a performer. He wrote dozens of magazine articles, a syndicated newspaper column and half a dozen books.
"This is the age of the journalist more than the age of the artist, the teacher or the pastor," he once said. "It is the age of nonfiction because imagination cannot keep up with the fantastic daily realities."
Mr. Severeid's best-known book, "Not So Wild a Dream," was first published in 1946 after his years of war reporting. The autobiography covered his boyhood in the Dakotas, journey by canoe through Canada to Hudson Bay, wanderings among hoboes, apprenticeship as a newspaper reporter in Minneapolis and his adventures in wartime. He never forgot witnessing the terror of Nazism and anti-Semitism in Germany. The book went through 11 printings over the next 28 years and became a reference book for historians and other students of the Depression and war years.
 
'The Concept of Citizen'
 "It was a lucky stroke of timing to have been born and to have lived as an American in this last generation," he wrote in 1976 for a new edition of the book. "It was good fortune to be a journalist in Washington, now the greatest single news headquarters in the world since ancient Rome. But we are not Rome; the world is too big, too varied. The 'American Century' concept of Henry Luce was an absurdity, too. We were not born to be imperialists; we never learned the style, and the time for this is gone. We understand the concept of citizen, not that of subject."
As an essayist who used journalism as the springboard for his idealism, he wrote: "Travels in all the continents have not lessened my love and respect for America, but deepened both, in spite of the distressing spread of our vulgarities. There is a civilization of the heart, too, and the goodness in Americans, the evangelical strain, has not disappeared. We have often been innocents abroad and at time have done unintended harm, but no other great power has the confidence and stability to expose and face its own blunders. We are a turbulent society but a stable republic."
Arnold Eric Sevareid was born to parents of Norwegian heritage on Nov. 26, 1912, in Velva, N.D. He spent his first years on the prairie wheatlands, but when drought struck in the 1920's, the family moved to Minneapolis.
After graduating from Minneapolis Central High School in 1930, he and a friend embarked on a 2,200-mile canoe trip from Minneapolis to Hudson Bay, to prove that it was possible to make such a trip through the continent's heartland entirely by water. He used his experiences as the basis for his first book, "Canoeing With the Cree" (1935).
At the age of 18, Mr. Sevareid worked as a copy boy and reporter for The Minneapolis Journal while attending the University of Minnesota. After being laid off from his reporting job in 1936, he and his first wife, the former Lois Finger, sailed for Europe. He studied political science at the London School of Economics, then attended the Alliance Francaise in Paris.
 
Europe During World War II
 In 1938, he was hired by the Paris edition of The New York Herald Tribune and soon became its night city editor. At the same time, he worked in the Paris bureau of United Press, the wire service.
In August 1939, only weeks before the outbreak of World War II, Mr. Murrow called him from London and asked if he wanted to try radio reporting. "I don't know very much about your experience," Mr. Murrow said, "but I like the way you write and I like your ideas."
Thus, Mr. Sevareid became one of "Murrow's Boys," who would enable CBS to dominate radio news for many years. He joined a group of former newspapermen turned CBS correspondents that was to include William L. Shirer, Charles Collingwood, Alexander Kendrick, Howard K. Smith, David Schoenbrun, Daniel Schorr and Richard C. Hottelet.
 
Last to Broadcast From Paris
 Mr. Sevareid covered the French Army and Air Force in Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, and he was the last American to broadcast from Paris. He fled the city with his wife and their infant sons just before the Nazis marched in. At Bordeaux, he broadcast the news that France was about to surrender. Then Mr. Sevareid joined Mr. Murrow in London for broadcasts during the Battle of Britain bombing raids.
Assigned to the CBS Washington bureau after his return to the United States in late 1940, Mr. Sevareid covered President Franklin D. Roosevelt and the war effort. Feeling restive at home while the war was still on, however, he headed for the China-Burma-India theater in 1943.
Back in Europe in 1944, Mr. Sevareid covered the campaign in Italy and Marshal Tito's partisans in Yugoslavia, landed with the first wave of Americans in southern France and accompanied them across the Rhine into Germany.
His postwar assignments included Washington, France, Germany and Britain. In 1964, he became a roving correspondent based in Washington; his commentaries were regularly featured on the "CBS Evening News With Walter Cronkite" until 1977, when Mr. Sevareid reached the company's mandatory retirement age of 65. His last appearance on a CBS News program was in "Remember Pearl Harbor," which was broadcast on Dec. 7, 1991.
 
'Passion and Beauty'
 Walter Cronkite recently commented that he regarded Mr. Sevareid as "a master of the extemporaneous essay," citing Mr. Sevareid's performance when he first covered a space flight. "I remember that he was skeptical of manned space flights until he witnessed his first moon launching," Mr. Cronkite said. "Then he turned to the camera as the rocket disappeared into the stratosphere and delivered a totally spontaneous tribute to the astronauts and the technical successes on which they rode, a tribute that was a lovely ode of passion and beauty."
Charles Kuralt, the anchor of "Sunday Morning" on CBS, said: "Eric was the best thinker and writer who ever sat down to a microphone. He was the one giant tree in the forest. He stood alone."
Mr. Sevareid's books included "In One Ear" (1952) and "Small Sounds in the Night" (1956), which are collections of his magazine and newspaper articles and CBS broadcasts. He once wrote of himself: "I am cursed with a somewhat forbidding Scandinavian manner, with a restraint that spells stuffiness to a lot of people. But . . . inside I am mush, full of a lot of almost bathetic sentimentality about this country, the Midwest, Abraham Lincoln and the English language."
 
Article Cited for Its 'Terrific Impact'
 He had a long conversation with Adlai E. Stevenson, the United Nations Ambassador, two days before Mr. Stevenson's death in July 1965. An article based on that conversation, which was published in the Nov. 30, 1965, issue of Look magazine, won the New York Newspaper Guild's Page One Award, citing Mr. Sevareid's "excellent writing" and the piece's "terrific impact on the United States and the world."
In retirement, at his home in Washington or at his weekend cabin in the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia, Mr. Sevareid wrote, read and fished.
He is survived by his wife, Suzanne St. Pierre, a former producer for the CBS News broadcast "60 Minutes"; three children from two previous marriages, which ended in divorce, and six grandchildren. His two sons, Peter, of Swarthmore, Pa., and Michael, of Mount Joy, Pa., were born during his first marriage to the former Miss Finger, and his daughter, Cristina Kennedy, of Frederick, Md., was born during his second marriage, to Belen Marshall. Services will be private and a memorial is being planned in September in Washington.

HEADLINE: TVWeekend;
Examining the Appeal Of David Duke's Oratory

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
"Backlash: Race and the American Dream" was evidently made while David Duke, the Louisiana politician best known as a former leader of the Ku Klux Klan, still seemed to be a formidable figure in the 1992 Presidential campaign. But even after the collapse of his candidacy, concern over his appeal lingers. So tonight's hourlong documentary is by no means out of date.
Clips from speeches and interviews show that Mr. Duke has tidied up his prose since the days when he wore the sheet and peddled Nazi pamphlets. But you don't have to be a historian to detect the nativist strains meant to incite white working-class Americans who have been hurt by the recession. 
 The Duke supporters interviewed here deny hating any group and direct their animus instead at Government programs, especially affirmative action. Workers on an oil rig tell of experienced whites losing jobs or promotions to untried blacks. An us-versus-them spirit predominates. "What more can we do for them?" is the refrain.
The program, made in Louisiana, comes together well, without the glue of narration. Pictures of cross-burnings and clips of Southern politicians of the 1950's in the throes of segregationist rodomontade establish Mr. Duke's roots. The only distraction here is a musical accompaniment that goes in for exclamatory clangs to punctuate racist statements.
Mr. Duke's support is said to be mainly among younger whites with incomes of $15,000 to $35,000 a year who are having trouble getting by. One of the historians on hand notes that such feelings of being kept down by what a Duke supporter calls "the unseen enemy" have in the past been directed against both the rich and the poor. This time, he adds, "The have-littles are turning on the have-nots." All present agree that the plausible-sounding Mr. Duke is focusing the free-flowing anger onto the black poor, whom he portrays as criminals and incorrigibly idle producers of illegitimate children.
His admirers seem to be longing for a return to what their man calls "traditional American western Christian values." Slogans of "white pride" are heard. As the historians note, the phenomenon is far from new, but these days those who would probably have been part of the white supremacy mobs 40 years ago tend to say, as one does tonight, "I hope I don't sound like a racist." And that must be accounted a sort of progress after all.
 
'National Audubon Society Specials'
PBS, Tuesdays at 9 P.M.
(Channel 13, New York, Saturdays at 7 P.M.)
The subjects of the Audubon Society's eight-program summer series are familiar; indeed, several of the documentaries have already been shown either on public television or on cable. But the hosts are even more familiar: Jane Fonda, Robert Redford, James Earl Jones, Michael Douglas and other actors.
Tomorrow night you can see Ms. Fonda express her concern for what is being done to "Mysterious Elephants of the Congo" by African ivory poachers and American consumers. In two weeks she will express her concern about environmental problems in the Great Plains. Also coming up: Mr. Jones and the Great Lakes, Mr. Douglas and the dolphin, Mr. Redford and the grizzly bear. The smog of virtue can become a little thick, but the photography is as sharp as ever.
 
'Brit Coms'
Channel 21, New York, Fridays at 8 P.M.
Fans of British sitcoms are herewith alerted to the weekly assortment strung together by Long Island's public station. Hilarity does not reign steadily through the evening -- it's more like an occasional shower -- but the English-style nuttiness can be engaging even when the shows are as dumb as any domestic product.
For viewers like me, with a weakness for music-hall madness, the funniest of them is "The Black Adder II," with Rowland Atkinson as the nastiest nobleman in the court of Queen Elizabeth I; the characters are dim, the punch lines are broad and low, the spirit is implacably irreverent. For more sedate tastes, Penelope Keith and Peter Bowles, who made a hit out of "To the Manor Born," are together again as a married team of book publishers in "Executive Stress"; no socko gags here, just the pleasure of seeing pros at work in a fairly sensible setting. And, in the interests of Anglo-American inanity, Anne Bancroft shows up as a transplanted American actress in "Freddie and Max." She seems to be having a jolly time.
 
'The Firing Line'
PBS
(Channel 13, New York, Saturdays at 10 A.M.)
William Buckley addresses the questions "Reunification in Korea: Is It Possible? Is It Probable?" in tomorrow's segment of a four-part series about that troublesome land. Kicking them around with him is Kim Kyung-Won, a former Ambassador to Washington from South Korea, who is not optimistic about any opening up of North Korea. In August Mr. Buckley moves on to Taiwan.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

A Rembrandt Leads
The priciest painting in this summer's round of Impressionist, modern, contemporary and Old Master sales in London may be Rembrandt's "Portrait of Johannes Uytten bogaert," which was sold at Sotheby's on Wednesday for $7.94 million to Alfred Bader, a collector from Milwaukee.
That an Old Master painting fetched significantly more than any Impressionist work is not surprising these days. In fact, compared with Canaletto's "Old Horse Guards, London, From St. James's Park," which was sold at Christie's in April to the composer Sir Andrew Lloyd Webber for $17.7 million, and Titian's "Venus and Adonis," which fetched $13.4 million at Christie's in London in December, the sum is quite small. Nonetheless, it exceeded Sotheby's $5 million estimate. "We were very happy," said Julian Stock, who heads Sotheby's Old Masters department in London. The painting belonged to the Earl of Rosebery, whose family had owned it since the 1860's. 
 "It's the same old story," Mr. Stock added. "When works are fresh to the market, they do well. It's the things that have been at auction over the last 10 years that don't sell."
The day's sale totaled $16.5 million, far below Sotheby's estimate of $21 million to $30 million. The big disappointment was that Guido Reni's "David With the Head of Goliath," which the auction house had expected would bring $3.8 million to $5.7 million, failed to sell. Christie's Old Masters sale in London takes place today.
The London sales of Impressionist and modern art at both Sotheby's and Christie's had no spectacular moments. Both sales fared worse than the auction houses had hoped. "It was a difficult season to persuade people to sell," said David Nash, the head of the department of Impressionist and modern art at Sotheby's.
Sotheby's sale on June 30 totaled $12.4 million, well below the auction house estimate of $24 million to $31 million. Christie's sale the day before totaled $15 million; the auction house had estimated it would bring $18.9 million to $26.4 million. Surprisingly, given the recent economic troubles in the Far East, particularly in Japan,Asian collectors bought the most expensive paintings in both sales. At Christie's, Asians purchased Monet's "Charing Cross Bridge, La Tamise" for $4 million, Chagall's "Grand Parade" for $1.9 million and Cezanne's "Bathers," a study for the "Grand Bathers" in the Philadelphia Museum of Art, for $1.4 million. At Sotheby's, van Gogh's "Still Life With Almond Branch" was sold to a Japanese buyer for $2.5 million. It was the most expensive work in the sale. "It just proves that contrary to popular belief, there is still Asian money for good things," said Michael Findlay, who heads Christie's department of Impressionist and modern art in London.
Experts at both auction houses agree that the overall mood of the sales was selective, with many of the same collectors who bought in New York in May bidding for the few high-quality works. "Prices of the top things are half of what they were at the height of the market," Mr. Findlay said. "But if priced properly, they will sell."
While the numbers weren't as high, the mood at the contemporary sales was far more upbeat. "There is more excitement in this field, in part because the price levels are more affordable," Mr. Nash said. Sotheby's sale on July 2 totaled $5.4 million, well below its estimate of $8 million to $11 million. The highest-priced work was Lucio Fontana's "End of God," which was sold to an anonymous buyer for $606,100. Christie's sale totaled $7.5 million, right on its high estimate.
Christie's fared better because about a third of the sale was the property of the Swedish collector Fredrik Roos, who died in May 1991. (A large part of the Roos estate, which featured artists who made their reputations in the 1980's, had been sold at Christie's in New York in May.) Not part of the Roos estate, but also a big draw at the London sale, were seven works by the Belgian Surrealist Marcel Broodthaers. Four out of the five most expensive paintings in the sale were by Broodthaers. The most expensive in the sale, Broodthaers's "White Armoire and White Table," was bought by the London dealers Berggruen & Zevi for $752,004.
Martha Baer, director of 20th-century fine art at Christie's in New York, said, "A concentration of works, whether it be by artists who made it in the 80's or artists like Marcel Broodthaers, whose work rarely comes up at auctions, triggered the excitement." So did the fact that all the contemporary works offered at either auction house were well under $1 million.
 
Suing to Tour
 It looks as if the trustees of the Barnes Foundation in Merion, Pa., are about to win a major battle in their struggle to break the restrictions established by Dr. Albert C. Barnes, the founder of the 70-year-old institution. Barnes prohibited works in the renowned collection from leaving the institution. But last week, in the Montgomery County Orphans' Court, Judge Louis D. Stefan concluded three days of hearings on whether the foundation can send about 90 of its paintings, including works by Renoir, Degas, Monet and Cezanne, on tour.
"The Attorney General has no objection to the exhibition," said Judge Stefan, who added that he expected to announce his decision next week. If he approves the plan, it will be a major step in the trustees' attempt to open up the famously reclusive institution.
The proposed exhibition is yet another cause of dissension between the Barnes trustees and the De Mazia Trust. The trust, created by Violette De Mazia, a protegee and companion of Barnes's, who was vice president of the institution and its education director, is suing the foundation, contending it is violating its charter. The exhibition is also opposed by Friends of the Barnes Foundation, a group of former students, employees and local residents who contend that some of the paintings are far too fragile to withstand the rigors of an international tour.
The show is to open at the National Gallery of Art in Washington next spring, then move to the Musee d'Orsay in Paris, the Museum of Western Art in Tokyo and the Philadelphia Museum of Art.
"There has been no final decision about which paintings will go abroad," Judge Stefan said. "Experts from the National Endowment for the Arts testified that if properly crated, the paintings would not be damaged. But if there is any danger that some of them are too fragile to travel, they simply will not be sent."
James Beam, the lawyer for the De Mazia Trust, said there were still many unanswered questions about the particulars of the tour. "The board of trustees have testified about generalities, saying everything will be fine," Mr. Beam said. "But the stakes are so high in allowing this priceless collection to travel we think it's crucial that the court have specifics before making its decision. Neither the French nor the Japanese have drawn up contracts detailing the exhibition, spelling out everything from dollars and security to insurance."
Richard H. Glanton, the president of the Barnes Foundation, said: "This is false. Yes, there are contracts from both the French and the Japanese. It was discussed as a matter of record in court. The De Mazia Trust is trying to sabotage our exhibition."
Mr. Glanton estimates that the show would make at least $7 million for the foundation. "But with the catalogues and books, it could be substantially more," he said. The proceeds would go toward modernizing the Barnes Foundation's building. During the tour, the museum, built in 1926, would close for renovations.
Another museum interested in the Barnes Foundation's holdings, particularly the prized works by Matisse, is the Museum of Modern Art, whose Matisse retrospective is to open this fall. "I'm not saying they haven't approached us," Mr. Glanton said. "But I have not had any discussions with them."
Asked if the Barnes would consider lending works to the show, Mr. Glanton declined to comment.
 
A Sudden Vacancy
 Robert Stearns, the director of the Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio, abruptly resigned last week. Insiders say Mr. Stearns was forced out of the Wexner, an avant-garde center for performing and visual arts at Ohio State University, by members of the center's board and by the staff.
"There were lots of personality clashes," Mr. Stearns admitted. "The job had become more about management than about art. The Wexner Center is a difficult place. There are a lot of different agendas. And being part of a university makes it especially complex."
Mr. Stearns had directed the Wexner Center since 1989, the year the $43 million highly abstract building by the New York architect Peter Eisenman opened.
Until a successor is named, William Cooke, who was the center's associate director, will be the acting director. Adrienne Bosworth, the center's director of communication, said that a search committee was being formed and that the center hoped to have a new director in place by the fall. Meanwhile, Mr. Stearns said he would pursue freelance curatorial work.

HEADLINE: Festival Featuring Hip-Hop Dancing

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
When the hip-hop choreographer Jamale Graves brings his troupe of dancers to the stage of Alice Tully Hall tomorrow night as part of Lincoln Center's Serious Fun festival, it will be a turning point in the evolution of urban street dance. Break dancing, a genre that is struggling for respectability after having nearly been exploited to death as a commercial fad, is being officially blessed by Lincoln Center, which has commissioned Mr. Graves's newest work.
Sharing the bill with his dancers on a program titled "Mo' Moves," are the Rhythm Technicians and Rock Steady Crew, two groups of young hip-hop dancers that joined forces last year to put on a musical, "So! What Happens Now," which won favorable notice when it was performed at Performance Space 122 in the East Village. 
 Two of Mr. Graves's new pieces -- "The Yard" and "Tech No Love" -- directly deal with the genre's struggle for artistic recognition.
 
'West Side Story,' Updated
 " 'The Yard' takes place in a schoolyard with two groups of kids dancing for control of the space," Mr. Graves said last week. "It's kind of like Jerome Robbins's 'West Side Story,' but with hip-hop. In 'Tech No Love,' competing groups of dancers, one classical, the other raw and street-oriented, fall in admiration of each other and decide they have a mutual love for dance."
The Rhythm Technicians and Rock Steady Crew will introduce a new work called "Concrete Jungle," which compares hip-hop dance movement to African and West Indian tribal rituals.
"The piece shows the relationship between the ghetto jungle and to the jungles of yesteryear back in Africa and their relationship to break dancing," said Richard (Crazy Legs) Colon, of Rock Steady Crew, last week. "It's a dance with a lot of expression that shows we're still in the jungle, except that it's not trees we're dealing with but buildings. The piece is political in that it deals with police brutality."
The arrival of black and Hispanic street dance on the stage of Lincoln Center is the latest sign of Lincoln Center's interest in producing and showcasing work that is not predominantly European-oriented.
"When we launched Serious Fun and Classical Jazz in 1987, one of our principal purposes was to open our curtains and stages to people who had not been represented before," said Nathan Leventhal, the president of Lincoln Center. "This is a natural step in that process."
 
Budget Exceeds $1 Million
 Mr. Leventhal also said that this year's Serious Fun festival, which opened on Tuesday evening with the director Robert Wilson's interpretation of Gertrude Stein's "Dr. Faustus Lights the Lights," was the most ambitious yet. For the first time, the budget for the series, which extends through July 30, exceeds $1 million, with most of that money provided by Philip Morris.
Serious Fun's commitment to the cutting edge of black culture will continue a week from tomorrow with "49 Blues Songs for a Jealous Vampire," a specially commissioned evening-length work by the Los Angeles-based poet and performance artist Keith Antar Mason. "Blues Songs," will be performed by six members of the Hittite Empire, a performance collective that formed in St. Louis in 1979 and settled in the Los Angeles area in 1985.
Mr. Mason described the collective, which has 10 to 15 members, as an "all-black male, indigenous, politically correct cultural elite who are redefining, reshaping and struggling to continue the struggle of our forefathers."
The title of the piece comes, he said, "from my grandfather's telling me when I was kid that if you sang 49 blues songs the vampire wouldn't get you."
"It's a contemporary ritual set in an interrogation room that deals with an oppressive authority nibbling away at your identity bit by bit," he said. "It uses a jazz esthetic, but brings it all the way to hip-hop. The piece is filled with Afro-centric cultural references that black people will get while everyone else will not know what I'm talking about. I'm concerned about the festival's effectively reaching to get an African-American audience to see it."
 
On the Avant-Garde
 For Mr. Mason, the work belongs squarely within the avant-garde tradition that Serious Fun celebrates.
"The avant-garde wouldn't be the American avant-garde without the African-American presence," he asserted. "This piece is in the tradition of Josephine Baker stopping in the middle of one of her Parisian shows and talking about racism in America."
In its milder way, this weekend's street-dance program is just as indicative of Lincoln Center's new open-armed cultural perspective as Mr. Mason's work.
"In the world of dance, there has always been debate about what is art and what is entertainment," said Mr. Graves, who has choreographed the music videos for C&C Music Factory and other popular acts. "What we need to realize is that art is entertaining and that entertainment is art."
Mr. Graves, who is in his early 30's, has studied both classical ballet and modern dance.
"Hip-hop dancers may not stand in front of a barre and a mirror, but they have their own school," he said. "The movement has a root and foundation in ethnic and primitive dance. Although my studies have not been that extensive, I know that a lot of the dances have influences from places like Senegal, and others from Katherine Dunham, who was from Haiti."
 
A Double Life
 When Mr. Graves was 5 years old and growing up in St. Louis, he said, he wanted to be James Brown. At 18, he won a $10,000 prize in a dance competition and used the money to go to Webster University in St. Louis, where he majored in dance education with an emphasis on choreography.
"In college, I would do my 'Nutcrackers' and 'Firebirds' and 'Giselles,' " he said, "then on Saturdays run over to Katherine Dunham's school in East St. Louis."
Since moving to New York in 1980, he has choreographed many music videos and television commercials and worked both on Broadway and Off. Two years ago with his partner, Kenneth Still, he established Onboard Productions, a production company and talent agency specializing in pop choreography. It has made him a force in a field that has grown into a small, thriving industry that offers new employment opportunities for professional dancers.
"It used to be that in order to make a living as a dancer you had to work on Broadway or be a concert dancer," he said. "Now you can make a living off of being a hip-hop dancer. Major artists like Hammer, Janet Jackson and C&C Music Factory tour with four or six dancers. In New York City, there are 20 videos being shot aday. For a dancer, what that means is that when you're not doing City Ballet or when Alvin Ailey is down for four months, you don't have to be unemployed. A dancer can do a video every other week and make an additional $2,000 or $3,000 and go on a tour with a recording artist. There's a whole new industry keeping the art alive."
Performances of "Mo' Moves" are at 8 P.M. tomorrow at Alice Tully Hall. Tickets are $20. Box office: (212) 875-5050.

HEADLINE: A POLITICAL PARTY;
For Children

BYLINE: By Dulcie Leimbach

 BODY:

'Re-electing George . . . Washington, That Is'
 Fraunces Tavern Museum
 54 Pearl Street (at Broad Street)
 Lower Manhattan
 (212) 425-1778
 Recommended ages: 7 and up
 Through Dec. 4
This mini-exhibition in a corner of the Revolutionary War museum lets visitors consider the Presidential qualities (or lack thereof) of four candidates for a restaged 1792 election: George Washington, George Clinton (the first Governor of New York), King George III of England and John Adams. The exhibition observes the 200th anniversary of Washington's re-election. Although he was the popular candidate, he himself was unsure if he wanted to be President again. 
 After reading placards displaying the candidates' curricula vitae, visitors may choose whom they would have liked to become President. Adams's resume describes him as "brilliant, witty and pompous," among other characteristics. Washington is described as "cautious, courteous, dull." King George, not an official candidate or even close to ideal, is "stubborn, intolerant and insecure." And Mr. Clinton, "frugal, businesslike and courageous," has the makings of a strong contender but opposes "big government." Anybody can vote, no matter how young. The votes will be counted on Dec. 4, the anniversary of Washington's re-election and also the day he bade farewell to his officers in the Long Room of Fraunces Tavern.
At the museum, visitors may also peruse the Clinton Room, with its panoramic French wallpaper depicting Revolutionary War scenes; the Long Room, with its eerie ambiance of invisible soldiers quaffing ale and slurping clams, and the exhibition, "Come All You Gallant Heroes: The World of the Revolutionary Soldier," with 18th-century war memorabilia. On display are muskets, canteens, an original haversack, various implements and tableware, a tricorn hat, and a fife and a very worn drum set.
The museum is open Mondays through Fridays from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Admission is $2.50 for adults and $1 for children.
 
 'The Age of Exploration'
 Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum
 Hudson River at West 46th Street
 Manhattan
 (212) 245-2533
 Recommended ages: 7 and up
 Through October 1993
Once you forge through the crowds waiting in line to board the Nina, the Pinta and the Santa Maria and make your way onto the Intrepid, there is a quiet but thorough exhibition in one corner of the carrier about European voyages to the Americas before and after Columbus. The displays feature boat models, artifacts, costumes, handsome maps, tapestries and videos as well as texts, all of which are presented coherently but require a lot of reading. Some of the texts are enlightening and supply enough information to write several school reports this fall. The Europeans' search for a sea route to Cathay (and the gold and silk that seemingly awaited them there) drove most of the explorers west. But they weren't too disappointed that they never arrived there. In 1499 and 1500, for example, as Amerigo Vespucci traveled along the northeast coast of South America en route to Portugal, he rightly said that it wasn't Cathay, but a "new world."
The most informative (and time-consuming display) presents the Old World explorers, from Jacques Cartier to Hernando Cortes, and their achievements, along with meticulously drawn portraits. In another part of the show, the grueling life of sailors is depicted (they worked four-hour watches, timed by sandglasses); replicas of the Columbus caravels hang in another display, and a cartography exhibition reveals that the science once relied on religious scribes. Two continuous videos (one of which is oddly obscured by a railing and hard to hear), present a dramatization in which Columbus's son tells what made his father tick. The videos are enhanced with taped music by the Waverly Consort.
The exhibition is not air-conditioned; strollers are allowed, but there are steep steps up to the show. The crowds milling outside to board the Columbus caravels may daunt some visitors, but getting aboard the Intrepid doesn't take long. Vendors on the pier also add to the general buzz. Admission to the Intrepid is $7 for adults and $4 for ages 6 to 11; hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily through Labor Day. The caravels remain there through Tuesday. The hours to board are 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. today through Sunday and 9 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Monday and Tuesday. Admission is $5 for adults and $3 for children 6 and up.
 
'From Sea to Shining Sea'
 Theaterworks/USA
 Promenade Theater
 2162 Broadway (at 76th Street)
 Upper West Side
 (212) 677-5959
 Recommended ages: 5 and up
 Through Aug. 3
The building of the American transcontinental railroad in the 1860's entailed more than sweat and dynamite. Theaterworks/USA's newest play, "From Sea to Shining Sea," conveys the human drama among the workers of various ethnic backgrounds. The hourlong play, which is swept along vigorously by Jeffrey Lunden's American folk-style music (inspired by Copland), depicts the racism and harsh conditions that many of the laborers endured. The multi-cultural, all-male cast (apparently the few women near the work sites were usually prostitutes) convincingly conveys the ordeal, say, of earning $3 a day for work that required Herculean strength, and the emotional trauma of being Chinese, not knowing English and being abused by a prejudiced boss.
The play switches back and forth between crews on the Union Pacific line and the Central Pacific line; the tactic is slightly confusing, but workable with a narrator's help. The Central Pacific crew (whose actors also play the Union Pacific employees) includes Chinese workers bold enough to risk losing their jobs when the group holds a protest. The Union Pacific crew is dominated by a relationship between Sean, a naive but industrious Irishman, and Nate, a runaway slave who escaped through the Underground Railroad. Sean and Nate become comrades despite their boss, who seethes with rancor. (The actor, Rob Woronoff, also plays the boss on the other crew and is just as nasty.) Eventually, both crews make decisions about their welfare, squaring off before their bosses.
The play presents the laborers' tough working conditions without making the characters seem like caricatures and without being a simplistic tale of prejudice. Woo Lee, for example, is a Chinese worker sent down the side of a mountain to light dynamite. He doesn't speak English and has never done this work before, but he takes the plunge.
Performances are at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. Mondays through Fridays and at 11 A.M. on Saturdays. Admission is free. Tickets may be obtained at the theater at 10 A.M. the day of performance. Groups may call ahead to arrange for tickets.
 
 'Kids and Politics'
 Children's Museum of Manhattan
 212 West 83d Street
 Upper West Side
 (212) 721-1223
 Recommended ages: 5 and up
When the Children's Museum asked children what they would do if they were President, many said they would focus on homelessness and unemployment, said June Schneider, the senior curator and director of public programs. As part of what the museum is calling a "Video Soapbox," the museum videotaped children ages 7 and up, asking them questions about the Presidency and how the present officeholder was doing, whom they would vote for, and their hopes for the country.
The children, despite their savvy, show some charming naivete. When asked whom they want to be President, many say their mothers. As a follow-up question, they are asked if they realize no woman has ever been President. "Then that question leads us to something else," Ms. Schneider said. The children are also highly focused on the environment and how money should be spent. (Not on weapons, many say.) Roving interviews will continue this week at the museum.
The museum has also invited the Democratic front-runner, Gov. Bill Clinton, and his wife, Hillary, to visit this week; no commitment has been made as yet. Museum hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Mondays and Wednesdays through Sundays. Admission is $4, but Democratic National Convention delegates with credentials and journalists covering the convention are invited to the museum free tomorrow through July 17.

HEADLINE: TENNIS;
Now a Money Pit Endangers U.S. Open Construction Plans

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN

 BODY:
The United States Tennis Association's controversial plans to construct a modern site for the United States Open adjacent to the current location at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park are once again in jeopardy. This time it is financing, rather than site selection or political snafus or architectural details, that is causing dissension over a project whose construction was originally scheduled to begin this year but continues to idle.
Although the project was supposed to reach completion in time for the 1995 Open, the latest forecast is that the tournament will be conducted under "as is" conditions possibly until 1997. That finding is certain to cause displeasure among the players, who toil under hot, noisy and cramped conditions there at the end of every summer. They have already voted the 15-year-old Flushing Meadows complex the least amenable of the four Grand Slam sites.
 
$197 Million in Total Costs
 
 The latest construction estimates given to the U.S.T.A.'s board of directors indicate that the much-delayed project could end up costing more than $197 million, an increase of nearly $50 million from the initial estimates.
The new facility, which would have three stadiums, carried a $150 million price tag when the plans were unveiled in 1990. Last winter the U.S.T.A. learned that minor renovations to their plans, which have yet to receive official endorsement from New York City or land-use approval from the state, would cost an additional $30 million. The latest inflation has prompted Robert Cookson, the U.S.T.A. president, to consider scrapping the plan, which the association is financing, unless a cap is put on its cost.
Meanwhile, the U.S.T.A. still has not received a formal lease agreement with its landlord, the city of New York, for the site, which contains 31 acres of additional parkland. Its $250,000 yearly lease of the current 17-acre site was signed in 1981 and expires in 1994.
The proposed complex has yet to undergo a yearlong community review and a series of environmental impact hearings, and the enthusiasm of Mayor David N. Dinkins was undercut when he learned of the U.S.T.A.'s plans to relocate its executive offices from New York City to Westchester County.
In addition, several conservation groups have pledged to oppose the project even it means losing the Open, which draws 450,000 spectators and generates $14 million in yearly tax revenues. The United States championships has been held in New York City since 1915.

HEADLINE: Clint Frank, 76, Dies; Won Heisman in 1937

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 8

 BODY:
Clint Frank, who won the Heisman Trophy in 1937 as a two-way back for Yale, died Tuesday at Evanston (Ill.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 76 years old.
Mr. Frank was the third winner of the Heisman, which goes to the outstanding college football player in the nation, and the second one from Yale, following the selection of his teammate Larry Kelley in 1936. The runner-up to Mr. Frank in 1937 was Byron (Whizzer) White of Colorado, who now serves on the United States Supreme Court. 
 After Mr. Frank graduated with a degree in economics, he went into advertising. After five years with the Army Air Corps during World War II, he returned to advertising. In 1954, he founded Clinton E. Frank Inc., which he sold to Campbell-Ewald Co. in Detroit in 1976.
He was elected to the Football Hall of Fame in 1955 and in 1988 was named recipient of the Gold Medal, the hall's highest award.
He is survived by his wife, Margaret Rathje Frank, three sons and six daughters.

HEADLINE: America's Mixed Neighborhoods Need Support

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Two Neighborhoods, and a Wall Called Race" (front page, June 21), about the Chicago communities of Roseland and Mount Greenwood, gives the depressing side of the story of racial change in urban America. 
 Curiously, you omit mention of the two stably integrated communities of Morgan Park and Beverly, which are situated between the two neighborhoods you profile and would give readers a more optimistic picture of race relations in Chicago.
In the 1970's these two communities lay directly in the path of southwest expansion of African-American families moving out of the inner city. Although some whites in Morgan Park-Beverly succumbed to the panic-peddling tactics of unscrupulous real-estate brokers and joined their Roseland predecessors in fleeing farther west, a sizable majority of families decided to put a stop to the insanity of white flight.
Under the leadership of the Beverly Area Planning Association, and with support from a local bank and from a shopping-center developer, neighborhood residents organized to resist panic selling, to quell rumors about crime and to promote their neighborhood.
The residents formed a housing center for the purpose of encouraging more integrated patterns of settlement by new home buyers.
Although racial divisions have not disappeared, the latest census attests to the success of these two neighborhoods in remaining integrated in the presence of a minority population whose proportion is well above the historical tipping point.
The census shows that between 1980 and 1990 the proportion of white residents held steady at about 34 percent in Morgan Park and that the proportion of black residents increased gradually from 14 percent to 24 percent in Beverly.
This is in sharp contrast with Roseland, which went from 72 percent white to 97 percent black in less than two decades.
What poses a major threat to the continued vitality of all four of these Southwest Chicago neighborhoods, beyond the racial distrust that lingers, is the reluctance of businesses to invest in them because their economic and demographic profiles compare less favorably with their suburban neighbors.
Unless economic investment in mixed-race and mixed-income urban neighborhoods becomes a higher national priority, our fears about a separate, hostile, unequal America are likely to become a self-fulfilling prophecy.
 
MARK TESTA
Associate Professor, Social Service
Administration, U. of Chicago
Chicago, June 25, 1992

HEADLINE: America's Mixed Neighborhoods Need Support;
Everything Changed

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I feel compelled to comment on "Two Neighborhoods, and a Wall Called Race" (front page, June 21), about the two South Side Chicago neighorhoods of Roseland and Mount Greenwood. 
 I grew up in Roseland, as my father did, his father did, and so on. While it's not in any history book, my forefathers were the first settlers of the Roseland area, first after the Potawatomi Indians, that is.
In 1865, my great-great-grandfather came here from Holland with absolutely nothing. He and his family lived in a squatter's shack on the Illinois Central Railroad at 95th Street and South Park Avenue (now Martin Luther King Jr. Drive). He ended up working as a gandy dancer for the Illinois Central. He was never rich, but he made a living from nothing, and his descendants lived in the area for more than 100 years, till 1970.
From the 1890's, when the nearby town of Pullman was established, Roseland was a melting pot of nationalities and cultures, including blacks. Like many ethnically integrated neighborhoods in Chicago, its diversity was its strength, and the community flourished.
Then, in the 1960's, in tandem with the civil rights movement, everything changed.
Roseland was no longer a nice place to live. I can personally relate experiences that are a heck of a lot more offensive than the one you describe in your second article on June 22 of the white cashier in Mount Greenwood who wouldn't put a black customer's change in his hand but only on the counter.
Local businesses could not withstand the vandalism, crime and violence any more than the residents could. People moved away, not from fear of integration but from fear for their own safety.
Now, according to you, Roseland's plight is the fault of the whites who left, as if we chose to walk away from our homes, our churches, our livelihood and our heritage.
Last year, Roseland received news media attention because of demonstrations against local businesses. Roseland residents were blaming their problems on Asian merchants who had established the successful businesses. It seems people can still make a good living in Roseland, despite racism and cultural barriers.
As we've seen recently in Los Angeles and other blighted urban areas, people are quick to blame someone or something else for their situation. You can blame your old neighbors or your new neighbors or the fact that your daddy was a sharecropper or a squatter. You can point an accusing finger at the "wall" between your neighborhood and the white neighborhoods or the lack of attention by public officials.
But, all the blame and finger pointing won't buy you a cup of coffee. To quote the lyric of a popular song, "If you want to change the world, just look in a mirror and change yourself."
 
PAUL H. TON
Westmont, Ill., June 24, 1992

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
CLINTON SELECTS SENATOR GORE OF TENNESSEE AS RUNNING MATE

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 9

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas today selected Senator Al Gore of Tennessee to join him as his Vice-Presidential running mate when he receives the Democratic nomination for President in New York next week.
In making the much-anticipated announcement on the lawn of the Governor's mansion here, Mr. Clinton emphasized Mr. Gore's experience in foreign policy and the environment. And with their wives and children arrayed behind them in the baking noonday sun, both men spoke of their commitment to family values. 
 Mr. Clinton offered Mr. Gore the position during a 20-minute conversation shortly before midnight on Wednesday.
 
Relative Youth Stressed
 If elected, Mr. Gore, 44 years old, and Mr. Clinton, 45, would be the youngest team to make it to the White House in the country's history.
Aides to the Arkansas Governor emphasized their relative youth as a positive factor in an election year that has turned on which candidate can offer the best formula for change, a pointed to reference to President Bush, 68, who has been a member of the Washington establishment for more than two decades.
"Throughout American history, each generation has passed on leadership to the next," Mr. Gore said. "That time has come again, the time for a new generation of leadership for the United States of America."
 
Ready to Battle in South
 In selecting a fellow Southerner, Mr. Clinton cast aside traditional strategies for choosing a Vice-Presidential running mate that have dictated the need for geographical diversity to balance the ticket.
The choice also signaled that the Democrats were ready to battle the Republicans to regain control of the South and gather the support of swing voters who are concerned about the environment.
"The running mate I have chosen is a leader of great strength, integrity and stature, a father who like me loves his children and shares my hunger to turn this economy around, to change our country and to do it so that we don't raise the first generation of children to do worse than their parents," Mr. Clinton said to a crowd of supporters and friends.
But the wisdom of Mr. Clinton's choice was immediately questioned by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who has twice unsucessfully sought the Democratic nomination for President and has on several occasions offered himself as a Vice-Presidential running mate. "I have deep concerns about the ticket. It takes two wings to fly and here you have two of the same wing."
And Republican campaign officials quickly denounced Mr. Gore as a liberal and said the Clinton-Gore combination would be far out of the mainstream.
"We think it shows Clinton is operating from weakness," said Frederic V. Malek, the manager of the Bush campaign. "And he's chosen somebody to cover those weaknesses -- his lack of a military record, his association with liberal social values, and his need to strengthen himself in the South, his own home region."
Ross Perot, the still-undeclared independent candidate for President, has focused most of his attacks on Mr. Bush and had only kind words for Mr. Gore today. "He's a fine man, wonderful family, and I think he's an excellent choice."
Mr. Gore, who like Mr. Clinton has tried to position himself in the moderate wing of the Democratic Party, sought the Presidential nomination in 1988 on much the same model as Mr. Clinton chose this year. By seeking to prove that Democrats can be strong on the military as well as supportive of social programs, he is among younger Democrats who have sought to prove that they can regain the White House by retaking the middle ground.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore are both active members of the Democratic Leadership Council, a group of mostly Southern Democrats who organized in 1985 with the mission of guiding their party toward more centrist ideals.
 
'Long Hard Fight'
 Nearly a year ago, Mr. Gore decided not to run in 1992, saying he was concerned that a grueling campaign could harm his family. His son, Albert 3d, who is now 9 years old, was seriously injured in an automobile accident in Baltimore in 1989 but is now fully recovered.
Mr. Gore said today that he looks forward to a "long hard fight" in the general election campaign. He also took up the Clinton campaign's theme that the ticket would point the country in a new direction.
"I believe in my heart that this ticket gives our country the best chance for the change we so deperately need, to move foward again," Mr. Gore said.
Successive Republican administrations, he said, have "driven this country into the ditch."
"I believe very deeply that this nation simply cannot afford another four years of the kind of leadership that we have now," he said. "They've run out of ideas, they've run out of energy, they've run out of the ability to inspire people."
Mr. Gore spoke with some force today in denouncing the Bush Administration, which he said "has been trying to divide us for too long." Some campaign advisers commented approvingly afterward that the Tennessee Senator's reputation for substance would contrast favorably with Vice President Dan Quayle.
Mr. Clinton has shown a renewed determination in recent days to challenge the President on the issue of what constitutes family values. In public remarks today, both he and Mr. Gore made special mention of their school-age children and of their wives, Tipper Gore and Hillary Clinton.
The Clintons -- who today stood beaming alongside their 12-year-old daughter, Chelsea -- had to fight backaccusations of marital infidelity and Mrs. Clinton's image as a woman who chose career over family early in the campaign.
The timing of the announcement reflected the campaign's concern that the selection would leak out and its desire to enter next week's convention with a ticket already in place. Campaign officials said this would help them avoid unnecessary distractions during a week that they hoped would focus on a unified party, with Mr. Clinton at its head.
Mr. Clinton called Mr. Gore to offer him the spot on his ticket at 11:15 P.M. Wednesday after meeting with three of his closest aides for about two hours at the Governor's mansion to go over the final list of choices.
Clinton campaign officials confirmed today that the other finalists were Senators Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia, Harris Wofford of Pennsylvania, Bob Graham of Florida and Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana.
In the end, Mr. Clinton went for the allure of youth. If elected, the combined ages of Mr. Gore and Mr. Clinton would make them the youngest Presidential team to enter the White House. President Ulysses S. Grant, who was 46 years old when he assumed offfice in 1869, and his Vice President, Schuyler Colfax, who was also 46, held the record previously.
As a courtesy, Mr. Clinton called Mr. Graham, who had to decide by Friday whether to run for re-election to his Senate seat, shortly before he called Mr. Gore. Today, before making the announcement, he called the other contenders, as well as Democratic Party leaders.
Mr. Clinton's list of finalists did not include either Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey or Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, apparently because both men had repeatedly said they did not want to be considered for the post.
 
From 40 Names to 6
 Former Gov. Madeleine Kunin of Vermont, who served on the selection team that was headed by the Los Angeles lawyer Warren Christopher, said in a telephone interview that Mr. Gore's name "would come up again and again" as they worked to winnow an initial list of about 40 names to the 6 from which Mr. Clinton ultimately chose.
Ms. Kunin said the choice of Mr. Gore was an important one for Mr. Clinton because the Democratic nominee would be "defined by the choices he makes."
Campaign officials said they expected the selection of Mr. Gore to be especially helpful in California, where voters express special concern about the environment. Mr. Gore, who has long been a champion of environmental issues in Congress, wrote a a best-selling book, "Earth in the Balance: Ecology and the Human Spirit" (Houghton Mifflin, 1992), that made it to The New York Times best-seller list.
Stan Greenberg, the campaign's poll taker, said the all-Southern ticket would put states like Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee and North Carolina "readily in reach" for Democrats for the first time since Jimmy Carter was elected in 1976.
He said Mr. Clinton's Southern roots alone might not have been enough to win the South because of the virtual certainty that Mr. Perot, the billionaire from Texas, would be in the race along with President Bush, who also calls Texas his home.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore will hold a joint news conference here on Friday before Mr. Gore and his family return to Tennessee. They plan to campaign together in Nashville on Saturday before flying to New York for the Democratic National Convention. After the convention, the two men will travel together on a five-day bus tour from New York to St. Louis.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 11, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: Grant System To Help Poor To Be Revised

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration, entering the volatile arena of antipoverty politics, is planning to abolish the community policy boards that have distributed tens of millions of Federal antipoverty dollars.
In a major overhaul of the poverty program run by the Community Development Agency, the city has also revised the formula that determines which neighborhoods are eligible for the money. It hopes to encourage the development of comprehensive services instead of the current hodgepodge of small programs now supported by the grants. 
 All told the proposals, which are to be presented today to a City Council panel, would give City Hall control over $13.5 million that has been the lifeblood of hundreds of small community organizations, and an important if obscure source of power for the local politicians who control the boards that disburse it.
Opponents charge that the administration is simply trying to take control of a lucrative patronage network the year before the mayoral election. Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch responds that the Mayor is trying to shake up an entrenched system of "employment mills" and "patronage mills."
 
Money Goes to 33 Area Boards
 Currently, Federal money is funneled through the city's Community Development Agency to 33 area policy boards that award grants for programs ranging from youth groups to services for the elderly. The boards, created by Mayor Edward I. Koch in 1977 after a series of scandals, are in a sense the inheritors of the war on poverty's call for grass-roots control of social services.
Under the new plan, the Community Development Agency would award grants directly, with some form of community participation. Who will benefit and who will lose under the draft proposals is not yet entirely clear. Some small, single-service nonprofit agencies like youth centers may no longer be able to compete successfully for grants unless they broaden their services. In the future, a new network of nonprofit service agencies may grow up to challenge those that now get funding.
The new plan would make two additional communities in Brooklyn eligible for grants. But 7 out of 33 areas of the city would lose eligibility for antipoverty money. In many of these areas, however, clusters of census blocks showing high concentrations of poverty would still be able to get grants.
Gladys Carrion, the commissioner of the Community Development Agency, said the review of the poverty program was long overdue and that money was still being distributed under an outdated formula, although the city's poor had increased and shifted. She added that some nonprofit agencies had come to view the money as an entitlement.
"In the past, people expected that they would always be funded by C.D.A. and that past performance wasn't necessarily a factor of future funding," said Ms. Carrion. "There are tremendous problems out there. There's less money. We really need to look at alternatives to what we're doing and different approaches, because poverty has increased."
She said the plan was to be presented today to a City Council committee and would be made public later this month. She said public hearings would then be held. She said it could be put in place administratively and did not require Council approval.
 
Reorganized in 1977
 When Mr. Koch, who campaigned in 1977 against "poverty pimps," reorganized the system, the Community Development Agency was put directly under the mayor's office. And 33 community councils, known as area policy boards, were set up to play a major role in deciding which organizations would get money. The boards replaced community corporations, which had been criticized for inefficiency, patronage and in some cases corruption.
But Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch charged in an interview that the program remained subject to abuse. Mr. Lynch said the system of grants had often led to the creation of "employment mills" and "patronage mills" that provide political bases and jobs for local politicians and community advocates. He said the system of poverty patronage had become so entrenched in the city that it was difficult to battle. "It's like trying to push the Queen Mary sideways," he said.
The status quo has a large and varied constituency. For while the money distributed annually through the Community Development Agency is only $13.5 million, a network of more than 300 nonprofit agencies have come to depend on the money. The recipients of the grants cover a broad range of groups, among them the Hispanic Service Society, the Korean Manpower Development, the Torah Academy for Girls, the Bronx Youth Ministry Leadership Council, the Chinese American Planning Council.
 
Meetings Poorly Attended
 Frank Marrero, chairman of Area Policy Board 2 in the Bronx, admitted that his group's meetings are poorly attended and subject to pressure from politicians. But he also said he opposed Ms. Carrion's plan because then "she can make her own political decisions and completely leave out the community."
In Crown Heights, Rabbi Jacob Goldstein, the chairman of Community Board 9, tied the overhaul of the poverty program to the Community Development Agency's move late last year to reduce the number of offices where the poor can apply for Federal subsidies for heat. The management of some remaining offices was shifted away from Jewish groups to black and Hispanic groups. "They wanted to see how much they could, as far as I'm concerned, hurt the Jews," he said, noting that both Crown Heights and the Rockaways would lose eligibility under the new plan.
Ms. Carrion vehemently denied that the overhaul of the poverty program had anything to do with race or ethnicity.
The formula for determining areas eligible for aid has been updated to reflect the 1990 census and revised to reflect the working poor instead of just recipients of public assistance, Ms. Carrion said. Under the plan, seven community boards would lose eligibility for antipoverty money, including Ms. Carrion's neighborhood: Bronx Community Board 12, covering the northeast Bronx.
The other neighborhoods that would lose eligibility are Community Boards 2, 6 and 9 in Brooklyn, including Fort Greene-Boerum Hill, Crown Heights, Carroll Gardens, Cobble Hill and Red Hook; in Manhattan, Community Board 4, including Chelsea and Clinton; in Queens, Community Board 14, the Rockaways, and in Staten Island, Community Board 1.
As another part of the reorganization, Ms. Carrion said, the administration plans to eliminate all 33 of the area policy boards that largely decided which nonprofit agencies received antipoverty money. The boards, which cover the same geographic areas as community boards, have up to 21 members each. Up to five members are local elected officials. Two seats are reserved for representatives of the private sector. And 12 members are representatives of the poor elected by local voters every four years.
But Ms. Carrion said that the last election in 1987 drew a turnout of only one-half of 1 percent of eligible voters and cost the city $700,000. She canceled the scheduled 1991 elections, which were expected to cost $1 million. "We didn't have $1 million and if we did I'd put it to another use," she said.
She said there had been numerous city investigations of grants made by the boards and that their grant decisions had been "fraught with problems." Last year, for example, Bertha Thomas, chairwoman of a Queens area policy board, pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor after she was charged with soliciting a bribe from a community service organization in the Rockaways over an antipoverty contract, according to the city Department of Investigation.
Mr. Marrero, the chairman of Area Policy Board 2 in the Bronx, described the pressures his board felt last year when it decided to cut off $35,000 to an agency headed by Caroline Velez, the wife of former City Councilman Ramon Velez, the political figure who carved a controversial empire out of antipoverty programs.
Mr. Marrero said that the Velezes came to his home and demanded that he sign a letter saying other nonprofit agencies had agreed to reductions to allow Mrs. Velez's program to be restored. Mr. Velez, he said, "Grabs me in a headlock, he says, 'What are you doing? You're messing up with my family.' " He said he signed the letter and sent an account of what happened and a letter of resignation to C.D.A. He said he subsequently rejoined the board after several months. The $35,000 grant was not restored.
Mr. Velez, reached by telephone yesterday, said he had gone to Mr. Marrero's home because his wife wanted to protest that the board's decision was "totally illegal."
"He was abusive to my wife and that is the only thing I remember about and I asked my wife to leave with me," Mr. Velez said.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 11, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about proposed changes in New York City's antipoverty system referred incorrectly to Crown Heights, Brooklyn, in some editions. Under the proposed rules, the community board district that includes Crown Heights would not be eligible to receive Federal antipoverty money. But poorer sections within the district, including black and Hasidic neighborhoods, would continue to receive grants.

HEADLINE: Private-Sector Grants Given For a New Breed of Schools

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 9

 BODY:
Grants were awarded today by a private foundation set up by business leaders last year at the request of President Bush to finance a "new generation" of American schools. Awards went to 11 design teams, including two New York-based groups.
The number was far fewer than the 20 to 30 grants the group had originally anticipated giving out by spring 1992, although officials denied that this was the result of the foundation's raising less money than anticipated. 
 "It's really in the eye of the beholder," said Ann D. McLaughlin, president and chief executive of the private, nonprofit foundation, the New American Schools Development Corporation, based in Arlington, Va. She said the group had raised $50 million for the 11 grants but had not yet determined how much money each project would get.
Today's 11 design team winners included several coalitions of well-known education reformers, like one teaming Theodore R. Sizer, head of the Coalition of Essential Schools, and James P. Comer, director of the School Development Program at the Yale Child Study Center. It also included some newcomers.
 
Radical New Thinking
 The New American Schools Development Corporation was created last July at the behest of Mr. Bush to persuade American businesses to donate enough money to create 535 experimental schools over a five-year period. The group's statement of purpose reads, "While NASDC recognizes that successful change may come from within existing schools, NASDC's responsibility is dramatically different: To help create radical new thinking about what American schools of the future might be."
When Mr. Bush announced the private-sector effort in a Rose Garden ceremony, foundation officials talked confidently of raising $200 million to finance 20 to 30 projects. Many business leaders saw the idea as an occasion to encourage corporate donations to education, but fund raising was slowed by a depressed economy and by competition with existing philanthropic programs financed by businesses.
Ms. McLaughlin, a former Secretary of Labor in the Reagan Administration, was elected to run the organization at the end of May with a mandate to improve fund raising. She joined the foundation five days ago.
"And I can assure you we're going to absolutely reach our goal" of raising $200 million for the foundation, she said.
Ms. McLaughlin said that the grant recipients would receive their money sometime during the next two months, after their contracts were signed and their grant negotiations completed.
 
One Winner Allied With Apple
 One winning proposal came from a design team of several well-known school researchers that included Marc Tucker, president and founder of the National Center on Education and the Economy, an education research and consulting group based in Rochester; Lauren Resnick, director of the Learning Research and Development Center at the University of Pittsburgh and of the New Standards Project, a testing reform group; and David Hornbeck, a former Maryland State Superintendent of Schools.
Their group, called the National Alliance for Restructuring Education, based in Rochester, includes Apple Computer Inc. as a partner and proposes a system that would address the health and psychological needs of children as well as their academic performance and would develop more efficient ways to channel the latest in instructional resources into schools. The proposal also calls for involving communities in supporting schools.
The team is meeting this week in Sagamore, N.Y., to refine the project with the help of more than 200 teachers, principals, researchers and state and local officials.
When the group at Sagamore heard that the project had won a grant, "250 people broke into an incredible level of applause," said Andy Plattner, communications director for the National Center on Education and the Economy. The other New York group to win an award is the College for Human Services in New York City, a design team led by Audrey Cohen.
Today's winners were selected from more than 600 proposals. These are the other winners:
The Odyssey Project, Gaston County School System, Gaston County, N.C.; The Bensenville Community Design Team, Bensenville, Ill.; Community Learning Centers, Minneapolis and other Minnesota districts; The Co-NECT School, Cambridge, Boston and Worcester, Mass.; Expeditionary Learning, Boston and other sites; Los Angeles Learning Centers; The Modern Red Schoolhouse, Indianapolis and other sites; Roots and Wings, Lexington Park, Md., and Johns Hopkins University.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 11, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about 11 grants awarded by the New American Schools Development Corporation to groups proposing to design new kinds of public schools identified one winner incompletely. The Boston-based project known as Expeditionary Learning is sponsored and organized by Outward Bound USA.

 BODY:

 Companies
Olympia & York reported a $1.76 billion loss that should have been much higher, its auditor said, if the company had followed standard accounting rules. Price Waterhouse, the auditor, criticized the real estate developer for not taking a markdown on the value of the bankrupt Canary Wharf project. [Page 33.]
Budget Rent a Car will start screening some renters by quizzing them about their driving records, in hopes of avoiding liability suits. [33.] 
 A jury awarded $3.3 billion in damages against Charles H. Keating Jr. for swindling thousands of savings and loan investors. The award was the latest chapter in the story of the defunct Lincoln Savings and Loan [33.]
McDonnell Douglas plans to cut up to 5,000 more jobs by the end of the year at its hard-hit commercial aviation division. The dismissals will strike particularly hard in California. [35.]
Pan Am was liable for damages in the 1988 explosion of Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, a Federal jury decided, opening the way for trials on individual claims that could total about $300 million. [1.]
Nike will have only limited use of its logo at the Olympics in Barcelona, as the result of a Spanish court's ruling in a trademark dispute. [35.]
Hunt-Wesson plans to use I.C.I.'s gene-altered tomatoes by 1995, in an effort to salvage the vegetable's shriveling reputation for tastiness. [35.]
A court threw out the conviction of the Exxon Valdez skipper, citing a law intended to encourage reporting of oil spills. [5.]
The Taystee Bakery plant in Queens closed after more than three decades. [21.]
 
 The Economy
Small-business owners are accusing the U.S. of stifling growth through the lending practices of the Small Business Administration. Some even equate the Government with a loan shark. [33.]
Prices paid by wholesalers rose only modestly in June, as widespread declines nearly offset a run-up in oil costs, the Government said in a report illustrating weak economic demand. [34.]
New Jersey's Personnel Commissioner said he had rejected the layoff plans of eight state departments. [25.]
 
 International
Sub-Saharan Africa's biggest steel plant opens this month, in Ajaokuta, Nigeria, after 12 years and many delays. The plant stands as a symbol of a nation's dream of greatness, but also the target of increasing cynicism. [3.]
 
 Markets
The stock market edged upward yesterday, squeezing modest benefit out of the favorable news on inflation. The Dow rose 6.48 points, to 3,330.56, gaining a scant 0.27 point for the week. [36.]
Prices of most Treasury notes and bonds fell yesterday, as traders chose to sell securities despite an exceptionally good inflation report. [36.]
A brief rally for the dollar lost momentum and sent it lower against all major currencies. Gold also fell. [42.]
Selling of gasoline futures helped weaken energy prices on New York's Mercantile Exchange. [42.]

HEADLINE: Dow Closes Nearly Unchanged for Week

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market edged up yesterday, squeezing some modest benefit out of the favorable news on inflation.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.48 points, to 3,330.56, to finish the week practically where it began, with a net gain of 0.27 point. 
 Advancing issues outnumbered those that declined, 1,023 to 675, on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Big Board was 164.8 million shares, down from 209.2 million on Thursday.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods rose two-tenths of a percent in June compared with a rise of four-tenths of a percent in May.
Analysts said investors saw the report as a favorable sign for the inflation outlook. But bonds managed no more than a mixed showing after the report was published. Enthusiasm was muted in the stock market because lower inflation also reflects sluggishness in the economy.
Similarly, a positive report on inflation is expected on Tuesday, when the Government issues figures on consumer prices for June. Estimates see that index rising only two-tenths of a percent, matching the increase for May.
 
Conner Is Active
 Conner Peripherals was actively traded, up 1 3/8, to 20 3/8. Late Thursday, the company reported second-quarter earnings of 77 cents a share, up from 45 cents a share in the corresponding period of 1991.
But as a sector, bank stocks took the lead. Citicorp gained 3/8, to 21 1/8; BankAmerica 1, to 43 1/4; J. P. Morgan 1 5/8, to 61 5/8, and Chemical Banking 5/8, to 38 7/8.
In the mortgage-finance sector, Federal Home Loan Mortgage rose 1 1/4, to 42 1/8, and Federal National Mortgage advanced 1, to 64 1/2.
Sierra Pacific Resources tumbled 5 3/8, to 18 3/8. The utility holding company cut its quarterly dividend to 28 cents a share from 46 cents, citing new capital requirements and lower rates of return allowed for its utility subsidiary.
Elan jumped 2 3/8, to 41 7/8, and was among the volume leaders on the American Stock Exchange. The company declared a 3-for-2 split.
Unilab, which is traded over-the-counter, dropped 1 1/8, to 5 1/8. On Thursday, the medical-testing and supplies company said it would take a $12 million charge against earnings because of changes in the billing system at its operations in Northern California.
Among Big Board issues, Boeing fell 1, to 39. The stock was under pressure since midweek, when the company lost out to Airbus in the competition for a big aircraft leasing deal with UAL.
Blue chips that contributed to the Dow's gain included United Technologies, up 7/8, to 51 1/4; McDonald's, up 1 3/8, to 47; Procter & Gamble, up 3/4, to 49 5/8, and American Express, up 1/4, to 24.
The Nasdaq composite index gained 3.05 points, to 567.80; the Amex composite index, 0.48, to 382.32; the Standard & Poor's index of 500 issues, 0.39, to 414.62, and the Big Board composite index, 0.33, to 227.88.
