HEADLINE: Taystee Bakery Closes in Bitterness;
Manufacturing Shift Leaves Flushing Workers Feeling Deserted, Betrayed and Afraid

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
For 20 years, Leroy Morgan rose early each morning to weigh and mix the dough at the Taystee Bakery plant in Queens. It was hard work, but he made a decent living, raised a family, bought his own house in Jamaica. Now it is over.
Just after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, the last packages of hamburger and hot dog buns rolled off the assembly lines at Taystee, ending more than three decades of production at the hulking plant in Flushing and leaving the last of more than 500 employees without jobs, and with dim prospects for new ones. 
 "I'm like a drowning man grabbing at a straw," said Mr. Morgan, who is 52 years old. "A man at my age looking for a job, with a wife and two kids, a mortgage. I try not to think about it."
 
'What Do We Have to Lose?'
 Taystee, once the largest bakery in the nation, closed despite months of pressure by the city and state, and an against-the-odds effort by its workers, to persuade its owner, Stroehmann Bakeries, not to move it to Pennsylvania. Now the workers, supported by religious and political leaders, are fighting the closing in court, boycotting Stroehmann's products and trying to start their own bakery, mostly because they have nowhere else to go.
"We can't give up now," said Mr. Morgan, whose wife lost her job at a bank two years ago when it moved upstate. "What do we have to lose?"
Both the closing and the workers' campaign have become emblematic of the shifts in New York City's economy that have eliminated thousands of manufacturing jobs, most of them unskilled, many of them held by minorities and immigrants.
From 1979 to 1991, New York City lost 205,000 manufacturing jobs, more than 40 percent, even as its overall economy boomed over most of that time.
"In those halcyon days of the 1980's, this was the forgotten sector of the economy," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Stroehmann Bakeries, through an arrangement with the city, bought Taystee in 1988 with $5.2 million in bonds exempt from Federal, state and city taxes, and $780,000 in tax abatements. It decided to move its operation to its bakeries in Pennsylvania for many of the reasons that have led other manufacturers to leave the city.
 
Building Called Antiquated
 David H. Allshouse, the company's vice president of human resources, said that the building was antiquated and that operating costs, including wages, utilities and taxes, were too high. Stroehmann, a subsidiary of George Weston Ltd., a Toronto conglomerate, has lost at least $23 million since buying the bakery, he said.
As the operations wound down yesterday and the familiar waft of baking bread began to fade, workers already laid off gathered outside the bakery beside the Van Wyck Expressway to greet those finishing their last day. The workers, embittered and afraid, said they felt betrayed by the company that had taken over, and then abandoned, the landmark bakery.
Stroehmann has offered severance packages and $1,000 grants for retraining, but most workers say they have little chance of replacing their $12- to $14-an-hour wages and medical benefits.
"People have nowhere else to go," said Lynn Bell, a Taystee employee for 13 years, and, as the union's shop steward, the leader of the workers' campaign. "All these people out of work puts a lot of people in the unemployment lines. A lot of people, I know, will end up on welfare."
Several workers, like Jennie Call, have been through this before. Ms. Call started working at Taystee eight years ago after losing her job at a bakery in Queens that moved away. With overtime, she was making more than $30,000 a year at Taystee until she was laid off in March.
Ms. Call, 31, a native of North Carolina with a high school diploma, has looked for jobs at other bakeries so far because she wants to stay in the union and maintain her pension, but there are few openings anywhere.
"I don't think what they did was fair," Ms. Call said. "A lot of people put a lot of their lives in there."
The workers' campaign began in the Maple Crest, a bar near the plant, after Stroehmann, based in Horsham, Pa., announced in November that it would close the bakery.
At first, the workers hoped to pressure the company to reconsider, but as it became apparent that Taystee would close, they concentrated on other options, primarily the opening of an employee-owned bakery somewhere in Queens.
The campaign's leaders, who have received support from several religious and community organizations, including the Ebenezer Baptist Church in Flushing, hope to model their bakery after City Pride, a bakery in Pittsburgh being built by a coalition of church and community groups.
As if to underline their optimism, they distributed job applications outside the bakery yesterday. "I'm happy we have somewhere to go," Ms. Bell said. "Otherwise, we'd go home, collect unemployment and cry."
City and state officials have expressed support. The city's Industrial Development Agency has ordered Stroehmann to repay its tax waivers because it violated its financing agreement with the city, and has voted to use that $780,000 to help the workers open their bakery.
The city's support of the workers has underscored a realization that after years of trying to lure and keep thousands of white-collar jobs, it must do more to keep what manufacturing jobs are left.
 
Company Says It Has Buyer
 "It is clear that manufacturing has not and will not have the same role it had 50 years ago," said Wallace L. Ford 2d, the commissioner of the city's Department of Business Services. "But it is still extremely important."
The workers have also sued Stroehmann in State Supreme Court to stop the company from dismantling the plant in preparation for its sale. On Thursday, Stroehmann announced it had reached an agreement to sell the property to another company, which Mr. Allshouse would not identify except to say it was not a manufacturer.
In the meantime, the workers have pressed their boycott, partly out of vengeance, and partly to clear shelves for their own products.
"This is our chance to get back at them," Randy Bowen, a packer at Taystee for six years, said as he sat in front of a Pathmark supermarket in Flushing the other day, handing out boycott fliers. "To hurt them for taking our jobs out of the city, but sending the bread back."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Former workers from the Taystee Bakery in Flushing, Queens, are trying to open an employee-owned bakery with the help of local religious and community organizations. Workers signed applications yesterday for the new bakery. (Steve Hart for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bridge

BYLINE: By Alan Truscott

 BODY:
There is no way to prove it, but it can be safely asserted that the number of home bridge games has declined in the last six decades. This is partly due to the increasing number of attractions: In the days of Ely Culbertson a bridge game with the neighbors was both convenient and economical, a consideration in the years of Depression.
A player from the 30's who was transported to the 90's would be surprised to find that the form of the game has changed. The standard rubber bridge game has given way in North America -- though not in Britain -- to Chicago or four-deal bridge. One of the few surviving regular rubber-bridge games is in East Norwalk, Conn., where the diagramed deal was played recently at the home of Dorothy Greenberg, who reported the episode. 
 Over the opening bid of one heart South leaped to four spades, and was surprised to be raised to slam. Slams with 20 points in the combined hands are rarely reached in the face of an opening bid, and this was an excellent one.
West led a heart, and South crossruffed to remove her heart losers and eventually drew trumps. Since East held the diamond king, a likely circumstance in view of the opening bid, the slam was made.
In the post-mortem it was suggested that a trump lead would have permitted the defense to prevail. It would indeed have prevented South from ruffing all the heart losers, but a loser-on-loser play would have succeeded. South would have won in dummy, led a high club, and discarded a red-suit loser. If West wins, the remaining high club can be removed from the East hand with a ruff, and all the red-suit losers disappear.
Even with the actual heart lead, this would have been a better play, for the danger that West has the diamond king is greater than the danger that he has both the ace and queen of clubs.
A diamond opening lead would have been somewhat awkward. Playing low from dummy would have allowed East to win and shift to a trump, so the winning play would be to take the ace, crossruff, and eventually lead a diamond toward the king. South would then feel foolish in the unlikely event that West had led a diamond away from the king. [Diagram]

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
A Native Son's Hopeful Return

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

 BODY:
APPROXIMATELY 15 minutes into Rolando Blackman's first official interview as a New York Knick, someone produced a newspaper clipping from 1977 that showed pictures of a group of New York city high school basketball stars.
In the middle, with the biggest picture, was Albert King, the star of Alexander Hamilton High School who was being billed as the greatest high school player in New York City history. There were also pictures of Riley Clarida, Joe Foster, Larry Washington. Not recognizable names now, but high school megastars then. 
 In the upper right-hand part of the page there was a small photo of a thin, young-looking player with a big Afro who played for Grady High School in Brooklyn.
Blackman looked at his picture, smiled and shook his head as memories returned.
"This was a time when I had no goals whatsoever as far as playing basketball," he said, laughing. "I was just trying to get a scholarship and go to school. All these guys were talking about being pros."
Blackman received his scholarship. He left the city on a journey that carried him to Manhattan, Kan., and Kansas State University, then to the National Basketball Association, where he spent 11 seasons with the Dallas Mavericks. In more than a decade Blackman established himself as a clutch player and a consistently deadly outside shooter.
Yesterday, Blackman began his newest odyssey, with the Knicks, who obtained the 33-year-old guard from Dallas for a first-round draft choice in 1995. The deal seems to be a gift.
Blackman could be the bridge, if not the missing link, to New York's ascendancy to an Eastern Conference championship.
Despite the Knicks' spectacular playoff run last spring, the coaching staff continued to stress the need for a consistent, lethal perimeter threat. There was an unspoken desire for a player who did not run from the ball in clutch situations. Blackman, it seems, fits the bill.
New York represents a rejuvenation for Blackman after playing with a team that lost 60 games last year. The trade also fulfills his teen-age dream of playing for the Knicks in Madison Square Garden.
"My dad used to bring me to the basketball games -- we didn't have the best seats; we were pretty high up," said Blackman. "You could only see 10 people running up and down the court; you really couldn't make anybody out. But at least we were at the Knick game.
"Of course, the applied pressures are greater here in New York. But the up side can be greater, too. For me the most important thing is being consistent."
A few changes have been made in New York in Blackman's absence. When he left the city for Kansas State in the fall of 1977, Ed Koch was elected Mayor and the Knicks were coming off a 40-42 season in which they failed to make the playoffs.
Fifteen years later, the city has its first African-American Mayor -- David N. Dinkins -- and the Knicks suddenly find themselves perhaps one point guard away from challenging Chicago for the Eastern Conference championship. In other respects, Blackman is returning to a city whose basic personality has remained unchanged. New York continues to be an expanding fabric of ethnic diversity with each group jockeying for elbow room and fighting to attach its signature to the city's political, cultural and economic tapestry.
Just as he has followed the Knicks' various ups and downs, Blackman has followed the city's social turmoil. Earlier this week he and his wife, Tamara, and one of his three daughters, 9-year-old Valarie, arrived in New York to the news of violence in Washington Heights in the aftermath of the shooting death of a Dominican man by a New York City police officer.
"It's like a little war going on here," said Blackman, who is vice president of the N.B.A. players association. "Communities are trying to come together and achieve peace, but it's just not happening. You have unrest in Manhattan. You have it in Queens. You have it in Brooklyn. It's not like everything is peachy keen and wonderful. In my basketball world it is. Outside of it, people are struggling and dealing with real life. I'm aware of that."
In addition to the athletic gifts he is expected to provide, Blackman may provide a needed intellectual presence to a team that is aspiring to a higher plane and to a city that could use enlightened perspectives from as many avenues as possible. "I don't know how I can help, but I know I'm going to be part of that effort to get out there and help," he said.
For a number of reasons, Blackman seems to be returning to the right place at the right time.

HEADLINE: Review/Opera;
Kirov's National Style, Before Homogenization

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH

 BODY:
It is hard to know how to judge musical performing groups from Russia and Eastern Europe these days. Although distinctive national vocal and instrumental styles have already largely disappeared in the West (and how might the earlymusickers bring those back?), much variety of coloration and accent still survives in the former Soviet bloc. But it probably cannot long endure in an era of heightened interchange with the West, despite the frenzied nationalism of the moment.
Under the circumstances, with so many venerable traditions in danger, it becomes too easy to adopt a skewed esthetic for a company like the Kirov Opera, setting aside relatively bland international standards of excellence and seeking Russian-ness for its own sake (though not mere provincialism of the sort displayed this year in New York by the St. Petersburg National Opera). But of course, the Kirov and other companies are entitled to their international aspirations as well and can only be judged accordingly. So there is little for the traditionalist to do but luxuriate in the remnants of the great national sounds where they can still be heard. 
 Fortunately, the Kirov's first performance of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov" at the Metropolitan Opera House, on Thursday evening, offered a wealth of national flavor in the singing and playing. At the same time, it met the highest current international standard. Indeed, it was remarkable in this house to hear such evenness of casting and such strength in the minor roles.
The production, directed by Andrei Tarkovsky with additional staging by Stephen Lawless, had less to offer. The dinginess of the single set, designed by Nikolai Dvigubsky, probably stemmed as much from the economic realities faced by the company and the exigencies of touring as from an attempt to suggest the woes of a nation decaying under Boris's rule.
In any case, the dinginess was concealed by washes of smoke in the prologue, affording the coronation scene a semblance of grandeur, and it never hampered the real work of the opera, carried out in the individual characterizations and crowd scenes. Its economy, in fact, brought to mind the Met's own production of Mussorgsky's "Khovanshchina," which was conceived on the cheap but has served as the backdrop for some stirring evenings.
Mr. Dvigubsky's costumes were lively, and the lighting added brilliant effects. There were few props to speak of, although the human "statues" in the Polish garden lent a nice touch of whimsy. On the other hand, ponderous symbols fell heavily, notably a mammoth pendulum, replacing the clock whose chiming unhinges Boris.
Compared with the Borises usually encountered in this house, imposing of voice and stature, Nikolai Okhotnikov seemed at first a lightweight, but he quickly won listeners over with the power and the expressivity of his characterization.
Gegam Grigorian, as the Pretender Dmitri, fell short of a few high notes but rang out spectacularly on others. Olga Borodina sang Marina beautifully. Sergei Leiferkus was exquisitely despicable as Rangoni, and Mikhail Kit carried Pimen's part with strength and dignity. Other considerable vocal pleasures came from Tatyana Kravtsova's Kseniya, Larisa Dyadkova's Fyodor and Nikolai Putilin's Shchelkalov.
Vladimir Ognovenko proved a delightful comic actor as well as a sturdy bass as the vagabond monk Varlaam, and Vladimir Solodovnikov gave an affecting portrayal of the Simpleton. For the rest, the vocal and theatrical work was solid, even down to the brief appearance of the two Jesuit priests.
But the real stars of this show were Valery Gergiyev's orchestra and chorus. Only in the choral work could purists find any of the nasal stridency that used to characterize so much Russian singing in high registers and grate on the Western ear. The orchestral winds, too, lacked most of the swagger once typical of Russian playing, but the strings gave off a haunting darkness. In general, the playing substituted a wonderful pliancy for the machine-tooled precision usually heard from the Met pit.
Mr. Gergiyev, using the re-orchestration by Dmitri Shostakovich, included almost all the music Mussorgsky wrote for his two main versions of the work, but he kept things moving nicely. His careful preparation was evident in the way even the most unwieldy scenes held together in surroundings unfamiliar to most of the performers.
"Boris Godunov" will have its four last performances next week with varied casts.
 
 
 
Boris Godunov
Opera in four acts and a prologue by Modest Mussorgsky; libretto by the composer after the tragedy by Aleksandr Pushkin and "The History of the Russian State," by Nikolai Karamzin; conductor, Valery Gergiyev; directed by Andrei Tarkovsky; designer, Nikolai Dvigubsky. Performed by the Kirov Opera at the Metropolitan Opera House.

HEADLINE: Adirondacks Will Remain a Wilderness Without More Rules

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Last Stand for the Adirondacks?" by John B. Oakes (Op-Ed, June 19): As the editor of Adirondack Life magazine for more than three years, and owner of a camp in the Adirondacks, I can testify that regulations galore exist to protect and preserve the Adirondacks. The sole purpose of the large and hard-working Adirondack Park Agency is to administer those regulations. 
 More regulations are not needed. Developers aren't waiting to tear up the woods. If the current legislation is not passed, the Adirondacks will not lose their wilderness character.
State Senator Ronald Stafford, who represents the Adirondacks, is doing what an elected official is supposed to do in a democracy: follow the wishes of his constituents, who are against additional regulations.
Outside the villages of Lake Placid and Lake George, the Adirondacks lack "intense speculative pressure," in boom times or recession. The reasons for lack of speculation: (1) no potential for profit; (2) an abundance of regulations; (3) the long distance from New York City; (4) long, cold winters, and (5) black flies.
In the last decade the populations of the only two counties entirely in the Adirondacks, Essex and Hamilton, have stayed the same or declined. Very little building, including second homes, is going on anywhere. Adirondack Park is there for everyone in this state, including those who live there, to enjoy.
 
JEFFREY G. KELLY
Altamont, N.Y., June 20, 1992

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Tourism After the Riots

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD; ROBERT REINHOLD is chief of the Los Angeles bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
ONLY a few days after the riots and arson that wreaked havoc on Los Angeles in April, a group of intrepid Italian tourists rebelled during their Starline Tour of movie-star swankiendas in Beverly Hills. They told the bus driver they preferred to see riot wreckage, and he obligingly wheeled around to the charred hulks of what had been shops in Koreatown, where the passengers happily snapped pictures of the blackened rubble.
The riot had become a kind of tourist attraction in the land of make-believe, a real-life mirror image of the fake mayhem Hollywood studios stage for celluloid and television. But if one tour group took a certain perverse curiosity in the terrible events that followed the acquittal of four Los Angeles police officers in the beating of Rodney G. King, the same cannot be said for the Japanese or most other visitors to the Los Angeles area. 
 The tourism and travel industry in what is the largest hotel market in the world with 86,000 rooms is struggling to recover from a body blow, and the experts say it could take years to return to pre-riot levels. While tourism always suffers after natural calamities, such as the 1989 earthquake in the San Francisco area, studies have shown that violent civil and political disorders have a much more lasting effect on travel plans than natural upheavals.
The June 28 earthquake -- whose epicenter was in the high desert near Landers, 125 miles east of Los Angeles -- is a case in point. Although it was the biggest quake in California in 40 years, reaching 7.4 on the Richter scale and underscoring fears of a major quake in the city itself, it did relatively little damage for its size. Hotel and resort operators in Palm Springs and other desert resorts just south of the epicenter said it had only a fleeting effect on bookings and business. There were cancellations for two days, then business quickly returned almost to normal.
The immediate effects of the riots were dramatic. With graphic televised news reports that carried terrifying images of murder, burning and looting on the streets of Los Angeles throughout the world, visitors canceled by the thousands in the first few days. Even those who went, or were there, found little to do, hemmed in by a five-day curfew that kept most restaurants, clubs, shows and movie houses shut at night. By one estimate, the city lost $146 million in direct spending by out-of-town visitors, mainly in downtown and Hollywood, during just the first five days.
At the Hollywood Tour and Gift Shop, next to the fabled Mann's Chinese Theater on Hollywood Boulevard, business during the first month or so after the riot was down by 75 percent, with a loss of as much as $50,000 a day in sales of movie kitsch. Downtown, the New Otani, a Japanese-owned hotel that caters mainly to visiting Japanese business people, lost half its normal occupancy in May, though it picked up substantially in June. Hotel occupancy in Los Angeles in May and June was 50 percent, down 15 percent from March, the month before the riots, and down 20 percent in May and June of 1990, the Convention and Visitors Bureau reported. (In this period in 1991 figures were depressed by the Gulf war.) Actually, the occupancy rates in May-June this year would have fallen by about 40 percent had it not been for the thousands of National Guard troops accommodated in hotels.
Japanese business at the landmark Yamashiro Restaurant, in a massive Buddhist temple-like structure on a hill overlooking Hollywood, has been slow, according to Thomas Y. Glover, the owner. It is not only visitors who are nervous. Mark Peel, a co-owner of the fashionable Campanile restaurant on South La Brea Avenue near Hollywood, says that many of his regulars from the affluent Westside have avoided the restaurant because when they exit the Santa Monica Freeway they must drive along a stretch of La Brea Avenue that was looted and burned in the riots. But Californians have continued to visit attractions like Disneyland -- 30 miles south of downtown Los Angeles -- that are not near areas affected by the riots.
If there has been a gradual recovery in recent weeks, local officials are uneasy about the summer high season for Los Angeles tourism -- already recession-stricken -- and for the long-term prospects. After the riots, the Convention and Visitors Bureau commissioned a special report from the San Francisco consulting firm Economics Research Associates. The report said that, before the disturbances, tourism generated $16.6 billion a year in direct and indirect economic activity in Los Angeles County, including $3.6 billion in incomes and the equivalent of 196,000 full-time jobs.
THE study estimated a decline in foreign tourism of 30 to 40 percent this summer and forecast a loss of $1.1 billion in visitor spending and 31,000 jobs over the next year. Over the long term, a decline of 15 to 25 percent and a loss of 14,000 jobs was forecast. As for domestic tourism, the report anticipated less damage, 15 to 25 percent in the short run, 5 to 10 percent in the long term. The task of repairing the image will be hardest among foreign tourists, who account for 22 percent of the visitors and a far greater share of the spending; most, 700,000 a year, are Japanese.
"We were their principal gateway into the country, so the imagery from civil disturbances is really punishing," said Michael Collins, vice president of the Los Angeles Convention and Visitors Bureau. "People in Osaka saw burning streets and violence on their TV screens with 'Los Angeles' written underneath. Our challenge is to show the scale, to show the large areas where this did not happen, and it will take a year or two to do that."
Indeed, the average visitor to the Los Angeles area will, like the Italians on the bus tour, have to go out of his way to find evidence of the disorders. The hardest hit areas, South-Central Los Angeles and Koreatown, are off the beaten tourist path. There was substantial looting and arson in Hollywood -- along Hollywood, Sunset and Santa Monica Boulevards -- but that has mostly been cleaned up now. Some visitors, along with Angelenos, were caught in the terror of the initial outbreaks of violence, but they were not a particular target. No hotels were burned or looted. The glittery boutiques on Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills, which now cater mainly to Japanese tourists, are as over-priced as ever. f
But none of this is likely to soothe fears quickly. "The travel industry's vulnerability to capricious and volatile events is immense," the economic report stated. "Violent acts of nature or manmade disturbances can create total disruption, upheaval and chaos to the tourism industry. The quest for paradise -- or just a fun place -- suddenly transforms into a dangerous journey that most travelers would rather avoid."
The economists compared the impact of crises on four other destinations heavily dependent on foreign tourism: Fiji after the coup in 1987, Sri Lanka during the Tamil uprising that intensified in 1985, China and Hong Kong after the Tiananmen Square protests and killings in 1988, and the San Francisco earthquake in October 1989.
In the first three cases, all involving civil unrest, the study found "rapid and long lasting" drops in foreign visitors compared with the levels expected had each area maintained its share of tourism growth for the Pacific area. The decrease was more than 30 percent for Fiji and Sri Lanka, 22 percent for China and 12 percent for Hong Kong. By contrast, San Francisco tourism had returned to normal a year after the quake.
The actual impact on Los Angeles will not be clear for some time, but this summer's high season should provide a good indicator of how severe the damage is. During other seasons, local tourism accounts for most of the traffic at such attractions as the Universal Studios Tour and Disneyland, and that has been largely undeterred. But the summer trade is more heavily dependent on out-of-towners. Tour operators report that Japanese visitors are hesitantly returning, particularly if business calls. Japanese tourists are more cautious, either opting for other destinations like Hawaii, Florida and the Caribbean or, if they still come to Southern California, choosing hotels far from the riot areas in Anaheim, Santa Monica and the Century City area.
Hotel and tourism leaders have begun the daunting task of trying to neutralize the searing television images seen worldwide. Within 24 hours of the outbreak of violence, the Convention and Visitors Bureau started to issue soothing communications by telephone and fascimile to such organizations as the American Society of Travel Agents, the United States Travel and Tourism Administration and the American Bus Association. The messages said the area's visitor attractions were unaffected and open for business. Similar messages were given to airline reservations systems, to Canadian tour operators and American consular offices abroad.
THEN, a week after the riots, bureau staff members fanned out to key foreign markets, meeting with tour wholesalers and airline officials in Japan, Korea, Australia, Britain, Germany and France. A week later, Disneyland was host to a group of visiting journalists from Britain, Germany and Italy who "spent a full day in Los Angeles, 14 days after disturbances began, to experience local attractions, restaurants and sightseeing opportunities first hand," to quote a release from the Convention Bureau. The theme park paid for the visitors' trip. In addition, the bureau took a topographical map exhibit of Los Angeles County to a major international travel meeting "to help orient the trade and pinpoint area attractions." The map presumably was meant to show how far the attractions were from mostly black and Hispanic South-Central Los Angeles where the worst unrest occurred.
Just how effective all this will be remains to be seen. Los Angeles is quiet now, with a veneer of normality covering deep-seated racial tensions. Over the next several months more trials are scheduled: for the one police officer still under charges in the Rodney King beating and for hundreds charged with arson, assault, theft and murder in the riots. The response to these verdicts will have as much to do with the capacity of Los Angeles to resume its tourism role as the fantasy getaway land as anything the fretful hotel and tourism people can do.

HEADLINE: DANCE VIEW;
'Romeo and Juliet' Filtered Through Socialist Realism

BYLINE: By Anna Kisselgoff

 BODY:
The big sleeper of the Kirov Ballet season was the revival of Leonid Lavrovsky's "Romeo and Juliet," created in 1940. Common wisdom had it that Lavrovsky's remarkable fusion of mime and dancing would look old-fashioned, that this Socialist Realist epic with decadent aristocrats pitted against "the people" could no longer be taken seriously.
Surprisingly, this once-controversial treatment of Prokofiev's score (seen in New York with the Bolshoi in 1959) was a superb revelation all over again. Here was dramatic realism made marvelously bold and conveyed through a choreographic style totally different from that seen in the West. In dance-dramas like Antony Tudor's, body language symbolizes psychological truths. (A fall might telegraph an emotional collapse.) In this "Romeo and Juliet," a gesture communicates its meaning directly. Yet such movement is never naturalistic but is incorporated into a gestural flow. The Juliet of Galina Ulanova, with her seamless line, introduced this sculptural and supple silhouette to the West and left hundreds of viewers deeply moved. 
 The Kirov's current leads looked more academic in their dancing, although the Bolshoi-trained Nina Ananiashvili and Andris Liepa, who were guest stars this season at the Metropolitan Opera House, showed genuine passion. Altynai Asylmuratova and Konstantin Zaklinsky were too sophisticated. Alekasandr Gulyayev partnered two Juliets: the lyrical Zhanna Ayupova and the more glittering Larissa Lezhnina. All three tended to be presentational in manner, drawing attention to themselves as dancers, not characters.
While this "Romeo and Juliet," restaged by Oleg Vinogradov, the company's artistic director, focuses on Juliet, there is another main character: the people. Lavrovsky's sure sense of dramatic structure is felt in the first scene, as he builds the action slowly from a spare beginning to an action-filled panorama. Much of the ballet's stunning pictorial impact comes from the sets, which are based on Pyotr Williams's originals. These do not use the checkerboard floor of the Bolshoi staging, and the curtain opens on a classical landscape.
There is no Rosaline, but Romeo, because he enters sleepily, may have been courting. It is morning, and he touches a Bacchus-like statue for luck. The town square begins to stir with activity. Three wenches plunge into a folk dance with Capulet men, who bar the path of two Montagues. Brilliantly, economically, this provocation sets the scene for the clan strife that explodes into highly animated dueling.
The interior scenes are danced against the simulated richness of Renaissance frescoes and tapestries. Juliet's playfulness with an ambling nurse is cut short momentarily by her haughty mother, penetratingly portrayed by Nina Mikhailova, who orders her daughter to meet Paris.
As much as Lavrovsky meant to bring out the aristocracy's decadence, the Kirov currently exaggerates some telling scenes. En route to the Capulet ball, a husband storms out after finding his wife in the arms of another man. A vain Paris preens before a mirror held by a page and ignores a handkerchief dropped by an admirer. The page picks it up and blows a kiss.
Later, in Act II, three women in men's clothing, all part of traditional Renaissance fun, come reeling in with Tybalt and his friends and kick a fruit seller.
The ballroom scene is resplendent. In a huge fresco, Europa is seen sitting astride her bull while below the Capulet banquet is in full swing amid goblets, tables and dazzling candelabra. Tybalt stands atop one of the tables, which are cleared for the now-legendary dance of the cushions. The Capulets advance with pillows, kneel on them and grab their partners in a voracious embrace.
The classical idiom, reserved until now for Juliet in her first scene, is expanded in her duet with Paris and later in her first encounter with Romeo. The image that Miss Ulanova made famous and which recurs in the lovers' other duets is seen here for the first time: Romeo lifts Juliet so that she is kneeling on his chest and looking down lovingly at his face.
A classical divertissement by seven troubadours and Juliet's friends leads into a moment that is surely one of the ballet's dramatic highlights. Juliet is told that Romeo is a Montague: Tragedy is foreshadowed by her reaction.
Miss Ananiashvili brought her hand to her mouth in horror and bowed her head. Miss Lezhnina looked dazed. Miss Asylmuratova closed her eyes. Miss Ayupova needed time for the thought to sink in before tilting her chin upward in determination.
The two key pas de deux for the lovers amplify the motifs of their first duet. But vivid contrasts color the second act. Revelers cavort on a terrace above the square, which becomes filled with colorful folk dances and a jesters' quintet. On the other hand, Friar Laurence's cell is austere, and Romeo strews lilies in Juliet's path before he marries her.
This version leaves no doubt that Tybalt kills Mercutio on purpose, and the best characterizations came from two different performers. Dmitri Korneyev made Tybalt a lout. Gennadi Bababin was more aristocratic and sardonic. When Lady Capulet, sitting on Tybalt's body as it was carried aloft, swore revenge, the townsfolk below cringed at the promised violence.
Indeed, the Soviet dance historian Yuri Slonimsky saw Lavrovsky's theme as "the unequal struggle waged by the children of tomorrow against the injustice of yesterday." Lavrovsky's stroke of genius consisted of his never losing sight of the love story while placing in it an interpretive social context. We might not agree with that context, but he gave the death of Romeo and Juliet a dimension that most Western versions omit. He reconciled the clans at the end and thus remained true to Shakespeare.

HEADLINE: New Federal Law For the Disabled Slow to Take Hold

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
WHEN the Americans With Disabilities Act took effect in January, it was heralded as a revolutionary Federal civil rights law that would radically revamp commercial real estate, removing many of the countless barriers that block the physically handicapped from moving throughout restaurants, offices, hotels, airports, theaters and myriad other privately owned places open to the public.
The day after the law took effect, groups representing the disabled in New York City began filing complaints with the Department of Justice against the owners of the Empire State Building, the Hotel Inter-Continental and other properties for failing to comply with a key provision that requires people who own or operate places of "public accommodation" to remove architectural barriers if the changes are "readily achievable." 
 In the last six months, however, most of those first complaints remain unresolved, the number of new ones has swelled, and businesses, landlords, real-estate companies and the disabled are all questioning the efficacy of the law, which was passed by Congress two years ago.
The most vexing problem appears to be defining "readily achievable."
" 'Readily achievable' is not a particularly high standard, and it is very vague," said Brian Diamond, a Manhattan lawyer who specializes in advising landlords on how to comply with the law.
"From the perspective of an owner attempting to comply," Mr. Diamond said, "you are given very little guidance in what it means."
To be sure, many property owners and their tenants -- both parties are liable -- have improved access for the disabled or are making sincere attempts to comply with the law's voluminous and somewhat arcane guidelines.
Last month, for example, the owners of the Hotel Inter-Continental, at 111 East 48th Street, agreed to build a ramp to make the building accessible from the street. They also agreed to other structural changes, including making the restaurant, bar, bathrooms and public telephones accessible to the disabled.
"It is an example for the hotel industry to follow in making their facilities truly hospitable to their guests with disabilities," said Herbert Semmel, an attorney with non-profit New York Lawyers for the Public Interest, which is representing Disabled in Action, a civil rights organization.
For the most part, though, the impact of the law is not yet what its proponents had hoped. "There will be good faith efforts to comply, and others will have to be pushed," said Deborah B. Beck, the executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York. She also said that the troubled economic times made compliance even more difficult for many property owners.
"The recession, coupled with the fact that there is a real liquidity crisis in the marketplace, not enough capital to do improvements, means that this is an environment where people are looking at profit margins and saying we cannot spend this money," she said. "Compliance will be a slow, gradual process. The responsible owner of office properties wants to make them accessible, but the constraints of the marketplace are such that it will be unlikely that there will be a massive infusion of capital going into A.D.A. work."
The costs may be particularly high for some older buildings, such as the Empire State Building.
"IN many office buildings, the corridor sizes in the primary entrances are of a dimension that would be considered in compliance," Ms. Beck said. "The major problems that occur are in vertical transportation. Some older buildings, particularly wedding-cake-shaped buildings, are not accessible because they sometimes have a floor at the top that encloses the top of the elevator shaft, and those upper floors are accessed by a stairway. In a more contemporary building, such as the World Trade Center, it is accessible."
The six-month-old, unresolved complaint against the Empire State concerns three flights of stairs that keep most disabled people from entering the 86th-floor observatory, gift shops, bathrooms or snack bars, which can be reached only by stairs. Though the 102d floor is accessible to the disabled by elevator, the observatory on that floor is not. The structural barriers on this floor, however, are not part of the complaint.
"The only thing that could possibly be done to enable someone to look at the view from a wheelchair is build something that they could wheel up on, and I don't think there is enough floor space to do that on the 102d floor," said Cary LaCheen, staff attorney with the New York Lawyers for the Public Interest. "That's why it is critical that the 86th floor be made accesible."
Joseph J. Carella, a spokesman for building, said its owners, Helmsley-Spear, would not comment until the complaint was resolved with the Justice Department. "We are looking to resolve this as soon as possible," he said.
Mr. Carella added that signs have been placed throughout the building that direct people in wheelchairs to where they can get access information or assistance. He said that some disabled persons, if they are able to stand, could, with the help of building personnel, maneuver the stairs. He also said that those unable to stand could be lifted up and down the stairs.
"The building makes every attempt to assist the visitors," he said.
Mr. Semmel, however, has been sharply critical of the Empire State Building owner's actions. The new signs are misleading, he said, "because someone would get the impression that there is some way to get up into the towers, where, in fact, they can't." He added that carrying the physically disabled up and down the stairs was "totally unacceptable" because it was not only an indignity but also increased the likelihood of an accident for which the landlord would be liable.
Mr. Semmel also said that the Empire State Building owners were refusing to negotiate a settlement, attempting to delay compliance and hoped to force an expensive legal battle. He added that the situation had been exacerbated by the length of time the Justice Department has been taking to investigate the complaints.
"They aren't going anywhere because the Justice Department doesn't have the staff to handle them," he said. "They have hundreds of complaints from all over the country, and they have to check everything out themselves."
SINCE the law took effect the Justice Department has received 286 complaints from around the nation; most deal with physical barriers in existing structures. The complaints, all but a handful of which are ongoing, are being investigated by eight lawyers and two architects. Three more lawyers are expected to join the staff within a few weeks. The department has requested an additional nine lawyers for the fiscal year that begins in October.
John R. Dunne, the assistant attorney general for the civil rights division, said that it was not overwhelmed by complaints.
"Right now, we feel it is under control," he said. "What the future will bring we can't be sure, but we have made a request to Congress for additional personnel."
The ratio of lawyers to complaints is about the same for other civil areas the Justice Department investigates, he said.
He also defended the length of time the department has taken investigating most of the complaints. "One complaint might be six weeks, another a year," he said.
Thus far, penalties for violating the new law -- which is only one section, Title III, of a sweeping anti-discrimination act -- can be levied only against large companies. Businesses with 25 or fewer employees and gross receipts of less than $1 million do not have to come into compliance until July 26. Businesses with 10 or fewer employees and gross revenue of less than $500,000 do not have to comply until next Jan. 26.
The new Federal law does not apply to residential buildings. But residential buildings do fall under the city's five-year-old Local Law 58, which imposes obligations on landlords to increase accessibility for the handicapped when a building is being renovated or altered, or if the building is newly constructed. Existing walk-up buildings, as well as one- and two-family homes, are exempted.
The city's strict local law also applies to commercial buildings and areas of public accommodation that are being renovated or newly constructed.
Unlike the Federal law, though, it does not mandate making existing areas of public accommodation accessible to the disabled where "readily achievable."
"There are many, many buildings already in compliance," said Jerry Lieberman, a senior vice president for property administration with Olympia & York Companies (USA). "The local law here is so stringent that little needs to be done."
In multi-use buildings that are primarily residential but have some areas of public accommodation, such as a laundry or a restaurant, the areas of public accommodation must comply with the new Federal law while the residential areas will continue to fall under the local law.
Thus, the principal impact of the Federal law will be on existing privately owned buildings that offer public accommodation. In these, existing architectural or communications barriers must be removed if the removal can be "readily achieved" without significant difficulty or expense.
There are no estimates on how much it costs landlords to bring areas of public accommodation into compliance, but the expense is substantial.
"You could easily spend $100,000 plus redoing a restroom," Mr. Lieberman said.
COST aside, one of the biggest questionmarks about the implementation of the law is how the phrase "readily achieved" will be interpreted. The law does say the cost of doing the work and the financial wherewithal of the owner should be considered when disputes over compliance arise.
"What a mom-and-pop grocery store might have to do is different from what Macy's might have to do," said Robert Boehlert, the counsel for the state Office of the Advocate for the Disabled.
Mr. Diamond noted that there is no certification process.
"We have been unable to get architects and consultants to tell us where readily achievable ends," he said. "You always want to comply. But you may not want to overcomply, and the vagueness of the law makes that very difficult."
And, he added, regardless of how much good faith a building owner may show, building owners might still end up in litigation.
The law allows an individual who has been subjected to disability discrimination, or who has reasonable grounds to believe that he or she is about to be discriminated against, to bring a civil action in court. In addition, the Department of Justice is authorized to investigate any alleged violations of the public accommodation provisions of the act and sue violators. If the owners or operators are found in violation, they can face fines up to $50,000 for the first offense and $100,000 for subsequent violations of the same offense.
Mr. Diamond also noted that those penalties might be dwarfed by legal expenses and the cost of a court-ordered redesign and construction.
"The law certainly has its troubles, but, hopefully, over time, these things will get hammered out," he said. "Any compliance law takes time to evolve over judicial hearings.
"Owners, though, should be in a position to know what is readily achievable and not readily achievable," he added. "And landlords should make sure that tenants comply because the burden is on both of them, irrespective of the fact that the landlord has written a lease that says the tenant is responsible. The A.D.A. gives the Department of Justice the right to look at both jointly."
Mr. Diamond noted that banks will also inquire about compliance with the law before lending money for a building renovation or construction.
"WE have been advising our clients that compliance is their responsibility," he said. "One would hope that eventually, even without the Department of Justice seeking enforcement at every opportunity, every building will fall into compliance just because of the increased business risk."
Several large New York City landlords, such as Olympia & York and Chase Manhattan Bank, have begun surveying their properties to determine what they will have to do to comply with the law.
Amy Sudol, a spokeswoman for Chase Manhattan, said that the new law has prompted the bank to hold sensitivity training sessions for employees who encounter the disabled and install TTDs -- telecommunications devices for the deaf -- in service areas. The bank has also recently added a ramp to the main entrance at Chase Manhattan Plaza on Cedar Street.
"We have tried to work with the handicapped to see what their needs are," Ms. Sodol said, noting that the bank has met with the Lighthouse, a nonprofit organization that supports the disabled.
Olympia & York has also made some structural changes in response to the new law.
"We are putting signage in place, changing doors, adding Braille characters," Mr. Lieberman said. "These are safety issues, and they have to be addressed. Besides, it makes a lot more sense economically to address these issues now, rather than later."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Regional Competition;
How David (Westchester) Beat Goliath (Connecticut)

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
IN what has been described as a "slugfest," Westchester County recently went toe-to-toe with Connecticut in a fight to hold onto a multimillion-dollar corporation that was looking to expand outside of the county.
In the end, Westchester scored a knockout. JWP Inc., a multinational technology company, agreed to lease 78,000 square feet of office space in the village of Rye Brook for its world headquarters and other operations, despite an offer of more than $3 million in relocation perks by Connecticut. 
 "It was important for us to keep this company," said Norma Drummond, an economic development specialist for the county's Office of Commerce and Economic Development. "With this move, the company will triple its square footage and bring new people and jobs into the county."
JWP, a New York Stock Exchange company with holdings in electronics, mechanical equipment, computers and information services, had revenues of $3.6 billion last year. It plans to move in August into a structure vacant for five years in the six-building Royal Executive Park, on King Street.
"With this lease, the first two phases of the development are now fully occupied," said Anthony P. Grant, chief executive officer of London and Leeds Development Corporation, the project's developer. "We're now looking at the third phase of the development, which would be for 345,000 square feet. We have the outline for the site plan, but don't know when we'll start on that."
JWP will vacate its current site in Purchase, where it leases 30,000 square feet for its corporate headquarters. That operation, with 125 employees, will move into the new Rye Brook building. It also will relocate its voice and data unit from Canton, Mass.
"The company wanted to bring down 225 people, but now it looks like only 125 employees will be relocating," said Ms. Drummond. "So some new jobs will be created."
The story of the county's fight to keep JWP testifies to the lengths local governments will go to these days to retain or attract business.
The effort began last February when JWP first approached the county. "They alerted us they were in the very preliminary stages of relocating to Connecticut or expanding in Westchester," Ms. Drummond said.
The company looked at buildings in Stamford and Greenwich, and was offered financial incentives, including the entire cost of relocation, for a total of more than $3 million, said Margaret S. Soter, director of Westchester's economic development agency.
In the last year and a half, Connecticut has stressedjob retention and creation. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker has made jobs his top priority. As a result, the state's Department of Economic Development has an array of loan and grant programs available to help businesses looking to expand in or relocate to the state. A spokesman for the agency declined to specify the incentives offered.
In contrast, Westchester seemed ill-equipped to compete, with few financial incentives in its arsenal.
When apprised of JWP's intentions, the county's economic development agency promptly got touch with Alfred B. DelBello, former lieutenant governor and Westchester County Executive, who now works as a private lawyer and unpaid consultant to the county.
"He's called the czar of the county," said Salvatore M. Cresenzi, Mayor of Rye Brook. "He knows a tremendous number of people and was really the catalyst to the whole negotiation."
Mr. DelBello worked in conjunction with the economic development agency, the Village of Rye Brook and the Town of Rye, in a coordinated attempt to persuade JWP to stay in Westchester. They could not find a state program that would induce a company to stay, according to Mr. DelBello, "especially when you're trying to compete against an offer like Connecticut's."
All they really had was bonds issued by Westchester's Industrial Development Agency, but since JWP decided to lease instead of buy, these did not apply. So they had to create something.
"YOU have to let a company know that you love them," Mr. DelBello said, "and you have to create a pro-business climate for them to operate in."
The major financial component of the eventual deal offered to JWP was a 33 percent reduction in property taxes on the Rye Brook buildings, to $534,000 a year from $784,000, retroactive to last year. Technically, that reduction goes to the owner of the buildings, which in this case is London and Leeds. But, said Mayor Cresenzi, "we were given an ironclad guarantee that those savings would be passed on to JWP."
In addition, the county is going to help JWP relocate its employees. "We're looking into what educational grants might be available to them, and we're going to help with other quality-of-life issues," said Ms. Drummond.
Despite Westchester's best intentions, some companies do cross the border to Connecticut, lured by offers they feel they can't refuse.
"We recently moved a few companies from Westchester," said Joseph M. Cohen, the spokesman for Connecticut's Department of Economic Development. "I can't say their names because they haven't made an announcement yet. Very few companies leave Connecticut for Westchester."
Purdue Frederick Company, an international pharmaceutical concern, announced last month that it would be moving its research and development division from Yonkers to a 156,000-square-foot building in Norwalk. The company already has several associated companies in Connecticut, with a total of 300 employees.
"We wanted to have our research facility on the same site as our corporate headquarters," said Howard R. Udell, the company's group vice president and general counsel. "The Connecticut building met our needs for the future."
THE move is expected to bring 100 to 125 new jobs. The state and the City of Norwalk offered the company incentives worth more than $2 million, including a flat-out reimbursement of $1 million in relocation costs.
The other $1 million will be garnered mainly from local property tax abatements and corporation tax credits.
Governor Weicker said that the Purdue Frederick deal "is a tremendous credit to the economic recovery package Connecticut has put in place to rebuild business and industry and provide a job to everyone who wants one."
Aside from the financial perks, a major component in the company's decision was the desire to consolidate its operations in a familiar environment.
The same could be said of JWP's decision to remain in Westchester. Most of the company's top executives already live in the county, and it would have been "disruptive ot our employee base" to move to Connecticut, according to a company spokesman.
Some people believe that companies are taking unfair advantage of the current economic downturn by threatening to relocate to gain financial incentives.
One multinational chemical company, the Loctite Corporation, pointedly declined public-sector assistance when it decided to build a new corporate headquarters and research and development facility in Rocky Hill Ken Butterworth, chairman of Locite -- which expects to add 40 to 50 people to its current workforce of 540 -- said Connecticut has "more pressing needs, than providing taxpayer dollars to profitable corporations."
Whether JWP would have remained in Westchester without the financial perks provided by the county was a risk no one wanted to take.
"When a company like that says they're going to leave the county, you can't just sit on the sidelines," said Rye Brook's Mayor Cresenzi. "You've got to do something."

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
Darien Gets a New Chinese Restaurant

BYLINE: By PATRICIA BROOKS

 BODY:
THE economy may stumble but chances are there will always be a new Chinese restaurant opening.
One of the most attractive to do so in recent months is Li's Brothers Inn in Darien. The restaurant, which occupies a large space in the Good Wives Shopping Center, is obviously a serious enterprise, not a neighborhood chop suey parlor. Frosted glass panels at the entrance lead into a spacious dining room with a pale plum patterned wallpaper, Chinese art and lacquered wainscoting. A green and rose carpet, well-spaced tables with comfortable high-back chairs and tapes of soft Chinese music add to the dining experience, which is enhanced considerably by an unusually considerate and well-trained staff. 
While all this merely sets the table for the main event -- the food -- it does indicate a purposefulness. When the menus appeared we were ready. Unfortunately, the offerings are much the same as so many Chinese restaurant menus, with the usual bases touched: General Tang's chicken, Hunan lamb, moo goo gai pan, Peking duck, moo shu pork and various seafood, poultry, pork, beef and vegetable dishes. It is a very large menu augmented by a short printed list of daily specials. One addition that should be welcome news for Sunday brunch fans: there are nine different dim sum choices with pictures of each, a help to those who wish to sample but are unfamiliar with or forgetful of the specific names.
We concentrated on the regular menu, succumbing to just one seasonal special, which turned out to be the best dish of all: sauteed soft-shell crabs. If you like these molted-shell blue crustaceans to begin with, we think you will find Li's Brothers Inn's rendering exceptional. The crabs were fried lightly to the crunchy stage, then cut into large segments. The legs were as delicate and wispy-crisp as good shoestring potatoes and the body portions were equally tasty. With the order came a small dish of sweet garlicky dipping sauce. It was an exemplary entree.
Also flavorful, if less memorable, was an order of crispy beef with orange flavor, though as is too often the case, the large pieces of beef were unable to be handled with chopsticks. Crispy whole sea bass, swathed in an assortment of finely chopped vegetables (scallions, carrots, et al), was deftly deboned by our waiter and proved meaty and moist, not desiccated as is frequently the case elsewhere. Both dishes, though, were gently seasoned, not hot and spicy as the red stars on the menu promised. In fact, we had specified that we wanted all starred dishes very spicy, a request that never made it to the kitchen. Inasmuch as the menu's subhead is "Hunan and Szechuan cuisine," one would expect that "hot and spicy" would be the norm. Something has been lost in translation.
Among appetizers, the sesame wontons, topped with chopped scallions, were winning. The steamed dumplings had good flavor and a tangy, creamy sesame sauce, similar to the one that enveloped our order of cold sesame noodles, which was another satisfying starter.
We could have done without the canned pineapple cube and maraschino cherry at the tip of each skewer in our order of Szechuan marinated beef, but the meat itself was tender and well-seasoned (though not spicy). For those who like spring rolls, the Li's Brothers' version had the advantage of fresh-tasting ingredients. That wasn't the case with fried Peking dumplings, which had thick casings and the taste of a frozen product.
Dinner for two came to $31.50 and included two courses each (no dessert) before beverages, tax and tip. There is a full bar but as is always the case with Chinese food, the preferred drink is Tsingtao beer. For comfortable dining, agreeable food and an ingratiating staff, Li's Brothers Inn brings a refreshing new dimension to Darien. There is a take-out menu as well. Li's Brothers Inn also has a cash-only take-out place (Broad River, Norwalk, on the Norwalk-New Canaan line) with four tables where one can eat in on trays with paper plates and plastic utensils. Fair warning, though: the food, while supplied in gargantuan portions, is several notches below the Darien restaurant's standard.
 
Li's Brothers Inn
Good
25-48 Old King's Highway North (Good Wives Shopping Center), Darien. 656-3550.
Atmosphere: A large, modish dining room with pale plum wallpaper, lacquered wood wainscoting, Chinese artifacts and taped music, well-spaced tables nicely appointed.
Service: Unusually attentive and helpful.
Recommended dishes: Sesame wonton, Szechuan marinated beef, cold sesame noodles, crispy whole fish, sauteed soft-shell crabs, crispy beef with orange flavor, shrimp and scallops with garlic sauce.
Price range: Lunch entrees $4.75 to $5.75, dinner entrees $6.25 to $13.95.
Credit cards: American Express, Discover, Mastercard, Visa.
Hours: 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. Monday through Friday, noon to 3 P.M. Saturday and Sunday, 3 to 10:30 P.M. Monday through Thursday, 3 to 11 P.M. Friday and Saturday, 3 to 10 P.M. Sunday.
Reservations: Accepted.
Wheelchair accessibility: Ground-level access.

HEADLINE: Showdown Looms on Sports Betting

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
LIKE a tied ball game in the closing minutes of play, the battle over sports betting in New Jersey's casinos has intensified in recent weeks as each side in the debate goes all out against its opponent.
With time running out to place on the November ballot a state constitutional-amendment referendum on sports betting, the opposing sides have stepped up their efforts to highlight either the economic advantages or the moral pitfalls of permitting gambling on sporting events. 
 Proponents say that legalized sports betting will bring increased revenue to the state through the Atlantic City casinos and will undermine the widely acknowledged illegal gambling that now takes place on sporting events. At the very least, they say, residents should be given an opportunity to make up their own minds on the issue by voting on a constitutional-amendment referendum in November.
Opponents, however, say that if sports betting undermines anything it will be the integrity of professional sports and the enjoyment that fans derive from wholesome competition unfettered by financial incentives. They say that legalizing sports betting will actually increase illegal gambling activities and will send a signal to youths that such activities are socially acceptable.
The debate comes as Congress contemplates Federal legislation that would ban sports betting except in states where it is now permitted. One bill under consideration provides a one-year "window of opportunity" for New Jersey to adopt the necessary constitutional amendment, but that opportunity could be missed if the Legislature fails to place the question on the November ballot by the end of this month.
"This either happens soon or it doesn't happen at all," said Thomas D. Carver, president of the Casino Association of New Jersey in Atlantic City. The organization, which represents the interests of the state's 12 casinos, has mounted an aggressive campaign in support of legalized betting on sporting events.
"All we want is for the people to vote on it," Mr. Carver said. "And we have reason to believe that they will support our position."
Proponents of sports betting have some hurdles to clear, however, if they are to see the practice legalized in New Jersey.
 
Two Bills Before Congress
 There are now two bills before Congress on sports betting. One, which was co-sponsored by Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, bans sports betting except in those states where it is already permitted. That bill has passed the Senate. The other bill, which has been passed by the House of Representatives, would similarly ban sports betting, but provides New Jersey with the one-year "window of opportunity."
Sports betting proponents say that the best way to insure that the state can take advantage of that provision would be for the Legislature to pass a resolution in time to put the amendment on this November's ballot. To comply with state law, that would have to be done by Aug. 3.
A resolution that calls for the referendum is now ready for a vote in the Senate, which has only two scheduled sessions in July -- on the 20th and the 23d.
Under the resolution, the state's voters would be asked in November whether they want to amend the State Constitution to allow sports betting in the Atlantic City casinos. Patrons at the casinos could place bets, in person, on the results of most sports events. Specifically prohibited, however, would be those events involving nonprofessional or educational organizations principally situated in the state.
If the resolution passes the New Jersey Senate by a three-fifths majority, it would then have to pass by the same majority in the Assembly, which is scheduled to meet only on July 23.
 
'The Clock Is Ticking'
 "The clock is ticking," said Assemblyman Robert W. Singer, Republican of Lakewood and a supporter of a referendum on sports betting. Both he and State Senator C. Louis Bassano, Republican of Union and sponsor of the Senate resolution, expressed reservations about the likelihood that the resolution will make it through both houses in such a short time period.
The casino gambling industry, however, sensing that this might be its last chance to get sports betting approved for Atlantic City, has organized a vigorous campaign to persuade legislators to give voters the opportunity to express their views on the issue.
Sharon Gordon, chairman of New Jersey Cares, a New Brunswick-based coalition that supports sports betting, said her organization was running radio advertisements and mailing 830,000 brochures to voters across the state urging them to ask their legislators to support the resolution.
"This is not something that should be decided in Washington," Ms. Gordon said. "This is a decision that should be left to New Jersey voters."
Ms. Gordon said that legalizing sports betting would also undermine the illegal betting that now takes place.
"There is sports betting going on all over the place," Ms. Gordon said.Legalizing the practice, she said, "regulates it and puts some of the money into New Jersey's coffers."
 
Opposed by Coalition
 Opposed to legalized sports betting, however, is the Coalition Against Sports Betting, a group of individuals and organizations including the New Jersey Sheriffs' Association, the New Jersey Council of Churches and the Garden State Athletic Conference. The coalition has started a campaign of its own with radio advertisements and mailings proclaiming the theme "Don't Gamble With Our Children's Heroes."
Gary R. Bettman, senior vice president and general counsel of the National Basketball Association, a member of the coalition, said that legalized sports betting "puts the game and the players under a cloud of suspicion." It also, he said, "changes our fans into 'point-spread' fans" who are predominantly concerned with the game's ultimate point differential, regardless of who wins or loses.
The point spread is the number of points by which a particular team is favored to win. A favored team must "cover the spread," or beat its opponent by the point spread, in order for a person betting on that team to win the bet. For example, a bet placed on a team favored by 5 points would be a losing bet if the team won by only 4 points.
"The players are adamantly opposed to it," Mr. Bettman said. "If you miss a shot at the buzzer and don't cover the spread, all of a sudden you're a bum."
 
Sports Betting in Las Vegas
 Mr. Carver, president of the casino association, pointed out that sports betting is legal in Las Vegas and that the professional sports teams seem comfortable with the practice.
Moreover, he said, making sports betting legal in New Jersey is essential if Atlantic City is to remain competitive with Las Vegas, which now books as much as $1.7 billion a year in sports bets. In fact, he said, if sports betting were allowed here, New Jersey could end up booking twice the amount that is bet in Las Vegas.
"We're sitting in the middle of 32 million people who can be here within an hour," Mr. Carver said. "We could do $1.7 billion in half a year, minimally."
If Mr. Carver's estimates are accurate -- they are fiercely disputed by his opponents -- then $3.4 billion bet on sporting events in a year could result in as much as $100 million in gross revenue for the casino industry from the sports bets alone. That, along with a projected 10 percent increase in other gambling revenue generated as a result of having sports betting, could amount to a total increase in revenue of as much as $400 million.
 
Money Would Help the Elderly
 Of that amount, Mr. Carver said, $32 million would go to the Casino Revenue Fund, which finances programs for senior citizens and the disabled, and $5 million would go into Atlantic City redevelopment. In addition, he said, one thousand new jobs would be created, casino vendor purchases in the state would increase by $30 million and $20 million more in sales and payroll taxes would filter into the State Treasury.
The total amount of money that the state could realize each year from legalized sports betting and its spinoffs, Mr. Carver said, could be as much as $127 million.
But William L. Stringer, an economist and former Deputy Treasurer of New Jersey, says the potential for increased state revenue is at best exaggerated and more likely nonexistent.
A study done last month by Mr. Stringer indicates that sports betting would not make any net contribution to state revenue and could, in fact, produce a net loss. He said the state would probably process about $715 million in sports betting as opposed to the $3.4 billion anticipated by the casino industry. His lower estimate was based upon the current ratio between total dollars bet in Atlantic City and the amount now bet in Las Vegas.
And any money spent on sports gambling in New Jersey, Mr. Stringer said, would draw from funds now being spent on consumer purchases in general and on other forms of gambling like casino games, horse racing and the state lottery. At the same time, he said, money spent on sports betting would produce far less revenue for the state than the same amount spent on the state lottery, for example, or the sales tax.
 
Study Says Loss Could Occur
 Mr. Stringer estimated that sports betting would result in either no increased revenue for the state or a loss of about $5 million, depending on its actual impact on consumer spending.
Arnie Wexler, director of the Council on Compulsive Gambling of New Jersey, said that even if economic benefits were derived from sports betting, they would not compensate for the problems that state-sponsored gambling creates.
"We're going to see an increase in illegal gambling," Mr. Wexler said. "That's what happens when you legalize this stuff." In fact, he said, illegal betting on sporting events among compulsive gamblers has already increased from 29 percent in 1987 to 51 percent in 1991, according to a study his organization has conducted of gamblers calling the council's compulsive-gambling hot line.
That, he said, will increase if sports betting is legalized. "You get people who never gambled before going into a casino to make a bet on their favorite team," said Mr. Wexler, whose organization accepts calls from compulsive gamblers at 1-800-GAMBLER.
The increase in illegal betting occurs, he said, when those people then discover that if they cannot get to a casino they can get better odds, generous credit and the convenience of betting by telephone, from local bookies. And to make matters worse, Mr. Wexler said, many of those most intensely interested in sports betting are youngsters of high school age.
"And what are we telling these young kids?" Mr. Wexler said. "We're telling them: 'Don't worry about winning or losing; let's worry about the point spread instead.' We're telling them that what's really important is the payoff."
