HEADLINE: Chrysler's New L/H, as in Last Hope

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
Live, from Chrysler Corporation headquarters in Highland Park, Mich., it's "Who Are We Anyhow?" Before an audience of hundreds of its advertising-agency people, Chrysler has brought in actors and stage props to produce the mock game show. The contestants are three couples who epitomize the ideal customers for a new line of three midsize cars on which Chrysler is staking its future. They answer questions about their tastes in everything from houses to magazines and reminisce about their first important cars. For one couple, it was a '57 Chevy for him, and the '60 Impala convertible she was driving when she met him.
The play-acting in Chrysler's auditorium last summer dramatized some deadly serious business for the nation's No. 3 auto maker. It is part of a three-pronged marketing campaign intended to win back a lost generation, buyers who have abandoned an auto maker that many associate with boxy, boring cars, sell-at-all-costs discounting, and corny pitches by Ricardo Montalban boasting of Corinthian leather interiors. 
 The company's make-or-break task is to persuade buyers to forget the past and snap up the new cars, which Chrysler began producing last week. The new line, code-named the L/H, comprises the Dodge Intrepid, priced at roughly $15,000; the Chrysler Concorde, around $25,000, and the Eagle Vision, at a still-to-be-announced price somewhere in between. The three, to be rolled out this autumn, have been widely praised by automotive enthusiasts. If they succeed, they could singlehandedly make Chrysler a financially stable company; if they bomb, Chrysler might never recover from the blow to its credibility.
"There's no way to overemphasize the importance of the L/H," said Laurel Cutler, vice chairman of the FCB/Leber Katz advertising agency and a former vice president of Chrysler. "If it was built by Ford or Toyota it would be the sensation of the decade. The issue is will people trust Chrysler? Trust takes years to win and seconds to lose."
 
Scrapping an Image
 The first step in the company's strategy is to use advertising, starting with a campaign last fall, to overcome Chrysler's reputation as a corporation of stodgy designs and old-fashioned, short-term thinking. For buyers who agree to reconsider Chrysler, a second wave of advertising, to start this fall, will focus on the three L/H models. Each model is aimed at a different kind of customer, as defined in the mock game show. Finally, Chrysler is undertaking a far-reaching retraining plan for employees and dealer personnel, aimed at eliminating the all-too-familiar hassles and indignities of car shopping.
The training and marketing campaigns, on top of the $1.6 billion spent to develop the cars, are lavish for a company whose pension fund is $4 billion short of solvency, whose bonds are rated as junk and whose losses last year totaled $795 million. The joke in Detroit is that the company is spending money as if it actually has it.
Chrysler executives bristle at the oft-made quip that L/H stands for Last Hope, asserting that the letters actually represent nothing in particular. But the fact is that the models represent Chrysler's last, best chance for stability. Chrysler hopes to sell 225,000 L/H models annually, on top of the roughly half-million cars it already sells. (All told, the company currently sells 1.5 million vehicles a year.)
Chrysler's Jeep and mini-van models have been money makers, but have not been able to offset the results of money-losing car lines. No auto maker expects to make much money on small cars, but midsize and large models can be quite lucrative -- as long as selling them doesn't require $2,000 rebates like those Chrysler offers for its hapless Imperial sedan.
But the L/H is important to Chrysler for another reason. The company has yet to prove that it can build a car that is equal, in substance and status, to the best Japanese and European competitors. By and large, its best and most successful models in the 1980's, like the Eagle Talon, were made with the help of the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation. Now that relations between the two companies have cooled, Chrysler must demonstrate competence on its own.
The three new models portend a radical departure from the doughty Dodge Dynastys, Chrysler LeBarons and Plymouth Acclaims, which inspired sneers and yawns from automotive enthusiasts. They have been been praised by magazine reviewers for improved handling and engine performance, tasteful aerodynamic styling and a design that makes them much roomier than earlier models, without a significant increase in exterior dimensions.
Wall Street apparently likes the cars as well. In the past year the company's stock price has more than doubled, to around $20, reflecting a positive reaction not only to Chrysler's new Jeep Grand Cherokee but also the glowing reviews of the L/H prototypes.
 
After Iacocca
 But convincing younger, affluent customers will be a chore worthy of Hercules. The buyers Chrysler will be trying to lure with the L/H have come to regard midsize models like the Honda Accord, Toyota Camry, Nissan Maxima and Ford Taurus as the standards of measure. These shoppers may be particularly skeptical of Chrysler's importunings, recalling that Lee Iacocca & Company permitted car development to languish while raking in fat paychecks and investing in non-automotive acquisitions like Gulfstream Aircraft.
One big reason for Chrysler's current financial struggle is that the company relied too long in the 1980's on models using a single basic chassis, known as the K platform. At first the K car fared well, but sales dove as customers migrated to other brands, and Chrysler's only success stories of late have been its mini-vans and Jeeps.
Chrysler officials acknowledge that their brands have grown bland and indistinct. In a similar way, the General Motors Corporation stumbled during the 1980's partly because key car models and brands were perceived as clones of one another. Instead of drawing from diverse pools of consumers, four or five G.M. models would attract only a single type of customer, so sales were weak.
The Ford Motor Company, conversely, scored a marketing victory by proving it could sell the similar Taurus and Sable models to two audiences, a middle-of-the-road buyer for Taurus and a more affluent buyer for Sable.
Chrysler's challenge, then, is to successfully differentiate its three L/H models.
So the mid-priced Eagle Vision will be shown in settings that appeal to young families who listen to public radio but don't watch much TV except for cable programs, are better educated than buyers targeted for the other two models, and have two wage earners. They aspire to an Audi or Lexus, but can't afford one yet.
Chrysler marketers view the buyers of the Concorde -- and the New Yorker, a slightly larger version to be built starting later this year -- as the oldest and most affluent of the three target groups. They may include the oldest baby-boomers, who owned imports but now are looking for something larger and more comfortable. And they might otherwise buy a Pontiac Bonneville or a Mercury Sable.
Dodge Intrepid buyers, Chrysler hopes, will be more numerous than those for the other two models, ranging in age from mid-30's to 50. They might otherwise buy a Honda Accord or a Pontiac Bonneville.
 
Getting the Word Out
 Conveying the message is the job of the Chrysler's three advertising agencies -- Campbell-Mithun-Esty for Eagle and its Vision, BBDO for Dodge and its Intrepid, and Bozell Inc. for Chrysler-Plymouth and its Concorde. Chrysler won't comment on the content of the ads, which are just now in production.
But it is clear that the company is pursuing a more affluent consumer and will sell its cars on the basis of their styling and performance, rather than cut-rate pricing. In the past, Chrysler's customers, less educated and of lower income, were "less frequently in the market and got knocked out quickly in times of economic weakness," said John Schnapp, a consultant with Temple, Barker & Sloane in Boston.
Selling buyers on a particular Chrysler brand will not work unless they can be made to trust the company behind the brand. "We did literally thousands of hours of research with import buyers in California," said John Damoose, Chrysler's vice president of marketing. "They said, 'You have to convince us you have re-invented your company.' "
Enter the corporate image campaign that began last fall. In 1989, Chrysler had thoroughly reorganized engineering and planning in order to speed model development, improve quality and lower costs. "We were changing the way we made our products and that required us to tell that story for the benefit of products that were coming and for the confidence of the public," said Ron DeLuca, who was vice chairman of the Bozell advertising agency until his retirement last year and continues as a Chrysler consultant.
 
'The New Chrysler'
 So Chrysler and Bozell have run a series of ads that proclaim a "new Chrysler" even before the new L/H models arrive. One showed the demolition of the old Jefferson Avenue plant in Detroit. Another was filled with aerial views of the $1 billion Chrysler Technology Center in Auburn Hills, Mich. The Dodge Viper, a sexy two-seat roadster built in limited numbers to give Dodge a racy image, starred in another ad.
In the campaign and in messages to the automotive press, the company has explained why it switched to flexible product teams, the system favored by Honda, Toyota and others. The L/H models are the first to be developed from start to finish by a team -- and were done in three and a half years, record time for Chrysler.
As Chrysler marketers discussed how to convince buyers that the company had indeed changed, they commissioned research on whether Mr. Iacocca would still be an appropriate spokesman. After all, he had been at the helm when many mistakes took place, but "research showed people still related to him in the same way, with a high degree of recall and awareness," Mr. Damoose said.
The decision: Mr. Iacocca's ad appearances will dwindle as he nears his Jan. 1 retirement. (Robert Eaton, who came from G.M. earlier this year to replace Mr. Iacocca as chairman and chief executive, has no plans to appear in the advertisements, a spokesman said.)
Finally, Chrysler is working with its dealers to improve its appeal. Lexus, under Toyota, and Saturn, under G.M., have earned their popularity not only because of their cars' intrinsic appeal but because of their dealers, who pamper customers with well-trained salespeople, loaner cars, free fill-ups and washes, tasteful decor and home delivery of vehicles. Most important, customers tend to favor dealers who seem to be fair if and when the price is negotiated.
However, many dealers still rely on high-pressure negotiating tactics. As independent franchisees, they are free to choose their style of retailing. Chrysler executives fret that those who don't become more like Lexus and Saturn dealers could drive away prospects for the L/H with ruses like "highball" bids for trade-ins (used as a come-on but offset by inflated prices for new cars) or "lowball" offers on new cars that are later withdrawn. Not to mention the notorious "closing rooms," where specialists to whom salespeople refer customers are paid according to how many people they can browbeat into signing contracts.
"We believe it is time for our dealers to undergo change, and the timing is right because of the introduction of the L/H," said Theodor R. Cunningham, executive vice president of sales and marketing. This month, Chrysler is undertaking a $30 million program to teach some 100,000 workers at its 4,900 dealerships how to deliver better service. To underscore the program's seriousness -- compared with scores of previous, more modest efforts -- the automaker's top 200 executives, including Mr. Eaton, will attend classes.
 
Lessons From the Ritz
 Chrysler studied companies like Walt Disney and Ritz-Carlton Hotels to find out how they achieved reputations for pampering customers. Chrysler and an ad agency, Ross Roy, spent 18 months formulating the training program, which employs techniques like role-playing to dramatize the need for empathizing with customers. In a typical drill, a Dodge mechanic might pretend he is a bellhop trying to calm an irate guest. The idea is to allow the employee to experience a difficult situation for himself rather than simply be lectured on it.
While dealers applaud Chrysler's push to satisfy customers, their support is tinged with skepticism. For it is the dealers who have really borne the brunt of customer anger.
"It seems like when new cars get launched and the company announces programs, they go on for the first month and then there's no follow-up," said Mark Cassidy, sales manager of Ed Barwick Chrysler-Plymouth in Napa, Calif.
Whatever Chrysler can accomplish through ads and dealers, its executives realize their best friend is positive word-of-mouth. So several hundred L/H cars will be lent to "opinion leaders" -- doctors, lawyers, politicians, teachers -- in 25 cities in the hope that after a few days' test drive, they will laud the car.
In an attempt to insure quality, Chrysler will build only 50,000 L/H cars through the end of 1992. This could cost the company sales if demand is strong. At the same time, the three car divisions will have an excellent opportunity to sell every car and avoid the embarrassment of dealer lots jammed with unsold inventory, requiring the rebates and other incentives that have haunted so many Chrysler models of yesteryear.
 
 
 
GOOD PREVIEWS, BUT WILL THE LOOK FLY?

Automotive enthusiast magazines, important shapers and predictors of consumer opinion, have almost unanimously bestowed rave reviews on Chrysler's new L/H line for its roominess, handling, engine performance and styling. Automobile magazine couched its description in messianic terms, deeming the model a harbinger of "Chrysler's Second Coming."
Chrysler's L/H line embodies a radically new configuration. The cars are wider than previous Dodges and Chryslers of the same class; at the same time, the passenger cabin is moved forward over the front wheels and the rear wheels are moved farther to the back. To accomplish a stretching of interior space, the windshield is enlarged and tilted backward at a more extreme angle. The technique, used first by Japanese automakers in models like the Honda Accord, devotes about 15 percent more space to passengers and cargo than did in previous models.
By widening and lengthening the car, engineers encountered the problem of how to make the body torsionally rigid, so that rolling and swaying were minimized. "We found the competitive vehicle with the best torsional rigidity, benchmarked its tautness and proceeded to beat the standard," said Dennis N. Renneker, Chrysler executive engineer for large-car platforms.
Engineers also improved the mechanical wheel suspension systems to improve handling. Mr. Renneker said the L/H's suspension "is a better package than our competitors'," which Chrysler says will include no less than the Lexus LS 300, Nissan Maxima and Acura Vigor.
Chrysler has also moved toward quieter, more powerful and more fuel-efficient engines by redesigning many components.
Although the automaker wishes to maximize sales by reaching three groups of buyers, the three L/H models look, at first glance, very similar. Auto makers typically create several models from a common chassis by creating different exteriors or sheet-metal "skins" and different interiors.
About 88 percent of the sheet metal panels of the Dodge Intrepid and Eagle Vision differ. About 50 percent of the the Chrysler Concorde panels differ from those of the other two models. By mixing color combinations, plastic cladding along the lower half of the body, headlights, tail lights and wheel coverings, the appearance among the three models has been differentiated as much as possible. But there is still the danger that a customer for the most expensive model will migrate to the cheapest one.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1284 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/July 5-10

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
The World's Richest Nations Are Too Poor to Party at Munich
 

The heads of state of the world's richest democracies plus Russia were in no mood to party last week at the economic summit meeting in Munich. What put these world leaders in such a snit was what President Francois Mitterrand of France called "the morose state of the world economy." All the nations in attendance were either in recession or struggling to emerge. They were in no condition to be generous. The deadlock on trade -- the United States wants Europe to end subsidies on grain exports -- remained in place. The seven nations did extend a hand to Russia, but not without a reproach. They decided to channel $1 billion in aid to Russia as part of a comprehensive partnership. ("I didn't expect more," said the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin.) But then they added a testy warning: no more money unless Russia pursues reforms more vigorously.
 
Picture-Perfect V.P.?
 
There were no driveway interviews with prospective running mates at the Governor's mansion in Little Rock, Ark. But the "podium picture" -- the wide-angle shot of the full Democratic ticket with families in tow -- was a consideration in the choice of Senator Al Gore of Tennessee as Gov. Bill Clinton's choice for Vice President. Analysts said Mr. Gore will strengthen the ticket's appeal in the South, where President Bush and undeclared candidate Ross Perot are strong. And with Mr. Gore's record on the environment, his grasp of scientific issues and support for high-tech and space research, he is likely to add to Mr. Clinton's appeal in the West. Mr. Gore is also savvy about the ways of Washington. While Mr. Perot had kind words to say about Mr. Gore, the Republicans were not quite so charitable. The choice -- said Rich Bond, the Republican national chairman -- was a "dud."
 
Detroit Accelerates
 
Detroit has been languishing in the slow lane for months. But late last month, at least two of the Big Three managed to step on the gas. Sales of North American-built vehicles surged by 23.9 percent in late June, the auto makers reported. But while Ford's sales were up 30.7 percent and G.M.'s by 18.4 percent, Chrysler moved 12.2 percent less metal than last year. After a spate of rave reviews in the buff books and consumer magazines, sales of Saturns, G.M.'s import fighter, soared to 20,000 last month. That pushed the two-year-old Spring Hill, Tenn., Saturn factory to the limits of its capacity, arousing speculation that Saturn might soon need another plant.
 
Fewer Jobless Claims
 
A little good news on the jobless front -- but it's the word little that needs the emphasis. The number of new claims for unemployment insurance fell by 4,000 in late June, the Labor Department said last week. Though the drop in new claims is welcome, the economy still has too little punch, economists say, when it comes to job creation. Last month's jobless numbers are "consistent with other data that the economy has lost some of its earlier momentum, but keeps moving higher," said Robert G. Dederick, an economist with the Northern Trust Company of Chicago.
 
Fear of Higher Prices
 
One benefit of having an economy without much oomph is that nervous suppliers are reluctant to raise prices. They don't want to scare away the few customers they have left. That was evident last week when the Labor Department released its Producer Price Index for June, which showed that prices at the producer level rose by a negligible 0.2 percent. That converts into a 2 percent inflation rate on an annual basis. Most of the increase was accounted for by rising energy prices. "Throw out energy and you don't have any inflation," said Donald Ratajczak, an economist at Georgia State University.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Girding for Future Bank Scandals
 
It took more than a year for them to get together, but last week the world's top banking regulators met in London to hammer out new rules to prevent a repeat of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International scandals. B.C.C.I. has been accused of massive wrongdoing in several countries, including charges of bilking depositors out of billions of dollars. The regulators decided that if a bank based in a country where the regulators are weak -- like Luxembourg, where B.C.C.I. was headquartered -- is suspected of committing crimes in a country where regulators are strong -- like the United States -- the strong regulators can initiate an investigation.
 
No Accord on Nuclear Safety
 
The leaders of the seven wealthiest nations meeting in Munich failed to reach an accord on ways to assure the safety of aging nuclear power plants in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Amoco's Turn for Layoffs
 
When the Amoco Corporation said last week that it would eliminate 8,500 jobs -- 15.7 percent of its work force -- it was the latest in a series of large-scale layoffs gripping corporate America. Since April, six of America's largest companies -- Exxon U.S.A., Hughes Aircraft, Aetna, Chevron, Digital Equipment and Alcoa -- have eliminated more than 23,000 jobs. Amoco attributed its cuts to sluggishness in the global economy and the need to downsize its operations. "This is a significant move," said Eugene L. Nowalk, an oil analyst at Dean Witter. The company said the cuts would result in $600 million in before-tax savings by the end of 1993.
 
Seldane's Safety Questioned
 
Hay fever sufferers who take Seldane got a jolt last week. Not only did the Food and Drug Administration tell Marion Merrell Dow Inc., which makes the drug, to warn doctors that Seldane can cause irregular heartbeats and even death, but two law suits filed in Federal court in Kansas City allege the company knew of the problem for two years. The suits say the information was withheld to keep the company's stock price from falling. The company said it would defend itself "vigorously" against the charges.
 
Patching Up Continental
 
Continental Airlines has been bumping along under the protection of Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code for more than a year. Last week, when it agreed to accept a $350 million offer for majority control from Charles E. Hurwitz, the Houston investor, it put itself on the path to recovery. Continental, which has $700 million in pension-fund liabilities, still must obtain court approval before it reorganizes under Mr. Hurwitz.
 
The Tinsel Frays for Japanese
 
The buzz in Hollywood is that when Japan's big electronics companies -- the Sony Corporation and the Matsushita Electrical Industrial Company -- bought into the studios, they got more than they bargained for. Instead of neatly managed businesses, they bought lots of chaos and loads of high-priced but temperamental executives. Columbia Pictures, owned by Sony, and MCA Inc., owned by Matsushita, brought out a string of money-losing flicks like last year's "Hudson Hawk." As a result, Tokyo told the studios to stop developing projects, some agents say. Tinsel town's ruling elite dismisses the talk. "It's patently not true to say we've stopped developing," said Mark Canton, Columbia's chairman.
 
Chalk Up One for Airbus
 
Lately, the most vicious dogfights in the air have been between the Boeing Company and Airbus Industrie, the European aerospace consortium. Last week the aces at Airbus scored a hit. United Airlines said it would lease 50 two-engine Airbus A-320's. Though it's uncertain if Airbus will make a profit, the deal gives it a renewed American presence. "It's a move of big strategic significance," said George Shapiro, of Salomon Brothers.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
A New President Signs On At a Downsized Dataquest

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Like the personal computer industry it provides market research to, Dataquest Inc. has been through some lean times recently, marked by layoffs and the lack of a president for nearly a year. Last week, Judith H. Hamilton, who has spent 26 years in computer services and software, was chosen to fill the empty slot. A unit of Dun & Bradstreet, Dataquest is based in San Jose, Calif.
As a former buyer of consulting services, Ms. Hamilton said she knows consulting is often among the first things cut back during recessionary times, which makes it all the more important to offer exceptional service. Companies "don't eliminate it, but they do go for best of breed," she said. The computer industry "is going through a real sea change right now, and there are all kinds of indicators that service providers have to go through the changes as well." 
 Ms. Hamilton, who is 48, comes to Dataquest from the Locus Computing Corporation of Los Angeles, where she was senior vice president and general manager of the systems division. She was previously a partner at Ernst & Young, where she was national director of market development, information services.
Dataquest has "had the trims and is positioned now to begin anew in a growth mode," Ms. Hamilton said. "It's a nice position for me because the cutting was done before I got there." She said she sees new opportunities for Dataquest in the coming together of computing, communications and consumer electronics products, and in the growing globalization of these businesses.
"Some of the merging of these technologies will provoke interesting changes in the computer industry that will be reflected in the research concerns," she said. "More and more people want information on world markets," she said, adding that this plays to Dataquest's strengths, because 70 of its 450 employees are analysts working abroad.

HEADLINE: The Unquiet Future of Commercial Health Insurance

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
New state laws aimed at insuring that older and sicker people get affordable medical coverage are expected to accelerate a shakeout in the $108 billion commercial health insurance industry.
The most recently approved law, passed in New York this month, requires insurers to accept any individual or small business that applies and charge the same rate regardless of age, sex and health history. Vermont, Maine and Oregon have recently approved less stringent versions of this approach, and Hawaii has long had a similar system. Other states are considering such proposals. 
 Many insurers predict that the state laws will force out some companies, particularly smaller ones with limited resources or large ones with only small numbers of customers in the state. Such companies have in the past been able to "cherry pick" the healthiest applicants and offer them coverage at a lower price, leaving the older and sicker customers to other insurers or without coverage. Now that they must accept all comers, these insurers will have to raise their rates, and many of the younger, healthier customers might decide to drop their policies.
Insurers with small numbers of customers could be hurt much more severely than a large insurer by someone with a costly illness like cancer. The larger insurers can not only spread such a risk over more customers, they also benefit from economies of scale in administration.
No company has left New York, where the new law does not take effect until April 1993. But Aetna Casualty and Life, for example, stopped selling to small employers in Vermont, where it had only a few such customers. And Chris Petersen, senior counsel for the Health Insurance Association of America, a trade group with 300 members who have 80 percent of the business, predicted that there would be fewer commercial insurers in New York.
Under the New York law, the state will now have to grant approval of rates for the commercial insurers, so it is too early to know how much policyholders' rates will rise and how they will react.
But Mr. Petersen said the law would mean higher rates for more than half the 500,000 New Yorkers with individual and small-group coverage from commercial insurers, and that 165,000 of them might decide to drop their coverage.
Emily Crandall, a vice president of the Guardian Life Insurance Company, which with about 100,000 people in New York is one of the state's bigger insurers of small groups, said her company had not decided whether to stay in New York, where it has 20 percent of its customers. "We are not a public utility," she said. "We have a business to run."
People who work for large employers, which usually insure themselves and use insurance companies only as administrators, are not affected by the state laws. And most health-maintenance organizations already accept all applicants at uniform rates even without the state laws.
In contrast to New York, 33 states have approved limits on rate increases for customers with expensive illnesses. Most big commercial insurers say they can live with the limits.
The new state laws are only the latest problem confronting the smaller insurance companies. They are also losing business to larger insurers who can afford to organize "managed care networks" that sign up doctors and hospitals with an eye to limiting medical cost increases. Squeezed by soaring medical costs as well, some companies have left the health-insurance business entirely, others are pulling out of certain states and some have stopped insuring individuals or small groups.
"The smaller companies are history," said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a health-care analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. "They don't have any buying power" to influence hospitals and doctors. He predicts that 50 insurance companies and 400 health-maintenance organizations will control the health-care system in 15 years, compared with 300 companies and 550 H.M.O.'s that now have most of the business.
Analysts said the new laws have not yet had a discernible effect on profits. Most insurance companies have a number of lines of business, including life and property and casualty as well as health insurance. Insurance stocks have been buoyed recently by general economic trends including lower interest rates, according to Denis Callaghan, at Alex. Brown & Sons.
The Health Insurance Association of America says health insurance is not very profitable. The 20 largest companies reported combined losses on their health insurance underwriting every year from 1986 to 1990, the latest available year, the association said. Adding income on investments, the companies still had a combined loss in 1987 and thin after-tax profits the other four years.
Between 1987 and 1991, 72 health insurance businesses failed, says A. M. Best, the independent insurance-rating organization. The shakeout is evident in three major sectors: managing care for larger self-insured employers, insuring small groups and insuring individuals.
Having lost their risk-taking role to the self-insurance plans that most large employers have adopted, large insurers have been transforming themselves into managed-care companies.
But the networks require heavy startup investments for computerized information systems and recruiting campaigns. As a result, Lincoln National, Equitable, American Express and Transamerica have pulled out of managed care altogether. Analysts say the strongest companies remaining are Prudential and Metropolitan Life, which are mutual insurance companies owned by their policyholders, and Cigna, Aetna and Travelers, which are publicly traded.
Only Cigna, Prudential and Metropolitan Life announced profits in managed care last year. Mr. Callaghan at Alex. Brown said Aetna's H.M.O.'s and care networks should become profitable later this year. Travelers stopped breaking out its managed care results in 1990 after several years of losses.
Sixteen smaller companies, including Northwestern National Life, CNA Financial and Pacific Mutual, are sharing costs and profits as partners in a joint managed-care firm, Private Healthcare Systems Ltd., based in Lexington, Mass.
Travelers, Principal Mutual Life and the Employers Health Insurance unit of Lincoln National are the strongest companies in insurance for small groups, usually defined as fewer than 25 employees. "The small groups are where the growth opportunities are," said Brian Quigley, a Travelers lawyer. Travelers has just bought the national small-group business of Paul Revere, covering 200 employers and 15,000 people.
The big players in individual-customer insurance are Mutual of Omaha, Bankers Life and Trust, and American Family Life of Columbus, Ga. (selling only cancer insurance). But many companies, including Travelers, Aetna, Allstate and Pacific Mutual, have sold their unprofitable individual-customer lines.
If there is a beneficiary of the new state laws requiring uniform rates, it is the nonprofit Blue Cross and Blue Shield associations, which in states like New York have been obliged to offer coverage to the people rejected by other carriers. These associations lobbied for many of the most stringent new state laws, and they reject the dire predictions that commercial insurance companies will be forced out of the market, leaving many more people uninsured.
 
 
ONE VOTE FOR COMPETITION
 Commercial health insurers, under fire because of rising rates and the fact that more than 30 million Americans are without coverage, are struggling to stave off even greater state and Federal regulation.
Industry spokesmen say that competition is the best way to lower costs and assure quality of care, but critics say the industry spends too much on administration and marketing, driving up the nation's $800 billion in annual health-care spending. The health-insurance industry has identified 120 proposals in 37 states, including New York, that would move toward a "single payer" health insurance system, like Canada's, in which the state pays the bill. Such a system could eventually eliminate all private insurers.
The California Legislature is considering a proposal by Insurance Commissioner John Garamendi that could eliminate many companies by funneling all payments through a few large H.M.O.'s and other insurers.
Congress is also debating proposals that could bring drastic reductions in the number of health insurers. "There's no way we can have significant reform in health care without reducing the number of insurance companies," said Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon. "You cannot rein in health costs if we continue to have 1,500 companies."
There are 1,150 commercial companies that provide medical and disability insurance, 73 nonprofit Blue Cross and Blue Shield associations, and 569 health maintenance organizations.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
A Bet That the Worst Is Over in Japan

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
John Koeneman is back in Japan, a signal that there are some prominent investors who think the worst is over in the world's second-largest stock market.
Mr. Koeneman, who is managing director of Koeneman Capital Management in Singapore, says his computer-driven analysis has given him a green light on Japan for the first time in more than two and a half years. 
 "So far, the methodology has worked very well for us," he said in an interview while in the United States last week, looking for new clients beyond his Australian-dominated core. "The Japanese market may not reach bottom for three to six months. But we cannot find a compelling reason not to adhere to our discipline."
It may not sound like a ringing endorsement of this market whose main index, the Nikkei 225, has fallen 60 percent since its all-time high at the end of 1989. But Mr. Koeneman, whose firm manages a total of about $400 million, has raised the portion of his global portfolios in Japanese stocks from 5 percent in April to 23 percent now.
What changed Mr. Koeneman's view on Japan is his analysis of expected returns from stock markets around the world. This gauge measures growth above a base that equalizes for the different investing risks among markets. It includes price-earnings ratios, the level of the yen against other currencies, interest rates and other factors he said have been crucial in driving stock markets' past performance.
The expected return for Japan has been negative for years. But all of a sudden it is back in positive territory and has swept past the United States, where the gauge is declining. In fact, Mr. Koeneman is getting the money to put into Japan by selling some of his stock in the United States.
Right now the expected-return gauge for the Japanese market is 1.27 percent for the next month, compared with 0.77 percent for the United States. That makes it far better than Germany, which is at 0.19 percent, but not nearly as good as Hong Kong, the go-go market of the year, at 3.77 percent.
But it was enough to nudge him back into the troubled Japanese market. Among the stocks he has bought are Chubu Electric Power, Itoham Food and Hokkaido Electric Power. He also likes the Suzuki Motor Corporation, which he sees as a bet that the export market for four-wheel-drive vehicles to the developing world will be strong. The sectors he likes are domestic Japanese companies, particularly utilities; some exporters, despite the strength of the yen, and consumer stocks, like food companies.
In June, his Tokyo investments fell 5 percent, while the market as a whole, as measured by the Topix index of more than 1,200 stocks, was down 10 percent.
Mr. Koeneman's decision to reinvest aggressively is not swayed by the shaky outlook for corporate earnings in Japan. The Institutional Brokers Estimate System in New York shows that earnings in Japan are forecast to decline for the third year in a row in the current Japanese fiscal year, which ends next March. And some forecasts predict a drop of 25 percent to 30 percent.
These earnings estimates are not a major factor in Mr. Koeneman's calculations. "Whether Japan is attractive or not does not depend on I.B.E.S.," he said. "It depends on the fundamentals and financial variables. Typically, a market will head up before you see an upturn in earnings."
But while Mr. Koeneman's investment direction has changed, others are not budging.
Barton Biggs, the global investment strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company, has been bearish on Japan for some time. He now believes that the Nikkei index could fall as far as 12,000 before the stock market reaches the bottom. That would be another 25 percent plunge from 16,783.72, where the Nikkei closed on Friday. And it would leave the market almost 70 percent below its all-time high.
Mr. Biggs looks at the same information as Mr. Koeneman, but it does not make him optimistic. He acknowledges that the market as a whole "is around fair value," when using 1992 earnings, cash flow and the current level of interest rates.
These indicators, he said, are for normal times. But things are not normal in Tokyo right now. The Tokyo market is not merely in a bear market; it is in a downward spiral. It is in the decline that follows the bursting of a bubble, the ending of a major speculative boom. And by Mr. Biggs's calculation, this process should bring the market down by 70 percent to 95 percent from its all-time high.
At the same time, Mr. Biggs said his Morgan Stanley colleagues in London, who specialize in finding stocks at good values, are buying in Japan again. They too are picking among the export stocks, like the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company. Mr. Biggs acknowledges that some of these export blue chips may be able to hold the line fairly well even as the rest of the market continues to decline.
Mr. Koeneman and Mr. Biggs are both strategists who pick their countries first. They are at the extremes on Japan and picking between them is a choice between process versus caution.
Mr. Koeneman is not being brave. He is following his system, the same rigorous pursuit that got him out of Japan. And he is being very careful in the choice of his stocks and is trying to find the kind of values Mr. Biggs's colleagues are looking for.
Mr. Biggs, on the other hand, doesn't even want to look for value stocks, "even the ones our value guys like," he said. "Are they among the 20 stocks that I'm going to buy for my father? No."

HEADLINE: All About/Ready-to-Assemble Furniture;
As Easy as Joining A to B and C to D

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
"Some assembly required." The words strike fear in the hearts of parents who have struggled to put together toys and of backyard warriors cursing the jigsaw pieces of a new hibachi. But for a growing number of Americans with a screwdriver and some patience, unassembled furniture is that rarity in hard times: an affordable option for sprucing up one's home.
Sales of traditional furniture have suffered in the recession, putting pressure on large manufacturers like Ladd Furniture Inc., which just entered the do-it-yourself market, and Drexel Heritage, now a subsidiary of the Masco Corporation. Some retailers have also been hard hit, with Seaman's, for example, filing for bankruptcy protection. 
 But sales of ready-to-assemble furniture have grown 10 percent a year in the last five years, now accounting for about 10 percent of all furniture shipped out by American manufacturers -- $1.1 billion worth in 1991 (or $1.8 billion at retail), up from $750 million in 1986.
"This is a product where the consumer adds value to the piece," said Jerry Epperson, a furniture analyst for Mann, Armistead & Epperson, an investment banking firm in Richmond, Va. "People like that. They feel like it's a bargain." It is estimated that consumers can save 25 to 50 percent on ready-to-assemble -- "R.T.A." to the industry -- compared with fully assembled pieces.
As demand has risen and technologies have improved, the range of furniture has moved beyond simple television stands and microwave carts. Consumers can now buy entertainment centers that cover half a wall, home office set-ups and even bedroom ensembles in a box.
Most unassembled furniture is still of particle-board construction. But new technology has meant more natural looking wood-like finishes and solid wood moldings -- even such intricate pieces as roll-top desks.
"In the old days, you'd say, 'Oh my God, don't put that in my house,' " said Ray Allegrezza, a furniture writer who concentrates on the R.T.A. market. "Now, you'd be hard pressed from across the room to tell if it's a solid wood piece."

 
 
Humble Beginnings
Particle Board, Born In Postwar Europe
 Unassembled furniture was developed, as were many consumer-product ideas, to alleviate a pressing problem in postwar Europe. After the devastation of World War II, there was a huge need for inexpensive home furnishings. With hardwood in short supply, furniture makers sought an alternative material. They found it: wood chips and shavings, compressed and then covered with stained paper, foil or melamine, a white resin. The new furniture was solid and potentially durable. And it was cheap because the materials were and the customer supplied the labor.
In the United States, manufacturers began experimenting with what they called knock-down furniture in the 1950's. Erie Sauder, founder of the Sauder Woodworking Company in Archbold, Ohio, marketed a snap-together end table that needed no hardware. It cost $9.95 in 1951.
In the 1970's, ready-to-assemble furniture became a function-driven industry, as companies made pieces for every innovation hitting the market. The trend grew stronger in the 1980's as new companies sprang up to provide TV/VCR stands, microwave carts and the surroundings for personal computers. (The second-largest R.T.A. maker, O'Sullivan Industries Inc., is owned by the Tandy Corporation, the computer maker, and sold through another Tandy subsidiary, Radio Shack.) They also began branching out into bookcases, bedrooms and children's furniture.
Prices have risen, naturally; your basic end table may run $39 these days. And some marketing drawbacks remain. Many people still consider particle-board furniture to be of low quality, especially in this country, where wood furniture has always been available at relatively moderate prices.
Thus, unassembled furniture still appeals mostly to younger people or to families furnishing a spare room or a second house.
"I don't think you're ever going to see it as primary furniture you sit on when the preacher comes to visit," Mr. Epperson said.

 
 
The Distributors
Pushing the Boxes At Kmart and Sears
 The real secret to the industry's success may be not in how the products are designed or made, but in how they are distributed.
The furniture is sold most frequently by major discount stores and mass merchants, not by traditional furniture retailers. Discounters like the Kmart Corporation and Wal-Mart Stores Inc. represent 30 percent of the retail market. Mass merchants like Sears and catalogue showrooms take another 35 percent. Discount retailers find R.T.A. pieces easy to handle: show one assembled unit and stack 20 boxed duplicates right next to it.
"You can't sell a set-up six-drawer dresser through Kmart," said Kevin Sauder, grandson of the founder and director of marketing for Sauder Woodworking, now the largest R.T.A. maker in the country.
Right behind the discounters have come home improvement centers, now with 7 percent of the R.T.A. market; membership warehouse clubs (6 percent) and office superstores (9 percent).
One of the most recent mass marketers to jump on the R.T.A. bandwagon is the Sears chain, which gets 9 percent of its furniture sales from unassembled furnishings.
"R.T.A., with its styling, was in the right place at the right time," said Mary Ellen Schumacher, a Sears buyer. "They make it differently than traditional furniture, but it's not any less of a product."

 
 
The Ikea Formula
Pick Out a Room And Drive It Home

If there is one aspect of the ready-to-assemble market that analysts and manufacturers can agree on, it is the Swedish phenomenon called Ikea.
The furniture retailer broke into the American market in 1985 with an enormous blue-and-gold store-cum-warehouse outside Philadelphia. There are now 10 stadium-sized stores in the United States, and the 11th will be opening in the Houston area this week.
Everything about the Ikea concept -- from quirky advertising to in-store signs depicting a talking Allen wrench that explains the do-it-yourself concept -- has helped to bring R.T.A. into the American mainstream.
The chain's total sales in 1991 were $284 million, up 68 percent from 1990, according to a spokeswoman, Pam Diaconis.
Ikea lures customers with splashy, colorful advertising and mailings. The maze-like pattern of its stores insures they see a dozen displays, even if they planned only to look at bookshelves. When a setting catches their eyes, they can take home the whole room -- from the shelves to the tables and chairs to the lampshades -- that day.
It's a concept shared by other specialty stores, like Conran's Habitat, that in total now account for an estimated 12 percent of the R.T.A. market. There is strong logic to it. Surveys show that most people hate the traditional furniture-shopping experience. The pricing and brands are confusing and once consumers have made a decision, they still must wait weeks for delivery.
Immediate gratification, then is one of R.T.A.'s biggest assets, a thought not lost on Ikea. .
"People walk around the store," said Robert Marks, a senior editor and furniture writer for HFD magazine, a home furnishings trade publication. "They find a piece, they strap it into the back of the car, go home and put it together and that afternoon they've got a new piece of furniture."

 
 
A TRADITIONALIST TAKES A FLYER ON THE R.T.A.
 Most times, a corporation with little more than than $400 million in annual sales does not cause much of a stir when makes an $8.4 million acquisition.
But the industry certainly took notice when Ladd Furniture Inc., the fourth-largest furniture maker in the country, best known for its Pennsylvania House line, announced July 3 that it was buying the Fournier Furniture Corporation. Fournier makes ready-to-assemble furniture, and this is the first time a traditional manufacturer has taken an R.T.A. maker into its fold..
Fournier is the fifth-largest ready-to-assemble furniture maker in the country, with sales of $30 million in 1991. It was founded in 1972 by Greg Sammons, originally to cash in on the market for something to put home electronics on or in. Now it offers furniture for every room in the house.
Mr. Sammons, who is staying on as president of Fournier, said the Ladd deal would help his company expand its styling efforts. "We want to bring the whole fashion design flair of the rigid furniture industry into our product," he said.
As Richard Allen, chairman and chief executive of Ladd, sees it, R.T.A. is just growing too fast to ignore. "There is a $15 billion market for furniture out there," he said, "and the distribution is changing."

HEADLINE: Technology;
Getting Nuclear Plants Down to Size

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
For the first 20 years of the nuclear era, reactor designers insisted that bigger was better. But in the last few years, as demand for existing designs dropped to zero, engineers have started fresh and are planning streamlined reactors incorporating advanced technology. Along the way they have rethought their ideas on size, and some people are now disputing the old idea that cheaper power can be achieved through economies of scale.
As a result, the most striking new nuclear designs are for reactors just half the size of the old ones, breaking a long trend of larger and larger plants. The trend began with the first commercial plant, a 60-megawatt generator in Shippingport, Pa., ordered in 1953, and ended with Palo Verde, a plant the Arizona Public Service ordered in 1973, which at 1,270 megawatts is 21 times larger. 
 In contrast, in a few weeks General Electric will submit to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission a safety analysis of a design for a 600-megawatt "simplified" reactor. Westinghouse, a competitor, submitted a design for a plant that size last month.
The two plants, which the industry refers to as of moderate size, are part of a new generation of plants that would rely heavily on gravity, natural heat circulation and other non-mechanical principles to prevent overheating, instead of "engineered safety features" like pumps and valves.
Using such "passive" safety systems sets a limit on size. A 600-megawatt plant, engineers say, can be kept below dangerous temperatures by natural circulation, but a 1,300-megawatt plant cannot. A reactor that makes more use of gravity and natural circulation needs fewer safety-grade pumps and valves, which are very expensive because they must be designed to exacting standards.
The passive design's smaller size may be a virtue in meeting the desires of the customers: electric utilities. According to the Utility Data Institute, a consulting firm in Washington, American utilities will complete 56 non-nuclear generating stations this year with an average size of 54 megawatts, or about the size of Shippingport. Christopher Bergesen, a vice president at the institute, said this average is the smallest in 20 years. Of 25 plants that entered service last year, only 3 were above 600 megawatts. In times of normal electricity demand, a 600-megawatt plant can supply about 300,000 homes.
Nowadays, the nuclear pipeline is nearly dry, with all the plants ordered after 1975 having been canceled, although some plants started before then are still expected to come into service.
The Electric Power Research Institute, a utility consortium in Palo Alto, Calif., undertook a survey in 1982, when the reactor manufacturers started to think about new designs. "We got a strong statement from the utilities that if we could get a unit that was reasonably economic, we'd prefer it to be smaller," said John Taylor, the head of the group's nuclear research program.
The reason is that any power plant order is a bet about how much demand will develop in the future, and a smaller reactor is a smaller bet. "You have less uncertainty in terms of projecting electric demand," Mr. Taylor said.
In the 1970's, many utilities rushed ahead with large reactors when the price of oil jumped. But as electricity prices rose, the demand for power dropped, leaving them with surplus capacity. Regulators have sometimes ruled that surplus capacity is not "used and useful" and that utilities may not raise rates to bill their customers for it. In the Chicago area, Commonwealth Edison is still trying to have its newest reactors recognized in rates.
"A lot of companies have been burned very badly," Mr. Taylor said.
At the New York Power Pool, a seven-utility consortium that arranges power swaps and helps to coordinate planning, William J. Balet, the executive director, pointed out that growth in demand in New York State is now less than 200 megawatts a year. There may be some retirements, he said, but even so, a plant of 1,000 megawatts represents several years of growth and may be a chunk that is too big to swallow.
But some reactor manufacturers think this logic does not hold true around the country, setting the stage for an interesting market test. General Electric has already submitted an analysis to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission of a more conventional plant of 1,300 megawatts, as has another company, Combustion Engineering, a subsidiary of Asea Brown Boveri. These are described as "evolutionary" designs, making improvements on the last of the current generation of American plants, but without radical changes.
In contrast, Westinghouse, at least for now, has all its eggs in the small basket, the plants described as being in a new generation. Thus, if all goes according to the nuclear industry's plan, utilities in the market for new generating stations late in this decade will face a choice.
General Electric is hedging its bets and preparing a large design in part because it is hard for a utility to win approval to build on a site and, with permission in hand, "a lot of utilities are going to want to pack as many megawatts into a site as they can," said Robert C. Berglund, general manager of advanced reactor programs at General Electric.
That certainly holds true in Japan, where reactors are still being ordered and where G.E. is in a partnership with Tokyo Electric, Toshiba and Hitachi to build large reactors similar to the "evolutionary" design that G.E. submitted to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Westinghouse is in partnership with a different utility, Kansai Electric, together with Mitsubishi, on a large plant design but is a step behind the General Electric-Tokyo Electric group.
There are still advantages to size. A 1,300-megawatt reactor has the same number of control rooms as a 600-megawatt reactor, advocates point out, the same number of guard shacks at the front gate and about the same size managerial staff. They do take longer to build, however, and, if interest rates are high, finance charges on capital invested in an unfinished plant for an extra year or so of construction could swing some utilities to favor the smaller plant.
A study by the United States Council for Energy Awareness, the public relations arm of the nuclear industry, estimated that a 600-megawatt plant coming on line at the end of this decade would produce power for about 4.5 cents a kilowatt-hour but said this could be lowered to 4.1 cents a kilowatt-hour by building two adjacent ones. But, the study said, the 1,200-megawatt "evolutionary" reactors could produce power for 3.8 cents a kilowatt-hour, which could be cut to 3.5 cents if they were built in pairs.
The point of the study was not to compare reactors of different sizes but to show that they could compete with coal- and natural gas-fired generation. One result, however, is to estimate the cost penalty for picking a smaller plant.
In the end, though, a utility that considers buying a nuclear plant may get the deciding push from its financial backers. Paul C. Parshley, who analyzes utility debt at Salomon Brothers, says no utility now seems eager to order a plant. But if one comes to market to borrow money to build one, he said, "if you're talking about a larger reactor, you've got an additional hurdle to clear."
In light of the stop-and-start nature of growth in demand for electricity and the risks of building a nuclear plant, he said, if there are utilities that want new reactors, they would probably prefer something even smaller than the new Westinghouse and G.E. designs, in the range of 400 megawatts, not 600.

HEADLINE: THE SEXES;
I Need You, You Need Me

BYLINE: By Suzanne Slesin

 BODY:
THERE'S a riddle going around at meetings where co-dependency is discussed. It is this: What is a co-dependent? Someone who, when hit by a bus, sees someone else's life flash by.
It was once assumed that in many troubled relationships it was the woman who was the co-dependent, the one who couldn't break away. The man had the drug or alcohol addiction and the woman had the job of caring for him, at the cost of subordinating her own needs and feelings. 
 Indeed, women predominate at co-dependency seminars, Al-Anon meetings and group therapy sessions. They also buy the majority of self-help books. But the image of the wife as victim is slowly being replaced, as people come to understand that there are men and women who willingly choose such relationships, and willingly participate in them.
Yet, perceiving co-dependency as a women's issue is still strong. The role women play in troubled relationships was probably first identified in the Al-Anon groups started by Lois Wilson, the wife of Bill Wilson, the founder of Alcoholics Anonymous. But these days, women are less willing to accept this passive role, and a new book has taken a hard look at the so-called recovery movement and the reasons women have embraced it.
WENDY KAMINER, the author of "I'm Dysfunctional, You're Dysfunctional: The Recovery Movement and Other Self-Help Fashions" (Addison Wesley, $18.95), sees co-dependency as "a catchall term for whatever ails you."
At a recovery conference, Ms. Kaminer said she saw "women that feminism bypassed." Through the recovery movement, she said, they have been given a "soft feminine pop message: 'You have a right to say no,' or 'You can't find yourself in someone else.' " Ms. Kaminer said it was strange to hear these things now, in the 90's, "as if they were being uttered for the first time."
What is missing at self-help conventions, she said, is any discussion of the fact that women are often trapped in relationships by economic circumstances. Women are told, "you are in this relationship because you are weak, not because we live in a society riddled with inequities," Ms. Kaminer added.
Some professionals see the issue differently. "Co-dependency, as in being dependent with, is everyone's issue," said Mary L. Bassett, a coordinator of Project Healthy Choice at the Bank Street College of Education in New York. "It is a feminist issue, but it is also a family, community and societal issue."
Tony Allen, a retired stockbroker who teaches meditation at the Renaissance Institute in Boca Raton, Fla., and who was a founder in New York of Adult Children of Alcoholics, said women "realize their victimization more quickly than men, who have been programmed not to be victims but perpetrators."
"When women realized they had the problem, they wanted to do something about it," he said. "When the movement grew, men became more aware."
Others contend that rather than selling women the pop bill of goods, as Ms. Kaminer suggests, the recovery movement has given women a new voice. "The recovery movement empowered women for the first time," said Marilyn White, the director of the Realization Center, an alcohol and substance-abuse treatment center in New York. "Many people are stuck in their lives, feel trapped and are looking for something to get them out of their situation."
T HE issue is "learned helplessness," Ms. White said.
"Early on, women are told they are nothing without men," she said. "But if women are so co-dependent, then who are we dependent on?"
Men, of course, in many instances. And men are just as dependent, Ms. White said. But on different things.
"It gets played out in their careers," Ms. White said. "When a man loses his job, it's as bad as when a woman loses a relationship. His relationship has been with work. Hers is with people."
Robert Subby, the executive director of Family Systems Center in Minneapolis, said the co-dependency pendulum swings both ways. "Do women always have to take responsibility for the emotional business of life?" he asked. "And do men always have to be defined by their work, education and position in a community?"
One effect of the recovery movement is that women are openly identifying themselves as alcoholics and addicts. In doing so, they encourage their mates to deal with their own co-dependency.
"Once I realized that my right as a man to control everyone around me, particularly my wife, was not a God-given right, then I had to try to understand what my real motives were," said Dick Fontaine, a film maker in New York.
Ms. Kaminer says the recovery movement has peaked and is fading. Mr. Allen agrees. "The part of the movement that has been taken over by high-powered hype people is waning," he said. "But not the 12-step grassroots level."
But for others, all the meetings, books and workshops have been only a beginning. "They won't fix the problems," Ms. White said. "The next step is to change the behavior."
And as a man who regularly attends recovery meetings noted, "There are still plenty of chairs waiting to be filled at any meeting I've ever attended."

HEADLINE: Why Supercollider Project Has to Stop

 BODY:
To the Editor:
On June 17, the House of Representatives voted to stop financing the superconducting supercollider. Your June 19 and June 20 articles emphasize the claims of contractors, high-energy physicists and the Department of Energy -- all with a stake in the survival of the project. All predict dire consequences for the country should the project be stopped. There is another side of the story. 
 If you believe the wailings coming from the self-interested champions of the supercollider, stopping the project is tantamount to dooming the United States to a hard scrabble, third-world quality of life in the next century. They ask us to believe that the sine qua non of improving America's competitiveness is to spend $8 million per high-energy physicist to build this one machine. This argument might be compelling if it weren't so self-evidently wrong. High-energy physics, with its expensive instruments and small cadre of experimentalists removed from practical questions or inventions, is a net consumer of national wealth.
The only thing that might correlate with having the most powerful high-energy physics facility in the world is winning Nobel prizes in physics. For most of the last 50 years, the United States has had the most advanced high-energy physics facilities. But while the United States has been collecting Nobels, the Japanese have been collecting markets (and not investing heavily in high-energy physics); and if there were a Nobel prize for national economic success, the Japanese would already have a 20-year lock on the award.
All the hype from the wounded supporters of the supercollider aside, we know how to make America more competitive. We must begin by separating merely desirable from absolutely essential investments; that is what the House vote on June 17 was about. While the supercollider is a laudable idea, it stretches the bounds of credulity to believe that it can become the cornerstone of an American economic renaissance.
After the Federal budget is brought under control and we have taken steps that do more than add to the rhetoric about restoring our competitiveness, I would invite high-energy physicists to come back to Washington with their most ambitious project, and we can then build it together.
 
(Rep.) SHERWOOD BOEHLERT
Washington, June 24, 1992
 
The writer is ranking Republican on the Investigations and Oversight Subcommittee of the House Science, Space and Technology Committee.

HEADLINE: JULY 5-11: A Very Bare Cupboard;
The House Votes Its Wishes But Its Budget Constraints Deny the Usual Pleasures

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

 BODY:
The House faced the 1990 budget act's spending limits twice last week. First it pretended they weren't a problem, passing a bill to raise the theoretical maximum of Pell grants to needy college students from $3,100 to $3,700 in 1993-94 even though an Appropriations subcommittee voted to cut them from $2,400 to $2,300.
Then the House voted to change the budget law's spending limits, so $400 million from the unpopular foreign aid budget, money it had cut last month, could be spent on politically appealing highways. But the measure barely passed, and is unlikely to become law. 
 Both moves reflect a painful truth: Money is very tight. The 1990 act was supposed to pinch this year, and it has, holding increases in some areas below the inflation rate, and leaving just about nothing for new domestic programs, like bigger Pell grants or the Surface Transportation Act that Congress and President Bush congratulated themselves on enacting as a jobs bill last fall.
Being on the Appropriations Committees used to be more fun. There were opportunities to provide money for grand national causes and for desperately needed local projects. But not this year. A federal deficit likely to exceed $350 billion and widespread contempt for Congress cannot be ignored by Congress and its Appropriations Committee.
Representative William H. Natcher of Kentucky, the acting chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, said recently, "This is going to be the most difficult year we've had since I've been on the committee." He's been there 38 years.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Laid-Off Bosses Scramble in A Changing World

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
AS the national economy teeters agonizingly between slow convalescence and recessionary relapse, the men and women who once helped run the private sector as mid-level bosses, as well as their sidekicks or their secretaries, are peculiarly plagued by America's economic ailments. A few jobs may be coming back -- but usually not their kind. Some of them may be returning to work, but it is taking longer than it once did. To fit into an economy that is reinventing itself, economists say, they may have to reinvent themselves, too.
When Peter Pollet was laid off from his job as sales manager of a manufacturing concern he joined a group called Capital Area Career Network near Concord, N.H. "We tell people to assess their skills, and we encourage them, if they can, to get into the service industry," he said. 
"If they can't, we tell them to figure out if they can get into some kind of business for themselves. We say, 'Don't plan on doing what you did before, because it won't be around.' " Janet Norwood, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, a research organization in Washington, said that "The mentality that says, 'We've had a downturn, eventually we'll have an upturn, everything is going to be the way it was,' has to change. Industry is changing, technologies are changing, even managerial styles are changing."
Dr. Norwood and several other economists see the unemployed managers, whose number topped 600,000 in May, as unwilling pioneers. When they joined the labor market, careers were like board games, with points or money slowly but surely gained. You might lose a few turns, but you moved inexorably along a defined route toward a defined goal.
That model is being replaced by something more like a Nintendo game, in which dodging, wheeling and grappling with the unexpected -- flexibility and quick reflexes -- are the skills of choice. Unlucky players don't lose turns; they drop off a screen and disappear.
While some economists point to labor force figures showing that managers have not been disproportionately hurt by the job losses that have hit the labor force, the segments of the economy that tend to hire the most managerial personnel are among the slowest to come back.
Andrew Sum, director of the Center for Labor Market Studies at Northeastern University, noted that in 1991, white-collar managers were unemployed longer, on average, than blue-collar workers. In 1982, during the last major recession, the reverse was true.
 
Flat Employment Rate
 "The sector that employs the greatest percentage of managers is finance, insurance and real estate," Professor Sum said, adding that more than a quarter of this labor force fits the Federal Government's classification of "executive, administrative and managerial" workers. In that sector, he said, "employment is flat -- there's no change at all" between June 1991 and June 1992.
"The second sector -- and the biggest employer in absolute numbers -- is the private services sector. There are 5 million managers there, 12 percent of the total. If you exclude health services, we added only 250,000 jobs, a total of not even 1 percent."
In 1991, he added, the average duration of unemployment for laid-off managerial personnel was 13.5 weeks. In the second quarter of 1992, the unemployment rate among managers stood at 3.7 percent, almost one and a half percentage points higher than the average rate in 1990, the year the recession began.
Some experts note the phenomenon of unemployed professionals and managers is nothing new. In Sloan Wilson's novel, "The Man in the Gray Flannel Suit," the protagonist runs into a fellow commuter who has been fired, but takes the train to keep his joblessness secret from his wife.
Nor is unemployment among these workers the dominant fact of the current labor market. More than 500,000 unemployed managerial personnel may be flailing around in an unwelcoming economy, but "if 10 million people are unemployed, this is not where the real problem in society is," said Sar A. Levitan, director of the Center for Policy Studies at George Washington University.
The issue, he said, is not who is geting laid off, but why. "It's more a question of the restructuring of the economy," Dr. Levitan said. "Before, industries continued to grow," weathering occasional downturns. "Competition was not as fierce as it is now," he added.
The ripples caused by these layoffs, however, may be more significant than the total number of managers displaced.
The first and most obvious effect is on the onetime bosses themselves, achievers deprived of the arena in which they achieved. "It's a severe process," said Sandra Smith Dupree, a spokeswoman for the state Employment Security office in New Hampshire, whose 1980's boom economy turned sour in 1990. Five major bank reorganizations and downsizing in the once feisty high technology sector led to a significant loss of management jobs, she said.
A second effect, Dr. Sum said, is on the sense of confidence, both emotional and economic, among family and friends of unemployed executives. These men -- and, Dr. Sum said, Federal statistics show that most newly laid-off managers are men -- tend to be visible members of their communities. For those around them, it is unsettling to realize that such a person can lose a job.
Another apparent result, economists say, is an increase in self-employed workers, as the executives become self-employed consultants, working on contract until better long-term prospects appear.
One possibly beneficial byproduct of the managerial dog days may be that it will prepare younger people for the job- and career-jumping likely to be their lot. They seem to be turning away from managerial careers.
An annual University of California at Los Angeles study of freshman showed that between 1987 and 1990 the number of students planning to major in accounting, business administration, finance, marketing or management dropped sharply.
"The economy's always in flux," said Dr. Norwood. "People have to recognize that it's going to be much rarer for people to pick an occupation, get a job, and stay with he same company throughout a lifetime. Or even stay with an occupation.
"I grew up in a family where my Dad was 50 years with one company," said Jim Murphy, a chemical engineer recently laid off from a Houston firm specializing in hydroblasting, the cleaning of chemical equipment with high-pressure water systems. "The two firms I was with before the last one took me everywhere -- I was with them for 15 years apiece."
But, he said, he tells his 20-year-old son, an electrical engineering major at Rice University, "Forget about brand loyalty. They're not going to be loyal to you. Don't be loyal to them." His son is preparing for two related careers -- one in Navy submarines, one in general engineering. The only question is whether two will be enough.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk
