HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Russians Line Up for Gas as Refineries Sit On Cheap Oil

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
BY mid-morning, the line of cars at Gasoline Station No. 35 stretches for half a mile down Trifonovskaya Street. Everywhere in Russia there are similar lines, and filling the family car has become as frustrating and uncertain as it was for Americans during the Arab oil crises of the 1970's.
But the reasons are different. While the Americans suffered from shortages of Middle East oil, Russia's supplies are sufficient. However, the oil is being held in huge storage tanks at Russian refineries, without being shipped to gasoline stations. The problem is price. With oil selling for $19 a barrel on the world market, Russian oil goes for about 300 rubles, or less than $3 a barrel. So the Russian oil industry is holding back as much fuel as it can, waiting for prices to be allowed to rise. 
 "Have you seen anyone in New York selling one dollar for 10 cents?" asked Lev D. Churilov, president of the Russian Oil and Gas Association, an industry trade group. "No one does that. Nevertheless in Russia today we are told by the Government to sell oil for one-tenth its value."
No single economic issue is more troublesome for President Boris N. Yeltsin than oil prices. While the West presses him to let oil prices rise over sixfold this summer to match world levels, Parliament says so steep an increase would bankrupt enterprises dependent on cheap fuel and bring hardship to families forced to pay more for heat and electricity, as well as gasoline.
Lately, Mr. Yeltsin has sided with Parliament. He announced in late June that another oil price increase, the third this year, would be postponed for a while. That insures gasoline lines through the summer as the chiefs of oil production companies and refineries -- still state-owned but operating nearly autonomously -- bet that Mr. Yeltsin will soon give ground.
Already, the increases allowed this year have brought the price of crude oil from less than 5 rubles, or about 5 cents, a barrel in January to the current price of nearly 300 rubles.
"Everyone is keeping back oil, waiting for even higher prices and selling just enough to get by," said Dimitri Gabrilov, director of Qualitet, an investment banking operation that lends to PermNeft, a Siberian oil production company, enabling it to have funds to operate without having to sell all the oil it pumps. Qualitet takes as collateral PermNeft's unsold oil.
Sometimes the industry finds ways to sell oil or refined products at world prices -- for example, by selling to Russian middlemen who then re-sell the petroleum at world prices. But most is held back, and the result is the gasoline lines. They get particularly long on Fridays, when many Russians fill the family car for a weekend trip to the summer dacha, typically a wooden hut and a vegetable garden in a country village 60 miles or so from Moscow or some other Russian city.
 
Trying to Beat the System
 Sometimes people wait in line twice, to get more than the Government-imposed limit of 40 liters -- 10.6 gallons -- for a single purchase at the official price of 7.3 rubles a liter, or about 23 cents a gallon. If a driver is impatient, he might buy on the black market from men standing at the curb who sell gasoline from 20-liter drums at 30 rubles a liter. It is gasoline they waited in lines to purchase legally for 7.3 rubles a liter.
Or, a driver might slip a gasoline station attendant a few rubles to pump more than the limit, as a father and son in a white Zhiguli station wagon did at Station No. 35 on a recent weekday. The attendant filled the car's tank and also two plastic drums, a total of 60 liters. To fool the cashier in the station, the father paid for 40 liters and the son approached a few minutes later to pay for the remaining 20 liters, as if his were a separate purchase.
"Everyone is irritated; you can hear all kinds of awful language," said Valentina Svetikova, a manager of the state-owned Station No. 35. "They are ready to pay more for gasoline, but there is none. We call up the central agency that sends us gasoline and ask for more, but they say there is none."
The supply problem would undoubtedly disappear if the West had its way. It wants Mr. Yeltsin to let Russia's oil prices rise toward $19 a barrel -- the world market level -- instead of requiring the Russian oil industry to sell 80 percent of the nation's output at home for under $3 a barrel. That would mean gasoline prices of 30 rubles a liter, or about $1.10 a gallon. And gasoline lines would disappear. As supplies rose, car owners would cut their purchases in a nation where most family income is under 10,000 rubles, or $100, a month. Driving a car would become very expensive.
Falling demand would make more oil available for sale abroad, earning Russia more dollars from its chief export, especially if untapped Siberian reserves were brought into production. That would make repayment of the nation's foreign debt much easier. More foreign goods could be purchased, and there would be more dollars to repatriate profits from foreign investments.
These are major goals of the Western industrial nations. Their agent, the International Monetary Fund, insisted that Russia provide "a very precise schedule" for raising oil prices, a Russian official said, as a key part of an overall agreement to release $24 billion in foreign assistance. Mr. Yeltsin refused and the agreement signed last week between the I.M.F. and Russia, for only $1 billion in credits, postponed oil price negotiations to a later date. Even at the economic summit in Munich last week, Mr. Yeltsin resisted higher oil prices, proposing instead to swap Russian property, including oil, in exchange for canceling debt.
But pressure is also coming from the managers of state oil companies, who say that without higher prices they cannot afford the investment necessary to reverse the decline in Russia's oil production. "Mr. Yeltsin told us he would raise oil prices by the end of the year," Mr. Churilov said, "but first there must be a formula for offsetting the inflationary impact. That is difficult."
 
A Shared Burden
 Hopefully, the formula will be worked out soon. As oil production declines, Russia is forcing other republics in the Commonwealth of Independent States to bear more of the burden than Russia. With its huge Siberian fields, Russia produces 8.2 million barrels a day of the Commonwealth's 9.3 million barrel output. But as production has fallen, Russian crude oil shipments to refineries in other republics have fallen by nearly 3 barrels for each barrel cut back at Russian refineries.
"The pattern is that the Russian refineries are getting enough crude and the rest of the Commonwealth is not," said Thane Gustaffson, of the Cambridge Energy Institute in Cambridge, Mass. The gasoline lines in the other republics are even longer than in Russia. But they might seem like a blessing if Russia gives in to the West's pressure and raises fuel prices to world levels, not only for Russia but for the other Commonwealth states. Cheap Russian oil makes the other states in the Commonwealth dependent on Russia -- a dependence that has helped to hold the Commonwealth together.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Irresolute Meetings Chip Away at Summitry's Stature

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: HELSINKI, Finland

 BODY:
BOTH at the economic summit of seven leading industrial democracies in Munich and at the larger gathering of the 52-state European security conference here last week, world leaders tried hard to create the illusion of resolve. They sounded firm about the crucial economic and military problems before them, but what they actually did was very little.
In Munich, the leaders said it was a shame they had been unable to get their negotiators to make good on past promises to reach a new global trade agreement, and they vowed -- for the third straight year -- to push for agreement by the end of December. 
 In Helsinki and in Munich, they rattled sabers at Serbia. But when President Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia and Herzegovina begged them to go beyond airlifts of emergency food and medical supplies and send troops and bombers to stop the Serbian bombardment of Sarajevo, they responded by ordering a naval blockade that will stand well offshore. They also vowed to keep the emergency supplies coming. "Aggression and its consequences cannot be stopped by charity," the Bosnian leader pleaded, but there was not a single national leader, President Bush included, who was yet willing to send troops into the quagmire.
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq could have told them that the illusion of resolve is never as persuasive as resolve itself. At their summits last week, the world leaders seemed to be trying to talk themselves into resolve, both on the trade issue and on the Balkans. They haven't quite got there yet, though this could change.
Most of them are in grave political difficulties this year. Without pressure from their domestic lobbies to worry about, both President Bush and President Francois Mitterrand of France might have found it possible to compromise on the trade issue. But Mr. Mitterrand was simply unwilling to make the concessions demanded by President Bush on reducing agricultural export subsidies for European produce -- not with French farmers still seething over the European Community's recent decision to cut back its expensive and extensive system of production subsidies. And, with his own political fate closely tied to a referendum on European unity to be held Sept. 20, Mr. Mitterrand is unlikely to change his mind for several months.
Even then, Mr. Bush will still be preoccupied by the political fight of his life, something that clearly inhibited him in Munich, where he kept such a low profile as to be practically invisible.
Domestic politics may also explain some of the American reluctance to march into the Balkans and chase Serbia back home the way allied forces chased Iraq out of Kuwait. "We have no plans to inject ourselves into a conflict situation in Yugoslavia," Mr. Bush said, confirming a series of briefings by American officials who made clear that at the most, the United States would be prepared to provide air cover for United Nations convoys of relief supplies for the people of Sarajevo if a new Security Council resolution authorizes such a step.
That leaves the ball in the court of international organizations like the 52-state Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, NATO, and the nine-nation Western European Union, the European Community's military arm. The security conference agreed at the end of the week that it could work with these military organizations and the United Nations, if beefed-up military operations become advisable to try to keep peace in Yugoslavia.
With or without domestic politics as an obstacle, it is hard to see any way to impose peace on the Balkans without the kind of sizable military operation that drove Iraq out of Kuwait -- only this would be likely to take years instead of weeks, and nobody, in Europe or in the United States, wants to be drawn into such a nightmare.
Keeping the Sarajevo airport open for relief supplies is about at the limit of the United Nations' present powers, though the leaders in Munich and Helsinki said they would support the use of force to open the roads of Bosnia to relief convoys if it became necessary to keep the flow of supplies moving.
Will President Slobodan Milosevic call off the Serbian onslaught in the face of such threats? Probably not, Western diplomats in Helsinki conceded, but perhaps future aggressors in the seething cauldron of ethnic and national rivalries that used to be the Soviet Union might think twice, if NATO and the others have got their act together by then.
The alliance and the Western European Union took a small first step by sending in warships to tighten the United Nations blockade of Serbia, and the security conference sent observers into the disputed enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh, in which Armenia and Azerbaijan have been practically at war for several years.
To keep things from deteriorating that far in Russia, the industrial powers agreed in Munich to support a loan of a billion dollars from the International Monetary Fund, with the prospect of another $500 million or so in import loans. If President Boris N. Yeltsin makes good on his promises of bringing about a market economy, he may also get the equivalent of another $2.5 billion a year in deferral of interest payments on Russia's $71-billion debt.
Mr. Yeltsin is another past master of illusion, and left the summit leaders to dream of prospects of a tantalizing debt-for-equity swap -- Russian oil and diamonds in exchange for bank write-offs, perhaps.
But were the meager results of these two gargantuan summits really worth all the disruption and the money they cost? What the leaders of the world actually do during the year ahead may provide the answer.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 2; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: Trying to Contain Anarchy;
As Some Nations Build, the Past Devours Others

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THERE is a factory outside Toyota City, Japan, where 66 human beings and 310 robots build 300 Lexus sedans each day. There are hills around Sarajevo where five children were killed by tank fire last month as they were picking fruit from a cherry tree. In many ways the Lexus and the cherry tree are the symbols of the post-cold war world. Some countries, it seems, are emerging from the cold war intent on building a better Lexus, while others are emerging from the cold war intent on renewing tribal feuds over who owns which cherry trees. In Japan, in Taiwan, in Singapore, in Maastricht, the future seems to be burying the past. In Sarajevo, in the West Bank, in Nagorno-Karabakh, in Moldova, in Northern Ireland, the past seems to be burying the future.
It was not supposed to be this way. After the long march of the cold war, it seemed to many in the West that they deserved a rest and that from here on, history would be a story about free-market, pluralistic, democratic values gradually spreading around the globe: Lexus triumphant. 
 But since the Berlin Wall fell, so too have many illusions. Indeed, last week's Group of Seven summit in Munich was a perfect snapshot of what really comes next. The leaders there spent half their time futilely trying to work out a new international trading system and the other half fretting about what to do with Yugoslavia and other ethnic flashpoints. It is this new world melange, not some idyllic new world order, that lies ahead.
It is actually logical that the Lexus and the cherry tree would compete side by side as symbols for the post-cold war world, the Harvard political economist Robert Reich argues. This is because when the world becomes more technologically advanced and economically intertwined, with economic borders all but erased, there is a counter-reaction of ethnic self-assertion. As national boundaries fall, personal boundaries rise. "On the one hand, thanks to the CNN effect, there is a growing awareness around the world of the standard of living that awaits a rapidly industrializing nation which gets its priorities and its technologies right," said Mr. Reich. "But as geographical borders disappear there is simultaneously a renewed yearning to assert one's own uniqueness -- to create new borders based on history, religion, nationalism and culture."
That tension is at work in America, Western Europe and Japan, as well as in the Balkans, although up to now the industrially advanced nations have kept it in reasonable balance. Nevertheless, "America First" nativism has been apparent in the Patrick Buchanan campaign, not to mention the Ross Perot phenomenon. In Japan, a stronger strain of aggressive nationalism is asserting itself on the margins of politics, and in Italy, France and Germany right-wing groups opposed to immigration have flourished in recent elections. Even European integration, which was supposed to flower this year, is suddenly being resisted from Denmark to England, as their citizens chafe at depositing their identities into the European Community Cuisinart to be homogenized into a bland Euro-mush.
The challenge for modern societies is to get people to work together and maintain the rising standards of living that come from economic interdependence and technological advancement, while at the same time allowing people to seek greater psychological warmth from their ethnic identities. France and America have had centuries to develop the rule of laws and institutions that make that balance possible, and even Japan and Germany have had nearly 50 years now. In reborn states like Serbia, however, the imperatives of ethnic solidarity have run riot.
Unfortunately, most societies seem to have to find this balance the hard way. The philosopher Isaiah Berlin tells a Russian folk tale about a sultan who punished one of his wives by having her sealed with her son in a barrel and set adrift at sea. Again and again, the boy says he wants to stretch his legs, but his mother talks him out of it, saying he would only push out the barrel's bottom. Finally the boy says he simply must stretch his legs, no matter what. So he does, the bottom of the barrel gets pushed out and they drown.
The parable fits Serbia or Armenia or the Czech and Slovak republics. They seem intent on stretching their nationalist legs, no matter what the consequences. When Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d went to Armenia and Azerbaijan last year he pleaded with their leaders to use their new freedom and scant resources on economic development instead of fighting over the enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh. They listened politely, nodding their heads. And as soon as Mr. Baker left they went back to pummeling each other. There were just too many pent-up scores to settle.
"You cannot tell the Serbs that independence is not a storybook tale, that it is not the utopia they think it is," said Fouad Ajami, the Lebanese-born historian. "People maintain imaginary homelands in their minds. They carry them around for generations. When the call of the tribe beckons, you just have to stand aside and let it play itself out. Where Pandora's box has been opened no prudent man should tread. These are situations that do not lend themselves to the outsider's touch."
 
A Journey of Delusions
 Eventually the Serbs, Armenians, Azeris and Moldovans will probably learn what the Lebanese learned after 15 years of civil war: that theirs is a journey of delusions, that a politics based on an eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth only ends up with a society with no eyes and no teeth. The lesson of Lebanon is that in the end reality always intrudes, because however good asserting one's identity is for the soul, it doesn't do much for the stomach. Eventually people have to produce something, even if it is not a Lexus. There is nothing like the collective pauperization the Lebanese have experienced to dampen a nationalist frenzy.
Two societies that may have learned that lesson without tumbling over the edge (at least for the moment) are Quebec and Israel. In both, the voters seem to have intuitively come to realize that in an era when Japan can assemble a Lexus with robots, they cannot afford to fall farther behind by focusing their energy on asserting ownership rights to a particular cherry or olive tree.
In Quebec, nationalists struggled mightily to persuade the middle class that separation would have no economic costs; but once people began to realize that there would, indeed, be less investment and fewer jobs, the separatist balloon burst. In Israel, voters seemed to say that it no longer made sense to risk being isolated and falling behind Taiwan and Singapore because they had to build another settlement in Gaza to fulfill the Likud party's religious-nationalist vision. "The Israeli public," said the Israeli political theorist Yaron Ezrahi, "wanted a better balance between the imperatives of security and the necessities of building a livable competitive society that is open to the world markets."
To the extent that Washington has a policy for dealing with these situations, that policy seems to have two facets. One is to help countries avoid succumbing to the call of the wild, by framing clear choices for them. President Bush made clear to the Israelis -- by holding up $10 billion in loan guarantees until Israel freezes settlements -- that they can have economic development or more nationalist settlements, but not both.
The other side of the policy is to isolate those countries like Serbia that have had choices framed for them but have made the wrong choice. World War I started in Sarajevo, but it seems unlikely that the current fighting there will ignite World War III. Why? Because great wars are made by great powers, and when Russia, Germany, Britain, France and the United States all decide that they do not want to get involved in the politics of small tribes because they have more important things to do at home, conflicts like Yugoslavia's become remarkably containable -- even in the heart of Europe.
In a way, Europe is once again being divided, but this time the Iron Curtain is being built not by Communists, but by those countries focused on building a better Lexus, who are trying to seal out those intent on fighting over their cherry trees.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
What Hidden Costs in Spreading the Insurance Risk?

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
SHOULD health insurers be obliged to cover a 50-year-old overweight bartender for the same premium as a 20-year-old secretary who swims a mile each day?
"This is what insurance was designed to do," said Robert Jaffe, a spokesman for the Gay Men's Health Crisis. The insurers' job, he added, is to "take those who are considered to be risky and blend them with those who are young and healthy." And last month the New York State Legislature agreed, requiring health insurers who write policies for any small group or individual to offer comparable policies to all, and at a uniform price. 
 But economists are skeptical. While many are in accord with Michael Blumenfeld of Empire Blue Cross that "health care is a right," they are reluctant to cut the link between the cost of providing insurance and the price charged to those insured. If universal access to health care is the goal, asks Richard Thaler, an economist at Cornell University, "why should we pay for it via insurance premiums rather than taxes?"
They also worry that similar risk-spreading rationales will be applied to other forms of insurance -- everything from auto to fire coverage -- pitting the middle class against the poor and drawing government into markets more efficiently regulated by competition. The "general socialization of risk," predicts Orin Kramer, a private consultant in Princeton, N.J., "will eliminate the possibility of non-political insurance coverage."
New York State's problem with health insurance illustrates the conundrum. As a quasi-public insurer, Empire Blue Cross allows anyone to enroll and charges a uniform rate. But commercial insurers have been under no such obligation. And with the help of computers, they have refined the abilities to discriminate by age, health and occupation.
The more precise commercial insurers became, Mr. Blumenfeld notes, the "more cherries were ripe for picking" and the higher the premiums needed to cover the costs of those left to insure by Blue Cross. Indeed, it was the pressure of exploding insurance rates for the increasingly concentrated pool of high-risk Blue Cross policyholders that forced the Legislature to act.
Uwe Reinhardt, an economist at Princeton University, concedes that Albany had little choice. Higher Blue Cross premiums would have forced more people to give up their insurance, leaving the state to pick up the tab for their hospitalization. And the alternative of appealing to the companies' better nature, asking them to take on bad risks voluntarily at bargain rates, was no alternative at all: "Even a bunch of nuns competing in the 100-yard dash can't be expected to pick up trash along the road," Mr. Reinhardt concluded.
But the Princeton economist is hardly enthusiastic about the New York approach. If health insurance is a private responsibility, he asks, is it fair to charge the same rate to people who take care of themselves as, say, to those who smoke? For that matter, is it fair under any circumstance to force 20-year-olds making $8 an hour to subsidize the care of 60-year-old millionaires?
And then there are the pesky issues of enforcement. While insurers with big stakes in New York will no doubt comply with the letter of the law, they will have potent incentives to flout the spirit. At the very least, mandatory "community rating" of risk promises to be a headache for regulators left with the job of assuring universal access.
Some argue that the problems of setting rates in health insurance are unique because the product is unique: Everybody needs it. But the idea that health insurance alone deserves special consideration because no one can do without it would play poorly in California, where the right to a lane on the freeway is deemed almost as important as the right to a bed in a hospital.
 
Insurance by ZIPip Code
 Since the passage of Proposition 103 in 1989, California auto insurers have been obliged to assess risk according to age, driving record and mileage -- as well as other factors deemed relevant by state regulators. That latter catch-all puts the insurance commissioner in the hot seat, because ZIP codes have become a favorite rating criterion. And while Steven Miller, the deputy commissioner of insurance, points out that rates do vary greatly from company to company, it typically costs two or three times as much to purchase the mandatory minimum policy in impoverished South-Central Los Angeles as it does in the surrounding suburban sprawl.
The parallel with health insurance -- society's ambivalence about whether driving an auto is a privilege or a right -- is striking. In New York those who cannot afford medical coverage are still treated in emergencies, albeit inefficiently. In California, those who cannot afford auto insurance simply ignore their legal obligation. Nettie Hoge, an attorney for Consumers Union in San Francisco, estimates that 90 percent of inner-city drivers are uninsured.
California could, of course, deny registration to uninsured vehicles. But then, in theory, New York could impose a head tax on residents who did not buy medical insurance, or just leave uninsured heart attack victims to die on the street.
Mr. Miller would prefer to start over with a bare-bones "no fault" system to compensate accident victims -- one that covers everyone in the state at a modest, uniform rate. Drivers might then buy additional coverage at rates set by open competition. That would satisfy Ms. Hoge, a consumer advocate who has nonetheless come to the conclusion that "the essence of insurance is discrimination."
 
Suburban Rates Would Rise
 But trial lawyers bitterly oppose no-fault insurance and seem to have the muscle to block it. Thus California probably will allow auto insurers to factor in geography, but not as much as they have in the past.
Could such a compromise work? Mr. Miller acknowledges that it depends on how much regulated rates differ from insurers' own estimates of risk, and whether regulators can prevent insurers from cherry-picking profitable customers while freezing out the rest. But there is also a political unknown: Would suburban drivers, whose rates would be sure to go up, go along with it?
The lesson according to Economics 101 is simple: Those who fiddle with cost-based prices in order to achieve socially desired ends risk unintended consequences. Mr. Reinhardt does not disagree.
But in an ideal world, he says, insurers would discriminate according to risk. If society did not like the consequences of, say, an insurer charging $5,000 a year to a family earning $15,000, it would subsidize the family's income. And if it did not wish to give families the option of buying less than some minimum coverage, it would short-circuit the market and pay the bill from government revenues.
But this not that ideal world. There is no consensus about the sort of insurance that should be provided as a matter of right. And in an era of rapidly rising insurance costs, there is no agreement about who should bear the financial burden. Until these issues are faced squarely, he suggests, the best we can hope for is to muddle through.

PUB-DATE: July 12, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1642 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
DEMOCRATS GATHER TO RESHAPE IMAGE AND CROWN CLINTON

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

 BODY:
As the cast of characters for the 41st Democratic National Convention assembled in Manhattan yesterday, the Rev. Jesse Jackson ended a long holdout and endorsed Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and Senator Al Gore of Tennessee -- the ticket the delegates will ratify later this week.
Mr. Clinton, who has seemed to regain his political equilibrium in recent days, won Mr. Jackson's backing, however grudging and however tardy, on his own terms. Unlike other recent Democratic nominees, he declined to bargain with the black leader for his support, lest he seem a captive. 
 "I have decided to vote for Bill Clinton and Al Gore," Mr. Jackson said, but he did not say he would campaign for them. And he implicitly chided Governor Clinton for his strategy of concentrating on middle-class voters with the comment, "We need a big-tent vision that makes room for us all."
 
Brown Withholds Endorsement
 The endorsement removed the next-to-last threat of a disruptive squabble at the convention, which opens Monday night in Madison Square Garden. Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who fought Mr. Clinton for the nomination through the last primaries on June 2, has still not indicated whether he will join the party's effort to present a harmonious picture to the nation as Mr. Clinton begins an arduous three-sided campaign.
With recent polls showing him closing the gap on his rivals, President Bush and Ross Perot, and with a generally warm reaction to his selection of Mr. Gore last week, the Arkansas Governor appears far more confident than he did during the primary season. When he arrived in New York last night, he was greeted by Mayor David N. Dinkins, who had been supportive of the Governor but timed his official endorsement to coincide with the arrival of the candidate.
But the convention, bereft of conflict and suspense though it may be, represents a crucial test for Mr. Clinton.
 
Projecting Image of Order
 He must avoid the kinds of confusion that marred the Democratic conventions of 1968, 1972 and 1980, and cost the party dearly in the fall of those years. Even with the reduced television coverage planned this time by the broadcast networks, the convention will leave an image of the party and its candidates with many voters; the Democrats want to seem orderly, unified, serious, concerned, determined and above all stable and trustworthy.
"We have to demonstrate that this is not your typical Democratic convention," Ronald H. Brown, the party chairman, said yesterday in a rueful allusion to the tumultuous gatherings of the past. "This is not a convention to heal wounds. We are already in the general election campaign."
But John C. White of Texas, one of Mr. Brown's predecessors, warned that important work in rebuilding party unity remained before the broader appeal to the country begins.
"Bill Clinton's got the nomination, and he's got the power," Mr. White said. "But he's still got to bring the party together. He's got to make these regular Democrats feel like they're really part of it."
The party leaders and Mr. Clinton's strategists hope to reintroduce him to the nation here, emphasizing the story of his rise from humble origins in the hope that it will make many voters forget, or attach less importance to, the character issues that have dogged his campaign. They say they are convinced, as Robert Squier, one of his media consultants, remarked recently, that "the more you get to know Bill Clinton the more you like him."
Mr. Gore began the process of reintroduction even before Mr. Clinton arrived in New York. In a joint appearance on the steps of the courthouse in Carthage, Tenn., his hometown, Mr. Gore told a friendly crowd how the Arkansas Governor had grown up poor, in the kind of single-parent family that is now an American commonplace.
Mr. Clinton said he intended to "renew the sense of can-do optimism" that had once typified the United States. He asserted that "the American people are at sea now, they're disillusioned, they're confused, and many of them are scared."
Mr. Clinton told reporters that he was happy to be returning to New York, where he won one of his most important primary victories on April 7, defeating Mr. Brown by a relatively narrow margin after a bruising fight that featured tough questioning by reporters. This time, the Governor said, "it will be a different campaign, one that really reaches out to the people of the state."
 
Families on Display
 Asked about a television advertisement designed to revive charges that he carried on a 12-year affair with a former nightclub singer named Gennifer Flowers, he replied: "America knows everything they need to know about it. They know what my position is. It is just more sleazy Republican politics."
The advertisement, which has not yet appeared on television, was produced by Floyd G. Brown, who produced the Willie Horton commercial in 1988. The new one, urging viewers to call a telephone number to listen to purported tapes of conversations between Mr. Clinton and Ms. Flowers, has been disavowed in strong terms by President Bush.
After their rally in Carthage, during which members of both families stood with them to symbolize the ticket's commitment to "family values," Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore traveled to nearby Nashville to speak at the convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Mr. Perot had preceded them to the podium.
In a preacherly introduction, the organization's outgoing director, the Rev. Benjamin L. Hooks Jr., predicted that Mr. Clinton would probably be "the next President of the United States." The Governor answered by telling the audience that his grandmother had once said, "You could be a preacher if you were just a little better boy."
"So I wound up in politics," Mr. Clinton said.
 
Bush Works the Golf Course
 To hearty applause, he harshly criticized Mr. Bush. "Last time we had a President promise us a kinder and gentler nation, it turns out he meant a meaner and harsher politics," Mr. Clinton said. "Last time you had a President who promised us, and I quote, a new economy and greater tolerance, turns out he meant he'd be the only President since Reconstruction, except for his predecessor, to veto a civil rights bill."
It was an important stop for Mr. Clinton because of his frayed relations with Mr. Jackson, with whom he recently clashed over Sister Souljah, a rap performer who he said advocated violence. Some black officials, though by no means all, have criticized the Democratic ticket, which is composed of two white Baptist men, as too narrowly based for a highly pluralistic society. Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan said yesterday he feared that Mr. Clinton intended to turn his back on economically marginal blacks.
While his rivals spoke in Tennessee, President Bush was at his seaside home in Kennebunkport, Me., resting up after summit conferences in Munich and Helsinki. Cameramen were permitted to videotape him driving onto the golf course in a cart, which many politicians here thought a curious bit of image management at a time when he is under attack for indifference to the economic plight of the middle class.
Before leaving Europe, Mr. Bush predicted an economic upturn that would help him in what he called a "dog-eat-dog" contest. In an interview on the MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour on PBS, he declined to predict victory, commenting that "it's a little early to know what the mood of the country will be come election time."
 
'Points of Creative Tension'
 Mr. Jackson's endorsement last night came on his CNN program, "Both Sides with Jesse Jackson."
Alluding to the thesis that the Democrats need to change their policies if they are to appeal to the half of the nation that now lives in the suburbs, he added: "We need not choose between city and suburb, between black, white and brown. Bill Clinton and Al Gore have the opportunity, if they will accept the burden, of putting forth a plan of healing, rebuilding and reconciliation to make America better. Thus, on Nov. 3, I have decided to vote for Bill Clinton and Al Gore. But for the Democrats to win, we must have more inclusive strategies and a broader vision."
Mr. Jackson said that "more and more people view both parties as two sides on one coin, one party with two names." He said that "points of creative tension remain" between himself and the Clinton campaign. He did not spell these out, but listed a number of his own priorities, including a plea for more help for the unemployed, the poor, and those without health insurance, implying that Mr. Clinton's programs did not go far enough.
"In the final analysis, people should exercise their right to vote, but they will not vote for exercise," Mr. Jackson added, in what some took as an implied threat to keep his supporters at home if his ideas were not adopted. "They will vote if their vote makes a difference in their lives."
Four years ago, Mr. Jackson, a candidate for the nomination himself that time, kept the eventual nominee, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, on tenterhooks all through Saturday and Sunday before the convention. Few people talked of anything else but his plans. Mr. Clinton was determined to avoid that this year and held no negotiations with him, but an official of his campaign said Mr. Jackson had been told that his speech on Tuesday night would be imperiled if he failed to issue his endorsement before then.
Mr. Dinkins's endorsement was far more enthusiastic and unqualified. Noting that the weeklong convention would bring about $190 million into the city's economy, he added, "But the best business of all for New York will be a new President and a new Vice President, for only then will this country and its cities have the leadership we need and the leadership we deserve."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1572 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Racial Politics;
Perot Speech Gets Cool Reception at N.A.A.C.P.

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, July 11

 BODY:
In his first campaign appearance before an organization of blacks, Ross Perot called today for racial harmony and said economic development was the answer to the problems of the nation's cities. But he elicited little response from the audience and left some listeners offended by what they said were patronizing or insensitive remarks.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and his Vice-Presidential choice, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee, also appeared today before the group, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, on a day that underscored the importance and uncertainty surrounding the black vote in the three-sided Presidential race. 
 Mr. Perot, in his most specific proposal, called for representation in Congress for the District of Columbia.
"I know that you feel, and I share the belief that Washington, D.C., should be properly represented in Congress," Mr. Perot told the group, which is holding its national convention here.
Mr. Perot, who has yet to announce his independent candidacy for President, offered no other specific programs and left much of his audience offended by his remarks. One man heckled him and others made negative comments to him when he twice used the phrase "your people" in singling out the problems of blacks. Mr. Perot also spoke of his parents' generosity toward blacks in the segregated South of his youth in a way that many said they found condescending.
 
Shouted Objections
 Talking about the nation's economic problems, Mr. Perot said: "Financially, at least, it's going to be a long, hot summer. I don't have to tell you who gets hurt first when this sort of thing happens, do I? You, your people do. Your people do. I know that and you know that."
One man called out objecting to the phrase. He called out again later when Mr. Perot said it was "your people" who suffer most from runaway crime.
Willie Clark, president of the N.A.A.C.P. branch in San Bernadino, Calif., said the overall tone of Mr. Perot's remarks and particularly his use of the phrase "your people" reflected how culturally out of touch he was with his audience.
"When he said 'you people' or 'your people,' it was like waving a red flag in front of a bull," he said. "It's something white folks have used when they don't want to call you nigger, but they don't want to treat you like an equal."
While Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore "were both very impressive" in their speeches to the group, Mr. Clark said, "Perot was just unprepared for this kind of audience. He blew himself out of the ball park."
Mr. Perot left the N.A.A.C.P.'s convention immediately after the speech. Asked later if he was aware that he had offended some people, he said, "If I did, then I'm sorry."
The Rev. Benjamin L. Hooks Jr., the group's departing Executive Director, said later that he planned to call Mr. Perot's campaign aides to try to explain why blacks were offended. "It's something we all have to work on, but I don't think it's a sign of irreparable failure," Mr. Hooks said. "None of us liked that language, but we don't want to lose the emphasis of the speech over one thing. I hate to see his appearance here marred."
In fact, most of Mr. Perot's speech was an appeal for racial harmony. He cited his opposition to the gubernatorial bid of David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader, in Louisiana last year and his experience as a youth with poor blacks in his hometown of Texarkana, Tex., as evidence of his sensitivity to the needs of minorities.
"We will not have a great country until we get rid of hate and divisiveness and come together as a united, loving, winning team," he said.
 
Clinton and Gore Speak
 Mr. Clinton's efforts, particularly in the South, depend on his getting the overwhelming share of the black vote that has traditionally gone to the Democratic candidate. Polls have shown that Mr. Perot's campaign has attracted some interest, particularly among younger members of minority groups. Even though many here voiced skepticism about Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush, Mr. Perot's appearance apparently gained him little new support.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore spoke later in the afternoon to a larger and somewhat more appreciative audience.
Mr. Clinton received a warm response, especially when he criticized President Bush, saying Republicans had failed to live up to their promises.
"I pledge to you an administration that believes in and enforces the Voting Rights Act, an administration based on principles of community and respect, not division and blame," he said.
"Last time we had a President promise us a kinder and gentler nation, it turns out he meant a meaner and harsher politics," he said. "Last time you had a President who promised us, and I quote, a new economy and greater tolerance. Turns out he meant he'd be the only President since Reconstruction except for his predecessor to veto a civil rights bill."
Mr. Clinton also said: "What I want to do is to make economic empowerment opportunity the civil rights issue of the 1990's. I want to bridge the racial divide in this country by giving us all something to say yes to, not just things to say no to."
Mr. Hooks praised Mr. Clinton as someone who "has been diligent in trying to heal the old stubborn wounds of racial division."
Mr. Gore, who spoke before Mr. Clinton, caught himself as he stumbled over the word "plan" in discussing Mr. Clinton's economic plan.To widespread laughter, he said, "I almost said the Klan." He said the background he and Mr. Clinton had growing up in the South during the civil rights era made them particularly sensitive to racial issues. He promised rapid progress on domestic issues in the first 100 days of a Clinton-Gore administration.
"You just watch what we are going to do," he said in closing his remarks. "We shall overcome."
 
'A Big Wall'
 For Mr. Perot, the speech today was the first time he has appeared before an audience other than one organized by his campaign. It was a rocky debut.
"He did a lousy job," said Joseph H. Duff, president of the Los Angeles chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. "He showed he had very little experience with black people. When he used the phrase 'your people,' he put up a big wall, and when he tried to tell us we're people, he made a big mistake. We know we're people."
Much of Mr. Perot's speech was his standard depiction of a nation in economic crisis and of himself as a problem solver who can produce economic growth.
But he also made pointed efforts to connect with his audience. He told of his father's insistence on continuing to pay poor blacks who worked for him after they had retired, his experiences as a paper boy in a poor black neighborhood, his mother's insistence on feeding poor Depression-era hobos, and his visits to baptisms at black churches.
But the anecdotes that usually fit comfortably into the Norman Rockwell Americana he uses in speeches to volunteers and in television appearances, fell flat before a black audience that for the most part listened in polite silence.
 
'It Was Condescending'
 He cited his father's remarks on the poor blacks who worked for him: "The only words I ever heard him say were, 'Son, these are people too, and they have to live.' "
"It was condescending," said John J. Mance, of Granada Hills, Calif., one of the N.A.A.C.P.'s 64 national board members. "I don't think he helped himself by telling stories about how his father used to pay his old black sharecroppers."
Mr. Perot received his biggest rounds of applause in talking about economic issues, the need for job creation, particularly in manufacturing, and the need to stop the exporting of jobs overseas.
"Hungry people steal, hopeless people kill," he said. "So if you could put people to work, that would be a tremendous step toward helping to rebuild the society."
His remarks on economic development and his ability to create jobs got the most positive response in interviews with the audience, which dominated by members of the black middle class.
"I was impressed," said the Rev. H. H. Singleton of Conway, S.C. "He said a lot of things that needed to be said about the rebuilding of the country. We need jobs."
 
Money for Inner Cities
 Mr. Perot talked of the need for improvements in education and health care, but offered no solutions. He talked of the need for reviving inner cities, but offered no plan other than to say that small businesses, the backbone of inner-city neighborhoods, are starved for credit and capital, and that as President he would make sure those resources were made available.
Mr. Perot repeatedly said, however, that he believed government action alone would not solve the nation's problems.
"I don't believe that government and laws can be nearly as effective as strong families, strong churches, tightly knit neighborhoods where folks look after one another," he said.
But after building his improbable outsider's Presidential campaign on the strength of his image as a nonpolitician, some people here turned that image around on him. "He didn't move us," Mr. Mance said dismissively. "He's no politician."
Similarly, Mr. Perot's oft-stated remark that he doesn't need handlers or speech writers struck a different note here than it has in the past.
Midway through the speech, James Sykes, who owns a public relations firm in Denver, rolled his eyes and said: "He said he didn't have any speech writers. I think he ought to get some."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Convention;
Hoops Gone, Hoopla Begins: Democrats Are Given a Party

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
Standing on a steamy platform -- the railroad kind, not the political kind -- Mayor David N. Dinkins welcomed the chairman of the Democratic Party to town yesterday as New York City kicked off what it hopes will be a financial and public-relations bonanza: the Democratic National Convention at Madison Square Garden.
With convention business giving hotels their best July in four years, the police spending $6 million, including overtime pay, and caterers whipping up hors d'oeuvres for hundreds of parties, city officials are upbeat about the prospect of an immediate psychological lift, with economic benefits to follow. Just how successful the convention is for the city will not be known until long after out-of-town delegates pack up and head home at the end of the week. 
 The first of the convention-week protests got under way yesterday: a handful of demonstrators from the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue gathered at one Manhattan abortion clinic, the Eastern Women's Center at Park Avenue and East 30th Street, and chained themselves to the door of another, Manhattan East Medical Offices at 225 East 64th Street, where three marchers were arrested. The confrontation at the Eastern Women's Center was a lopsided one. The Operation Rescue demonstrators were overwhelmed by more than 500 abortion-rights supporters. The police said that three others were taken into custody later at a third demonstration at St. John the Baptist Church on West 30th Street.
Abortion was not the only issue being argued in the streets yesterday. A demonstration to demand public support for homeless children drew about 40 people, who rallied at Union Square and then marched up Fifth Avenue to Central Park. But the event did not attract the contingent of 300 children the organizers said they had expected to take part.
As the day waned, the partying began. At Bryant Park, the city played host to many of the 15,000 journalists covering the convention. Delegates rushed off to private parties at the Plaza Hotel and the Water Club. The Hispanic Political Action Committee U.S.A. sponsored a Ruben Blades Festival at Roseland, where, for $30, revelers could dance until 4 A.M. today. Democrats who had donated at least $5,000 a year since 1988 filled the old waiting area at Grand Central Terminal, where the remodelers' scaffolding had been taken down and the almost-completed room opened for its first big event.
Mr. Dinkins promised to attend all of the gatherings planned for state delegations tonight, from the Georgia party on the Staten Island Ferry to the Washington State party at the Central Park Zoo to the Oklahoma party on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. The Mayor was waiting yesterday at Pennsylvania Station when a "victory train" carrying Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, rolled in.
 
A Blooming Garden
 "New York knows how to throw a party," Mr. Dinkins said. "But we are not here only to have fun. We are here to elect the next leader of the free world." Asked about Vice President Dan Quayle's continued gibes at New York City, the Mayor said, "It shows how uninformed he is."
Mr. Brown, who seemed to have economics on his mind when he needed etiquette, flubbed his thank-you line. "On behalf of all of you, I want to express my appreciation for this tremendously warm recession," he said.
The Democratic volunteers who cheered the arriving Democrats were outnumbered by reporters and photographers, who jockeyed for the best angles. Several bewildered-looking travelers asked police officers what all the hubbub was about.
Later, Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Brown went on a "walk through" of the Garden, the last in a seemingly endless parade of Democratic officials who have been given glimpses of how the Democrats have changed the arena. The ice and the basketball hoops are gone, replaced by a giant wall of television monitors and renovations that cost the city more than $10 million.
Never mind that the Garden gave itself a face lift only last summer. Construction crews have put up temporary walls, electricians have put in new outlets and telephone installers have put in new lines. They all have to be taken down, taken apart or taken out once the Democrats leave. But yesterday, Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Brown stood on the podium, trying out the sound system.
The Democrats have issued 15,000 press credentials, three times as many as for delegates. Yesterday it seemed as if every other person walking down Seventh Avenue had a camera, a tape recorder or a notebook waiting to be filled with quotes.
 
Vigils Are Planned
 Advocates for the homeless had been concerned that the city was planning a pre-convention sweep of people living in the neighborhood near Madison Square Garden. City officials denied that. Yesterday the Coalition for the Homeless said it would hold candlelight vigils near the Garden each night of the convention to protest the Democrats' inaction "in addressing modern mass homelessness." The group also said it would provide space inside St. Francis Church on 32d Street for homeless people to sleep.
There were indications that an agreement between the Parks Department and protesters who wanted to camp out in Central Park was unraveling. The accord, announced Friday, promised space in a recreation center on East 54th Street off First Avenue, where the demonstrators could spend the night. In return, the protesters agreed to leave the park by 1 A.M.
But yesterday a group said it had parted company with the Rainbow Affinity Tribe, which agreed to the no-camping deal. John Green, from the breakaway group, said his group did not plan to leave the park after an Arlo Guthrie concert this afternoon.
"We are still planning to camp out," he said. "The leadership went behind our backs."
Unlike Mr. Brown, a native New Yorker who rarely misses an opportunity to say that Democrats have the answers to urban problems, not everyone who will be inside the Garden this week is enthusiastic about his decision to hold the convention in New York.
"Hellish traffic," said Katherine Drake of Burke, Va., whose job during the convention is handing out credentials. "Very disorienting. Our boss told us there were four muggings outside of the Garden on Thursday night." So instead of carrying a purse, she stuffed her hotel-room key, a granola bar and a dollar or two in the plastic credentials pouch she was wearing around her neck.

HEADLINE: Rural Cuba Speaks Up for Castro

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLGUIN, Cuba

 BODY:
In a rundown prerevolutionary building off the main square of this industrial town, Cubans fresh from food lines mill about an exhibit of home-grown biotechnology that the Government promises will soon increase crop production and help stem their encroaching misery.
In cosmopolitan Havana, 400 miles to the northwest, most residents long ago grew skeptical of such ballyhooed Government efforts in the face of economic realities that only seem to grow grimmer. But in provincial cities like this and in rural areas visited during a five-day trip to eastern Cuba, many people, though certainly not all, express faith in the country's Communist leadership, even as they declare that their lives have never been harder. 
 As he looked over a display of vials containing bacteria that are being introduced in fields to attack ravaging caterpillars, Osman Nasser, a 54-year-old high-school teacher, spoke proudly of the efforts of the Castro Government to overcome the worst economic conditions since it took power in 1959.
"We didn't just wait for the crisis to begin developing our own means," Mr. Nasser said, referring to the abrupt termination of Soviet subsidies last year. "We have been investing in our own ingenuity since the revolution. Of course times are hard, but I can honestly say that the little food we have tastes better when you know the love and sweat that has gone into producing it."
 
Rights Record Defended
 At an art exhibit on the same square, an anthropology student in her late teens angrily warned a visiting journalist not to write critically about human rights in Cuba.
"Cuba has a good human rights record, and if it weren't for the constant attacks of the United States, it would be the best in the world," she said.
On the outskirts of Holguin, a city of 250,000, sits the huge Bariay factory. Opened with great celebration on the 60th anniversary of the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution, the plant builds the gigantic sugar harvesters that were to mechanize the country's main crop and propel growth.
Although a plaque outside still salutes the "unshakable friendship between the peoples of the Soviet Union and Cuba," the sugar industry here has been plunged into deep crisis since the country lost its long-subsidized supply arrangements with the Soviet bloc. Critical items, from fertilizers and pesticides to the gasoline needed to run the lumbering harvesters, are now in short supply.
While the Bariay plant continues to crank out about 620 of the machines each year, just adjacent to it, in a hastily assembled hangarlike building, the Government recently began assembling the bicycles that people are being encouraged to use in place of a faltering public transportation system.
The workers on the assembly line for the clunky 40-pound bicycles, all painted the same shade of blue, are paid 200 pesos monthly, or $160 at the official exchange rate. On the black market, that amount is worth about $7.
One worker quickly spoke up to defend the wage, saying that housing, education and medical care were all provided by the state, and that food, while scarce, was inexpensive. Even so, a tour of downtown Holguin showed large old department stores reduced to selling only two or three items each and long, snaking lines wherever food or new goods were available.
"I have the greatest wealth anyone could ask," said Miguel Gonzales, a 32-year-old engineer who recently moved to the bicycle plant from the harvester factory next door. "Do you know what that is? It's security. I can walk the streets at night without fear of anyone. If you ask me which country I would rather live in, yours or mine, the answer will always be mine."
Another worker responded angrily when asked about liberty of expression and freedom from attack for those who disagree with Cuba's Communist system.
"The Government doesn't need to attack dissenters," he said. "Most of us love our country and are working hard to save it. If someone disagrees with that, we will stop them before the Government can."
Since the American visitor's arrival was both unannounced and unplanned, factory managers and party officials could not have prepared workers for the visit, as has often appeared to be the case during Government-guided tours in Cuba.
 
Cautious Comments
 Nonetheless, there was a sameness to many of the exchanges, a fact that suggested that whatever their faith in the system or sentiments toward the United States, these Cubans had a feeling for the bounds of safe discussion with an unknown foreigner. Many were unwilling to give their names, even as they spoke positively.
A local Roman Catholic priest, the Rev. Francisco Exposito Cordon, used a Cuban expression to explain the contrast between most conversations with strangers in the country's smaller cities and towns and those in Havana, where complaints and political commentary have become commonplace.
"Small town, big hell," Father Exposito said. "Everyone here knows everyone else, and nobody wants trouble."
Some residents did speak of their grievances against the system, in each case careful that no other Cubans could overhear.
On a drive through decrepit old mill towns along a barren, buckled highway that leads to Santiago, Cuba's second city, farmers bent in the sun weeding rows of tall sugar cane.
"Since they suppressed the markets, we just have the feeling of being exploited," said one farmer, his face deeply creased by the sun. "We are working for nothing. There is nothing to buy, and people are losing interest in the land. Soon there will be nothing to eat too."
The reference was to peasant markets that allowed farmers to sell their surplus production. They were closed by Havana amid much ideological infighting in 1985. Asked why the Government had closed the markets, the farmer issued a wry laugh and said: "They said we were getting too rich. Can you believe that?"

HEADLINE: Ambassador to Moscow Returns To Lobby House for Russian Aid

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 11

 BODY:
Ambassador Robert S. Strauss says he is planning to spend several weeks in Washington to "work the phones" there until the Bush Administration's Russian aid package "is out of the way."
Mr. Strauss, a Texas Democrat with a reputation as a dealmaker, said Friday at a briefing before his departure today that he recognizes the difficulties members of Congress have in voting for foreign aid in an election year, and that he believes he can spend the next few weeks acting as a nonpartisan lobbyist for the Russian aid package, which passed the Senate last week but is facing a tougher time in the House.
 
Democrats Seek 'Cover'
 He said that he thought House Democrats favored the bill, but that they wanted enough Republican votes to provide "political cover" in an election year. 
 Asked if there was anything Gov. Bill Clinton or Ross Perot could do to help the legislation along, Mr. Strauss said they had endorsed the bill, which was all the Administration could expect.
"It's up to me to go get the votes," Mr. Strauss said. "And frankly, I don't think any of them know how to work the phones as well as I do."
The bill calls for a $12 billion increase in the United States contribution to the International Monetary Fund, so the Fund can advance Russia some $4 billion this year as part of a $24 billion Western aid package. The Fund and Russia recently agreed over a first loan of $1 billion.
Mr. Strauss said he had been spending most of his time recently trying to get approval for American investment projects through the Russian bureaucracy. He met Friday, for example, with Acting Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar, the main architect of Russia's economic reform, and gave him a list of projects that, Mr. Strauss said, "would put a couple billion dollars of U.S. investment into place in the next six months or so."
"But we can't close these deals," Mr. Strauss said. "We can't get them through the bureaucracy."
The difficulty, he said, is getting Russian bureaucrats to approve more reasonable export rules and tax exemptions, especially for American companies who want to export natural resources like oil and timber.
Mr. Strauss also said he thought that the new Russian tax rate on foreigners, after many complaints by foreign businessmen and diplomats, would be "in the 30-40 percent range," down from the 60 percent called for in a draft bill.
On Friday, the Russian Parliament approved a second reading of a tax bill that would set the maximum rate on individuals residing 183 days in Russia to 40 percent if they earn more than 600,000 rubles, or about $4,500, a year in worldwide income.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: In His Own Words;
Excerpts From Perot's Nashville Talk

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech yesterday by Ross Perot to the N.A.A.C.P. in Nashville, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a transcription service. 
 I love this country. I love the principles it's founded upon. I don't like to see those principles violated. We've got a lot of work to do in our country. Talking about it won't get it done. We need action. We need good, careful plans and sure-footed action to finish the job.
You have made tremendous progress in your work, but there's more to be done. There's more to be done. I hope before I turn out the lights that every single American is looked on as an absolute first-class full partner in our country without all the biases and prejudices.
But where we are right now is, among other things, you've got to be financially strong to deal with all the problems our country has. And I don't have to tell this informed group that when you're $4 trillion in debt and you're going $400 billion in debt every year, you're about to break the bank.
Let's look at where we are right now.
 
Rising Unemployment
 I just picked up a magazine this morning. I say that our highest short-term priority is to put America back to work so that we have the tax base to do the things we must be doing.
June 30, Aetna Insurance Company cut its work force 10 percent and 4,800 jobs went out the window. July 1, the Aluminum Company of America cut 2,100 jobs. July 1, Hughes Aircraft cut 9,000 jobs and had to write off $789 million. July 2, hold on to your hat, the State of California is out of money and is paying its employees with scrip, or I.O.U.'s. That's California, folks.
July 2, the unemployment rate nationally surged to 7.8 percent. One hundred and seventeen thousand U.S. jobs were lost in the month of June alone. And California's unemployment has now reached 9.5 percent. Now, California we think of as kind of a recession-proof state, right? That's just a quick fix on where we are.
And I say with that in the background, financially at least it's going to be a long, hot summer, right? I don't have to tell you who gets hurt first when this sort of thing happens, do I? You, your people do. Your people do. I know that and you know that.
 
. . .
 We are who we are. Our values and beliefs are shaped when we're small. I had wonderful parents. My father and mother taught me, by example, that we are all equal. Interestingly enough, they never preached about it; they did it. The people who worked for my father who happened to be black, after they were too old to work, my father kept paying them with money he didn't have, and the only words I ever heard him say is, 'Son, they are people, too, and they have to live.'
Sunday after church, my father would take me out to visit with the people who were too old to work and he would go into their homes in the wintertime or we'd sit on the front porch in the summertime, and he would go to see them for one simple reason: He loved them. Now, he never said it, but I knew it because he always did it. Every person who worked for him carried his business card with the understanding that if anybody ever treated them rudely, to show them that card.
My dad, while he was a very modest man, was a very respected man in our community. And he was glad to put his name and his reputation on the line to see that everybody was treated fairly.
My mother, during the Depression -- we lived five blocks away from the railroad tracks -- had a steady stream of hobos, many of them black, come to our house looking for food. She always fed them. She never said anything, she just fed them.
And one day, I'll never forget, one came and said, 'Lady, do you wonder why so many people come to your house?' And she just smiled and said, 'Well, yes, I do.' And he took her out and he showed her a mark on the curb. He says: 'You're a mark, lady. This house is marked. People know you'll feed people.'
And after he left, I said, 'Mother, do you want me to wash that off?' And she looked at me and said, 'No, son, these are people just like you and me. The only difference is they're down on their luck.'
So I had the great fortune to grow up in that environment. My father used to go to the black churches. And white people didn't do that. If you've ever been in Texarkana, a long time ago, there was a famous Polly Chapel Church and the Polly Chapel Choir, and I will never forget those visits, and I will certainly never forget the beautiful singing in that church.
When the people who worked for him were baptized and their children were baptized and their relatives were baptized, we went because they were his friends. And as you know, back in that point in time, they weren't baptized in the church or in baptismals. It was in ponds and creeks. And we were there because he loved them.
 
'I Was Very Fortunate'
 Now, I was very fortunate. And finally, as a young man, I had a paper route in the poorest section of my town. It was so poor that people assumed that those who lived there would not take the paper because they only made $9 a week and many of them could not read. The streets were of sand and I had to ride a horse since a bicycle could not go through the streets. I found that these were just like the people my father was associated with, were warm, caring, decent people.
And I'll tell you one brief story. In the middle of that paper route, while I was delivering the papers, my dad had to have a kidney operation, which was a major operation at that time. No one else would throw the paper route. So I went to each of my customers, explained to them I would have to be gone for a few days. And almost a 100 percent of them said, 'Son, keep the papers and deliver them when you get back.' I said, 'You don't want old papers.' And they says, 'No, we don't want old papers, but if your dad is having an operation, your family needs the money.' Now, see that, that is an act of love from people who did not have the ability really to help others, but who did.
 
A Call for Unity
 I have learned throughout my life that there is something in each human being that cries out -- I'm unique, I'm special, there's only one person in the world like me, treat me as a human being, treat me with dignity and respect. And any society or any company that operates on that fundamental principle is a society or a company or a group that has a distinct advantage. We will not have a great country until we get rid of the hate and divisiveness and come together as a united, loving, winning team.
Can we agree that our diversity is a strength and not a weakness? Certainly it is.
As I go across this country for years, I like to look at what a person did before he got into this sort of thing. I've said for years, No. 1, we ought to love one another, and most of us do. Then, for those who can't do that, we ought to get along with one another, because a united team wins and a divided team loses. Very simple. In sports we'd know that in a minute, right? On the battlefield, we know that in a minute. But somehow in our country, we haven't figured that out yet. Divided teams lose.
Now, finally, there's a few hard-core haters. And my advice to them is, we're stuck with one another. Nobody's going anywhere. We're stuck with one another. So get up in category two at least. But I'd love to see everybody in category one because if you love one another, you're in better shape.
Since I've been involved in this process, I have said again and again on podiums across this country, if you hate other people, I don't want your vote because our country will fail. It's very simple.
If anybody here questions my sincerity, get my comments when David Duke was running for Governor of New Orleans -- Louisiana. I was in New Orleans on business, was besieged by the press and was asked what I thought about it, and I made it clear. So if you have any question, that pre-dates this activity, and that was straight from the heart and the heart hasn't changed.
So we must take advantage of diverse backgrounds. We must cross the final threshold of making each person in this country a first-class citizen. Some of this we can do by law. Much can be done by creating jobs for segments of our society who lose their pride and self-esteem because they have no work.
Hungry people steal. Hopeless people kill. So if you can put the people to work, that is a tremendous step forward in helping to rebuild the society.
There's no substitute for caring, sharing and loving one another. And this is a responsibility that cannot be legislated, and each of us must assume. But never forget that Teddy Roosevelt said that the White House is a bully pulpit. And I suggest that there should be a lot of talk like that coming out of the White House, no matter who's there.
I don't believe that government and laws can be nearly as effective as strong families, strong churches, tightly knit neighborhoods, where folks look after one another. And there's no substitute for that. We can't do it all by law and police work. You know that. All of us must assume part of this burden.
 
. . .
