HEADLINE: SOME U.S. OFFICIALS REMAIN SKEPTICAL ON TRADE PROGRESS

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
Countering what they perceive as unwarranted optimism after the Munich summit meeting this week, high-ranking Bush Administration officials say the meeting did not produce substantial progress toward a 108-nation agreement aimed at lowering world trade barriers.
Carla A. Hills, the United States Trade Representative, said Friday that the Munich meeting left unchanged the stalemate in farm trade negotiations with the European Community. "I'm tempted to say they're not affected," she said, "because in effect we still don't have a proposal from the Europeans." 
 "The E.C. has never had a single proposal," Mrs. Hills added. "They have had a wish list. Their negotiators have never had a mandate to negotiate."
 
Gloom and Frustration
 At the heart of the dispute are farm subsidies, which the United States and other food-exporting nations have been trying to eliminate or sharply reduce. Washington contends that the subsidies the French and other European Governments pay to their farmers enable them to compete unfairly.
Gloomy remarks similar to Mrs. Hills's echoed around Washington as American officials reviewed the negotiations in Munich.
"Substantively, I don't think anything took place," said another senior Administration official, who insisted on anonymity. "I know of no detail that was settled there, no issue that was set in concrete." Three other senior American officials echoed similar frustrations.
In Munich, State Department and other officials in Munich had sought to put a rosy glow on the outcome, presenting the occasion as a diplomatic success at which the heads of state from seven leading industrial democracies narrowed their differences on trade.
 
Different Trade Agendas
 Traditionally, diplomats and politicians have attempted, for both domestic and international consumption, to portray summit meetings as triumphs. On the American said, the effort was to project President Bush as a world leader and America's foreign alliances as strong.
Mrs. Hills, by contrast, has a different agenda, trying to force heads of state to focus on trade issues.
"Her analytical view is that she is making a distinction between the politics and the technical level," an Administration official speaking for the White House said today. The official spoke on the condition of anonomity.
Several officials in Washington noted that President Bush himself, in a news conference at the summit's end, said he was disappointed by the lack of progress on trade.
"I've made very clear," Mr. Bush said, "some political comments to the contrary at home notwithstanding, that the politics does not interfere with the United States' readiness to go forward. And we made that point here. But I'm disappointed."
Mr. Bush, however, refrained from criticizing the Europeans or assessing whether any progress had taken place, and his remark received little public attention.
Indeed, more in keeping with the publicly expressed sentiments were the words of Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, who said of the summit meeting, "I am not only optimistic, but I truly expect that we will finally reach an agreement by the end of the year."
 
Hills Blames France
 While saying she still hoped a broad agreement could be struck by the end of this year, Mrs. Hills took the unusual step of repeatedly holding the French responsible for the European Community's reluctance to make compromises. She expressed concern about the two and a half months of negotiating time that could be lost if France did not show more flexibility before Sept. 20, when it will hold an important referendum on whether to pursue European monetary and political integration.
That was a departure from her tack in recent months, during which Mrs. Hills had been consistently blaming the European Community as a whole for the impasse.
In Washington, a French diplomat who insisted that he not be identified strongly disagreed that France was obstructing or delaying a global trade pact.
"It's not correct to say the French are standing in the way of a deal," the diplomat said. He pointed out that at a news conference in Munich, President Francois Mitterrand denied that France was unwilling to strike a deal until after the September referendum.
Mrs. Hills's tone marked an escalation in a public relations battle between the United States and the countries of the European Community, as each seeks to avoid being portrayed as the obstacle to a deal that could increase world economic growth.
And Mrs. Hills did acknowledge that the summit talks produced some improvement in the international mood for trade talks.
"There may have been a greater awareness among the heads of state" about the issues involved, Mrs. Hills said, and a greater potential for an extra $1 trillion in economic output during the rest of the century if a deal can be reached.
 
Four Big Obstacles
 Efforts to achieve a global trade pact, orchestrated by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world body that oversees trade, failed in 1990 and again last year. And they now face four possibly insurmountable obstacles.
One is the declining personal popularity of Mr. Bush and other leaders of major trading nations. Another is the international ground swell of resistance to free trade from environmentalists who fear unsafe food imports and the large-scale transfer of polluting industries to poor countries that have no environmental safeguards. A third obstacle is the continued weakening of foreign economies; while imports seem to be driving factories out of business, additional exports have a less visible effect on employment.
The fourth obstacle lies in the fairly strong but steadily waning interest of many large corporations. This is especially the case in the United States, where many senior executives see few benefits in a global deal and increasingly prefer regional trade pacts, like the free-trade agreement being negotiated with Mexico.
The steel and textile industries, for example, have long been hostile to the loss of their protection from Asian imports. And now some high-technology companies, including pharmaceutical and semiconductor manufacturers, are contending that the preliminary drafts of a global trade agreement provide inadequate protection from foreign products that violate American patents or provide other forms of unfair competition. Bilateral deals, they say, may offer more protection.
Even if the controversy over the European Community's subsidies can be resolved, serious disputes loom over international trade in telecommunications, shipping, banking services and certain tariffs. The European Community, for example, contends that American limits on interstate banking unfairly prevent large foreign banks from setting up national operations in the United States.
American officials respond that the interstate banking rules affect foreign and domestic banks equally, and that Congress would not allow these and other basic tenets of American financial regulation to be displaced by a trade agreement.
 
Both Sides Await Concessions
 In specificially blaming the French for the lack of progress, Mrs. Hills said that they had blocked a consensus on agricultural trade within the European Community and prevented European officials from presenting a new negotiating position since the community's decision in May to pursue modest subsidy reductions unilaterally.
President Bush said on Wednesday that he foresaw "more of a readiness on the part of the French" to negotiate after France's referendum. But Mrs. Hills said that French officials had given her no indication that they were prepared to change their stance then or at any other time in the future.
While denying that the referendum was a factor, President Mitterrand said on Wednesday that the European Community had already made all of its concessions and that he was waiting for the United States to move.
Noting that France will be holding parliamentary elections in March and that French polls showed that the Government-backed referendum in September was likely to pass, Mrs. Hills criticized the consensus in Munich that trade talks could not proceed until the end of September.
"You might legitimately say, 'Why is that date important?' " Mrs. Hills said, adding, "Everyone faces an election."
 
Congressional Deadline
 The prolonged deadlock in the world trade talks seriously threatens the prospects for Congressional approval of an overall agreement. Support from corporate and farm groups is eroding, and time is running out for a trade pact to be submitted to Congress under special rules that require speedy consideration and prevent amendments.
A complete agreement must be initialed by March 1 of next year for inclusion under the special rules. Mrs. Hills said it would be "nearly impossible" to persuade Congress to extend that date for a global trade agreement.
Mrs. Hills also denied reports from the summit that the United States had made any offer to cap exports of corn gluten, an animal feed product. European Community officials have been calling for such export limits by the United States as one way to appease European farmers angered by cutbacks in government subsidies.
The negotiations have already lasted almost six years -- so long that even some farm-trade experts are beginning to lose interest. "People are jaded, except for those who have the luxury of time to follow every twist and turn," said Steven A. McCoy, the president of the North American Export Grain Association, a Washington-based trade group. "The rest of us are sitting back and seeing it all as improbable."
 
Not a Campaign Issue
 Even in rural areas of the Midwest, which might benefit from increased grain exports as the European Community cut subsidies for its exports, the trade talks have become less and less a topic of conversation. "It just hasn't hit the forefront; we've been more attuned to frost and the lack of rain," said Don Smolek, the grain manager at the Buckeye Ag Center Inc. in Monterey, Ind.
As a result of voter disinterest, there has been no pressure from Mr. Bush's campaign staff for a quick trade deal. And a few campaign officials are even hostile to reaching any pact before the November elections.
"I don't see any upside in doing it and there's no downside in not doing it," one campaign official said. "Is there a downside in doing it? Yes, you could alienate critical constituencies in key states."

HEADLINE: Church's Land Deal Stirs Call for Inquiry

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, July 11

 BODY:
Elected leaders of the Greek Orthodox Church met here this week to discuss issues like church governance, seminary budgets and youth programs. But the meeting was shadowed by a matter that the leaders voted not to pursue: a real estate deal that went sour, costing the church at least $5.5 million and raising questions about the accountability of the church's chief financial managers.
For several years, a handful of prominent lay members have been trying to open the decision-making process in the church, America's largest and wealthiest body of Eastern Orthodox Christians, to greater scrutiny. In particular, they are asking the church to clear up questions about the role of Chris Demetriades, a Scarsdale, N.Y., builder of luxury homes who for many years has also been the church's unpaid director of economic development. 
 In his church job, Mr. Demetriades raises money and oversees investments, which in the early 1980's included a 51-acre tract in Purchase, N.Y., that the church began to develop with the hope of selling it at a profit.
In 1987 the church did sell the property, to Mr. Demetriades himself. And last January it reduced his obligations by $5.5 million, by deducting $2.3 million from the original price and writing off at least $3.2 million more in deferred payments and interest.
In an interview this week, the 55-year-old Mr. Demetriades said that he had done nothing improper, that he had entered the deal reluctantly and that because of falling real estate prices he was now facing insolvency.
At the meeting here, a biennial congress of elected delegates who oversee the administrative and financial matters of the church in the United States, Canada and Latin America, church officials distributed a report that came to the same broad conclusions.
The delegates soundly rejected appeals for an independent investigation of the real estate transaction. The delegates frequently referred to a 1992 audit of the church by the New York accounting firm Price Waterhouse, which also included a note on the real estate deal and the subsequent losses, as proof that the transaction was beyond reproach.
 
Church Sought a Buyer
 But critics of the deal said that neither the audit nor the report, by a seven-member committee of top church officers, gave a precise reconstruction of the transaction or answered questions about possible conflicts of interest or special treatment for Mr. Demetriades.
The church report says that the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America bought the 51 acres in 1980 and 1983 and began building luxury houses on it. In 1987, seeking to avoid a new tax burden and to limit its risk, the church sought a buyer for the partly completed project.
After finding other bids unsatisfactory, church officials "turned to Chris Demetriades," the report says. The purchase price, according to the report, was $14.3 million, plus deferred interest that would be paid as houses were sold.
Different figures are found in papers submitted by the church in 1987 to the New York State Supreme Court in Westchester County, a step required when not-for-profit religious corporations make major sales of their property. Those papers said the church was to earn $19.9 million, including deferred interest payments of $7.5 million.
Mr. Demetriades's firm, Demetriades Developers Inc., sold 32 new homes in the tract for a total of $48 million. Whether he made a profit is not clear.
In the interview this week he said that if his business turned around, "my fervent hope and wish is to be able to return" at least $2 million to the church.
At the congress here, members of the Orthodox Christian Laity, a five-year-old group striving to increase lay members' role in church decision-making, urged the church to authorize an independent counsel and accounting firm to explore the transaction and report on it.
 
Questions 'Continue to Fester'
 "When we say we've investigated ourselves and we find that we haven't done anything wrong, people won't be convinced," said George D. Karcazes, a lawyer from Glenview, Ill., and a member of the Orthodox Christian Laity. "The questions will continue to fester and hurt the church."
But little sentiment for such an investigation was expressed in a meeting on Monday, when more than a hundred delegates reviewed the church's finances and endorsed its budget. Mr. Demetriades, who led the meeting, apologized for the losses and then was warmly praised by church leaders for his service to the church. As a church officer who has visited hundreds of parishes to raise money, Mr. Demetriades is well known throughout the church.
On Wednesday, when Mr. Karcazes tried to introduce the proposal for an independent investigation to a plenary session of the congress that was voting on budgetary matters, he was angrily ruled out of order.
The critics "should stop all this nonsense when the governing bodies of the church have spoken," said Theodore O. Prounis, a New York lawyer who represented the church in the real estate deal.
In New York, however, Simos Dimas, a lawyer and church member, said on Thursday that he would go ahead with plans to challenge the real estate transaction in court.
 
Membership of Church
 The congress brought together 781 delegates elected from the archdiocese's 10 dioceses -- eight in the United States, one in Canada and one in South America. The archdiocese, which is directly under the jurisdiction of the Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew of Constantinople and a synod of 11 Greek Orthodox bishops in Istanbul, Turkey, is headed by Archbishop Iakovos, one of the most influential religious leaders in the United States.
The actual membership of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese is disputed, with estimates ranging from 500,000 to 1.5 million people.
Attended by more than 2,000 people, the congress was distinctly different from many of its 30 predecessors. The delegates extensively revised the regulations for both Archdiocesan-wide governing bodies and local parishes.
Instead of the current Archdiocesan Council in which members are all appointed by the Archbishop, future councils will consist of 10 priests and 20 lay people elected by the dioceses, and of 31 members appointed by the Archbishop, in addition to other bishops. All investment decisions will have to be considered by the full council rather than its nine-member Executive Committee.
Despite his failure to win attention on the real estate transaction, Mr. Karcazes said: "This is the most productive congress in years. The overall impact of the revisions is to support openness."

HEADLINE: Revenge at Exxon Tied to Kidnapping

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NEWARK, July 11

 BODY:
Arthur D. Seale, charged with kidnapping and killing Sidney J. Reso, an Exxon executive, may have been motivated by revenge against the company for his firing in 1987, an F.B.I. spokesman said today.
"There may be some basis for saying that Seale wanted some revenge against Exxon," said Bill Tonkin, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Newark. "That's certainly one of the motives we're looking at as to why Exxon was chosen." 
 Until now, authorities portrayed Mr. Seale and his wife, Irene Jacqueline Seale, as desperate fortune-hunters. The Seales were unemployed and living at his parents' home in Lebanon Township when the crime occurred.
Mr. Tonkin cautioned that any theories about the Seales' motivation should be "characterized as speculation at this point."
Mr. Tonkin, however, confirmed an account in early Sunday editions of The Philadelphia Inquirer saying the former Hillside police officer also seemed to strongly resent the F.B.I. because some former agents were promoted over him at Exxon's security division.
Mr. Reso, 57 years old, the president of Exxon International, died May 3 inside a dingy, poorly ventilated storage building in Warren County just four days after he was abducted from his $650,000 home in Morris Township.

HEADLINE: In Profit Search, Postal Service Goes Mailer-Friendly

BYLINE: By BARTH HEALEY

 BODY:
The United States Postal Service, slipping deeper into deficit and concerned over a four-year decline in the volume of business mail, has greatly expanded the marketing of its business services.
Beyond its traditional role of delivering the mail, the Postal Service has started helping companies design envelopes for advertising material and computer-compatible addresses. It even sends employees to private offices to help move the mail. 
 The Postal Service ascribes the decline in business mail -- also called bulk-rate mail, third-class mail or (in a whisper) junk mail -- to three factors: the continually sluggish economy, two sharp increases in the rates for business mail in three years, and the rapid spread of alternative ways to deliver advertising material, like inserts in Sunday newspapers and flyers delivered door to door by contract workers.
There is not much the Postal Service can do about the economy or the rates, so it is offering more services than the small, scattered alternative delivery services provide.
 
Winning an Uphill Fight
 The effort seems to be showing the first slim signs of success. Bulk mail, which accounts for more than a third of total mail volume, rose 2.3 percent in the March-to-May period from the comparable 1991 period.
It has been an uphill fight, says Jeff Martin, the general manager and postmaster for the Long Island division of the Postal Service. On average, he said, it costs $110 to mail 1,000 8 1/2-by-11-inch envelopes; door-to-door delivery of advertising flyers by contract workers costs just $20 for 1,000.
The Long Island division is one of the largest in the postal network, accounting for an estimated $700 million a year in gross revenue of the Postal Service's total of $42.5 billion. It is also the home of one of the 73 centers that have been set up to promote greater use of third-class mail. The centers are high-profile offices, a world away from the neighborhood post office.
The Postal Service has no control over actual mailing costs. The rates are set by the Postal Rate Commission, an independent agency that analyzes costs and revenue. In both 1988 and 1991, the commission increased rates for third-class mail much more sharply than the rates for first-class mail, leaving both mailers and the Postal Service unhappy.
In 1988, rates for third-class mail rose 23 percent and for a first-class letter 13 percent; the comparable figures last year were 25 percent and 16 percent. The clearest result of the shift in mailing costs was an abrupt end to the growth in business mail.
 
Sharing the Work
 But business finally picked up this spring, said Sandra Stewart, a spokeswoman for the Postal Service in Washington. In the three Postal Service accounting periods covering roughly March through May, the volume of third-class mail rose 2.3 percent from the similar period a year earlier, to 14 billion pieces.
An important response to the stagnation of the last four years, said Salvatore A. Sparacino, marketing director for the Long Island division, has been to accelerate work sharing, an idea first developed in the 1970's, just after the Postal Service was set up as a Government-sponsored corporation.
The fine print in the February 1991 rate increase offered the Postal Service the chance to give substantial discounts to mailers who would share its work. A bulk mailer must sort mail at least by region, paying the top rate of 19.8 cents.
But similar pieces sorted by ZIP Code, with a printed bar code of the ZIP Code, cost 14.6 cents each. There are further discounts if the mailer delivers the mail to the post office, bringing the very cheapest rate down to 4.9 cents for some nonprofit groups.
 
Cutting Processing Costs
 "We can do everything for the business mailer," Mr. Sparacino said in a recent interview at his division's new offices in Islandia, L.I., "from designing the mail piece to assuring the hygiene of the address."
The "hygiene" reflects a layout and bar code that can be read by automated sorting machinery, which cuts the Postal Service's processing cost to $3 a thousand, compared with $19 for mechanized sorting (where a human helps a machine) and $41 for manual sorting.
Third-class mail accounted for 37 percent of the volume and 22 percent of the revenue of the Postal Service in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 1991, and the erosion over the last four years has hurt the balance sheet.
In 1991, the Postal Service had a loss of $874 million, caused entirely by a Congressional assessment that the service was responsible for $1.9 billion in retroactive health-care costs and cost-of-living wage adjustments.
That loss could have been avoided, said Robert J. Kamerschen, chairman and chief executive of ADVO Inc., the country's largest direct-mail marketer, if the steady gains in third-class mail through 1987 had been maintained. Instead, he said in a recent issue of Mail: The Journal of Commercial Distribution, "Large rate increases have encouraged businesses to seek alternate vehicles for delivery."
While every one of several Postal Service executives interviewed agreed that the rate increases have hurt, they also disputed Mr. Kamerschen's view that a lot of business has gone elsewhere. But Postal Service executives are determined that bulk mail will not go the way of parcel post.
Remember parcel post? At one time the old Post Office Department had a 65 percent share of the market. But "we didn't attend to business," said Thomas F. Rosati, a director of the Long Island division. Now the Postal Service has only 6 percent of the market.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Then and Now;
New York City, a Decade Older, Has a Great Many New Wrinkles

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
The New York City Pat Lehman will find as a delegate to the Democratic National Convention is one that she experienced at the 1980 convention -- only more so.
There are hundreds of thousands more people living here, millions of extra square feet of offices massing along the skyline, new populations of immigrants from more than a hundred countries, surges in crime, drug use and unemployment, health crises, poverty that has grown more extreme and gripping and great examples of defiance, pluck, and exuberance. 
 For Ms. Lehman, a Clinton delegate from Wichita, Kan., the contradictory trends will no doubt produce additions to a scrapbook of New York memories.
But who can say what those additions will be? If there is a constant in New York, it is the swirling change that quickens the municipal heartbeat. In ways uplifting, dispiriting, bemusing, and sometimes numbing, it has altered life in fundamental ways since the Democrats last came.
The changes since 1980, from the terrible effects of AIDS, homelessness and crack to the remarkable boons that have come with new immigration, the rebuilding of burned-out neighborhoods and the improbable improvement of the subways, will alter the visits of conventiongoers in ways incidental and profound.
 
Beleaguered and Resilient
 How will they find the the local spirit?
"It seems as if every possible plague has been hurled upon us, and I think it's got everybody down," said Larry Kramer, the playwright and gay activist. "It's certainly a city where the populace is much more cynical and depressed. This is a war zone."
Glenn Close, who was in "Barnum" when the Democrats were here last and is now starring in "Death and the Maiden," said, "I want to be positive about the city, because I love it, but I think crack is the big difference."
"It is a city that has a great soul and refuses to lay down and die, but it is a little more frightening and a little bit more out of control," she said.
And, yet, said the city's most famous psychotherapist, Dr. Ruth Westheimer, "There is a certain stability in this great city of ours. I would not use the word 'cynical.' People are more sophisticated. They know better. The last time the Democrats were here the attitude was this city is doomed. It's not that I don't see the problems and the homeless and the fact we have the dreadful disease of AIDS, but the city wasn't doomed. People have come through that. They know that they can survive very many terrible things if they have to and they can come out psychologically stronger. I actually feel there are less people saying they have to get out of the city."
Ms. Lehman will likely find the same sorts of attitudes that colored her favorite memories. These include:
Sitting in an Italian restaurant when a diner at an adjacent table looked over her at the spaghetti served to her husband, Leroy, became indignant at the meagerness of his portion, picked up the plate, marched to the kitchen and implored, "Are you gonna serve this guy a meal or what?"
 
Chasing Money
 Flagging down a cab with her husband and two friends and telling the driver she was late for a convention-related meeting, she recalls that "it was the only time in my life that I passed an ambulance on a full emergency run." When the cab screeched to the finish line, Mr. Lehman and a friend each shoved money at the driver. "He took both fares and drove away," she recalled.
Delegates will find that prices have risen all over town. The subway costs $1.25, up from 60 cents, and the average cab ride runs $5.57 compared with $3.96. The top ticket to "Annie" cost $30 in 1980. Today $65 will buy the best seat at "Guys and Dolls." They are advised not to ask the locations of B. Altman, Ohrbach's or Alexander's. And if an operative from another state asks a delegation's leanings on a rules amendment, it would not be savvy to assume a New York air and reply, "Does Macy's tell Gimbels?"
Macy's, albeit under bankruptcy protection, is alive. The others, retail powers during the last convention, are not. Among the corporations that have left: Mobil Oil, American Airlines, Trans World Airlines, Western Union and the J. C. Penney Company. City officials point to the establishment or bolstering of headquarters operations by RJR Nabisco, Sony USA, and the German media conglomerate Bertelsmann A.G.
 
Grimmer Employment Picture
 When the Democrats were last here, the unemployment rate was 9.1 percent. Today it is 11.5 percent. In between, the city experienced its best record of job growth since World War II, gaining 330,000 private-sector jobs before March 1989. It lost all of them -- more than the work force employed in Delaware --- since, according to Samuel M. Ehrenhalt of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The most critical losses have been in manufacturing jobs that have sustained generations of immigrants -- down from 489,000 in August 1980 to 295,000 -- but that hasn't stopped Greek diners from hiring Mexican cooks to serve bagels with schmeers.
Between 1982 and 1989, 685,000 immigrants who became permanent residents in the United States declared their intentions to live in New York City -- more than anywhere else -- and by city estimates an additional 90,000 a year have been coming since. The city population, up from a Census Bureau count of 7,071,000 in 1980 to 7,322,000 in 1990, has tilted from predominantly white to nonwhite.
The city has changed in other ways, too, many of them sobering and heart rending. Three times as many people are in jail -- 21,000 on an average day. More than twice as many children are in foster care, 48,924 compared with 20,953 a decade ago. And more than three times as many families are homeless and living in shelters or hotels -- roughly 5,200. There was no disease called AIDS at the time of the last convention. More than 26,100 people have died of it in New York City since. Tuberculosis, with 1,186 cases in 1980, had stricken 3,672 recorded victims last year.
 
Stalked by Crack
 The 1980 total for homicides was a shocking 1,826. But after years of decreases, the numbers began to rise again in the mid-80's, and although they have dipped slightly since 1990, they totaled 2,245 last year.
Lynn Saunders lives with her two daughters in a section of the South Bronx where six people were shot in one hour July 4th in separate incidents within seven blocks. Crack, which has dominated the lives of two of Ms. Saunders three brothers since arriving in the early to mid-80's, was the culprit, in her opinion.
"It just degraded the neighborhood, and it made people degrade themselves, especially the women," she said. "Now, you don't catch night air. You catch night bullets."
And yet, after years in the same apartment in a housing development, Ms. Saunders's mother, Imani Kummba, fulfilled her dream of moving out last year, to a formerly abandoned building rebuilt by the city.
Hers is one of 27,139 abandoned apartments that have been reborn under a 10-year program started by Mayor Edward I. Koch on which the city has spent $2.4 billion.
The housing plan is financed without federal help, and Richard C. Wade, professor of urban history at the City University of New York, said this is indicative of the most significant change since the last convention: the loss of billions in federal aid during the Reagan and Bush administrations.
Construction was, of course, not limited to poor neighborhoods. According to the Real Estate Board of New York, more than 56 million square feet of office space, or enough to fill more than 20 Empire State Buildings, has been built in Manhattan since the last convention. Add converted space and the sheer growth is greater than the entire office stock of metropolitan Boston or metropolitan Atlanta.
A lot of it, however, is empty. When the Democrats were last here, the vacancy rate was 2.4 percent downtown and 6 percent in midtown. It is 17.5 percent downtown and 22.2 percent in midtown today. One place that is less empty is Broadway, which, as in 1980, is experiencing a banner year.
Is Broadway finally coming back? Will the economy ever revive? Can the city survive, or has it died already? In 1980 and today, as in 1970 and 1960, the questions are the same, even if the discos and clubs -- remember Bond's? -- are different.
In fact, it was in 1927 that the critic Ford Maddox Ford noted in a book titled "New York is Not America," that the city was ever moving in unpredictable ways.
It had the appearance, he said, of "a storming-party hurrying towards an unknown goal."
